HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
SOVIETS OPEN LINE FOR LITHUANIA OIL TO HELP END CRISIS

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 30

 BODY:
The Soviet Union reopened the oil pipeline to rebellious Lithuania today to begin fulfilling its part of a compromise to end the impasse on the republic's move for independence.
The resumption of oil supplies began less than a day after the Parliament in Vilnius voted to suspend its March 11 declaration of independence for 100 days in exchange for Moscow's agreement to negotiate on the issue and to lift economic sanctions.
The accord relaxed a grave sovereignty challenge to the Government of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
 
No Comment From Moscow
After months of confrontation, the end of the embargo was announced in a brief telephone call to Vilnius from the Ministry of Petroleum and Gas Industry in Moscow and then in an engineer's telegram to Lithuania's refinery in Mazeikiai. 
There was no immediate comment from Moscow on the resumption of oil supplies nor any further word from Vilnius on other supplies. Those involved mainly raw materials for industry. [President Bush, told of the Lithuanian developments while playing golf near his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Me., said, ''I am very encouraged by that, very.''] Something for Both Sides Moscow and Vilnius reached the compromise after a 16-week standoff in which Lithuania managed to withstand an array of economic sanctions.
Tens of thousands of workers were laid off and numerous factories were closed. But the determination for independence did not wane and the Lithuanians coped by relying on black-market oil supplies and local farm produce.
In the standoff, President Gorbachev had to endure the Lithuanian rebellion as the cutting edge of a wave of separatist politics sweeping the the Soviet Union and shadowing his busy agenda in world affairs.
In the compromise, Mr. Gorbachev achieved the moratorium he sought on the overall declaration of independence, while the Lithuanian Government could tell its predominantly pro-independence people that a series of laws enacted since independence declaration remained in effect.
These include measures laying claim to federal property in the republic, sparing Lithuanian men from the Soviet military draft and setting citizenship conditions that alarmed Russians who live in Lithuania.
The Soviet leader's strategy fluctuated from outright denunciation of the declaration of independence as an unconstitutional affront, dramatic midnight tank movements through the streets of Vilnius and rough arrests of Lithhuanian soldiers who deserted and of draft resisters.
 
Gorbachev Invited a Solution
Mr. Gorbachev's tone has eased recently and he invited conciliation, saying that with the rebellion on hold negotiations might lead toward a revised, more liberal Soviet Union.
He has been promising a less monolithic union along with decentralized authority in an attempt to deal with the separatist movements that dog his attempts to rouse the nation to economic and political reform.
This union is supposed to offer a liberalized option of secession to the republics, but only after years of negotiations and subject to the Soviet Parliament's final decision.
Lithuania, however, has insisted throughout that there is no option of drawn-out secession to be considered because Lithuania and the two other Baltic republics, Estonia and Latvia, lost their independence 50 years ago in forced annexation. Tacit Backing From U.S. The United States and other Western nations complained for years about the annexation until Mr. Gorbachev's disarmament initiatives and worldwide popularity left most important critics, including the Bush Administration, tacitly backing his approach to the crisis.
The 100-day time limit on Lithuania's independence moratorium is to begin with the start of negotiations. The moratorium on the independence declaration would end automatically if negotiations were broken off or if ''certain circumstances or events'' prevented the Lithuanian leadership from carrying out its duties.
 
An Allusion to Use of Force
The latter was an allusion to Lithuanian concern that the Kremlin might ultimately resort to force to keep the republic in the union.
The Lithuanian Parliament voted to enact the moratorium after a personal appeal from President Vytautas Landsbergis, one of the most respected founders of the independence movement in the republic of nearly four million people.
He had been particularly critical of the Kremlin's earlier dismissal of Vilnius's appeal for negotiations, and his blessing of the moratorium weighed considerably in the vote - 69 in favor, 35 opposed and two abstentions.
The proposal produced bitter divisions in Parliament, and a small crowd of demonstrators gathered outside to denounce the resolution as a sellout.
Mr. Landsbergis said that the moratorium would be in keeping with Lithuania's peaceful approach to regaining independence and that the compromise would include guarantees against the Kremlin's resorting to legal maneuvering or the use of force during talks.
 
Many Complex Issues
Beyond the basic issue of independence itself, which remains unsettled, the talks, if they proceeded successfully, would have to touch on many complex details involved in the republic's breakaway attempt, including property confiscation and compensation.
The talks will be closely watched by other republics, including Latvia and Estonia, which have chosen more gradual moves toward independence.
The technicalities of starting up the Lithuanian refinery are expected to mean a period of up to two weeks before the plant is again operating at full capacity. The refinery, which receives oil from Polotsk, in Russia, produces more than 10 million tons of petroleum products a year.
The republic requires only about three million tons, meaning that the embargo was costly as well to the Soviet Government, which had to press other sources to meet its regional commitments.

HEADLINE: NEW PERU LEADER IN ACCORD ON DEBT

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 30

 BODY:
Peru's President-elect, Alberto Fujimori, has reached a tentative agreement with the International Monetary Fund and other development agencies on a plan to stabilize his country's tottering economy, resume payment on at least some of its external debts and reintegrate Peru into the international financial system.
The agreement was hammered out here on Friday in a series of meetings between Mr. Fujimori and the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus; the president of the World Bank, Barber B. Conable, and the president of the Inter-American Development Bank, Enrique Iglesias. The meetings were organized by the Secretary General of the United Nations, Javier Perez de Cuellar, who is Peruvian.
''Peru is going to rejoin the world economy,'' Mr. Fujimori said in an interview afterward. 
 
Repayments Had Been Stopped
During the five-year term of President Alan Garcia, Peru imposed limits on debt repayment, then stopped them altogether. The action was hailed in other debtor nations as a reassertion of sovereignty eroded by the international lending agencies and the biggest commercial banks, but it left Peru cut off from virtually all outside economic assistance as it struggled to deal with a 2,000 percent annual inflation rate, an empty treasury, 60 percent unemployment, a growing leftist insurgency and an increase in the cultivation of coca leaves, the raw material of cocaine. In agreeing to come back to the international fold, Mr. Fujimori removed the most visible symbol of debtor nations' defiance of the international financial community. But the practical effect on other debtor countries is unclear, since the political and economic conditions in each country differ.
Mr. Fujimori's plan includes a 300 percent tax increase and other measures that constitute the kind of drastic changes that the I.M.F. and banks want from Peru and other debtor nations. I.M.F. officials confirmed the outlines of the plan. In Washington, a spokesman said the Treasury Department had not seen enough details of the plan to know whether it would make Peru eligible for write-offs of debt to the United States under a Latin American assistance plan announced by President Bush on Wednesday. In the interview, Mr. Fujimori welcomed Mr. Bush's plan.
Mr. Fujimori, the son of Japanese immigrants, was elected on June 10 over Mario Vargas Llosa, the novelist, who campaigned with a detailed program of economic austerity.
Mr. Fujimori courted the poor peasantry in the countryside and urban slum dwellers who would suffer most under austerity, and refrained from making detailed economic prescriptions. But he said in the campaign that he would seek to resume debt payments, and he made clear in the interview that he is committed to enacting a tough austerity program under I.M.F. supervision after he succeeds Mr. Garcia on July 28, his 52d birthday.
''We will enact a vigorous anti-inflation campaign and program of institutional reforms,'' he said.
The agreement reached Friday seeks both to stabilize Peru's economy and allow the nation to resume borrowing from international development agencies. Peru has been ineligible for assistance from these institutions since 1987 because it cannot repay the roughly $1.7 billion it already owes them. Peru's total external debt, to foreign governments and commercial banks as well as international lending agencies, is estimated at $17 billion.
Mr. Fujimori said the centerpiece of the austerity plan would be a 300 percent rise in taxes, customs revenues and charges for state-owned services, intended to increase the Government's revenues from the current 4 percent of the gross national product to 12 percent.
The principal utilities, such as telephone service, water and electricity, will remain nationalized, he said. But about 250 smaller state-owned companies will be sold to private investors, and utility rates will be raised enough to make these businesses profitable.
Peru's complex system of multiple exchange rates will be abolished, and its currency, the inti, will be given a single, more realistic value against the American dollar, Mr. Fujimori said.
Monetary Fund officials said that once this economic stabilization package has been drawn up and approved by the Fund, the I.M.F. will in effect convert the roughly $800 million Peru owes it into a new loan, giving the nation the right to start borrowing again.
When Peru starts carrying out the plan, Mr. Fujimori said, he will ask Western industrialized nations to form what is called a ''support group'' to lend his Government the money to pay the $650 million it owes the World Bank and the $250 million owed the Inter-American Development Bank.
The President-elect said he had ''no illusions'' about the difficulty of combating the Shining Path guerrilla movement, which has stepped up attacks in recent months.
But he argued that his austerity measures would not strengthen the guerrillas' support among poorer classes, because his best showing in the election came in those regions where Shining Path traditionally gets most of its recruits. ''The mass of the people have shown quite clearly that they prefer me to Shining Path,'' he said.
Nevertheless, Mr. Fujimori may face parliamentary difficulties in winning support for his new economic program because his Change 90 party has only 32 of the legislature's 180 seats. As a result, it will need to form alliances with other parties.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Democrats Try Not to Gloat And Begin Planning for 1992

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., June 30

 BODY:
Suddenly, Democrats are dusting off their sheet music and learning to sing ''Happy Days Are Here Again.''
They insist they do not want to gloat over President Bush's reversal on tax increases this week. But the change of positions is just one of several developments - economic, cultural and political - that have stirred optimism among party leaders and helped them throw off the funk they have been in since the 1988 Presidential debacle.
Their mood is changing so rapidly that Democrats who gathered here for a summer meeting were talking about something that a few months ago they did not even let themselves think about: a serious challenge to Mr. Bush in 1992.
 
Brave Talk and New Mood
''Bush's vulnerabilities are coming to the forefront,'' said James Ruvolo, the Ohio Democratic chairman, who is president of the Association of Democratic State Chairmen and among those attending the Democratic National Committee's meeting. 
Ronald H. Brown, the national chairman, said, ''We've got a Republican Party that's coming unraveled.''
This is brave talk from a party that keeps losing Presidential elections. But at the heart of the new mood, Democrats say, are several significant changes.
 
Economic Unease Grows
After decades of having the word ''divided'' attached as a permanent modifier to their name, Democrats are watching with pleasure and little apparent sympathy as the Republicans wrestle with issues like abortion, the environment, taxes and even Mr. Bush's Friday veto of a bill requiring job leaves for parents who have sick children.
Public anxiety about the economy, the fundamental domestic issue on which Presidents rise and fall, is increasing, various public opinion polls have shown, as voters worry about regional recessions, tightening credit and the Federal budget deficit. While Democrats still have not repaired the damage Jimmy Carter did to their image as managers of the economy when inflation spiraled out of control in the late 1970's, polls also suggest the voters are having increasing doubts about how well Mr. Bush is doing in this crucial area.
Democrats think they may have finally found a message to win back the middle class: the increasing economic inequality under Republican rule. And they believe they can use the collapse of the savings and loan industry to drive home the point.
 
Finding Cause for Hope
''We have found the one cause for which George Bush is willing to break his 'no new taxes' pledge,'' Mr. Brown said in a speech here today. ''To clean up a mess caused by America's wealthiest people.''
One intriguing example of the new Democratic attitude was a presentation by Paul Tully, political director of the Democratic National Committee. Using color-coded national maps, Mr. Tully sought to show the assembled Democrats that the 1988 Presidential defeat was not as bad as they thought it was.
Sure, he said, the party ran a terrible campaign. But ''even in the middle of all the mistakes,'' he said, there were 324 Congressional districts in which Michael Dukakis in 1988 collected more votes than Walter Mondale had in 1984, while Mr. Bush attracted less support than had Ronald Reagan.
Mr. Tully's point was that winning back the White House ''is not this overwhelming preposterous challenge.''
Unseating an incumbent President remains a daunting challenge, but the notion that the Democrats can at least give Mr. Bush a run is begining to take hold. Until recently the talk in political circles was about how no one, except Jesse Jackson or possibly Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, wanted the 1992 Democratic Presidential nomination.
But now, as if a light had flicked on overhead, Democrats have begun to realize that the current trends, particulalry rising anxiety about the economy, could be the start of the most important political development of the 1990 and 1992 elections. They say that if public opinion, and the economy itself, continue to sour, President Bush will not be the overwhelming figure he has seemed.
Democrats say they are convinced that it was fear of exactly this, a recession in 1992, that caused Mr. Bush to take the political risk of a tax increase now to try to bring down the Federal deficit, and thus interest rates, before his own campaign. If the strategy succeeds, Mr. Bush may have hurt Republicans this year but secured his own re-election by bolstering the econonmy in years to come.
 
Candidates Start Stirring
Democrats have been slow to get their nominating process under way compared with past years, but party insiders say Presidential aspirants are now stirring behind the scenes as they sense the opportunity.
''I'm getting a lot more calls about 1992 than I did a few months ago,'' said Terrence McAuliffe, a Democratic money raiser who worked on the Presidential effort of Representative Richard A. Gephardt in 1988.
Democrats say that two men who had publicly ruled out Presidential bids in 1992, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey and Mr. Gephardt of Missouri, are prepared to take another look at the question.
Mr. Bradley would wait until after his campaign for re-election to the Senate, and Mr. Gephardt would have to ask his colleagues to free him from the pledge he made not to run when they elected him majority leader.
 
Savings Issue Tactics
One of the party's central themes as its leaders take more aggressive public positions has been the economy in general with particular attention to the failures of savings and loan institutions and the billions they will cost taxpayers.
The Republicans are clearly senstive on the subject. Mary Matalin, their chief of staff, issued a list on Friday of 10 Democratic lawmakers she said were responsible for delaying actions aimed at solving the problem. She said Democrats were faster with their mouths than with their votes.
Asked at a news conference today whether Democrats were not also to blame, Mr. Brown said that voters might have to make decisions about individual Democrats in certain contests but that this was different from the overall policy errors, which he said were the responsibility of two Republican administrations.
Who is to blame is probably less important in the end than whether Democrats succeed in making voters see the savings and loan problems as part of a larger package of economic issues, all tied together by the theme that the prosperity of the 1980's was built on greed, corruption and unfairness. Mr. Brown calls the 1980's ''an extraordinarily unfortunate decade in American politics that has made the rich richer, the poor poorer and that has squeezed the very life out of the middle class.''
While the economy continues to grow slowly, the public mood has clearly shifted in the last two months.
 
Disapproval Has Risen
The latest New York Times-CBS News Poll found that disapproval of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy had risen to the highest point in his Administration. In the poll, conducted by telephone June 5-8, 43 percent of Americans approved of Mr. Bush's handling of the economy and 45 disapproved. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.
Anxiety was highest among groups, and in regions, that are most strongly Democratic, just as regional downturns have been worst in traditional Democratic strongholds like the Northeast. Mr. Bush can win re-election without those regions or those groups, but crucial swing groups, like independent voters, are also showing increasing uneasiness, the Times-CBS News Poll indicated.
Mr. Bush must hold on to them, and to do that he must hold the economy together. Or as one Republican strategist conceded, if the economy goes south, ''we lose.''

HEADLINE: American Blacks Talk of Change As Main Legacy of Mandela Visit

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ATLANTA, June 30

 BODY:
With the euphoria of his visit here still dominating her thoughts, Pearl Cleage is thinking about life after Nelson Mandela.
''The danger is we get caught up in it like it's a rock concert, like going to see Prince, where it's wonderful, but three days later you don't think about it anymore,'' said Ms. Cleage, a playwright and artistic director of the Just Us Theater here.
''If we allow that to happen,'' she said, ''it's a travesty. If there's no connection between his struggle and ours, then the whole visit is really not the tribute to his life and work that it needs to be.''
 
A Transforming Event
Like pilgrims contemplating a joyous vision, millions of American blacks are struggling with similar emotions as they try to gauge the long-term effects of Mr. Mandela's visit to the United States. But interviews with black officials, intellectuals and community workers around the nation indicate a widespread belief that the passionate feelings of pride and renewal aroused by Mr. Mandela can have profound consequences for American blacks. 
Mr. Mandela, whose eight-city American visit ended in Oakland today, has been explicit in saying he is in the United States to focus attention on apartheid in South Africa, not on American domestic problems, although today in California he did say he would return to the United States in October to look more closely at the situation of American Indians.
But virtually without exception, blacks interviewed said Mr. Mandela's visit had touched and energized black Americans as much as anything since the height of the civil rights era. And many are already beginning to try to find ways to channel the energies he has aroused.
They cite potential effects like a surge in political activity and voter registration, increasing ties between American blacks and Africa, a renewal of black militancy and a search for new charismatic leadership.
''I think you're going to see a lot of African-Americans break out of the cycle of hopelessness we've had,'' said Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., executive director of the United Church of Christ's Commission for Racial Justice. ''We have a new Jerusalem. When he gets back on the plane to fly back to South Africa, we have to keep that flame alive and thank God Mandela has lit a flame that was extinguished in the 1960's.''
 
Doubts That Will Not Die
For many, however, there are nagging questions about how far the enthusiasm that has greeted Mr. Mandela can carry.
George Gee Jr., executive director of the Vanguard Urban Improvement Association in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn, said he was still struck by the look of rapture on the faces of teen-agers he took to see Mr. Mandela last week. But Mr. Gee said he could not even guess whether the inspiration that Mr. Mandela provided would win out over the lure of the streets. Similarly, he said he knew that the lost souls of the ghetto would not be saved by a one-day dose of inspiration.
''The drug dealers could care less who comes to town,'' Mr. Gee said. ''The only thing it could do to them is to have some impact on their customers for one day.''
Similarly, Ronald Walters, a Howard University political scientist who has long been an adviser to the Rev. Jesse Jackson, said it was unclear how much of the emotion that Mr. Mandela evoked would last.
''If people have the opportunity to hear him speak every day or every week or every month somewhere in their midst, it is possible that someone like him could generate all sorts of activity,'' Mr. Walters said. ''But given the fact that he's passing through and leaving, it leaves a question mark in my mind if one can sustain that fervor, and if one can't, whether or not one can have political involvement based on it.''
But most others say the visit will have a profound impact on American blacks, in large ways and small.
For instance, Hank Thomas, a former civil rights worker who now owns two McDonald's franchises in Atlanta, is trying to put together a student exchange program that will bring black South African students to colleges in Atlanta. He is confident that companies that were lukewarm to him before Mr. Mandela's visit will now be more receptive.
''I'm sure the doors are going to be cracked open a little bit wider this time,'' Mr. Thomas said.
Mr. Jackson sees Mr. Mandela's visit opening much larger doors, leading to more political activity and a surge in voter registration that could help change Southern politics, immediately affecting races for governor in Georgia and South Carolina and United States senator in North Carolina.
''We're going to begin immediately mobilizing people around the country for voter registration,'' he said. ''The biggest threat Andy Young has in Georgia to his winning the runoff is 500,000 African-Americans unregistered in Georgia. There are 300,000 African-Americans unregistered in North Carolina. If they register, Harvey Gantt will beat Jesse Helms. Same thing with Theo Mitchell running for governor of South Carolina. If Mandela can give an entire life for the right to vote and then not have it, those of us who have it must exercise it.''
Similarly, Representative Kweisi Mfume, Democrat of Maryland, said he thought Mr. Mandela's visit would enhance the chances of Congress's passing legislation that addresses minority problems.
Several of those interviewed said the visit might have its most telling effect on black leadership in the United States and would create an avenue for new figures to rise to prominence..
''Nelson Mandela's visit has shown the hunger for leadership of integrity and dignity and humility in black America,'' said Cornel West, a religion professor and director of the African-American studies program at Princeton University. ''I was there at Riverside Church. I was there at the Koppel show, and I was there in Harlem. And the hunger in people's eyes for leadership with integrity is profound. And we simply don't have it.''
 
A Paragon of Leadership
It is a measure of how raw that issue is and how much hope has been invested in Mr. Mandela that similar views are offered by blacks at opposing ends of the political spectrum.
Thus, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, who is a persistent critic of black establishment politicians, says that Mr. Mandela's visit ''has set a new standard'' for judging prominent blacks and that those who do not show enough solidarity or seem too prone to influence by whites will be judged harshly.
On the other hand, Bob Woodson, president of the National Center for Neighborhood Enterprise who is a prominent conservative, said it was Mr. Mandela's ecumenical vision and his generosity of spirit in the face of persecution that contrasted most sharply with much of America's black political leadership.
''I think there was such an outpouring of emotion because there is a quiet kind of yearning on the part of many black Americans to return us to this moral high ground and not use race as an escape from personal responsibility,'' Mr. Woodson said.
But influential blacks like Mr. Jackson and the Rev. Joseph Lowery of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference said Mr. Mandela's long imprisonment, the urgency of the battle against apartheid and the fact that he is a foreigner rather than a domestic figure made such comparisons inappropriate.
''I've never seen the U.S. media give the kind of attention they gave to Mandela to any black man,'' Mr. Lowery said. ''The reason is he's going home. If he were going to set up residence here, the stuff you hear about the violence and the communism and Castro would be magnified a million times because they'd try to cripple him.''
 
Tough Problems to Tackle
Ms. Cleage and others say the problems facing black Americans - from crack to economic despair - are more complex problems to isolate and address than the stark struggle to end apartheid in South Africa. And there are certainly blacks who will not be touched at all by Mr. Mandela's visit. For example, gang members interviewed by reporters in Los Angeles on the day of Mr. Mandela's visit there did not even know who he was.
But nonetheless there is a widespread feeling that the inspiration Mr. Mandela provided has the potential to touch and uplift millions of lives. Admirers say his presence provides both an example of commitment to social change and an eloquent refutation of lingering American stereotypes about Africa and Africans.
Representative John Lewis, a Georgia Democrat who is a longtime civil rights leader, said Mr. Mandela's presence could have the same impact on young blacks today that hearing and seeing the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had on his generation 30 years ago.
Leroy Keith, president of Morehouse College in Atlanta, said Mr. Mandela, more than anyone else, could symbolize for his students the need for ''disciplined perseverence and resilience'' in working for social change.
Mr. Chavis said Mr. Mandela ''has given us a vision of what is necessary,'' adding, ''We now have to go about the hard task of rebuilding, reknowing and reconstructing a movement that will produce many Mandelas.''

Many American blacks are trying to gauge the long-term social and political effects of Mr. Mandela's visit to the United States and the inspiration it provided. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times) (pg. 18)

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Bumpy Road Ends at Budget for New York City

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Because of a transmission error, an article on Sunday about the negotiations over the New York City budget misidentified a City Council member from Staten Island. He is Alfred C. Cerullo 3d.
After all the wrangling and wangling, the agreement on New York City's $28 billion budget that is to start today came down to twin prerogatives: $40 million in modest new service initiatives for Mayor David N. Dinkins and $40 million in other services saved from cuts by the City Council.
For taxpayers, of course, the new budget will mean more than $800 million in higher charges - the biggest overall annual increase in the city's history - dirtier streets, more unkempt parks and 50 cents for a Staten Island Ferry ride that used to cost a quarter. 
But for the politicians who agreed to the budget - and who waited around City Hall late last night for the printers to finish and give them the chance to pass it - weeks of worry and gallons of coffee went, as they always do, into fighting over far less than 1 percent of the plan. The stakes were high, since it was Mr. Dinkins's first budget as Mayor and the Council's first as the sole approver of appropriations under the new City Charter. Huge revenue shortfalls and a stagnant local economy left each side little room to maneuver.
Perhaps the biggest issue was control. For the Mayor that meant keeping it and for the Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, asserting it. By that standard, both sides could claim some credit. Mr. Dinkins persuaded the Council to pass higher property taxes than they wanted, but they blocked his efforts to raise taxes on dry cleaning and automobile use and other items, and persuaded him to accept a higher personal income tax surcharge than he sought.
Mr. Dinkins got some new programs, mostly for social services, and the Council could take credit for saving from the Mayor's ax some extra police officers, sanitation and parks workers and money for cultural groups.
One of the last sticking points in negotiations Friday centered on the Council's powers to approve spending. In each year's budget, lump discretionary funds are appropriated within city agencies. This year, such funds totaled nearly $1 billion, Council aides said, and they said the Council should not only approve the unrestricted money now but control how it is spent later.
The Dinkins administration contended that that would give the Council the power to appropriate the money twice, and refused to agree. But it did agree to give the Council monthly reports about such transfers, which could provide the Council with ammunition to raise objections in the future.
 
But Not on Weekends
 A funny thing happened on the way to the City Council's approving higher taxes - the law got in the way.
The little-known law - Section 11-220 of the New York City Administrative Code - prohibits the Council from enacting new taxes on Saturday, Sunday or legal holidays.
But the Council refused to let a dusty, seldom-heard-of 22-year-old law stand in its way. With not a word of real debate, the Council yesterday unanimously passed an amendment allowing it just this once to enact taxes on a weekend.
Before the vote, however, there was one more roadblock in the path to higher taxes. New laws require a five-day public notice period, which was impossible in this case since the Council only discovered the provision of the law prohibiting new taxes on Friday. Never fear, the Council and the Dinkins administration agreed to make the amendment retroactive.
 
Some of the Usual Sniping
 Mr. Dinkins and the Council were clearly eager to avoid the bickering that made the state budget seven weeks late this spring. But they could not avoid some of the usual sniping.
On Wednesday, as negotiations began to heat up, Mr. Dinkins flew to Miami to speak to a convention of the American Federation of State County and Municipal Employees, whose New York local is one of his biggest political backers. That led some Council members to complain that he was not minding the store. Others said that the visit of Nelson Mandela had so distracted Mr. Dinkins and his senior aides that few focused on the budget until the last minute.
Late Thursday, Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Vallone met face-to-face, but even on this, their supporters differed. Aides to the Speaker said the Mayor had spent only 20 minutes with him, while aides to Mr. Dinkins said it was at least 45 minutes. In any case, the most intensive talks were carried on by aides.
Mr. Dinkins took note of that as he announced the settlement late Friday night and praised the hard work of First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel.
''I know that he and the excellent members of his team will not be back at their desks on Monday,'' Mr. Dinkins said as the room exploded in laughter. ''I mean, will be back at their desks,'' Mr. Dinkins said, correcting himself. ''I will not be.''
 
A Little More Secrecy
 One consequence of the new personalities negotiating this year's budget, and the new stakes involved, was that the talks seemed to take place a bit more behind closed doors. In past years, the Council shared power to approve the budget with the Board of Estimate, and borough presidents routinely shmoozed in the hallways, adding to the mix of Council members and lobbyists advocating their points.
Without them, the cast was a bit smaller this year, and the Mayor's staff and Council leadership, eager to save face, kept their cards close to the vest. When the Council's 34 Democratic members held a closed-door caucus Tuesday to discuss proposed cuts, the leadership handed out numbered lists to each member.
But when the lists were collected at the end of the session, several were missing. Only then did the leadership decide to release copies of the proposals to the press.
State law allows closed party caucuses, but Gene Russianoff, a senior lawyer for the New York Public Interest Group, said the practice is disturbing in the Council, where there is only one Republican, Alfred C. Cerdlo 3d of Staten Island.
''We deplore the spectacle of citizens and public officials waiting outside the Council while nearly its entire membership debates the budget in secret,'' he wrote to Mr. Vallone last week.
 
Big Budget and Big Thirst
 On Friday, as both sides struggled to reach agreement, a notice circulated in City Hall from the Department of General Services advising occupants that the water supply to the building would be shut off yesterday from 7:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. The prospect of an unresolved budget and an unquenched thirst was too much for the negotiators to bear, and it was quickly arranged to keep the water flowing.

HEADLINE: In Thicket of Environmental Policy, Bush Uses Balance as His Compass

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
President Bush's decisions on knotty environmental problems, like those he made this week on offshore oil drilling and the ancient forests of the Pacific Northwest, show a strong tendency to placate opposing interests and to soften the impact of difficult political calls.
This impulse toward straddling and buying time is typical of Mr. Bush's style on many issues, but on the environment there is a particularly sharp contrast between him and his two immediate predecessors.
President Ronald Reagan consistently and unapologetically championed economic development over environmental concerns. President Jimmy Carter made preservation and anti-pollution efforts a theme of his Administration.
Last Tuesday, Mr. Bush gave one decision to each side. 
His decision to cancel leases for offshore drilling off the coasts of California and Florida was a gesture of concern for the coastal environment that most oil industry spokesmen attacked as a serious mistake. It also gave him time to work out differences between oil and environmental interests and to break a deadlock with Congress that has blocked oil development on large swaths of the outer continental shelf for nearly a decade.
But environmentalists were angered by the President's decision to delay protecting the ancient forests and their northern spotted owls, declared a threatened species by the Government just four days earlier, so as to safeguard logging jobs. The environmentalists complained that the decision ignored a scientific report by Mr. Bush's own Administration and set a dangerous precedent in wildlife protection.
The decision also ran counter to the advice of senior officials in the Agriculture and Interior departments, who had urged adoption of the recommendation in the report, by the Interior Department's Fish and Wildlife Service, that eight million acres of ancient forest be set aside for owl habitat. But the White House decided not to act on the recommendation and to take more time to devise a plan to minimize the loss of jobs.
 
A Tradition of Balancing
This kind of balancing has been characteristic of Mr. Bush's environmental decision-making in his first two years in office. He proposed legislation that would require industries to clean up their airborne emissions, but threatened to veto any bill he thought would cost too much. He promised leadership on the problem of global warming caused by pollution, but then called for more scientific and economic research before making specific policy commitments.
Even his appointments reflect his on-the-one-hand, then-again-on-the-other approach to environmental issues. He named two men popular with environmentalists, William K. Reilly and Michael R. Deland, to head the Environmental Protection Agency and the Council on Environmental Quality. But their initiatives have been restrained by the White House chief of staff, John H. Sununu, and the White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, who generally oppose environmenal actions that might hamper economic growth.
Mr. Bush is probably bound to act as he has on these issues. In his 1988 Presidential campaign, he recognized the political benefits of fighting pollution and protecting natural resources, pledging to become ''the environmental President.'' But as a Republican President with close ties to business, Mr. Bush must frequently make decisions that conflict with environmental goals but accommodate his basic constituency.
 
Buffeted by Cross Pressures
''The problem here,'' said one well-placed Republican political operative from the conservative wing of the party, ''is that Bush constantly gets cross pressures. He knows politically what he must do, and he sets out to do it. Then, whatever he sets out to do usually gets watered down.''
''He knows he should have blocked offshore drilling entirely,'' said this Republican, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ''It's what he started out wanting to do. Then all of his oil buddies from Texas start calling, and then Sununu weighs in, and by the time it comes out the other end, it doesn't please anybody.
''The same thing with the spotted owl. He started out wanting to restrict timber work, but then the Republican senators start screaming, and then the White House starts backing off, and the cross pressures build up again.
''What comes out is so much of 'please these people, please those people' that it winds up pleasing no one.''
White House aides take a different view. Both decisions, they noted, came after years of intensive lobbying by economic and environmental interests, heavy maneuvering by Congress and intense activity in the courts.
Roger Porter, assistant to the President for domestic and economic policy, made it clear to both the Agriculture and Interior departments that the President wanted a solution that found a balance between protecting jobs and saving the owl. ''The President genuinely considers himself an environmentalist,'' Mr. Porter said. ''On the other hand, he cares about jobs.''
One Administration official, who insisted on anonymity, also said the White House was guided by concern over the economic implications of enforcing the Endangered Species Act, which requires protection of threatened species regardless of economic consequences. Senior officials in the White House believe that the act was intended to save species from specific local activities like the construction of a dam, not to block economic activity on a regional basis, like blocking logging throughout the Northwest.
On the offshore oil issue, the President came down largely on the side of the environmentalists, the officials said, because he was persuaded that the risk to the environment was high and that the potential for finding large quantities of oil and gas was low.
 
Fewer Headaches on Oil
While neither decision this week pleased any faction completely, the new oil policy is likely to cause fewer political headaches for the President.
It removes from the table for at least a decade an issue that has troubled and divided Republican legislators, particularly since the Exxon Valdez oil spill 15 months ago mobilized public opinion against offshore oil activity. Republican strategists are pleased that their candidates in important races in California and Florida this fall will now be spared a pummeling on the issue of offshore wells.
Representative Leon E. Panetta, a Democrat from California who is a leader in his state's efforts to block offshore oil development that might threaten the environment, said Mr. Bush's decision meant ''that we have a long-term cease-fire instead of having year-to-year battles over temporary delays.''
Mr. Panetta added, however, that the decision was not a permanent solution and that Congress would have to pass legislation codifying the President's decision so that this or other Administrations could not disavow it. Steven Goldstein, a spokesman for Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., said, however, that such legislation was unnecessary and would be opposed.
 
Jobs vs. Owls
The decision on Northwest forests is likely to generate more difficulty for Mr. Bush than the one on oil. Now that the northern spotted owl has been declared threatened, the White House will have to seek a change in the Endangered Species Act and perhaps other legislation, like the National Forest Planning and Management Act, to avoid complying with the recommendations of the scientific report to save large parts of the ancient forest. That would entail a fight with environmentalists and their allies in Congress.
''I do not think the Administration will find national political support for re-doing the Endangered Species Act,'' said George T. Frampton Jr., president of the Wilderness Society. ''It will not fly on the Hill.''
While consensus building may be the preferred method of making policy in American government, Mr. Bush is obviously discovering that it is difficult to find a middle ground in the uncertain terrain of environmental politics.

HEADLINE: Social Security Fund for Tuition Is Proposed

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
As many as nine million Americans at all income levels could pay for college and vocational training by borrowing from the Social Security surplus, under a newly proposed educational loan program.
The proposal, by a group of economists, comes as college tuitions continue to climb, American workers need new skills to compete in a changing economy and Federal loans and grants become harder for both low- and middle-income students to get.
Under the plan, outlined on Thursday in a paper by the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal research organization, students and workers could borrow up to $40,000 from a revolving loan fund for college and vocational training, paying back the money over 25 years through automatic deductions from their paychecks. The loan fund would draw on the surplus in the Social Security Trust Fund, the money collected from Social Security payroll taxes that is now helping to pay for the Federal budget deficit. 
Barry Bluestone, an economist at the University of Massachusetts who is a co-author of the plan, said it had several advantages over the existing Federal student loan program. Federal loans with subsidized low-interest rates are now restricted to students whose families earn no more than $28,000, a cut-off that excludes many students from middle-income families. Students are also defaulting on the loans at record rates, costing the United States Treasury an estimated $1.5 billion a year.
The new program would be available to students regardless of family income. Repayments would be guaranteed by automatic payroll deductions and would be set as a percentage of future income, giving students the freedom to choose professions like teaching rather than be forced to select high-paying jobs because they are burdened by debt. Interest rates for the loans would be slightly higher than for federally subsidized loans, slightly under 10 percent, but the longer repayment period would counterbalance that, Mr. Bluestone said.
Proposals to borrow from the Social Security surplus, however, are politically volatile. The surplus was created in 1983, when Social Security payroll taxes were increased so that enough money would accumulate to pay benefits for the large baby-boom generation that is expected to retire starting about 20 years from now. This surplus is now used to help cover the budget deficit, with the Government issuing Treasury bonds to pledge that the money it borrows now will be paid back in time.
Mr. Bluestone said using the Social Security surplus to educate and train future workers was a far sounder investment than paying the deficit. He and his co-authors estimated that repayments would make the loan fund fully self-supporting by the year 2039, and that borrowing would never amount to more than 42 percent of the entire Social Security surplus.
Critics, however, say the plan glosses over the fact that the Social Security surplus now pays for Government programs. The proposal would thus mean cutting back spending on those programs or raising new taxes.
''What is the net effect of this?'' said Stuart M. Butler, director of domestic policy studies at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research organization. ''You raise taxes and create a new program. Are we going to raise taxes so that a millionaire's son can go to Harvard?''

LENGTH: 1575 words

HEADLINE: Brave New World Seen for Robots Appears Stalled by Quirks and Costs

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HAMILTON, Ohio

 BODY:
Steve Antenen runs the nation's biggest employment agency for laid-off robots. He has 70 industrial robots for sale on the fringe of this riverside community between Cincinnati and Dayton. All look impeccable, most having worked no more than a few thousand hours before their former owners, some of the nation's leading companies, showed them the door.
It was not supposed to be this way. To labor unions, robots presented the specter of automation in the extreme - motorized androids that would drive real people out of their jobs. To industry, they were expected to be an uncomplaining solution to round-the-clock production.
It turns out that people still work better than robots in many jobs, and where they do not, more mundane forms of automation than robotics work better. 
Robots have found a place in industry, but mostly in arduous, dangerous or monotonous jobs that workers shun anyway, like wielding a 200-pound welder on an automobile assembly line or handling radioactive materials in nuclear reactors. #1 Robot for 500 Workers But the American population of robots is not the hundreds of thousands once predicted but 37,000, or about 1 for every 500 factory workers, according to the Robotic Industries Association, a robot merchants' trade group in Ann Arbor, Mich.
The total includes 200 or 300 that owners have dispatched to used-robot dealers like Mr. Antenen, plus an indeterminate number of graybeards that have been scrapped. Still others have moved on to colleges that teach manufacturing, where, like cadavers in medical schools, they become learning aids.
''Here's an Ultimate Puma 700,'' Mr. Antenen said. ''It was in an electronics plant in Texas. They had it in a lab, perfecting a process to make a certain product. They had a change in plans and decided not to make the product. It has under 1,000 hours of laboratory use. We've brought it in, checked it out and aside from a minor gear adjustment, it's like new. It's going to a school in Arizona.''
''We've even got some brand new ones,'' Mr. Antenen said as he roamed among his idle toilers, a few several times the size of a man, some half the size. Most have a torso but only one limb, an arm with an elbow and a wrist. The wrist is fitted with tools to do a particular job, like drilling holes or welding or putting together parts on an assembly line.
 
Simple and Complicated
Mr. Antenen has some lumbering ''bang-bang'' or ''pick-and-place'' robots, as they are called in the industry, that can do nothing more than lift things, move them a bit and put them down. He has others, their arms guided by sophisticated computers, that can do a variety of tasks and confer, in a way, with fellow robots that work along the same assembly line. He said that in a clean working environment, they need about the same care as other machines - periodic oiling, adjustments, occasional replacement of tired parts - to run for 10 or 15 years.
The average price of a new robot is about $70,000. The oldest and simplest of the robots in Mr. Antenen's warehouses can be had at fire-sale prices - $5,000 or $10,000 - and the best for $40,000. Twenty brainier new ones, the International Business Machine's 7540 assembly robots, still in their original packing crates, came from a company that encountered financial strains and decided it could not use them.
Well into the 1980's, robot enthusiasts were predicting that by now hundreds of thousands of the machines would have displaced millions of workers because they believed they would work better, faster, longer and at lower cost than regular mortals.
Goliaths of American industry -among them General Electric, General Motors, Westinghouse, Cincinnati Milacron, I.B.M. - jumped into the business of selling robots, some making their own, some through alliances with Japanese robot makers.
''It was 'Star Wars,' '' said Walter Bohland, the Ford Motor Company's expert in using robots and automation. ''They became bigger than life.''
At a Congressional hearing on robots seven years ago, an alarmed Senator, Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat, cited predictions that by 1992, sales of robots would exceed $2 billion. He warned of an upheaval in the work force.
But the more competent and versatile that scientists and engineeers try to make a robot, the more it costs, to the point where the price of a robot exceeds a factory workers' lifetime wages and therefore what companies are willing to pay to do a factory worker's job.
Keith McKee, director of the manufacturing productivity center at the Illinois Institute of Technology, said, ''A lot of companies will buy a robot or two and then find that its care and feeding is more difficult than the care and feeding of a man.''
 
Peak Year in 1987
Mr. Bohland said Ford could use robots and other forms of automation to make automobiles without any human intervention at all. ''Would that be economically justified?'' he asked. ''Or would we go broke? I think the latter.''
Robots' best year was 1987, when 6,219 were sold, for $443 million. Shipments have not exceeded 4,000 a year since then, but because of price increases, sales last year were just short of the peak, at $437 million. General Electric and Westinghouse have gotten out of the business entirely, and more than half the 50-some companies that were making them five years ago have disappeared.
With the nation's unemployment rate at 5.3 percent, even in today's slow economy, any toll on the work force from robots is hard to discern. Peter Unterweger, a technology analyst for the United Automobile Workers union, said that perhaps 80,000 workers have lost jobs to robots but that some of them have new jobs -making, running and servicing robots.
''Yeah, workers worry about robots,'' Mr. Unterweger said. ''In a two-shift operation, one robot might replace two people. But those are mainly guesses. They worry more -correctly - about market developments, which are a much bigger threat. Why aren't General Motors cars selling? The real issue is foreign competition.''
 
'Robots Are Just Machines'
The evolving view of robots is expressed by people like Walter Seering, a professor of mechanical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''Robots are just machines,'' he said. ''They have a place like all other machines. They'll continue to account for a small fraction of all automation. They tend to be most effective at jobs people don't want very much or aren't very good at.''
He said they are are particularly good for painting automobiles, working in rooms where paint spray clouds the air. ''Robots don't have to breathe,'' he said.
The least important reason for robots' limitations in the workplace is the one critics most like to cite -behavioral lapses of robots at General Motors, which with 10,000 of them has more than any other company. There have been instances there of robots painting each other rather than cars, and reports of instances, unconfirmed by the company, of one robot that installed windshields and of another that spun around and smashed them.
Mr. Antenen cited a robot incident at a G.M. Fisher auto body plant near here, which closed about a year and a half ago, where the company made hoods, trunk lids and doors. ''They had robots that were picking up sheet metal and transferring it from one press to another,'' he said. ''But instead of grabbing the sheet metal, they were grabbing each other.''
 
'Lot of Painting Robots'
Frank Caiati, executive director of the company's artificial intelligence and advanced systems staff, said: ''Some of those things did happen. We had all new high technology stuff, and it took a long time to debug it. You have to keep things like that in perspective. There are a lot of painting robots out there, and they work.''
The mishaps are less the fault of the robots than of the people who prepare the instructions or programs for them, say officials in the industry.
They say that the tepid reception of robots in the workplace is more the result of another human failure - the presumption that robots could simply stand in for people on the assembly line and work better and faster than people.
''You took what you did with humans and substituted a robot,'' said William J. Sheeran, vice president for technology at General Electric's appliance division. ''The fallacy there was that human beings have infinitely more flexibility and adaptability. People found that to use a robot effectively, say in an assembly-type operation, you had to redesign the product you were assembling to make it easier for a robot to handle it.''
 
What's Good for Robots
''They like to stack things up,'' Mr. Sheeran said of robots. So G.E., like other companies, devised their production processes accordingly. But the redesigning led to a discovery that what worked well for robots could often work even better for people, negating the appeal of robots.
''When we redesigned the product, we made it so much easier for humans to do the operation that we enhanced the effectiveness of humans doing it,'' he said. ''So there was no payback to using robots.''
Companies like G.E. have also been developing other, more efficient forms of automation in which robots simply don't fit.
Mr. McKee said: ''The robot was something to replace what people were doing. But it doesn't think anywhere as well as a man, it is not nearly as fast as a man, and now it's become a very expensive beast.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robots have fallen out of favor with many American businesses. Steve Antenen's company in Hamilton, Ohio, buys used robots that other companies no longer want and resells them. (Mark Lyons for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

 
 
International
3-13

HEADLINE: Alison Beach Is Wed To David A. Jaeger

 BODY:
Alison Isdale Beach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Beach Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Allen Jaeger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Jaeger of Cedar Grove, N.J. The Rev. Vance E. Polley performed the ceremony at the Rye Presbyterian Church.
Mrs. Jaeger, 26 years old, is a candidate for a doctorate in medieval history at Columbia University. She is a graduate of Smith College with a master's degree from Columbia. She was presented at the Westchester Cotillion. Her mother, Martha I. Beach, is the president of N-Con Systems, a manufacturer of water pollution controls equipment in Larchmont, N.Y. Her father is the company's vice president.
The bridegroom, 26, is a candidate for a doctorate in economics at University of Michigan. He is a graduate of Williams College and has a master's degree from Michigan. His mother, Jean Jaeger, is an elementary school teacher in Cedar Grove. His father teaches mathematics and computer science at Millburn (N.J.) High School.

HEADLINE: Lifestyle;
The Vanities, They Were Oh So Tepid

BYLINE: By GEORGIA DULLEA

 BODY:
The rich of New York are decamping for their summer capital on the South Shore of Long Island and other watering holes, signifying the end of what is quaintly called the spring social season, although the revels spill over into summer. Some season. ''Was there a season this year?'' asked Bill Blass, who knows better. He ran a recent gala for the Hospital for Special Surgery, one of the season's few big benefits for which tickets sold out.
''The gravy train doesn't stop here anymore,'' said George Trescher, who organizes most of the big benefits. 
The billionaire quotient was lower in the ballrooms this season, along with the count of charity stars. Worse, some names on the Tiffany Feather Ball committee appeared on the very night of that ball on place cards at a Park Avenue dinner for the designer Valentino.
 
Avoiding the Ghastly
Nan Kempner's appearances at benefits were limited to pet causes. Her social plate was vulgarly full, she explained, while her husband, Thomas, refused to get done up in black tie to be ''paraded around at those ghastly galas.''
Her theory - ''They're just as happy to get my check as my body'' - may have sounded good to others on the charity circuit.
To the envy of Mortimer's habitues, Mrs. Kempner has been cast as a social X-ray in the film ''Bonfire of the Vanities.'' Gone Hollywood, as they say, but yet to go before the cameras.
Some in this set tried out for bit parts. Others had hoped to be elegantly dressed extras in a ballroom scene that was to have been filmed in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But the museum had second thoughts about the Temple of Dendur as a movie set, and so the scene will be shot in Los Angeles, presumably with mere actors.
New York noses are out of joint about this. Why, they taught Tom Wolfe everything he knows. But despite the ''Bonfire'' disappointment, the season offered plenty of chances to relive the old 80's glories.
 
From Minor to Major
There was a television miniseries based on the Dominick Dunne novel ''People Like Us,'' said by socialites to be based on people like them. There was Mr. Dunne's new best seller, ''An Inconvenient Woman,'' whose characters struck some as composites from New York and Los Angeles society. There is the new John Guare play, ''Six Degrees of Separation,'' which has been likened to a ''Bonfire'' for Off Broadway.
The spring season was in some ways a replay of the fall season (which stretched well into winter), with dark minor themes becoming major ones and nostalgia for those middle-age birthday parties that were once allowed at the Met.
''People are not as happy as they used to be,'' said Mary McFadden, who nonetheless seemed happy with Kohle Yohannan at a party marking their first wedding anniversary in May.
''A black cloud looms over the city with the idea of recession,'' she went on. ''Everyone sees the cloud but no one speaks about it. So they get dressed and go out to another party.''
 
Out, Out, Ostentation
Again this season women made an effort to dress down in public. Ostentation was not only unfashionable, but also unwise. With the backlash against Wall Street, the press was no longer tame. Who dared risk being photographed for Women's Wear Daily wearing an extra diamond?
''It's an uncomfortable climate, this gap between the haves and the have-nots,'' said Lisa Schiff, a chairwoman of the Gold and Silver Ball. ''All that show-offy stuff is out of vogue.''
Mrs. Schiff said she was not sure what would replace the showiness, adding, ''Let's hope good taste.''
Some parties that were supposed to be wonderful turned out otherwise. Some parties that were supposed to be wonderful never happened. In the latter category was a dinner Brooke Astor has been trying to give for Mayor David N. Dinkins at her Park Avenue apartment. The date was changed three times, as dignitaries in New York and Washington juggled schedules. Everyone agreed to June 20, and then along came Nelson Mandela. Now the dinner is off until fall.
 
Some Great Funerals
Funerals are becoming grand social gatherings, with Halston and Nancy Lady Keith remembered this season, as Diana Vreeland and Malcolm Forbes had been earlier in the year. Auctions are still social, although bidding by Wall Streeters has been less spirited and at a sale of Vreeland memorabilia, the bidding was sluggish.
On the other hand, the Daily News columnist William Norwich observed, ''the Sotheby's auction sure has replaced the Frank E. Campbell viewing in society.''
Gossip columns are beginning to sound like police blotters. One read that John Pomerantz's BMW had been stolen at the Metropolitan Opera and that Mai and Paul Hallingby's Mercedes had been taken at gunpoint from their chauffeur on Sutton Place. In other widely publicized crimes, Elizabeth Rohatyn's purse was snatched, and $40,000 in jewelry was taken from Georgette Mosbacher in a hotel by a man carrying a machine pistol.
''An Uzi!'' a woman at the bar at Mortimer's kept saying at a party for Mario Buatta. ''An Uzi!''
 
Fearsome Tablemates
''People are afraid to go out at night,'' Mr. Buatta said. ''Afraid to wear jewels, to go to charity parties. They don't know who's sitting next to them anymore. They don't have a clue.''
People will still go charity parties. ''But people will be more keen in the editing of events they choose to go to,'' Mr. Trescher said. ''If they can, they'll go to things they think are amusing, and maybe send money to the others.''
With hard work and some luck, the charity party picture for fall may look less bleak than it does now. For now, the door to vacation swings wide, and so it's off to the Hamptons and other summer camps.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Boston College;
Social Problems Are the Focus Of a New Program

DATELINE: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass.

 BODY:
It's summertime and a student's thoughts turn to sun, sand, surf - and social consciousness?
At Boston College, human rights, the environment and a score of other social issues are on the summer agenda for Richard Culliton, a senior English and philosophy major from Swampscott, Mass., and his newly established Department of Social Awareness.
While volunteerism and social service have always been hallmarks of Boston College, a Jesuit institution, and have been on the rise of late, the new department is the first to coordinate and encourage social advocacy on the campus and beyond. 
''We just can't sit back and wait for things to get done,'' said the new director of social awareness, David Cohen, a senior majoring in economics and political science from Damariscotta, Me. ''Students can have such a powerful voice in the world. We have to utilize it more.''
 
A $30,000 Program
The new department is being organized by Mr. Culliton, Mr. Cohen and Scott Sellers, a senior psychology major from Reading, Mass., who is the vice president of social awareness, along with three committee members from the student government.
Mr. Sellers has developed a $30,000 program intended to address broad concerns related to the environment, human rights and other social issues.
There are plans for an emergency disaster fund, charity fund-raising contests among residence halls, biweekly social-awareness forums, a volunteer bus service that will visit Boston area shelters, a campuswide system to prevent food waste and the creation of national student networks to exchange ideas on social programs.
Educational programs will be a departmental priority, said Mr. Sellers, who believes that ''education breeds activism'' and who estimates that a high percentage of Boston College students are ready to volunteer.
 
'Phone Tree' for Students
While issues of social consciousness are likely to be the most popular targets for department efforts, students' rights and current political issues also have their place. ''Laws are being passed that affect our generation and we can't just ignore it,'' Mr. Sellers said. ''Students should be the largest lobbying faction in the country.''
To that end, the social-awareness team is proposing a ''phone tree,'' a listing of participating colleges and universities through which students nationwide will be kept abreast of important events as they occur.
In the case of a student march in Washington, for example, students at the university closest to the event would contact the universities above and below it on the phone tree to spread the word and stimulate students to act. ''There is so much information, knowledge and energy at all universities,'' Mr. Cohen said. ''It should be shared.''

HEADLINE: RECORDINGS;
Early Opera Is the Latest Rage on Disks

BYLINE: By GEORGE JELLINEK; George Jellinek conducts ''The Vocal Scene'' program on WQXR.

 BODY:
Contrary to grim prognostications, opera is alive and well as it approaches the end of its fourth century. And while it is true that only relatively few modern works have attained repertory status, our generation has turned toward opera's first and second centuries with remarkable industry and concentration. Monteverdi, Cavalli, Handel, Lully, Rameau and Paisiello have become festival fare all over Europe and even in America and, for a broader audience, recorded documentation assures their permanence.
 
Monteverdi, Stage to Disk
Monteverdi's last opera, ''L'incoronazione di Poppea'' (1642), was recorded following nine staged performances in 1988 by the City of London Baroque Sinfonia under Richard Hickox (Virgin Classics 90775; CD and LP). Posterity was left without specific details of instrumentation by the composer, and contemporary editors who approach the score rarely escape without critical reservations of one kind or another.
In this instance, the performing edition by Clifford Bartlett (who has also provided thoughtful annotations) allows full prominence to the voices, limiting the accompaniments to continuo instruments (harpsichord, lute or organ, but hardly ever in combinations) and using the strings for ritornellos and two cornets for the ceremonial passages. Even compared with the relatively spare Harnoncourt version (Teldec 35247), this seems excessively lean, yet it creates a very appealing aura of chamber opera. 
Fortunately, Mr. Hickox's singers surmount the test of such risky exposure. The Poppea of Arleen Auger combines bewitching soprano tones with sharp cunning and steely determination in the right measure. As her worthy partner in an opera that glorifies the triumph of illicit love, the mezzo-soprano Della Jones portrays a vital and imperious Nero; their love duet in Act I Scene 10 sizzles with sexuality.
In a large and almost uniformly strong cast, the bass Gregory Reinhart deserves to be singled out for his eloquent and properly pompous Seneca, along with the sopranos Sarah Leonard (Drusilla), Juliet Booth (Valletto) and the bass Brian Banatyne Scott (Mercurio).
Whatever scholarship may say on the subject, I am uncomfortable with a tenor (Adrian Thompson) in the role of the nurse Arnalta. The mezzo-soprano Linda Hirst is capable in the important role of Octavia, Nero's discarded wife, but lacks the opulent tones to do it full justice.
As Ottone, Poppea's cuckolded lover, the counter-tenor James Bowman nearly succeeds with his expressive means in overcoming the handicap of an unattractive tone. All in all, though, this is a successful realization of an opera that must be savored in its entirety to fully appreciate Gian Francesco Busenello's amazingly literate and sophisticated libretto.
 
Shakespeare Via Purcell
Italian opera made virtually no headway in 17th-century England, but the genius of Henry Purcell flourished nonetheless. ''The Fairy Queen'' (1692), a thorough musical reworking of Shakespeare's ''Midsummer Night's Dream,'' was his fourth work for the stage - a masque, as it was called, combining spoken dialogue with singing and dancing. We have the generous musical portions of ''The Fairy Queen,'' recorded following a staged performance at the Aix-en-Provence Festival in July 1989 with Les Arts Florissants under William Christie (Harmonia Mundi HMC 1308/89; two CD's).
The orchestra is quite large, including woodwinds and trumpets in pairs, percussion and a full continuo, and used with great diversity for excellent coloristic effects. The dance interludes are lively and most imaginatively scored. No fewer than 16 singers are in the cast, all capable or better and some even displaying notable comic gifts.
A considerable theatrical atmosphere is conveyed in an approach that is straightforward and devoid of the kind of coyness that sometimes invades such presentations, and it is all captured in crisp and clear sonics.
 
Handel's 'Rinaldo' With Cuts
Italian opera took wing in England with the arrival of Handel, whose first opera for London, ''Rinaldo'' (1711), initiated a glittering period for the genre. With its showy arias, flamboyant characters and elaborate stage action, ''Rinaldo'' has recently entered the repertory of several large opera houses, the Metropolitan included. For it to ''play'' in such theaters, however, the opera's generous Baroque proportions invariably have to be shortened - a procedure followed by Venice's Teatro La Fenice, as a recording made there in June 1989 bears witness (Nuova Era 6813/14; CD only).
In addition to cuts, this performance also deviates from the original sequencing of the numbers in some instances, and no efforts are discernible to honor Baroque performance practices. The orchestra under John Fisher gets off to a good start with a brisk Prelude; thereafter the results are more variable. Marilyn Horne gave a powerhouse performance in the title role in New York; shecommunicates the same authority and fearless agility on records, albeit with less reliability in intonation.
The soprano Cecilia Gasdia brings a cultivated tone and discreet ornamentation to Almirena's gentle music, while the soprano Christine Weidinger portrays the magician Armida with steely tones and rough vocalism but impressive dramatic strength. As the warrior Argante, the role Samuel Ramey so triumphantly made his own in several productions, Natale de Carolis shines more modestly but respectably. With undistinguished sound and less than painstaking technical processing, this is not a set for the purist, but certainly acceptable.
 
And a Masque From Handel
Handel's ''Acis and Galatea'' (1720) is a masque in the Purcell tradition, which contains such admirable arias as the tenor's ''Love sounds an alarm'' and the bass's ''O ruddier than the cherry.'' Robert King conducts the King's Consort in an intimately scaled performance with an instrumental ensemble of ideal size. There are no outstanding voices here, but all the soloists represent the fine English tradition with true pitch and clear enunciation. Technically, the recording is a model (Hyperion CDA 66361/1; CD only).
 
In Handel's 'Flavio,' Shortness Is Relative
Handel reached his operatic apex between 1723 and 1725, a period that produced ''Ottone,'' ''Flavio,'' ''Giulio Cesare,'' ''Tamerlano'' and ''Rodelinda.'' ''Flavio'' is admittedly the weakest in the lot, and it was not well received by Londoners, who were somewhat baffled by the opera's mixture of tragic and comic elements. In his informative notes to what appears to be ''Flavio's'' first recording (Harmonia Mundi 901312/13; CD only), the Handel scholar Winton Dean observes that ''since it is a short opera . . . therefore it needs no cutting.'' The recording is indeed uncut, but its ''shortness'' (2 hours and 36 minutes, longer than ''Aida'') must be understood in Handelian terms.
The opera's subject was clearly influenced by Corneille's ''Cid.'' Its hero, Guido, must choose between love and family honor. Intrigues and complications abound, and the vocal writing is virtuosic. Jeffrey Gall, the counter-tenor, brings to the title role - a lovesick but magnanimous king - a smooth tone and bravura flair, and another counter-tenor, Derek Lee Ragin, displays similar virtues in the role of the tormented Guido. Excellent, too, is the mezzo Bernarda Fink as Teodata, a lady of the court with whom Flavio is infatuated, though her heart (and the rest of her anatomy, as we learn) belongs to a young man named Vitige.
The role of Vitige is sung by a soprano, an odd choice but it was Handel's. A good-sized orchestra of period instruments is used, Ensemble 415 led by Rene Jacobs, and the sound is quite wonderful. ''Flavio'' is not top-drawer Handel, but some of the arias, usually in lively tempos, are lovely, and the orchestra is used with Handel's customary imaginativeness.
 
A Mozart Singspiel Worth Collecting
Opera in Handel's time was still largely a succession of arias, frequently of excessive length, that militated against dramatic flow. Mozart, who was to change all that, was still hampered by these old conventions in his early works. ''Die Schuldigkeit des ersten Gebots'' (''The Obligation to Keep the First Commandment''), K. 35, is a sacred singspiel from his 11th year (1767). Following another Baroque convention, it presents allegorical figures to extol Christian virtues and caution against vices. There is a brief overture, followed by seven arias preceded by recitatives and a final trio.
Melodic gifts and orchestrating inventiveness are already in abundance; a sense of proportion and economy were yet to develop. Even allowing for the likelihood that Mozart's father, Leopold, peered over the shoulders of his prodigious offspring, the mind boggles at the results. Collectors of Mozartiana will be pleased to add this set (Philips 422 360-2; 2 CD's) to their library. It is unlikely that they will ever encounter a better performance than that offered here by Margaret Marshall, Ann Murray and Inga Nielsen, sopranos; Hans Peter Blochwitz and Aldo Baldwin, tenors, and the Stuttgart Radio Symphony Orchestra under Sir Neville Marriner.

HEADLINE: Currency;
Canada's Dollar Holds Firm

 BODY:
So much for Meech Lake. That accord, meant to be a constitutional bridge tying French-speaking Quebec to English-speaking Canada, disolved last weekend. But the financial markets have felt nary a ripple. For the week, the Canadian dollar - still supported by high interest rates - was up 1 percent at 1.1633 to the dollar. The Toronto stock index on Friday was up 14.01 to 3544.6, an increase of 1.5 percent for the week. President Bush's acceptance of the possibility of a tax increase weakened the United States dollar against major currencies at the end of the week. And looking ahead to an economically united Germany, East German marks were to begin trading for West German marks today, an event currency traders will watch carefully.
