HEADLINE: Equipment Drags on A.T.&T.

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
A generation ago, telephones were mostly black and square. Corporate switchboards were full of tiny gears and wheels like an alarm clock, and the equipment in telephone-company central offices was crammed with copper wiring. One company made almost all of it: Western Electric, the manufacturing arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
Today the latest central-office equipment uses hair-thin glass filaments to carry calls, and the switchboards are small computers. The telephones come in all shapes and colors, and even the Western Electric name, which evokes vague and romanticized images of cowboys stringing wires across the prairies, has been replaced at A.T.&T. with pedestrian titles such as the ''network systems group'' and ''business communications systems unit.''
Yet A.T.&T. continues to make a vast range of phone equipment, remaining the world's largest producer of switchboards and central-office equipment. Sales and rentals of equipment made up two-fifths of the company's $36 billion in revenues last year. But the products are mostly in markets that, unlike long-distance service, are stagnant and vulnerable to imports, and becoming more so. 
Western Electric grew fat as an in-house supplier to the nation's telephone monopoly, and A.T.&T.'s current manufacturing operations are still trying to shake a legacy of slow-moving technical perfectionism and inattention to customers.
Corporate officials still sound tentative and a little apologetic about being competitive. ''We're sort of lean and mean and hungry,'' said Robert S. Russell, vice president of marketing for A.T.&T.'s network systems group. ''It's an awful way to describe us, but that's the way I feel,''
Wall Street analysts and investors alike were painfully reminded of all these facts on Wednesday, when the company announced that weak equipment sales, as well as high credit-card costs, would depress its profits for the second quarter and the year. The unexpected statement from the company briefly panicked institutional investors, who promptly pushed down A.T.&T.'s stock by $2.125 a share, to $39.125, in a trading avalanche that totaled 11.5 million shares, or 8 percent of all consolidated New York Stock Exchange trading that day. Trading of the nation's most widely held stock continued to be extremely heavy on Thursday, at 3.8 million shares, and Friday, at 2 million shares. The stock price ended the week at $38.50.
The strong reaction startled company officials. ''I'm a little surprised at the volume,'' said Morris Tanenbaum, chief financial officer and a vice chairman of A.T.&T.
Mr. Tanenbaum said the company felt obliged to issue the unusual statement because Wall Street analysts were so wrong in their estimates of A.T.&T.'s second-quarter earnings, predicting they would go up, instead of down as the company's own forecasts indicated. Part of the problem is that the people who pay closest attention to A.T.&T. are telephone-service analysts. When they are not writing about A.T.&T., they write about the MCI Communications Corporation, say, or the regional Bell operating companies created by the 1984 breakup of A.T.&T. None of these companies have large manufacturing operations.
Some analysts wish A.T.&T. would sell its manufacturing business and focus on long-distance service. ''I'd just as soon see them get rid of it,'' said Jack B. Grubman of Paine Webber, who slashed his estimate of A.T.&T.'s second-quarter earnings by a fifth after Wednesday's announcement. But with a few exceptions, such as an agreement four weeks ago to sell a huge factory in South Carolina that recycles copper from old wires and cables, A.T.&T. says it has no intention of leaving the equipment business. And with $14 billion in annual sales and rentals, A.T.&T.'s manufacturing operations alone are nearly as big as the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and larger than the Digital Equipment Corporation, Caterpillar Inc. or the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.
Some of these A.T.&T. manufacturing operations have had trouble this year, although the company says the difficulties are not serious. Particularly weak during the second quarter were sales of telephone network switching, transmission and cable equipment to telephone companies; sales of electronic switchboards, multiple-line telephones and computer equipment to corporations, and sales of all products to the Federal Government, said Richard A. Gray, a spokesman for the company.
Analysts say that the problems are a combination of weak demand in a sluggish economy and growing competition, from domestic, European and Japanese rivals. ''It's a little of both,'' said J. Michel Guite, a telecommunications equipment analyst at Salomon Brothers Inc.
Other telephone equipment producers agree, with the notable exception of A.T.&T.'s archrival, Northern Telecom Ltd. of Canada. Northern Telecom has grabbed huge chunks of the American market share because of its quickness in seeing the advantages of digital equipment, which uses the computer language of ones and zeros to convey calls instead of the old analog method of mimicking the wave pattern of the human voice.
Siemens AG, which is based in Munich and sold $9 billion in electronic switchboards and telephone network equipment last year, thinks that the American market for switchboards is flat and that the regional Bell operating company market for network equipment may actually shrink by up to 15 percent this year. ''The central-office business has, over the last four or five years, been under intense competition that's building and building and building, as a result of both Northern Telecom and A.T.&T. competing against each other and new entrants such as ourselves coming on the market,'' said Frederick R. Fromm, Siemens vice president of United States network systems sales. The result, he addded, is that ''The prices have eroded and the margins have been substantially reduced.''
Industry sales of central-office equipment in the United States are in a downturn and are unlikely to recover for two years, said Bo A. Nilsson, vice president for United States marketing and sales of network systems at L.M. Ericsson of Sweden.
Roy Merrills, head of Northern Telecom's United States operations, disagreed. Early predictions by some consultants that the United States network systems market will grow by 7 percent this year and the electronic switchboard market by 3 percent match Northern Telecom's latest estimates to within a percentage point, he said. ''I don't see the softness in the market - in fact, I think it's very active,'' he said. His company expects to increase its profit margins this year.
A.T.&T.'s sales of network systems equipment, which account for half of its equipment sales and a fifth of overall sales, fell in the first five months of this year from the same period a year ago, said Mr. Russell of A.T.&T. The group's sales to the seven regional Bell operating companies, its main customers, were 5 percent below the company's target for this period, he said, adding, however, that strong prospects for international and cellular equipment sales made him confident that the group would meet its targets for the year. Two Bell operating companies, one with high growth and the other with low growth, notified A.T.&T. in March and April that they would slash their equipment spending and dedicate more of their investment budgets to the labor-intensive task of repairing their outdoor wiring, Mr. Russell said. He declined to identify the companies, but industry experts said the slow-growth company is the Nynex Corporation and the fast-growth company is the Bell South Corporation.
A decision on June 21 by the Federal Communications Commission, which A.T.&T. has praised, may further dampen equipment demand, said Richard M. Wolf, a consultant in Ridgewood, N.J. The F.C.C. ordered local telephone companies to reduce by $1.1 billion a year their charges to long-distance companies for conveying telephone calls from homes and businesses to the nearest long-distance switching centers. That decision should help A.T.&T.'s long-distance operations but will likely hurt the equipment manufacturing divisions because local telephone companies will likely cut back on investment to save money, Mr. Wolf said.
A.T.&T.'s failure to move quickly into digital equipment in the 1970's, after pioneering its development, is widely cited by critics of the company who contend that it is too slow-moving to compete effectively in today's telecommunications equipment market. The company replies that it has shortened the time it takes to bring a new product to market and now seeks to promote more aggressive executives.
The new aggressiveness has paid off in sales of electronic switchboards to corporate customers, said Berge A. Ayvazian of Yankee Group, a Boston telecommunications consulting firm. From 1987 to 1989, A.T.&T.'s market share rose 2 percentage points, to 25 percent, while Northern Telecom lost 1 point to 19 percent and the Rolm Company fell 4 points to 15 percent, he said.
Yet the sheer size of what was once Western Electric, combined with its lumbering reputation, have made A.T.&T. the target of every American and foreign equipment manufacturer. ''A.T.&T. is probably losing share,'' as Northern Telecom and new market entrants expand, Mr. Fromm said. ''There's only 100 percent, and it has to come from somewhere.''
 
SQUABBLING OVER A BAN
American Telephone and Telegraph and its progeny are squabbling. The seven regional phone companies are barred, under terms of the 1984 A.T.&T. breakup, from making telephone equipment, offering long-distance service and selling their own computerized data. The regionals want the bans lifted - not to mass produce equipment by themselves, but to write their own equipment software and take part in ventures with other manufacturers. On Friday, a bill was sent from committee to the Senate floor allowing them to make equipment if they set up separate subsidiaries to do so. A bill in House committee would lift the equipment ban and allow some computer-data service. A.T.&T., already concerned about foreign competition, is fighting passage of both bills, whose prospects are regarded as modest.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY;
Is U.S.-Japan Pact a Fair Trade?

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
A new trade agreement promises to bring Japan some of the greatest products of American culture: wide-open, overbuilt roads, discount shopping and maybe even some American merchandise. Thursday's agreement commits the Japanese to vastly increase their spending on public works, revamp their retailing system and prosecute monopolistic abuses. The United States pledged to trim its budget deficit and welcome continued foreign investment. Economists say the pact will benefit Japanese consumers more than American exporters. ''The Japanese quality of life will improve,'' said Donald M. Krueger, research director at Sanyo Securities. ''But it doesn't seem that it will have a major impact on Japanese demand for U.S. goods.'' Japan, with its third-world roads and sewers, plans to spend $2.8 trillion more on public works during the 1990's than the 1980's. Who needs the Hubble telescope to see the edge of the universe, when the Japanese have the money to build a highway there? 
 
Iraq Menaces OPEC Neighbors
 
President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is emerging as the bully boy of the Middle East, and higher oil prices are bound to result. He warned Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates last week to quit busting production quotas set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Implicit in his warnings was a military threat. With 42 armed divisions, chemical weapons and a larger air force than Great Britain's, Iraq ''clearly has territorial designs on Kuwait,'' said Willaim L. Randol, a senior petroleum analyst at First Boston. Iraq is seeking to displace Saudi Arabia as OPEC's unofficial leader. A top Iraqi official said in Kuwait that oil prices - at $14 a barrel, now $4 below OPEC's current target - should rise to $25. Having fought a war to humble one enemy, Iran, Iraq is now threatening to devastate Israel should it dare attack any neighbors.
 
Nissan Rescues Subaru
 
In Japan, the social safety net catches fallen corporations. Last week, the Nissan Motor Company effectively took control of Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., the maker of Subaru automobiles. The move came about through a discreet change of management, not any embarrassing bankruptcy or forced merger, and without the mass layoffs that plague Detroit. Fuji's Subaru sales have been slipping, and it lacks the scale to compete with Toyota, Nissan and Honda. With Nissan's plants strained to their limits, the company could make good use of Fuji's excess capacity.
 
U.S. Raider, Japanese Resolve
 
T. Boone Pickens may be no sokaiya, but he knows how to break up a Japanese shareholders meeting. On Thursday, he and his retinue stormed out of the Koito Manufacturing Company's annual gathering, loudly denouncing it as a farce. Mr. Pickens, Koito's largest shareholder, with 26.4 percent, demanded four seats on the board for his allies and himself. Koito, a supplier of auto parts, has hired American investment bankers, public relations advisers and lawyers to help fend him off. Sokaiya are the real professionals in disruption, racketeers who extort corporate payoffs in return for minding their manners. Mr. Pickens insists that he is a long-term investor, with no interest in ''greenmail'' to hush him up.
 
In Brief
 
Motorola Inc. and Hitachi Ltd. reached a preliminary agreement last week to settle a court battle over computer chip patents. The dispute threatened to keep Motorola from shipping its 68030 chip used in Apple and Hewlett-Packard computers.
 
*
 
Gustave Leven, the 76-year-old founder of Source Perrier, resigned as chairman on Friday, nearly five months after the discovery of benzene in the company's mineral water. The company will reserve $71 million this year, in addtion to $78 million last year, to pay for a worldwide recall.
 
The Germanys Exchange Marks
 
East German banks are open today to issue West German marks in exchange for East German savings. Citizens can celebrate the first day of economic reunification by changing as many as 4,000 East marks for an equal number of West marks - by all accounts, a generous rate. Stores have taken drastic discounts to clear out their old, Communist-era merchandise before citizens have the hard currency to afford much better. But many East German companies and jobs are unlikely to survive exposure to free-market competition.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
An About-Face on Taxes
 
It was a proposal that the President hoped would draw attention at the Capitol, the Federal Reserve and in Tokyo - but nowhere else. The wording was vague, the day crowded with other headlines. But the news that the tax-hike-proof President now sees the need for ''tax revenue increases'' spread rapidly last week, with the Democrats doing most of the spreading. The Japanese, who have admonished the United States to close its budget deficit, did agree two days later to revamp their own economy. At the Federal Reserve Board, where Chairman Alan Greenspan has urged the White House to reduce the deficit, the Administration seeksr lower interest rates. Some of the least welcome attention came fromeconomists who said that a tax increase risks pitching a weak economy into a recession. As David M. Jones, the chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Co., said, ''The concept of this budget agreement is excellent, almost noble, but it could not come at a worse time.''
 
Indicators Tell a Mixed Story
 
Economists have delivered a dull gloss on the index of leading economic indicators. They explained away a seemingly strong, eight-tenths of 1 percent rise in May as no departure from the economy's slow course, given the index's volatility and a one-tenth of 1 percent drop in April. Manufacturing is firming - growth abroad might improve exports - but consumer confidence fell sharply. ''For the rest of the year we're going to see consumer spending going nowhere,'' said Bruce Steinberg, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
 
COMPANIES
 
Now Banks Hold Trump's Cards
 
Like some savings and loans that binged and busted, Donald J. Trump has been bailed out. Banks agreed on Tuesday to lend him $65 million just in time for him to avoid defaulting on ''junk'' bonds that back one of his Atlantic City casinos. In return for being saved from possible bankruptcy, Mr. Trump consented to sell off several of his properties and review all his business transactions with his bankers. But he didn't give up ownership of many of his assets. For many of them, he paid so much and piled on such debts that their net worth is no greater than the value of some failed savings institutions. But if New York and Atlantic City regain their prosperity soon, Mr. Trump could again have some bucks to match his boasts.
 
*
 
Mr. Trump's plight puts only the bankers, not the taxpayers, at risk. The banks have agreed to defer his payments on almost $850 million in loans. Manufacturers Hanover said on Thursday that it will classify $157 million in loans as ''nonperforming,'' and other banks are expected to follow. No loan losses yet, but analysts doubt that Mr. Trump's cash flow and asset sales can possibly cover his debts.
 
*
 
It may be a diet, but pizza and beer are still allowed, and desserts are 100 percent exempt. To win his loan package, Mr. Trump had to accept a personal spending limit of $450,000 a month this year, $375,000 next year and $300,000 in 1992. But the mortgage payments on his grandiose dwellings and the costs of running his plane and yacht are not included.
 
Cohen Gets $10 Million Package
 
Peter A. Cohen might not have a high-rise office fireplace anymore, but a $10 million severance package from Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. should keep him warm through the winters. Mr. Cohen lost his job as Shearson's chairman and chief executive in February when the firm's parent, the American Express Company, decided that Shearson should quit chasing mega-deals and start earning more money. The settlement, including an agreement to avoid public sniping, has somehow transformed hard feelings into warmth and gratitude. ''It's a fair and generous resolution,'' said Mr. Cohen's lawyer, Stanley S. Arkin. Mr. Cohen, who will remain a Shearson consultant until March 1991, is said to be assembling his own investment group.
 
New York Restaurants Retrench
 
The surest signs of New York's economic decline: Restaurants are lowering their prices, and master chefs are unemployed. Every week brings fresh reports of restaurant woes from publications whose readers regard dining out as a form of communal worship, but who are becoming less able to tithe as part of the rituals. Huberts, much favored by its Park Avenue neighbors, has cut its prices four times in the last year, from $175 to $100 for dinner for two. Same food, but no wine steward or starchy uniforms for waiters. ''With the real estate business off, and the investment banking business so seriously affected, it has made a major impact on the restaurant business,'' said Len Allison, the owner and chef. ''Everybody is complaining.''
 
In Brief
 
Clone computers, but not software. A Federal judge ruled on Thursday that competitors have infringed on the copyright of Lotus 1-2-3, the best-selling, $495 spreadsheet program. The ruling, against some $99 programs, is likely to keep upstarts from imitating the formats of the most successful software.
 
*
 
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said last week that lagging computer and telephone-equipment sales, and the costs introducing a new credit card, will lower its earnings.
 
*
 
The Campbell Soup Company announced plans to sell several businesses, mostly in fresh foods, with annual sales of more than $300 million. The sales are expected to result in a $302 million charge against earnings.
 
*
 
RJR Nabisco Inc. has budgeted $250 million in fees for bankers, lawyers and underwriters working on a huge financial overhaul.
 
*
 
Clone computer, but not software. A Federal judge ruled on Thursday that competitors have infringed onthe copyright of Lotus 1-2-3, the best-selling, $495 spreadsheet program.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Waiting for the Other Shoe in Mexico

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The Mexican stock market has been one of the best performers in the world recently. It is up 52.3 percent this year and is the top performer for the last two and one-half years in the Financial Times world market index.
The troubling fact about the market is that everybody seems to be on the bandwagon and there is scarcely a contrarian to be found. How long can this dramatic run go on? 
''I see 15 to 20 percent earnings growth over the next three years,'' said Robert W. Lovelace, an analyst at Capital International in Los Angeles. He aruges that the price-earnings ratios, now averaging about nine, and the price-to-book value of 1.1, are substantially lower now than when the market was at its peak before the October 1987 crash. A recent eight percent decline, led by Telefonos de Mexico, the telephone company, and by banking stocks, did not shake confidence. And the market rallied two percent Friday as the government proposed allowing foreign investment in brokerage houses.
But Mr. Lovelace is concerned about the lack of concern. ''I worry about the fact that there is nothing to worry about,'' he said.
The rise in the Mexican market this year, while noteworthy, has not been as broad as in the past. Bank stocks, because of the scramble for stock ahead of the Government's plan to privatize the banks, and the stocks popular with foreigners, like Cifra, Telefonos and Kimberly Clarke, have risen more than the average industrial stock.
The main spur to the market has been the debt reduction agreement, finalized in March, between Mexico and its commercial bankers. This restored some confidence to the market and helped bring down interest rates. The move to privatize state companies - especially President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's promise to sell the state banks - also boosted the market. The government has also opened the economy and allowed more participation by foreign investors.
With returning confidence and high interest rates, some Mexicans have brought some of their investments abroad back home. The propsect of a free-trade agreement with the United States buttresses the outlook.
''Things this year in Mexco are kind of coming together,'' said Antoine W. van Agtmael, president of Emerging Markets Management in Washington.
Americans have been part of the rally, with net purchases in Mexico in the first quarter of 1990 totaling $86 million, according to the Securities Industry Association.
The easiest entry to Mexico is through the Mexico Fund, a closed-end country fund which traded Friday at $15.25, near the high for the year. But this might not be a time to buy. The fund's price has not fallen with the Mexican market.
It is also easier now for foreigners to buy Mexican stocks directly. But buying stocks, analysts warn, can be tricky because of the insider trading that has marked the Mexican market in the past. ''It can be like walking into a lion's cage,'' said Mr. van Agtmael. The biggest threat to the market is a major devaluation of the peso. Chrstopher Whalen, a trade and financial analyst in Washington and a critic of the Mexican government, thinks there will be one. He argues that the government's current delicately balanced policy of attracting foreign money with high intertest rates - still in the 32-percent range - on Mexican certificates of deposit could backfire.
A sudden rise in inflation, a drop in oil prices or political discord from next year's mid-term elections could shake confidence and prompt investors to pull their dollars out of Mexico. This could force a major devaluation, spreading losses far and wide.
But such a devaluation, analysts contend, seems unlikely now, and is perhaps unlikely in the longer term as well. They point to the government's recent move to slow down what is known as the ''slide,'' the daily official mini-devaluation of the peso. The slide rate was cut from one peso a day to 80 centavos, about 10 percent, a year.
They argue that this is just a sign that Mr. Salinas is interested in attracting foreign investment. Mr. Whalen sees it as a signal that the government is having trouble attracting enough foreign money, making the economic balance in Mexico more difficult to maintain.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 1, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 505 words

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Wall Street Shrugs Off Tax Threat

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Are higher taxes just what the economy, and the stock market, need? Wall Street seems to think so.
The economic logic of that thesis proves, if nothing else, that President Nixon's statement that ''we are all Keynesians now'' is no longer true. John Maynard Keynes, for those who have forgotten, thought governments should raise taxes when the economy was booming, and cut them when growth was slow, or nonexistent. 
That opinion was far from conventional wisdom when Lord Keynes was writing. Then, the Wall Street chorus was calling on the Government to ''restore confidence'' by balancing the budget. Franklin Roosevelt won the 1932 election on a promise to do just that. Fortunately he, like President Bush, was not a slave to campaign promises.
Just now, the economy is slow, and consumers have a great reluctance to spend what money they have. But a tax cut to spark some spending just won't do, not with the Government deficit being what it is. The deficit was running at an annual rate of around $150 billion as 1990 began. Now it is at $190 billion and rising.
It is axiomatic that the stock market hates recessions. But share prices leaped on news of Mr. Bush's latest statement, in which he conceded that ''tax revenue increases'' were needed to narrow the deficit. The share prices settled back amid confusion over just what he really meant, but remained firm for the rest of the week. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week up 23.51 points, to 2,880.69. Wall Street, it would seem, hopes this tax hike won't hurt.
The reason for that cheery outlook is a belief that the Federal Reserve won't let a recession happen. ''I think part of the deficit-reduction package will be at least an implicit pledge by the Fed to lower short-term interest rates,'' said Edward Yardeni, the chief economist at Prudential-Bache.
That lowering, coupled with a cut in the capital gains rate that Mr. Bush also wants, is supposed to provide boosts for the economy and the stock and bond markets that will more than offset the dampening effect of higher taxes.
One past market that may have relevance is that of the early 70's. At the moment, notes Mr. Yardeni, the total debt outstanding for consumers, companies and government is growing at an annual rate of just 7.6 percent, the lowest figure since 1971. As it happens, more cash-strapped companies are eliminating dividends than at any time since the same year. The Dow rose 6 percent in 1971, and 15 percent in 1972. But in the following two years, the index fell 40 percent as a severe recession hit.
Before prices collapsed, that market was dominated by the ''nifty 50'' big-growth stocks. These days, some similar stocks are doing well, but so are the smaller technology stocks that dominate the Nasdaq industrial index. The big losers are the interest-sensitive utilities and anything related to real estate.
But the markets retain faith in the Fed to keep things running smoothly. Whether that faith is justified may be the big question for the rest of 1990.

HEADLINE: Headliners;
Whose Habitat?

 BODY:
Environmentalists, ever wary of President Bush's insistence that he is really one of them, were delighted in mid-June when his Administration declared the spotted owl a threatened species. The Government was expected to follow the move last week with a sweeping plan to control cutting in the old-growth forests that serve as the owl's habitat. Instead the Administration formed a study group, to report to the President by Sept. 1, and called for changing the Endangered Species Act to take into account other endangered life forms - like loggers. Federal officials say saving the owl would cost 28,000 jobs in the Pacific Northwest over the next 10 years. Andy Kerr, conservation director of the Oregon Natural Resources Council, called the Bush proposal ''the Tiananmen Square for American wildlife.'' But Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said, ''We take the Endangered Species Act seriously and will implement the law faithfully. We have set in motion a process to balance our responsibility in preserving the owl and the forests while protecting the economic lives of American men and women who live and work in the region.''

HEADLINE: The World;
Without Yeltsin Is the Party Over?

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH he presides over three-fourths of the Soviet land mass and is probably the most popular Communist in the country, Boris N. Yeltsin does not expect a place of honor at his party's quinquennial reunion this week.
When the delegates convene tomorrow for the 28th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, the faction allied with Mr. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, will be vastly outnumbered and in some disarray. There is little likelihood that his proposals - such as surrendering the party's organized influence in the army and security police, and parting with much of its accumulated wealth - will be incorporated into party documents, or that Yeltsinites will find seats in the higher party councils.
Yet it is probably fair to say that the immediate future of the Communist Party now depends as much on this consistently underrated politician as it does on anything the congress is likely to do. 
In its contempt for Mr. Yeltsin, the Communist Party establishment is not alone. Many Soviet intellectuals disdain him as a lowbrow and a demagogue. The Bush Administration belittles him as a lightweight, possibly unstable, and certainly an inconvenient disruption to the plans of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Much of the outside world seems to view him as a cartoon Russian, subject to pratfalls and outrageous statements, important mainly as a foil for Mr. Gorbachev.
 
Instinct and Influence
Mr. Yeltsin has always been an instinctual politician with a nose for the political mood. He got on the anti-privilege bandwagon early, and he was the first politician of such stature to call openly for a multi-party system and the legalization of private property.
The surprise is that in his first month as leader of the Russian republic the great populist, the perennial skunk at the Communists' garden party, has begun to seem . . . presidential. Conducting his divided parliament, where only about a third of the deputies can be counted as allies, he has used tact and public pressure to build impressive majorities. He led the parliament to vote sweeping challenges to the central Government (a declaration that Russian laws take precedence over Soviet laws) and to the Communist Party (a resolution that on Russian territory influential party cells are to be outlawed in industrial enterprises, police and army units, the K.G.B. and the criminal justice system). That measure would neutralize much of the Communist autocracy, and render the dithering of the party congress somewhat immaterial.
He has established direct political and trade relations with democratic leaders in Leningrad and Moscow, with the Baltic republics and others, using the lure of Russia's oil wealth to plot a detour around the economic power brokers at the central ministries.
Mr. Yeltsin has made good use of his public status. His televised appeals for a grace period, a ''credit of trust,'' may have helped persuade Russian miners to hold off on a devastating coal strike. If it is true that a market-oriented economic reform depends on the willingness of the workers to accept change, Mr. Yeltsin at the moment may be the man best positioned to bring them along.
Lately, he has begun to press a more problematic theme - Russian pride. Many believe there is a huge untapped political force in the brooding resentment of ethnic, peasant and blue-collar Russians who have seen their traditions, religion and resources ravaged by the Communists. Mr. Gorbachev's reformers, who are mainly what George Wallace used to call pointy-headed intellectuals, have not found an effective way to reach this constituency. The hard-liners, on the other hand, have worked this issue doggedly, appealing in the name of Russian patriotism for iron discipline and a rejection of Western democracy, sometimes adding a crude undercurrent of anti-Semitism.
Mr. Yeltsin, the son of a plowman and the scourge of the party, may be the one man who can cheat the hard-liners out of the Russian vote and deploy it in a more benign direction. At least he seems to have something of the sort in mind with his campaign for Russian sovereignty. He has become an aggressive booster of the Russian Orthodox Church, the main pillar of the Russian spirit, showing up at religious services with television cameras in tow.
He sensed early the dwindling authority of the Communist Party, and has managed (with help from party strategists, who increase his popularity every time they attack him) to remain relatively untainted by his background as a party apparatchik. Now the question is whether he will choose the impending congress as an occasion to quit the party altogether.
If he stays, the party is still in for a prolonged period of erosion of power, with Mr. Yeltsin both leading the assault on party influence and benefiting as power flows from party to government hands. If he leaves, hordes of wavering party members are likely to go with him, leaving behind a party that is shrunken, predominantly conservative, potentially dangerous but powerless to run the country.
''Yeltsin is the detonator,'' said Pavel Voshchanov, a party congress delegate and writer for the daily Komsomolskaya Pravda. ''The disintegration of the party is already inevitable, but if Yeltsin leaves the collapse will come much more quickly.''

PUB-DATE: July 1, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1604 words

HEADLINE: Triple Play;
The Rich Nations Get Richer. And Then?

BYLINE: By LEONARD SILK

 BODY:
The currencies and economies of the two Germanys become one today, solidifying the German role as leader of a bloc of European states that are themselves rushing toward economic union and a closer political federation. And next week, the leaders of the seven strongest industrial democracies - the United States, Japan, Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada - gather in Houston for an economic summit meeting to survey the problems and opportunities of a world changed in subtle and not-so-subtle ways. It is a world they helped make but never expected to see so soon.
In this world, the Communist threat has collapsed, leaving the Big Three of the world economy - the United States, Japan and Europe -richer and more powerful than ever. But there is an overriding economic issue: how to hold the Western nations together now that they have won.
With the cold war ending, a hot peace among the victors is breaking out as the industrial world, once dominated by the United States, becomes tripolar. In coming decades, the strains and conflicts among Western Europe, Japan and the United States could become chronic. 
These conflicts are already evident in a host of issues: how to break remaining barriers to trade that threaten to split the industrial world into regional trading blocs; how to integrate Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union into the global economic system; how to deal with a polluted environment and ward off the danger of global warming; how to fight the international drug trade; how to stimulate sufficient savings to meet the explosion of demand for capital all over the world, and how to redress the imbalances among the rich industrial countries and the debt-ridden countries of the third world.
And, although it may take years to realize its benefits fully, the peace dividend - resources no longer needed for wars hot or cold - should make the capitalist democracies still stronger by enabling them to exploit more completely their basic advantage: the ability to capitalize on the individual talents and drives of their people and businesses to innovate, invest and thus grow richer.
The peace dividend promises to be greatest for the United States, simply because it has been carrying the heaviest military burdens of the West. Partly because of those burdens, the United States has slipped from being the world's largest creditor nation to becoming its largest debtor, and has lost ground in world markets to Germany and Japan, its two strongest allies - and former enemies.
In 1989, the United States ran a deficit of $106 billion in its balance of trade and payments - a total roughly matched by the $57.2 billion surplus of Japan and the $52.8 billion surplus of the Federal Republic of Germany. The outlook for 1990 is for an even greater disequilibrium in trade deficits and surpluses.
But this disequilibrium is by no means due only to the differences in military burdens. The United States's large budget deficits and low savings rate have worsened its trade deficits and made it increasingly dependent on an inflow of foreign capital to finance its rising debt and its economic growth, which has now slowed to a crawl.
The most startling economic event of the last week, President Bush's call for an increase in tax revenues, was triggered by the worsening budget deficit outlook and the need to break the deadlock with Congress; Mr. Bush himself acknowledged these heightened pressures for a new look at taxes, saying, ''Like Abraham Lincoln said, I'll think anew.' '' But, as his chief aide for the Houston summit, Under Secretary of State Richard T. McCormack, stressed in an interview, Mr. Bush's decision to act on taxes was also linked to America's weakened external position and its strained relations with Japan. The Japaneseclaimed some credit for persuading Mr. Bush that he simply had to take tougher fiscal action if the American trade deficit were to be cut.
Mr. Bush's aides say many other factors were involved in his decision, including his sense of economic stewardship for the nation's welfare and his belief that the United States had better get its act together and hustle lest it see the heels of its Japanese and European competitors as they race ahead into the future.
The United States still has the world's biggest economy, with a gross national product of more than $5 trillion compared to Japan's $2.8 trillion and a unified Germany's $1.5 trillion. But much of the total G.N.P. gap is due to population differences, with the United States numbering 249 million compared to Japan's 123 million and one Germany's 78 million. The 12 nations of the European Community number some 325 million, not counting the 16 million East Germans who joined the Western economy today, or other people in Eastern Europe who may join up fairly soon.
At present exchange rates, per capita gross national product of the United States is a bit less than Japan's, but ahead of unified Germany, now weighted down by the newly incorporated East Germans. But the West Germans will be investing scores of billions in the East, and productivity there should catch up fast.
The outlook for the American position versus the other two has been worsened by a disparity among their investment rates; the United States's rate of gross investment has been running at about 15 percent, West Germany's at 20 percent and Japan's at 32 percent. In addition, the levels and quality of education and labor skills, as well as the intensity of research and development, will also play vital roles in the outcome of the growing rivalry among the major industrial countries. A United States running huge budget deficits is hard pressed to deal with its domestic problems or lead internationally.
And, without fear of the Soviets to hold them together, the United States, Japan and Germany could spin out of their common orbit, pulling other countries into North American, Pacific and European blocs. So, as Robert Hormats, an investment banker who served as a top Presidential adviser at earlier economic summits, puts it, ''The cardinal job of the Houston summit is to keep centrifugal forces from pulling the allies apart.''
Hopes that those centrifugal forces can be resisted were raised by the announcement last week that the United States and Japan had agreed on a trade pact designed to discourage excess spending in the United States and stimulate foreign business in Japan. But doubts about whether the accord will be enforced persisted in Congress. The possibility remains that the Big Three of the economic world could still become inward-looking zones, focusing their trade and investment among countries in their own backyards and fighting each other for advantages elsewhere - in the third world, the Middle East and the present and former Communist countries.
 
Differences Over Gorbachev
That last issue has surfaced in advance of the Houston summit meeting. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany has been pushing for a much stronger Western effort to support President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's efforts to save the Soviet economy from an even worse collapse. But the United States, with its budgetary problems, has been arguing that a large aid effort for the Soviet Union at this point would pour money down the drain and would even be counterproductive, because it might enable Mr. Gorbachev to avoid pressing for the reforms that are crucial if foreign aid is to accomplish anything.
The same issue emerged last week at the European Community's summit conference in Dublin, where Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain proposed that a team of economic experts prepare a report on what aid the Soviet Union needs and how best to make it effective. Proponents of quick help for the Soviets believe that if the West waits for reforms to come before it helps, the aid will be too late, and an important opportunity for furthering Soviet democracy will have been lost. The Houston summit meeting is likely to reverberate with intense discussion of this issue.
But the Soviet issue, important as it is, does not pose the most dangerous threat to relations among the industrial democracies; the most serious danger is that of conflict over trade. The immediate threat is of a collapse of the current round of international trade negotiations, known as the Uruguay Round. These are aimed at knocking down barriers to trade in copyrights, patents and other intellectual property, agricultural products, and financial and other services, areas crucial to binding the modern world together.
A collapse or failure of these talks would result if there were no breakthrough on agriculture. The Europeans, heading for unity and needing popular support in coming elections, are shrinking from taking on their own farm interests. The Americans say that if the Europeans don't yield on cutting barriers to trade in farm products, then nothing can be done to get the support of either the United States or third world countries on other issues. The United States intends to hang very tough on the agricultural issue.
Thus the rich industrial powers are at a crossroad on the extent to which they will work together or split. The decisions they are making now in the trade talks, the summit discussions and the continuing deliberations over the military and economic future of Europe could set patterns for decades to come - whether nations will become more closely intertwined or divide into competing regions, and how fast the world economy will grow or regress. Ultimately, these patterns could affect the well-being of all people, rich and poor, in all countries.

PUB-DATE: July 1, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16, Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 389 words

HEADLINE: Borrowing Is Unreasonable Way to Bail Out Savings and Loans

 BODY:
I was startled and dismayed by ''The Bailout: No Savagery Required,'' your June 22 editorial supporting Government borrowing as the appropriate way to deal with the bailout of bankrupt savings and loans institutions. Borrowing may be politically expedient; it is, however, wrong, from both an economic and moral point of view. The straightforward, and least damaging way to deal with this fiasco, is to pay off the $130 billion loss with a temporary three- to four-year surcharge on income taxes. 
The economics are simple: (1) Borrowing will turn a $130 billion loss into a $500 billion drain over 20 to 30 years. It will maintain pressure on the credit markets and lead to higher interest rates. It will add $10 billion to $15 billion annuallly in interest costs to the Federal budget deficit, when interest costs constitute, after defense, the largest Federal expenditure. It will require continued high inflows of foreign capital. It will squeeze out badly needed domestic programs. (2) A three- to four-year temporary tax surcharge will eliminate $300 billion to $400 billion in interest costs and contribute to lower interest rates and capital costs. This will foster economic growth. The tax will not have negative economic impact because the bailout is basically a transfer program from taxpayers to depositors. (3) A basic economic principle justifies borrowing only to pay for assets with a useful life. Nothing is more remote from that definition than borrowing to finance losses that have already been incurred.
The moral issue is even simpler. Borrowing burdens the next generation with the repayment of our foolishness and burdens lower-income Americans with the interest costs. The income tax puts the burden where it belongs: on the present generation and on higher-income Americans.
In the damaging legacy of the 1980's, excessive speculation and borrowing will play a prominent role. Unfortunately, your support for borrowing to bail out the savings and loans is, along with your previous support for the use of junk bonds in the private sector, consistent with that legacy. Your voice is, for many of us, the voice of reason. That, however, requires the support of reason in Government financing and private financing. Excessive borrowing is not reasonable.
 
FELIX G. ROHATYN
 New York, June 25, 1990

HEADLINE: A Mexico Trade Pact Will Cost 2 Million Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''A Boost for Both Countries,'' your June 16 editorial endorsing the proposed United States-Mexico free-trade agreement, shows callous disregard for the livelihoods of two million United States workers in the fiber, textile and apparel industries.
So what, you say, if a free-trade agreement with Mexico forces United States textile and steel workers to ''scramble for new jobs at lower wages.'' How can anyone contend that swapping $7 an hour wages in the United States for $7 a day wages in Mexico is in the best interest of workers in either country, especially with no evidence that lower manufacturing costs reach the consumer.
You point out that the agreement would encourage the flow of money from the United States to Mexico, ''thereby creating desperately needed jobs.'' And making thousands of Americans desperate for jobs.
Greater manufacturing unemployment is no problem, you say, because ''this country can afford to provide its jobless with generous assistance.'' This begs the question. Such assistance, if widespread, becomes burial insurance for this major manufacturing sector.
 
DONALD R. HUGHES
President, American Textile
Manufacturers Institute
 Washington, June 22, 1990

LENGTH: 1437 words

HEADLINE: Forecast: Cloudy;
Bush Moves His Lips But Not His Troops

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
BENEATH their public optimism about striking a deal to reduce the budget deficit, the negotiators from the White House and Congress are uneasy. President Bush's surprising concession last week that higher taxes would be needed to cut the deficit got the budget talks started again. But even the President's reversal of his ''no new taxes'' pledge will not translate quickly into an agreement on increased taxes and reduced spending.
''It would be a foolish person who would think the odds are in favor of getting this done,'' said a top Congressional leader who would not allow his name to be used because he promised the President and his colleagues in Congress that his public statements would be upbeat.
Senator Wyche Fowler Jr. of Georgia, a key Democrat in the talks, said that finding a way to trim the deficit was ''a whale of a political challenge as well as a substantive challenge.'' The Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley, called the task ''daunting.'' 
A senior Presidential adviser said he was not sure most Congressional Republicans would ever vote for a budget deal that raised taxes, even if it had Mr. Bush's endorsement. Within hours of the President's turnabout last Tuesday, 90 of the 176 Republican representatives had signed a letter to him saying, ''A tax increase is unacceptable.'' The authors of the letter stopped collecting signatures once they had a majority. All sides agree that no budget agreement can become law unless a majority of the lawmakers in both parties in both houses support it; to win the most difficult political fight of his Presidency, Mr. Bush must begin to twist arms hard.
 
Correcting Mixed Signals
The main problem, Mr. Foley and the White House official agreed, is that the public has been told by Washington for years that the economy is strong and growing, and voters see no reason now why taxes should be raised. The economy, in fact, is, as the President said at his news conference Friday, sluggish. But the unemployment rate is reasonably low. Inflation is no worse than it has been for years. And few economists in or out of Government believe an economic crisis is at hand.
If that is the case, why did President Bush so abruptly abandon the pledge against taxes that was the centerpiece of his election campaign and his first 16 months in office? At his news conference, the President suggested that he had no choice, and he took a first step toward trying to draw a connection in the minds of voters among the budget deficit, the national economy and their own day-to-day lives.
Without action on the budget, he said, the rules of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced budget law will kick in, and spending will be slashed automatically. ''The potential results,'' he said, ''are Draconian cuts in defense, student grants and a wide array of other necessary domestic services.''
The budget deficit for the next fiscal year is now projected at $160 billion, not counting additional spending for the savings and loan bailout. Including the bailout money, the projected deficit is well over $200 billion. Even the lower figure is nearly $100 billion above the $64 billion deficit limit set by the law. If the target is not met or the ceiling not raised, cuts of 25 percent in military outlays and 37 percent in most domestic programs would be mandatory.
The gap is now too large for Mr. Bush to pretend that it can be closed without higher taxes. And the financial markets and the country's trading partners abroad could be expected to rebel if the President and Congress simply ducked the issue by changing the law rather than addressing the problem.
The President seems to have had another reason to act as well. Mr. Bush has been advised that the only obstacle to his re-election in 1992 would be a sour economy two years from now. The best way to guard against that, he has been told, is to drive down interest rates. And the only way to get lower interest rates is to reduce the budget deficit.
In this respect, the President's decision to renege on his pledge against higher taxes was aimed not only at Washington politicians but also at the Federal Reserve and Wall Street financial markets. Administration economists are confident that a serious deficit-reduction deal would lead to a reduction in interest rates of at least one percentage point and possibly more.
After Mr. Bush's statement Tuesday, the budget negotiators - Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady; Richard G. Darman, the budget director; John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and about 20 Congressional leaders from both parties - returned to the bargaining table for three days in a cramped, windowless room just off the Senate floor. But when Congress adjourned for its Fourth of July recess, they were hardly closer to a settlement.
The one sign of progress was that both sides were saying publicly for the first time that any agreement would have to include tax increases, the Republicans' bugaboo, and cuts in popular social programs like Social Security and Medicare that are dear to Democrats' political hearts. Saying that, however, is easy compared with deciding on which taxes to raise and which cuts to make.
Wherever they turn, they face opposition. Substantial spending reductions are probably impossible without trims in Social Security and Medicare. They account for about 35 percent of the budget now, and the proportion is expanding rapidly. The question is how to tackle them without arousing the elderly, the nation's most potent demographic political force. No one favors cutting benefits outright, but some way must be found to slow their growth if a budget compromise is to be reached.
Democrats prefer taxes that hit the rich hard and spare the middle class. Republicans, if they have to accept taxes at all, favor new taxes on cigarettes and alcoholic beverages. Northerners and Midwesterners, regardless of party, would not mind a higher gasoline tax, and legislators from those states reflect that view. Southerners and Westerners, on the other hand, rely more on cars, and lawmakers from those states oppose a gasoline tax. They might vote for one on imported oil, which would lift the price of domestic oil as well, but the burden would fall on consumers outside the oil states. On top of all that, there are deep divisions over President Bush's proposed reduction in the capital gains tax.
The best hope for a settlement appears to be to tie all the painful compromises into one large package and present it for an up or down vote, avoiding votes on the individual elements. If such an agreement cannot be enacted, there are only three alternatives, none of them attractive.
The first would be to allow the across-the-board spending cuts required on Oct. 1 by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law to go into effect. The consequences are unthinkable economically and politically, and few if any politicians advocate this option. Vital programs like food inspection, the border patrol, the Federal prison system and air traffic control would cease to function adequately. Students with Federal aid would have to drop out of school. Roads and bridges would go unrepaired. The economy would collapse.
A more reasonable possibility is to let the cuts become effective for a month or so, which would cause no real damage, and return to Washington after the November election to try to work out a solution. Some lawmakers running this fall are for taking this tack. But there is no guarantee that an agreement to cut the deficit could be reached even after the election. More serious, a lame-duck session cannot last more than a few weeks, and a budget deal could be killed by a Senate filibuster. No one is confident that any agreement could win the 60 votes needed to break such a filibuster. And the result would be that the budget cuts would stay in effect long enough to wreak havoc.
Finally, the politicians could abandon the notion of cutting the deficit and simply rewrite the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law to set the deficit limit higher. That, however, would send a signal to the financial markets that Washington was not serious about controlling the deficit. Furthermore, it would break the pledge made to the European and Japanese allies that the United States would lower its deficit to stop draining investments from abroad and improve the United States' position in international commerce. If the politicians took this route and, in Speaker Foley's words, ''simply punted,'' interest rates would probably soar and the trade balance worsen.
The result might well be a recession. That is what George Bush is trying to avoid.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 1, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 591 words

HEADLINE: Serious, Not Savage, on the Deficit

 BODY:
Tax revenue increases. With those three words, President Bush last week ushered in feverish budget negotiations. Proposals that were taboo on Monday - like taxes on Social Security benefits or cuts in Medicare - suddenly became possible on Tuesday. Swinging into action, Congressional leaders promised to cut next year's budget deficit by $55 billion or more. 
Responsible budget talk is long overdue. But it's also important that Congress not go overboard. Yes, the deficit has to be cut, and substantially. But that need does not justify throwing a fragile economy into recession or starving vital social programs. More deficit reduction is not necessarily better. Revised estimates, incorporating the escalated costs of the savings and loan bailout, indicate that to satisfy the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit target for next year, the deficit must be cut by about $200 billion. That much would be ruinous. So Congress will revise the Gramm-Rudman law and set new targets. A consensus seems to be building for a cut between $50 billion and $60 billion.
Yet a deficit reduction of that magnitude would be twice the size of reductions in recent years - and would fall on an economy that's already sagging, possibly verging on recession. Those who call for cuts this big assume that the Federal Reserve Board would respond by lowering short-term interest rates. That, it is argued, would stimulate the economy and offset the impact of tax hikes and spending cuts.
Maybe. But the Fed has no magical formulas or theories. No one knows for sure how to fine-tune monetary policy. If the Fed erred, it could trigger inflation.
At the same time, Congress knows it can safely reduce the deficit by $30 billion or so; it has done so in recent years. By keeping the reduction in the $30 billion range, Congress would make it easier for the Fed to keep the economy on an even keel.
There's another reason not to go overboard. A reduction in excess of $50 billion would require deep program cuts, probably in excess of $25 billion.
Is there $25 billion to $30 billion in waste? Of course. The problem is that one voter's waste is another voter's welfare. Much of the undisputed waste, like the welfare for the rich involved in agriculture subsidies, is politically entrenched.
Forced to make dramatic cuts by next year, Congress will be tempted to savage truly meritorious programs like aid to Eastern Europe and investments in infrastructure and children.
Wholly apart from these political concerns, the purpose of controlling Federal deficits is to free money for private investment. If the Government borrows less, businesses can borrow more and invest in new plant and equipment. That's how to make the economy grow.
But it makes very little difference whether the Government borrows $20 billion more or less this year. Whether it borrows $20 billion less each year for a decade matters a lot. That's why a long-term plan of steady deficit reduction is better than a dramatic one-year burst. Since 1983, Congress has managed to lower the deficit, measured in relation to the size of the economy, by half. That required nothing draconian. Annual cuts of $30 billion or so will continue to do the trick.
The important point is that the way the deficit is lowered is ultimately more important than the amount. Public investment can be every bit as important for economic growth as private investment. Congress will improve neither economy nor society by lowering deficits at the expense of highways, research and healthy, educated children.
