HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in: Downtown

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
TEN years ago, residential Manhattan all but ceased at Chambers Street. To the northwest lay TriBeCa, to the northeast the Brooklyn Bridge, the government district and the outer fringes of Chinatown.
Below Chambers Street, human life all but disappeared after banks and brokerage houses closed for the day. Except for tourists waiting for the Statue of Liberty ferry, weekends were desolate.
But all that has changed, dramatically in some cases. Entire blocks have been created on what was once part of the Hudson River to form Battery Park City, a glittering enclave of apartment buildings and commercial towers. Older buildings that once housed offices are now homes, and some landmarks have been preserved and turned into co-ops. 
People who have moved in find much to recommend the area - sea breezes, spectacular views of the harbor, convenient public transportation and relative tranquility after hours.
''There's a terrific resurgence of community feeling down here, for the first time in hundreds of years,'' said Mother Barbara Crafton, the associate for mission at Trinity Church on Broadway at Wall Street. ''You can't tell by looking at the place that it's residential, but it is.''
The recent recolonization of Lower Manhattan is the city's development come full circle. In the 17th century, this was Nieuw Amsterdam, founded by the Dutch in 1626. Bowling Green, the squarish patch of grass at the foot of Broadway, was established as the city's first public park in the mid-17th century.
The area became a financial and government center in the 18th century, but gradually was all but deserted by residents. Its slow repopulation can be traced to the development of areas like South Street Seaport and Battery Park City, as well as the popularization of ''downtown chic,'' begun by artists moving into SoHo.
Some of New York City's oldest surviving buildings are here, including Fraunces Tavern, which includes a museum and a functioning restaurant side by side. St. Paul's Chapel, on Broadway at Vesey Street, is the only Colonial church still standing in New York City.
''It's a unique part of town, with all the architecture and the history,'' said Elyn Rosenthal, who has lived in a loft on Beaver Street for the last three years.
There is a diversity of housing styles, from Southbridge Towers, a Mitchell-Lama subsidized cooperative, to slick new luxury apartment buildings, some 30 or 40 stories high, like Liberty Court in Battery Park City. As the population has grown, so have some services like dry-cleaning establishments, although grocery stores remain few and far between.
Some local supermarkets, such as the Food Emporium on Greenwich Street in TriBeCa, let customers set up charge accounts and will deliver, said Paul Carberry, who lives in the former W. R. Grace headquarters at 3 Hanover Square. And 24-hour delicatessens have emerged for those who need ice cream or a quart of milk late at night.
There is a Red Apple in Battery Park City, a Gristede's in Southbridge Towers (and a second scheduled to open there by autumn) and a Sloan's on Madison Street, above the Brooklyn Bridge. Still, many residents say they go uptown for better prices and a wider selection. Another common complaint is that there are no movie theaters south of Canal Street, although a triplex is scheduled to open in Battery Park City next year.
There are local branches of Rizzoli Books, Brooks Brothers and Ann Taylor, and clusters of boutiques in Battery Park City and South Street Seaport. Restaurants range from the venerable Harry's, on Pearl Street, to the new Le Pactole, in the World Financial Center.
''People come here because costs are not as high as you find in other areas,'' said Paul Goldstein, district manager of Community Board 1 and a resident of Southbridge Towers, ''and many of them find nice spaces in older buildings.'' Prices in the area range widely, from $150,000 for a one-bedroom co-op to more than $1 million for a seven-room apartment, according to brokers. Availability also varies: There are long waiting lists for Southbridge's Mitchell-Lama apartments - the only ones in the area - with co-ops and condominiums easier to find.
There are problems in this emerging community. One neighborhood group, the Nassau Area Residents, has been trying to get better sanitation service, especially on weekends, when tourist-generated trash can be overwhelming. And subway station entrances open only during ''business hours'' are a source of annoyance.
As it has been in much of the rest of the city, the resale market has been flat or soft for some time now, brokers and residents say. And as activity in the financial markets has waned, some major construction projects meant to appeal to brokers and others in the financial district have been put on hold, leaving the neighborhood more intact than it might have been.
''Pie-eyed development seems to have come to a close,'' said Chuck Delaney, a photographer who has lived on Pearl Street since 1975. ''You can feel that something has changed'' since the stock market fell 500 points in 1987.
Cooperative apartments in the area have been hard hit by real estate taxes, mainly because they are often in commercial buildings that have been converted to residential use but that are still assessed at commercial rates, said James Roman, sales manager for the Halstead Property Company Downtown. Asking prices have been pushed down by maintenance fees that are far higher than for comparable space uptown, he added.
One-bedroom co-ops in such conversions listed with Halstead range from $147,500 to $395,000, with most of the high-priced listings around $295,000, Mr. Roman said. Two-bedroom apartments with two bathrooms range from $150,000, with a monthly maintenance of $1,800, up to $750,000 with a monthly maintenance of more than $3,000.
''You would have a doorman and an elevator man for half that in many other parts of Manhattan,'' said Mr. Roman of the $750,000 apartment package. ''Someone has to be sold on the neighborhood first before they make the investment.''
RENTS in Battery Park City, where there are 4,096 apartments, of which 2,251 are rentals and the rest condominiums, range from $1,200 to $1,800 for a one-bedroom. Resales there are somewhat stronger than in other parts of the city, said Julie Stevens, director of sales for Battery Park City Realty.
''If it is a well-priced apartment, we find it moves quickly,'' she said.
Prices for one-bedroom resales in Battery Park City range from $180,000 to $500,000, Ms. Stevens said. Two bedrooms generally run from $300,000 to $500,000, she said, although there are exceptions, like a two-bedroom duplex on the water that is listed at $1.8 million. Common charges range from $350 to $550 a month for one-bedrooms, she said.
Rentals in other parts of the area are available but are not as common as condominiums, of which there are 353, or co-ops, of which there are 2,719.
The life style is different, Ms. Rosenthal said, noting, for instance, that she and her husband, Barry - also a photographer - like to board the Staten Island Ferry early on weekend mornings and have a picnic breakfast.
Schools have become an issue recently, intensifying with the arrival of more people with young children, Mr. Goldstein said. Public School 234, built in 1988 at the corner of Chambers and Greenwich Streets in TriBeCa, is zoned for people living west of Broadway. For the others, the option is P.S. 126, on Catherine Street, which is closer to Chinatown. Parents and community members have been lobbying the Board of Education to redraw the zoning lines, but so far nothing has been done. On recent citywide reading tests, P.S. 234 ranked 87th and P.S. 126, 545th.
Children must leave the neighborhood for junior high school, and the only public high schools are Murray Bergtraum, a technical school, and the elite Stuyvesant High School, which will occupy a new building at the northern tip of Battery Park City by autumn.

Just in Case: Castle Clinton, at the foot of Battery Park, was built between 1807 and 1811 by New Yorkers worried about a naval invasion. Originally called West Battery and later named Fort Clinton for Gov. De Witt Clinton, it was built with cannons pointing out to sea, but they were never fired for defense. Over the next century and a half, the fort became a reception hall, a theater, an opera house, an immigration ''holding pen'' and an aquarium. In 1952, Congress declared it a national monument, and it continues to attract many visitors.

HEADLINE: Failure in Denver Hits Manhattan Co-op

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
Aftershocks from the collapse of the Silverado Savings and Loan Association in Denver are shaking a Manhattan cooperative near Lincoln Center, where residents have become the reluctant partners of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.
The failure of the Silverado, which until its demise in 1988 was one of the largest financial institutions in Colorado, put 141 of the 276 apartments in One Harkness Plaza, a 10-year-old building at 61 West 62d Street, in the hands of the Government. The apartments were among the assets seized by the F.D.I.C. when the bank went under.
Silverado is one of hundreds of savings and loan associations across the nation that have fallen apart in the last 18 months under the weight of bad loans and in some cases the free-spending ways of directors. But the involvement of Neil Bush, the President's son, who was on Silverado's board, and a Congressional investigation of the its former principals, has thrust Silverado into the spotlight. The House Banking Committee is looking into charges that Mr. Bush and other directors violated Federal conflict-of-interest rules by not disclosing their relationships with people to whom substantial loans were made. 
Since Federal officials stepped in last year to liquidate the Government's assets in the 26-story Harkness Plaza building, there has been little peace there. The F.D.I.C.'s involvement has set neighbor against neighbor as two camps on the co-op board battle each other at meetings and in court. One side sees no reason to fight the Government's liquidation plan, which calls for a bulk sale of the seized apartments to an investor, and looks forward to having a strong partner buoying the building; the other, concerned with protecting the value of shareholders' investments, is trying to block what it calls the ''fire sale'' of the apartments at only 25 percent of their original value.
Caroll Roos, the account manager for the F.D.I.C. who is in charge of the Harkness Plaza assets, confirmed that a contract is now pending to sell most of the seized apartments to a real-estate investment company, but he refused to name the company or say what it has agreed to pay.
At the heart of the dispute between the two factions on the co-op board is the potential economic impact of the F.D.I.C. sale on shareholders. Original buyers, who bought at insider prices when the building was converted from a rental in 1986, paid $300 a share, or about $180,000 for a typical two-bedroom apartment.
If the F.D.I.C. deal goes through, say board members who oppose the sale, the buyer will get the apartments for about $74 a share, or approximately $45,000 for a two-bedroom unit. The investor could then sell apartments for much less than the prices insiders paid for their units.
Some board members contend that the Government's bulk sale will substantially hurt the value of the apartments owned by tenant-shareholders. They accuse the Government's representatives of ignoring the F.D.I.C.'s legal mandate to protect the shareholders' investments. Other Harkness board members, including its president, Neil Goldstein, believe that what is best for the co-op at this point is for the shares to move into private ownership as quickly as possible.
THAT Harkness Plaza residents are entangled in a mess involving a defaulted bank 1,800 miles from New York can be traced to the financial troubles of the sponsors of the conversion, Robert Postel and Phillip DiSanza. And the complicated case shows the creeping nature of the savings-and-loan crisis, as well as the extent to which the homeowners can be touched by it.
Silverado acquired its Harkness shares - about 47 percent of the total - not from foreclosing on a defaulted loan, which usually happens when a bank or savings and loan takes over, but in the settlement of a suit against it by Mr. Postel and Mr. DiSanza.
Like other converters, they thought their project would succeed when they bought the building in 1983. The building, only three years old at the time, is on West 62d Street, opposite the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center, one of the city's most desirable neighborhoods. It had a high turnover rate for its rental units, which the sponsors hoped would increase the number of apartments they could sell at higher ''outsider'' prices. And many tenants were professional people with high incomes.
The sponsors ran into trouble, Mr. Postel said, when the building's inside buyers demanded costly concessions that led to a cash crunch before the conversion closed in 1986.
Among the most expensive was a demand by buyers that the sponsors reduce the building's second mortgage, held by the Beverly Hills (Calif.) Savings & Loan Association, by $10 million, to about $1.8 million, to lower maintenance costs. In buying the building, Mr. Postel and Mr. DiSanza had assumed a $22 million first mortgage held by the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company.
Another costly condition, Mr. Postel said, was giving inside buyers the option of selling their apartment shares back to the sponsor within six months of the conversion for $360 each, $60 more than they paid. Mr. Postel said the 25 buyers who elected this option cost him and his partner $4 million.
''The bottom line was that we had to come up with in excess of $10 million more than we expected,'' Mr. Postel said. To cover the shortfall, he and Mr. DiSanza took a short-term $14 million loan from the American Savings Bank.
After 130 units were sold, mostly to tenants, sales slowed to a trickle, Mr. Postel said, partly as a result of a glut of new condominiums in the neighborhood.
''We were facing a serious crunch,'' Mr. Postel said, ''American Savings Bank held the shares on the unsold apartments as collateral and would be able to take them over in the case of a default.''
Mr. Postel and Mr. DiSanza approached Silverado for an $18 million loan to enable them to pay off American Savings Bank and to help defray their maintenance costs for unsold apartments, some of which were warehoused and had no tenants. Mr. Postel contends that, as part of the deal, Silverado required him and Mr. DiSanza to take over a mortgage Silverado held on a Denver housing complex known as Tara Woods. That additional mortgage obligation meant they had to increase the amount they borrowed from Silverado to $22.4 million.
They agreed, but the deal soured a few months after it was completed, and Mr. Postel and Mr. DiSanza sued Silverado, charging it had made the loan under fraudulent terms.
''Silverado had vastly overestimated the value of the property in Denver,'' said Mr. Postel, who was ill at the time and unable to inspect Tara Woods personally before the closing. ''They presented us with appraisals saying that it was worth at least $12 million. We found out that a $5 million value was closer to the mark.''
Silverado, in a complicated settlement approved by Judge Robert J. Ward of Federal District Court in Manhattan, agreed to relieve Mr. Postel and Mr. DiSanza of liability for the Tara Woods mortgage and the loan on the Harkness shares. In exchange, Silverado took control of the Harkness shares.
Less than a year later, Silverado went bankrupt, setting the stage for the turmoil on West 62d Street.
''AS far as I can see,'' said Owen McCormack, a resident and board member who is opposed to the F.D.I.C.'s bulk-sale plan, ''the sale is going forward with a total disregard for the shareholders' welfare. But what troubles me even more is that the F.D.I.C.'s representatives in this case have kept crucial information from shareholders.''
Mr. McCormack said, for example, that Eastdil Realty, the company hired by the Government as consultant on the management and sale of apartments, filed an amendment describing the sales plan with the New York State Attorney General's office in August 1989, but did not distribute them to the resident shareholders until February 1990. The Attorney General's rules require that all shareholders receive amendments as soon as they are filed.
Mr. McCormack said that the delay prevented resident shareholders from organizing a joint effort to buy and market the seized apartments themselves. He has filed complaints with the F.D.I.C. and the State Attorney General's office in an effort to halt the proceedings. Mr. McCormack has also sued the co-op corporation in New York State Supreme Court, challenging the right of three F.D.I.C. representatives on the board to vote the Government's shares.
George Pieczenik, another board member who opposes the bulk-sale plan, says he feels the F.D.I.C.'s handling of the Harkness shares violates its own rules.
''The rules require that our interests be considered in any liquidation process,'' Mr. Pieczenik said, referring to Section 212 (h) of the Financial Institutions Reform Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989, which requires the F.D.I.C. to consider any adverse economic impact of a liquidation on local communities. ''It seems to me that a fire sale of apartments is not in keeping with those rules.''
Both Mr. Pieczenik and Mr. McCormack said that if a bulk sale cannot be avoided, tenant-shareholders should be included in the bidding process.
Nancy Kramer, deputy director of the financial services bureau in the Attorney General's office, said the agency found no cause to stop the F.D.I.C.'s bulk sale of Harkness shares.
Neil Goldstein, the president of the Harkness board, said he is ''neutral'' about F.D.I.C.'s role. ''But I do believe,'' he said, ''that it is in the best interest of the co-op to have a responsible and legitimate real estate concern take over the shares so we can go to lenders next year when our mortgage comes due with a financially stable partner.''
Mr. Roos, who is handling the Harkness Plaza case for the F.D.I.C. and who now has a seat on the co-op board, defended his agency's strategy. He said that given the dramatic downturn in the residential real estate market in New York it would have been irresponsible to try to sell the units individually - as some shareholders would have liked - rather than as a package.
''The F.D.I.C. as a fiduciary has a mandate to preserve value of its collateral for the estate,'' he said, ''in this case Silverado Bank. But even though that responsibility does involve liquidations, we do have the impact in mind in every case.''
Even with the offer of a bulk sale of the apartments - some of which have Hudson River views - the F.D.I.C. had trouble attracting bids. Mr. Roos said that after sending marketing material to more than 100 potential investors, it received only two bids high enough for serious consideration.
Arthur Beckerman, a partner in Coronet Properties, a Manhattan real estate investment concern that reviewed and rejected the Harkness share offer, said he thought the $9.5 million asking price was too high, even though he acknowledged the value of the building's location and the fact that most units for sale are empty.
''WHEN you are looking for investments of this type there are many things to consider,'' he said, ''and the price is only one of them. There are all kinds of things that affect the value of unsold shares. There is the building's condition, any shortfalls between rents and maintenance and the building's overall financial situation.''
Mr. Beckerman said his company, which has been an active buyer of both occupied and vacant apartments recently, was especially concerned about the high maintenance charges on Harkness Plaza units, on average about $1,300 a month, and about the corporation's legal entanglements.
Mortgage payments account for about half of shareholders' maintenance payments.
Moreover, the cooperative is currently involved in litigation with the sponsors over unpaid rents on the building's commercial spaces. The co-op is also named as a co-defendant in a suit involving the sponsors' charges that Douglas Elliman, Gibbons & Ives, the real estate management and brokerage company in charge of the original sales campaign for the Harkness apartments, failed to meet its contractual obligations as the marketing agent for the building.
Mr. Goldstein, the president of the co-op board, is just one of many Harkness Plaza residents who hope that life there will soon return to normal.
''Nobody here is happy about what has happened over the past year,'' he said. ''But it looks like we are going to get through it. What matters now is that we get on with the business of making Harkness Plaza a good place to live and a good investment for the shareholders.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

INDUSTRY: NAICS524128 OTHER DIRECT INSURANCE (EXCEPT LIFE, HEALTH & MEDICAL) CARRIERS (94%); SIC6399 INSURANCE CARRIERS, NEC (94%); 

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); 

STATE: COLORADO, USA (93%); NEW YORK, USA (92%); 

CITY: DENVER, CO, USA (93%); NEW YORK, NY, USA (92%); 

COMPANY: FEDERAL DEPOSIT INSURANCE CORP (94%); F D I C (89%);

HEADLINE: Postings: Howard Beach Offices;
Out of Retirement to Build Again

 BODY:
In an effort to broaden the economic base of Howard Beach, Queens, a local developer has created a sleek, two-story office building on the community's main commercial strip. The Pan-Bay Office Building, at 156-36 Cross Bay Boulevard, was completed at a cost of $2 million by Attillio W. Panzarella, who came out of retirement in Scottsdale, Ariz., to realize his vision of giving his old neighborhood an economic boost. The developer, now 70 years old, returned to A. J. Panzarella Realty to pursue the project.
The building, which looks like a cross between a slide rule and a carpenter's level, is wedged between two others on the boulevard, where Mr. Panzarella built a shopping center in 1959.
Clad in brick, aluminum and tinted bronze insulated glass, the 21,000-square-foot building, was designed by Miele Associates of Middle Village, Queens. It offers 8,000 square feet on the ground floor and 13,000 on the second at $21 a square foot. It got an eight-year city tax abatement that will be passed along to tenants when they sign on.
''I would have built an office building eight stories high,'' said Mr. Panzarella, ''but we're on the landing path of JFK and can't go any higher than 33 feet.''

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Family Life Education: Needed Now More Than Ever

BYLINE: By Susan N. Wilson; Susan N. Wilson of Princeton served on the State Board of Education when the family life education policy was adopted.

 BODY:
THIS year marks the 10th anniversary of the adoption of the policy requiring family life education in the New Jersey public schools.
New Jerseyans led the nation in requiring family life education programs. Since New Jersey took the lead, 20 more states have adopted mandates for family life and sexuality education programs, many based on our model.
With the exception of requiring education on HIV-AIDS prevention, state education policy makers have taken no action in the last decade to strengthen family life education programs. Now more than ever, new initiatives are needed. 
Legislation proposed by the Florio administration requires the State Board of Education to develop core concepts and principles that apply to all public schools for science, geography, history and the arts ''as part of the preparation of individuals to function politically, economically and socially in a democratic society.'' The omission of family life education from this list is dismaying.
Family life education focuses on preparing young people to function socially in a democratic society better than any other school program. Family life education requires instruction in four areas: interpersonal relationships, human growth development and sexuality, responsible personal behavior and building strong families. None of the other subjects listed in the legislation aim to help children and youth make safe, responsible and healthy decisions about their personal lives. None offer opportunities for the discussion of feelings and values, and none give students opportunities to develop communication, refusal and decision-making skills.
By excluding family life education from the legislation, administration policy makers are refusing to look directly at the problems affecting New Jersey youth. They are ignoring the fact that 50 percent of high school students have sexual intercourse before the end of school; they are ignoring the high rates of unintended pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases among teen-agers.
Alone, family life education cannot solve all these societal problems, many of which are caused by poverty and lack of life options, but experts agree that early and comprehensive school programs can help to prevent them.
Ten years ago, the support for family life education was strong in all areas of New Jersey; no evidence suggests that the support has flagged. In 1985, for example, a statewide poll showed that ''sex education in the schools is a consensus issue because it is supported by over 90 percent of New Jerseyans.'' Only a very small minority still opposes instruction.
Omitting family life education from the list of major curriculums will weaken its importance in school districts. The Report of the New Jersey Task Force on Adolescent Pregnancy (1988) calls for strengthening primary prevention programs. The study asks more resources to strengthen local implementation of the mandate, more funds for teacher training, school personnel and agency staff and better resource materials in Spanish and other languages for parents.
Students are supporters of family life education. Seniors at a Middlesex County high school recently said their 12th grade program provided needed information about sexuality, AIDS, contraception and pregnancy. They recommended, however, that all the information they received in the 12th grade be offered in the seventh grade. They said earlier information would cut down on the number of unintended pregnancies in their school.
Students in Monmouth County also wanted better family life education. They said their peers ''don't know the facts, they just know hearsay,'' because ''they give us sexual education in our senior year, and that's not enough.''
We should listen to students' appeals for solid programs that help them make responsible decisions about their personal behavior.
Of course, it is important that students know about science, geography, history and the arts, but they also need to know about their personal, sexual and family relationships. They need to know about postponing sexual involvement until adulthood or marriage. They need to know how to protect themselves from unintended pregnancy and sexually transmitted disease. They need to understand the difficulties of teen-agers' raising children. They need to understand about love and trust, respect for self and respect for others.
Without good family life programs, students in public schools will not receive a complete education. Programs will improve if the State Board of Education develops core concepts and principles. Administration officials and legislators should amend the bills to include family life education.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 653 words

HEADLINE: Varied Views on Gun Control

 BODY:
The New Jersey Legislature recently took a first mincing step and passed a gun-control law, long overdue.
Gun owners need to be reminded this is the end of the 20th century, not the middle of the 18th or 19th. The West is secured, and people in our settlements fear Indians much less than raiding government bureaucrats. We are a crowded and compact society, and regulation, like it or not, is king. 
As a dentist coping with government controls and regulations, I cannot resist comparing my position with that of the gun lobbyists.
To establish a perspective: my annual gross is in the modest six figures. My economic impact on the community is negligible; dental offices are not socio-economic power hitters. I do not have the administrative or clerical resources of a major corporation. All that notwithstanding, let me describe some of what must be done to conform to government regulations.
I file form 941 every payday, 940 every quarter, NJ 500 monthly. At appropriate times during the year I file forms BPPT, NJW3, WR30, UC27B, CBT-200T, CBT-100, 7004, 1120, TB32, 940-EZ and BPT-1.
I am registered or licensed by the United States Drug Enforcement Agency, the New Jersey Department of Labor, the State Treasurer, the New Jersey Department of Health, the New Jersey Consumers Division, the New Jersey Secretary of State and the Wyckoff Fire Department.
The pension plan covering me and my employees necessitates filing Schedule P form 5500 R ''and/or forms 5500-C, or EZ where indicated.'' Also schedules A, T and B form 5500. After the schedules comes the PA census form, then forms 2848, 5307, W-2p and 5300.
The above list is incomplete. These are only the regulations requiring payment. There are perhaps half again as many requiring no payment. Accounting fees for guidance through this maze are $5,000 a year.
Since time immemorial, the Drug Enforcement Agency has required us to file an annual drug inventory. Starting in 1987, it required that we also record and keep forever the names of the patients we dispensed to. So I stopped storing and dispensing. If a patient needs a narcotic, I write a prescription.
Now that New Jersey has promoted me from dentist to Regulated Medical Waste Generator, I pay a $528.50 annual registration fee to the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection so it can track my six ounces of medical waste. To satisfy the department, I file tracking forms (''boxes 1-15 completed, retain copy 4; supply copies 1-3 to regulated medical waste transporter''), and retain (again in perpetuity) daily/monthly logs of the fractions of ounces of regulated medical waste generated.
Because I have three employees, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration requires me to identify clearly all Hazmats, maintain a Hazmat list, have a Hazcom program, retain attendance records from our Hazmat training program, keep MSDS's (form OMB 1218-0072) readily available for employee inspection and display OSHA form 2203 prominently.
In summary, to run my little practice, which is likely to harm no one, I have to be licensed or registered with nine government agencies and fill out at least 32 different forms (with accompanying payments) at varying intervals during the year.
Keep in mind that I'm one of the good guys. I give the community no trouble. The cops know me only from my contributions to the P.B.A. I obey the law, pay my taxes, work 10-hour days and associate with no known hoodlums. During lulls in the paper work, I manage to see the patients and possibly relieve pain.
Then the gun lobby tells me guns, bullets and their owners shouldn't be controlled. Baloney.
 
WALTER J. KENT, D.D.S.
 Wyckoff
The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and daytime telephone number and be addressed to The Editor, New Jersey Weekly, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

SECTION: Section 12WC; Page 24, Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1176 words

HEADLINE: ART;
For Diverse Reasons, an Exodus Of County Arts Administrators

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR

 BODY:
IT would seem that art professionals in Westchester are dropping like flies. As of today, Dominique Nahas no longer heads the State University's Neuberger Museum in Purchase; Barbara Bloemink joins the line of Hudson River Museum ex-directors; and Christopher Bruhl concludes his reign over the county's Council for the Arts. The Rye Arts Center, meanwhile, continues its search for an administrator to replace Christina Banks, who left on June 13.
Are these symptoms of a local malaise or are they a sign of the times? 
Mr. Bruhl terms the changes ''coincidental,'' each the result of different circumstances. Looking back at his own job, the former director described it in a recent telephone conversation as a matter of ''building up the arts in Westchester,'' raising and redistributing money (to artists as well as arts organizations) and ''cheerleading so they won't feel lonely.''
After 14 years with the council, 10 of them as director, Mr. Bruhl said it was time for him to move on. But the change comes at a difficult moment, what with the National Endowment for the Arts in crisis and, by implication, the state, county and city agencies, too. And when it comes to dividing up the financial pie, the arts are finding themselves - rather suddenly - in competition with social programs.
Mr. Bruhl said that ''the social needs of the county are enormous.'' He also said that ''the arts are every bit as important as education or solid-waste disposal.''
Noting that the major cutback in Federal financing took place a decade ago, under the Reagan Administration, Mr. Bruhl pointed out that $170 million accorded the National Endowment works out to 70 cents per head of the population, and that the state council's $280,000 costs the state taxpayer $3.10 (the figures are approximate). He compared these figures with the savings and loan bailout, in which estimates of the cost run to thousands of dollars per capita.
Where is the culture money to come from? Apparently, not from the Westchester corporations, whose contribution, Mr. Bruhl said, ''has been minimal.'' Now, it must come from individuals - presumably just as soon as they have taken care of the savings and loan problem.
The Arts Council director has joined another nonprofit organization in Connecticut, but there, he will be dealing with economic development as it pertains to education and transportation. When asked if the state of the arts had anything to do with leaving Westchester, he replied: ''On the contrary, it is at times like these that our agencies come into their own.''
Sven Carlin was bullish on the subject of the Rye Arts Center, where he is chairman of the board. The departure of Ms. Banks was, he said, ''by mutual agreement'' He said the center now needs an administrator ''to work closely with the board and make professional presentations that will attract corporate patrons.''
The center was started 30 years ago by five couples with $250 and a vision of Rye as ''the Athens of the Sound.'' They ran their art school in, among other places, a barn, the upstairs of a Woolworth's on Purchse Street and the basement of a Presbyterian church, until they found the present premises at 51 Milton Road in the early 1970's.
Though evicted in 1984, the group reached an agreement with the city whereby they paid $1 a year rent and fixed up the 200-year-old building itself. Three years and $1.2 million later, the group was back in business.
Mr. Carlin said the center's budget had gone to $400,000 from $40,000 - hence the need for a professional capable of the kind of balancing act expected of museum directors. ''We have never had Federal funding,'' the chairman said, and ''the individual kind is running dry.''
Citing the artists among the board's 40 members, Mr. Carlin dismissed a suggestion that fiscal stability achieved in this way could jeopoardize esthetic standards.
As for the Hudson River Museum, Ms. Bloemink's departure has yet to be announced and the board president, Joyce Green, did not return phone calls. So it remains only to say that within the decade since Richard Koshalek left for the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, the Hudson River Museum has seen a series of directors, of whom Peter Langlykke seemed the most adept at reconciling the museum's requirements with those of a diverse community.
The most significant of the departures is that by Dominique Nahas from the Neuberger Museum. Ensconced on a campus that is not 20 years old and is isolated to boot, the Neuberger is one of the university's two public attractions (the other is the Performing Arts Center). The university's primary purpose is education and the academic departments have to compete with the arts for money, if only to insure a flow of distinguished alumni.
A university museum has a certain freedom that is denied its independent counterparts - it doesn't have to produce blockbusters, but can entertain smaller and more experimental shows. The ideal director for any kind of museum is one who provides leadership, initiates shows, cooperates with but is not dominated by the board and (not in his or her spare time) raises money by cultivating existing benefactors and finding new ones. Notwithstanding the growing difficulties of running a museum, such paragons do exist.
By his own admission, Mr. Nahas is not one of them. ''I have a one-track mind,'' he said in an interview recently, and it is obvious that the track leads directly to exhibitions. At the same time, he realizes that the director of a university museum must act as a kind of universal joint between the board, the campus administration, students and faculty and the public.
Not that Mr. Nahas had much time to put his wisdom into effect. Director of the Everson Museum of Art in Syracuse for nearly five years, he lasted only 10 months at the Neuberger. Yet this was long enough to impress the dean of fine arts, George Parrino, who said that he regretted not being able to see the ''fruits of his vision'' but otherwise kept his own counsel, as have other bystanders. The atmosphere at the Neuberger is tense.
One definition of an ideal board would be a group of individuals committed to art but not necessarily well informed about it. They would know the difference between a rented show and one generated by their own museum and they would see themselves as part of a collective personality. Whether the Neuberger board approaches this ideal is unclear.
But it is certain that the need has developed for directors who are not only paragons but who also come on like MBA's is widespread. It seems, too, that museum boards too often feel compelled to act like corporations, even though the only profit they can show is prestige.
The president of the Purchase school, Sheldon Grebstein, has announced a search committee consisting of himself, the senior vice president for academic affairs, Nathaniel Siegel, and the assistant vice president for organized activities, Deanne Molinari. They don't have much time: the capital campaign is due in November.

HEADLINE: Taking a Broader View Of Drugs in the Suburbs

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
LEE P. BROWN, Commissioner of the New York City Police Department, said in a speech here on Tuesday that it is ''wrong and dangerous'' to regard drug abuse and its criminal consequences as an inner-city scourge threatening the suburbs.
''Addicts and pushers are too busy finding the money to get high or get fixed'' to commute to the suburbs, Mr. Brown told a luncheon audience at the White Plains Hotel. Rather, he said, ''the reverse is true: so-called recreational users travel to our cities to purchase drugs.''
Failing to recognize the full scope of the nation's drug problem ''sows the seeds of divisiveness which contributes to social disharmony and prejudice,'' the Commissioner told the 92 people attending the yearly meeting of the Westchester Council on Crime and Delinquency. 
 
Broad Approach Is Stressed
The 34-year-old council, based here, is a nonprofit organization that promotes citizen involvement in criminal-justice issues and monitors developments in the field. It is the only local affiliate in the state of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency, whose members include Mr. Brown.
The Commissioner, who was appointed by Mayor David N. Dinkins in January, emphasized the country's need for a ''holistic'' approach to a spectrum of social ills, including the deterioration of the nuclear family, joblessness and the resulting disabling effects on children.
''Enforcement is a valuable tool,'' Mr. Brown said, ''but the better part of the answer lies in demanding reduction through education.''
 
Children at Risk
Mr. Brown cited statistics showing dramatic increases in cocaine abuse among pregnant women, which has raised the incidence of infant mortality, as well as the increases in the deaths of children from drug-related abuse or neglect. He also warned that young people were more likely to buy drugs from a friend than from a pusher because of peer pressure. ''It's not just inner-city children who are at risk, but the entire nation's children who are at risk,'' he said.
The Commissioner, who holds several master's degrees and a doctorate degree in criminology, called on the business community to ''fund youth activities'' that would occupy the after-school and vacation time of latch-key children in particular.
Jobs should be found for teen-agers, he urged, to ''help them get a jump on the corporate ladder and provide an opportunity to see what a drug-free life style can be like.''
 
A 'Drug-Free Corps'
Mr. Brown suggested offering scholarships to urban youths as ''a way out of the ghetto.'' In addition, he proposed a ''domestic drug-free corps'' along the lines of the Peace Corps, in which college students would help tutor and counsel young people.
In return, the students would be relieved of their obligation to repay educational loans or would receive special consideration when applying for Federal or state loans for graduate studies.
After Mr. Brown's speech, Robert M. Maccarone, the county's Director of Criminal Justice Services, said the corps proposal was a ''very worthwhile idea,'' since it might induce more young people to enter the drug-counseling field. ''One of our largest problems is a deficit in personnel, not money,'' Mr. Maccarone said.
In stressing the need for educational programs to reduce the demand for drugs, Mr. Brown cited New York City's School Program to Educate and Control Drug Abuse, which combines classroom teaching teams composed of school and community figures with narcotics teams working near schools in high-risk neighborhoods.
 
Opposes Legalization
The Commissioner said he was opposed to legalizing drugs, not only because of the ''monstrous economic, medical and hidden legal costs'' that he predicted would follow, but also because ''the wrong signal'' would be sent to young people.
Rather, he said, people need ''the willpower as a country'' to develop effective social policies - such as a commitment to ''full employment.''
Mr. Brown called the $400 million that has been allotted to state and local governments for drug programs ''a drop in the bucket.''
''It doesn't make sense to have a war on drugs without the resources,'' he said.

LENGTH: 1487 words

HEADLINE: A Changing Mortgage Market in County

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER

 BODY:
THREE years ago, during the real estate boom, a professional couple in their 30's sold their ''starter'' house, a small two-bedroom in Harrison, for $150,000. By stretching their budget to the limits, they bought a three-bedroom split level in Rye for $295,000.
''We took an adjustable rate mortgage from the bank, with a special rate of 8 percent for the first year,'' said the husband, who asked that his name not be published. ''It looked like we were getting a good deal, but now we're paying the piper: every month we're falling further behind.''
Not only have their mortgage payments risen by about $5,000, but their real estate taxes have gone up, too. And they recently discovered that they needed a new furnace. 
''We're stretched too thin now and I don't know what we're going to do,'' his wife said. ''We thought about sell ing. But the couple next door, whose house is almost identical to ours - it's a little nicer, actually - put their place up for sale three months ago but they've had very few lookers and no offers. The market is dead.''
 
Effort to Prevent Defaults
But few mortgage lenders will take steps to start foreclosure proceedings without exploring every alternative, said William J. Foley, vice president for public affairs at the New York League of Savings Institutions, a trade group based in Scarsdale.
''Banks are anxious to prevent defaults,'' Mr. Foley said. ''They don't want to have to take over residential real estate in this type of market.''
Delinquent loans in the fourth quarter of 1989, the latest period for which figures are available, were 4.3 percent of all loans. This compares with a delinquent loan rate of 2.8 in the fourth quarter of 1988.
Until about a year ago, Mr. Foley said, ''Westchester was a self-contained unit. Houses, especially expensive ones, were selling well. But now the county is more like the rest of the state. Loan demand is weak. Mortgage volume is half of what it was last year. And compared with 1987, a banner year, last year's figures were not good.''
 
Stricter Handling of Loans
Even competition for mortgage business, Mr. Foley said, is down: ''Regulators are requiring that lenders have heavier reserves. No one is making questionable loans today. And teaser rates, such as 7 or 8 percent for the first year, are pretty well a thing of the past.''
The prevailing rate today for a 15-year fixed-rate home mortgage in the county is 9.75, plus 2 1/2 points; for a 30-year mortgage, the rate is 9.875, plus 2 1/2 points.
In the wake of the savings and loan disaster, Mr. Foley said, the industry has become more heavily controlled.
But Richard Komosinski, president of the Yonkers Savings and Loan Bank, which has been in business for more than 100 years, said that well-run banks have always imposed strict loan requirements.
''Today, it's hard to stand up and say that you're a banker,'' he said. ''All the savings and loans are getting an undeserved bad press because of the activities of a few. When they deregulated the banking industry, the regulators didn't watch what was going on and a lot of questionable people entered the industry. Now all of us are paying, including the lending institutions. Our insurance premiums, for example, have risen from $195,000 a year to $245,000.''
Mr. Komosinski said his bank has had no foreclosures this year. ''Whenever we see someone falling behind, we bend over backward to work with them on a one-to-one basis,'' he explained.
 
A Way to Work Things Out
Yonkers Savings and Loan's four offices, all in Yonkers, make the majority of mortgage loans to neighborhood people.
''The people on our board are local,'' Mr. Komosinski said. ''They know our customers, we know our customers and we know that most of their financial difficulties are temporary, the type that are caused by a personal or family crisis. They are stable people. We don't want to push them into foreclosure; we prefer to help them find a way out by working with them.''
Michael R. Pulver, manager of the Sibley Mortgage Corporation in Elmsford, said his company began to experience an increasing demand for mortgages in mid-June.
''It was kind of unexpected,'' Mr. Pulver said, ''I think a lot of the activity was because of the decrease in interest rates. People seemed to sense it was going to be short-lived and took advantage of it.''
Unlike banks, Mr. Pulver explained, mortgage bankers offer nothing but first mortgage and home-equity loans. The funds for mortgage-bank lending come from not one, but several, private investors.
''Because we do mortgage financing and nothing else, we're able to offer a wide variety of mortgage options at very competitive rates,'' Mr. Pulver said. ''And as we see it, the mortgage picture is not as bleak as it has been generally presented. We haven't had any defaults. Back in 1987, when houses were going up in value 25 percent a year, there were a lot of loans made based on future appreciation of house prices. But as appreciation has slowed, customers' assets and wages are getting prime consideration when we make our loan decisions.''
 
Loans to the Elderly
The Hudson Valley National Bank, also headquartered in Yonkers, is making fully verified loans only, said Elizabeth M. Lindberg, vice president and mortgage officer. ''Business is slow but fairly steady,'' she said. ''We have an excellent mortgage portfolio. We have never had a foreclosure.''
Hudson Valley, in conjunction with the county, is sponsoring for the second year what Ms. Lindberg referred to as ''a reverse-mortgage program'' - loans to elderly homeowners.
Unlike a home-equity loan, the borrower receives a monthly payment from the bank. No monthly payback is required, however, until 10 years have elapsed, when the total sum, with interest, is expected.
''Last year, we were approached by the county,'' Ms. Lindberg explained, ''and in the interest of helping the community we made $5 million available to elderly homeowners in loans, and recently we've added an additional $5 million for use in the loan program.''
 
A Loan, Not a Gift
The loans, she said, are offered at a competitive rate to older customers: ''It's currently 10 percent - the same terms we offer for our 15-year mortgage. The loans are loans, not a gift.''
The program is administered for the county by Westchester Residential Opportunities, a nonprofit agency that receives $17,500 a year from the county for its administration costs.
''Basically, the program helps older people convert the equity they have built up in their homes to cash,'' said Doris Schear, the mortgage program's director. ''Without it, many of them would be forced to sell their homes. We've tried for years - five or six actually - to get a bank involved and get the program off the ground. But we couldn't do a thing until Hudson Valley agreed to make the loans. We had 350 inquiries in the first year and we made 37 loans to older homeowners.''
 
Who Is Eligible
According to Ms. Schear, anyone older than 60 can borrow up to $125,000, which includes interest costs, against the equity in their home. The money may be borrowed in a lump sum or taken out in monthly installments for a period of 10 years.
Reviewing several case histories, Ms. Schear cited a spirited woman in her 70's, with a passion for travel but no disposable income.
''Her chief asset is her house, which is worth about $400,000, but she's not ready to sell it and leave Westchester,'' Mrs. Schear said. ''Yet, she said she wanted to take a few trips while she's still mobile. With the money she got from the loan, she's going to travel and have a good time. She has a plan. In a few years, she intends to sell her home, pay back the loan, and with the remaining money move to an inexpensive place in Florida.''
 
Medical Bills and Taxes
One infirm couple in their 80's who received a loan were anxious to stay in their own home as long as possible but needed the money because of medical bills and the rise in the cost of living.
''A nationwide profile for the typical person in the program is a 74-year-old widow who owns her own home, free and clear, but lives on an income of less than $800 a month,'' Ms. Schear said. ''Our people fall into every category. We have a family, for instance, in which the husband is in his late 60's and is still working, but he's not making enough to keep up with the bills and the rise in taxes.''
Another family consistsof an elderly mother and her middle-aged son, who is mildly retarded. ''The mother had used up most of her resources and she was frantic because the son's small disability payment wasn't enough to make ends meet,'' Ms. Schear said.
''It's a loan, not a gift,'' she noted. ''People fully understand that they are expected to repay it with interest at the end of the term. The big advantage of having it is that it buys people more time to live in their homes.''

LENGTH: 1606 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Savings Bailout Irks State Officials

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
REPORTS that the Federal cleanup of the savings and loan disaster will result in Connecticut residents paying $1,237 a person more to rescue the failed thrifts than they will receive in bailout benefits has angered state lawmakers and banking officials, and last week several were looking for ways to offset the situation.
''We seem to be getting a double whammy,'' said the State Banking Commissioner, Howard B. Brown. Federal regulators have already put severe restrictions on still-solvent Connecticut institutions, he said, resulting in a credit crunch, and now the Federal bailout program will require Connecticut residents to rescue savings and loans in other states.
''There must be a more equitable manner of dealing with this,'' Mr. Brown said. He said he had already contacted Federal officials about the situation and planned to talk with the Governor's staff to determine what steps the state could take to offset it. 
United States Senators Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of New Haven, and Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of East Haddam, said they would press for investigations of the savings and loan industry. ''The only way to ameliorate the anger and frustration people in states like Connecticut are feeling,'' said Mr. Dodd, ''is to go after - hammer and tongs - the people who are responsible.''
Both Senators said they might seek to use the fact that Connecticut will be a big loser under the bailout program as leverage in getting other Federal aid for Connecticut, for housing or transportation or a program to save defense jobs. ''After this, I think they owe us a big one,'' Mr. Lieberman said. ''There's the matter of equity here,'' he continued. ''There's a transfer of money going on here that is enormous, and one that we cannot afford, because our own economy is vulnerable right now.''
All taxpayers will pay the same amount under the Government's $203 billion bailout of the savings and loan industry, but many economists and politicians have concluded that it will result in a significant transfer of wealth from the Northeast and Middle West to Texas and other states in the Southwest, where the savings and loan failures are concentrated. This shift, they say, will result in a stronger economy in the Southwest in the years ahead and a weaker economy for most other states.
But one financial expert said Connecticut should not complain too loudly, because the financial troubles being faced by the state's own savings institutions could result in a number of bailouts here. ''We may end up very happy there is this kind of a rule on the books,'' said Lewis Mandell, a professor of finance at the University of Connecticut who is a consultant for the United States Comptroller of the Currency and is writing an article for Grolier's Encyclopedia on the savings and loan problems. ''All the bailouts aren't over yet, and Connecticut may be in for its share.''
He noted that the state-chartered Savings Bank of Brooklyn is in serious trouble, and the Community Federal Savings Bank of Bridgeport is on the list of vulnerable institutions compiled by the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Federal agency that is trying to develop plans for troubled savings and loans.
The savings and loan failures were ''stupid'' and are ''going to be very costly,'' Dr. Mandell said. ''But what is the alternative?'' If the Federal Government does not bail out the banks, the depositors lose their savings, he said, and the real estate speculators would be no worse off than they are now.
The money to keep the banks solvent will come out of income taxes, and because Connecticut residents earn more, they will pay more. Also, because so few banks have failed in Connecticut - one federally chartered bank closed last November in Meriden but reopened within a week after it was purchased by another bank - few of the dollars paid into the bailout fund will flow back to Connecticut.
 
Loss of $1,237 a Person
An analysis of the plan to save ailing savings and loans around the country, compiled by Prof. Edward W. Hill of Cleveland State University, showed that the net cost per person in Connecticut will be $1,237. In only three other states and the District of Columbia, will the cost exceed $1,000 a person. In all, 37 states will lose money under the bailout plan, and 13, most of them in the Southwest, will gain.
The biggest winner will be Texas, where the net cash inflow will be $4,775 per person, according to Professor Hill's analysis.
He estimated a total bailout cost of $203 billion, but Dr. Mandell said it could approach $300 billion, and some say it could go higher than that.
The problem is particularly troubling, Mr. Brown said, because while Federal regulators are seeking massive amounts of money from Connecticut's economy to pay for the bailout, they are taking steps that will slow the state's economy down.
Mr. Brown said Federal examiners left the failed savings and loans of Texas and came to Connecticut earlier this year and began imposing strict limits on bad loans.
Even state-chartered savings institutions have to comply with some Federal regulations, including requirements about reserves. An institution must put some of its surplus or capital into a reserve to cover loans that are not being paid on time and might go into default. Mr. Brown said that before this year, Federal regulators required 35 or 40 percent in reserves, but they have boosted that to about 66 percent.
 
Fresh in the Minds
''The rules are being applied much more stringently in the Northeast than they have been in the past,'' Mr. Brown said. He blamed that on the fact that the Texas disasters were still fresh in the minds of the examiners, and they want to prevent that from happening again in Connecticut.
''Had regulators been doing their job as diligently all along as they are in Connecticut now, none of this would have happened,'' Dr. Mandell said. He said if the first losses in Texas in 1981 and 1982 triggered a similar response, the losses might have been contained to $50 billion.
''The real scandal is that they took some of the toughest and best administrators and tried to put them in Texas, and the bankers and their politician friends forced them out,'' Dr. Mandell said.
A result of the new rules on reserves is that banks are showing less of a profit, which is causing their stock prices to plunge. As a result, Mr. Brown said, banks are tightening up credit, so they do not have to put so much into reserves. Lending activity at federally chartered banks in Connecticut has dropped $1.2 billion since last September, while at state-chartered banks, it has dropped about $640 million.
''The mind set of certain bankers right now is to not make loans, to wait until this blows over,'' Mr. Brown said. Even good credit risks, he said, are finding it difficult to obtain loans.
''As a regulator I have mixed feelings about all this,'' Mr. Brown said. While he wants to see the banks solvent, he does not want to see the economy choked, he said.
 
Reaction of Senators
But officials said an even larger problem looms, as Federal tax dollars begin to flow out of the state to help failed savings and loans throughout the Southwest.
''I'm outraged about what happened,'' Senator Lieberman said. ''The numbers of the transfer of money are so galling it leads me to take a look at the formulas involved.''
Mr. Lieberman said there has long been debate about the fact that Connecticut gets back less in Federal aid than its residents pay in taxes. Congressmen from other states point to the fact that Connecticut has long received a disproportionate share of defense spending. But that is because Connecticut workers are skilled, Mr. Lieberman said, ''not because we've had a lot of crooks stealing from our savings and loans.''
The Senator said he was so concerned about the problem that he submitted legislation that would enable the Secret Service to investigate bank fraud. The Federal Bureau of Investigation is so backlogged, with more than 1,000 cases involving fraud of $100,000 or more, that it would welcome the help, Mr. Lieberman said, and Secret Service officials have told him they could field 100 agents on the cases immediately and another 200 agents during the next 6 to 12 months.
''We have to do what we can to catch and punish those people who are responsible for this rip-off,'' Mr. Lieberman said. ''And then we have to put a cap on it.''
His bill was incorporated last week into a bill to stiffen the investigation into savings and loans that was introduced by Senator Joseph M. Biden, Democrat of Maryland, chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee. That should improve its chances of success, Mr. Lieberman said.
Mr. Dodd, a member of the Senate Banking Committee, said he would push for a full investigation of the savings and loan industry and its regulators.
He also said that his ''strong temptation would be to craft some funding scheme to allow states that are paying so much of this money for the savings and loan bailout to get favored treatment for things they need, such as housing and transportation for Connecticut.''
But, he added, ''whether or not you can equitably do something like that is another matter.''
Dr. Mandell said that while the cost to Connecticut taxpayers sounds high, it will not have as great an impact as people expect, because the bailout will take place over a long period of time.
''It'll probably be paid our over 10 years, which amounts to another $100 per person per year,'' Dr. Mandell said. ''That's just a rough number, but that's the magnitude of what we're talking about.''

HEADLINE: FORUM;
The Latest Political Litmus Test

BYLINE: By JOESPH STANISLAW and DANIEL YERGIN; Joseph Stanislaw is managing director, and Daniel Yergin president, of Cambridge Energy Research Associates. Mr. Yergin is author of ''The Prize: The Epic Quest for Oil, Money, and Power.''

 BODY:
President Bush's decision last week to limit offshore drilling demonstrates that hardly any politician can risk being seen as anti-environmental. The reason for this is the growth of the environmental consciousness among the American people.
Americans believe in economic growth. But a significant majority think that we can have economic growth and a cleaner environment. This is what we found in a new survey of 1,250 people we undertook with the Opinion Dynamics Corporation to assess how Americans think about the environment, energy and the economy. 
Seventy-four percent of the public we surveyed said that if they had to choose, they would select environmental cleanup and slower growth over economic growth. A large majority also says that it would reject political candidates who do not agree with the preference for environmental protection over economic growth - that is, if a choice has to be made. Environmentalism will increasingly be a litmus test for candidates.
Underlying these attitudes is a strong streak of pessimism. A majority of Americans believes the nation's environment has become worse over the last year, and almost half think it will be in worse shape ten years from now. Both business and government suffer from a credibility gap.
The public's response to the question of which environmental problems have most directly affected them indicates why clean air has been so compelling a cause. Half the respondents we interviewed said that they had been adversely affected by pollution - water, air, acid rain, and 29 percent said they had encountered respiratory or breathing problems.
While the environmental consensus has emerged as a potent political force in the last few years, its strength, we found, would be tested in an economic downturn. After all, the focus on such concerns tended to recede during the economic slump of the 1970's. The consensus could also be challenged by the public's worries about the adequacy of energy supplies, we found.
Although environmental anxieties currently outweigh economic concerns, 72 percent of the public thinks it is likely the United States will face problems getting an adequate supply of oil in the next 10 years. Most favor incentives to encourage domestic oil production and support offshore oil drilling to keep oil imports down. On the other hand, 81 percent think their local electricity supplies will be adequate in the next few years.
Yet that is the energy shortage that could well develop the soonest, particularly in the Northeast. If so, that will mean the United States must confront some of the trade-offs and choices the over-supplied energy markets of the 1980's allowed us to avoid. It does not, however, mean that the environmental consensus will be overturned.

LENGTH: 1521 words

HEADLINE: New Weapon Against Harbor Oil Spills

BYLINE: By LEO H. CARNEY

 BODY:
THE Coast Guard is preparing to install a system of radar and television cameras in New York Harbor that will alert ships' pilots to traffic conditions and emergencies, in an effort to prevent some of the oil spill accidents that have plagued the harbor area and, most recently, the Jersey Shore.
Capt. Robert C. North, the Coast Guard's captain of port for New York and New Jersey, said the system, the Vessel Traffic Service, would be set up in three phases, the first of which will be in operation by Dec. 1 along Newark Bay, and between the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and the Brooklyn Bridge. The entire service area, from Sandy Hook to the Hudson and East Rivers, will be covered by December 1992, he said.
Emphasizing that the system is not as sophisticated or demanding as air traffic control for aircraft, Captain North said that the new system nevertheless ''will give us a closer look at what is moving in port.''
''We will be capable of telling a tanker what is around the corner, for instance, or what unanticipated dangers to avoid,'' he said. 
The system, which was approved by Congress last year in an amendment to the Coast Guard Reauthorization Act that was proposed by Representative Frank Pallone Jr., Democrat of Long Branch, will be monitored by an operations center at Governors Island, N.Y.
 
Required to Check In
Vessels of 100 gross tons or more - this excludes most pleasure craft and small passenger ferries - will be required to check in with a Vessel Traffic Service operator as they approach the harbor, said Lieut. Comdr. James E. Bussey 3d, an officer in charge of Vessel Traffic Service operations.
Ships' masters or pilots can be warned or advised of traffic conditions by the Coast Guard or receive whatever traffic or navigational information they themselves request, he said.
The total cost for the system will be $17.6 million, with about $5 million going to cover the cost of the first phase, Coast Guard officials said.
Mr. Pallone said in a recent interview at his office in Long Branch that a similar system had been operating in New York Harbor until it was discontinued two years ago because of Coast Guard budget cutbacks. Unlike the new service, it was voluntary for pilots. But, Mr. Pallone said, a report by the Government Accounting Office last year warned that some ports like New York were ''in jeopardy'' for lack of a vessel traffic service.
Work on the service has already begun, Commander Bussey said. Electronics equipment had been purchased last month, he said, and next month a five-month training program will begin for the 33 Coast Guard members who will operate it.
Preparation for the system began as numerous regulatory agencies, legislative committees and task forces undertook major inquiries into the recent spate of oil spill accidents in New York Harbor.
Judith A. Yaskin, Commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Protection and the co-chairman of the New York-New Jersey Harbor Oil Spill Prevention Task Force, told the Coast Guard Board of Inquiry on Governors Island last month that the petroleum industry had failed to adequately take control of vessel and pipeline transfers in the harbor. Last year these operations involved 1,700 vessels and 18 million gallons of refined and crude oil.
 
Beaches Forced to Close
The latest major spill, on June 7, was of 260,000 gallons that leaked from the BT Nautilus, a large British tanker. The vessel ran aground in the Kill Van Kull. Its cargo partly congealed in the water and formed tar balls that, days later, polluted New Jersey beaches from Sandy Hook to Long Beach Island, forcing some bathing beaches to close.
Commissioner Yaskin said in an interview that oil spills had increased precipitously since 1986 in the harbor. More than a million gallons, she said, found their way into the harbor since January alone, starting with 567,000 gallons on Jan. 1 and 2 from a ruptured Exxon pipeline between New Jersey and Staten Island.
Although it was difficult finding anyone in government or the petroleum industry who did not enthusiastically favor the Vessel Traffic System, Mr. Pallone, Captain North and others agreed that it was not a panacea for averting oil spills.
According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the Coast Guard, since 1976 there have been at least 63 major oil spills in New York Harbor, each involving 10,000 gallons or more.
Lieut. Brian Bubar, a Coast Guard spokesman, said that the 63 accidents spilled 5.9 million gallons of oil into the harbor, a figure that does not reflect what officials generally admit could be dozens or hundreds of smaller spills or discharges from loading docks, bilge pumps and other sources.
The fact that spills from vessels accounted for 24 of the 63 spills has led Mr. Pallone and others to look for additional solutions at both Federal and state levels - all with considerable opposition for the petroleum industry.
Mr. Pallone said, for example, that discrepancies between the House and Senate versions of the Spill Liability Act of 1989 had delayed for many months the passage of that measure and, therefore, the imposing of more stringent regulations on oil transporters by the Federal Government.
 
Topics of Discrepancies
These discrepancies, he said, included a requirement that tankers have double hulls and mandatory drug testing for all licensed ships' officers, as well as the issue of liability for spills.
The bill, Mr. Pallone said, has become ''bogged down'' in a joint House and Senate conference committee.
Among other things, Mr. Pallone recently told the House Coast Guard Subcommittee, of which he is a member, that Congress needed to bolster harbor safety by requiring spill response equipment in New York Harbor, not in North Carolina as the proposed Spill Liability Act now reads, and by improving the ability of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in Seattle to project accurately where a spill can be expected to spread, based on the weight of the oil and conditions of weather and tide.
Mr. Pallone said in the interview that the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration trajectory for the June 7 oil spill had predicted that the oil would not wash ashore, when in fact it did, and that the reason for this was a staffing deficiency in the Seattle headquarters of the agency.
 
Fines of Up to $10 Million
In Trenton, the Assembly voted favorably last month on a package of anti-spill measures that includes fines of up to $10 million for major spills, a type of penalty that has upset the petroleum industry. One of the causes of the industry's concern, according to spokesmen, was the issue of pre-empting or prohibiting individual states from imposing their own restrictions in addition to Federal ones.
Bill Taylor, a spokesman for the Washington-based American Petroleum Institute, said in an interview that regulatory ''inconsistencies from state to state'' made it ''very difficult to operate an industry spill response network on a regional basis.''
''It makes it very expensive to operate,'' he said, ''and imposes severe liabilities, which can become greater than a company's ability to generate revenues. So, a company is forced to choose, say, between doing business in Virginia and maybe not doing business in Maryland.''
Noting that the Royal Dutch Shell Company this year had cut back United States delivery to all ports except one in Louisiana because of severe pollution liability regulations, Mr. Taylor said that the threat of economic abandonment of an individual port by petroleum companies was ''a viable option that is always available.''
 
Threats Called 'Not Viable'
Commissioner Yaskin said that economic threats like these had not been made during recent talks with industry officials in New Jersey and New York. She added that in light of the vast amount of oil handled in New York Harbor, ''the reality is that such threats are not viable in this market because of the industry's self-interest.''
''The cost benefit ratio that I am most concerned with,'' Mrs. Yaskin asserted, ''is New Jersey's $7.5 billion tourist industry - billions of dollars in boats and marinas, the fishing industry and shore property - in the effect of the oil spills on benthic animals and the health of our estuaries.''
She said the thing she had feared most since the Exxon spill in January, when she took office, ''was the potential for a spill polluting our coast.'' She added, ''It has happened this time.''
Meanwhile, Commander Bussey of the Coast Guard said that the new Vessel Traffic Service, because it is now mandatory, would include many more vessels.
Several mandatory and voluntary systems have been in place in several ports since the 1970's, he said, including Galveston and Prince William Sound in Alaska. But, he said, the efficacy of these systems will not have been evaluated until the release later this summer of the Coast Guard's port-needs study.
''It sometimes can be hard,'' Commander Bussey said, ''to measure when a warning you gave a vessel prevented a serious accident.''
