The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 2, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 1734 words

HEADLINE: In North Carolina, the New South Rubs Uneasily With the Old Ways

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STOVALL, N.C.

 BODY:
Forty-five minutes down Interstate 85, researchers are pushing at the boundaries of medical science at the Duke University Medical Center, but there has recently been an epochal breakthrough here: nearly all the residents who had been using old pine outhouses have been able to replace them with indoor bathrooms.
For North Carolina, this is a familiar paradox. Often viewed both within and outside the region as the most progressive state in the South, North Carolina now symbolizes more than any other state the contradictions of a region increasingly split between metropolitan areas that prospered in the Sun Belt boom of the last two decades and rural areas left behind.
Long known for excellent universities like Duke and the Univerity of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, its high school students ranked last nationally in Scholastic Aptitude Test scores in 1989.
Home to the high-technology complex at the Research Triangle between Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill, the state also has the highest infant mortality rate. 
 
Integration and the Klan
Perhaps the most successful Southern state in integrating peacefully in the civil rights era, North Carolina now has both a black man, former Mayor Harvey Gantt of Charlotte, running for the Senate and one of the nation's highest reported levels of hate crimes and Ku Klux Klan activity.
And the race between Mr. Gantt, a symbol of the increasingly diverse and urban character of the region, and Senator Jesse Helms, a contentious conservative who as much as anyone symbolizes the South's rural traditions, is providing perhaps the ultimate juxtaposition of the South's conflicting currents.
''North Carolina mirrors its landscape,'' said Fred Chappell, a novelist and poet who teaches at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro. ''It stretches from the highest mountains east of the Rockies to the ocean, and somehow we embrace those contradictions. What's changed is the emphasis. In the past it was more social. Now, it's more brutally economic.''
The disparities are shocking, even to some North Carolinians, because of a statewide image shaped more by the Research Triangle and the allure of the Great Smoky Mountains and the Outer Banks than any vision of Deep South poverty.
The 10th most populous state, North Carolina had led the South in industrialization, and in many ways has been the region's most successful state. While states like Mississippi and Alabama were electing politicians dedicated to preserving segregation, North Carolina was electing governors like Luther Hodges and Terry Sanford, who became the model for New South moderates on race.
 
Jump in Per Capita Income
North Carolina's unemployment rate, 4 percent, is the lowest among the 11 largest states, and the state has jumped from 44th to 34th nationally in per capita income over the past several years. It has led the nation in adding manufacturing plants in each of the last three years and has averaged about 100,000 new jobs annually in recent years.
Most of the gains have come in booming areas like Charlotte, which is now considered the banking capital of the South, and the Research Triangle, which has one of the highest concentration of Ph.D.'s, scientists and engineers of any comparable geographical area in the United States.
But just beyond the economic orbit of cities like Durham, where old tobacco warehouses are being converted to trendy shops and boutiques, the glitter quickly disappears. This little town of 470 people, eight modest businesses and not a single stoplight, within commuting distance of Durham, has the feel of an isolated country hamlet where residents grow tobacco and the big concern of Mayor Janet C. Parrott is getting indoor plumbing.
 
Inadequate Sewer System
About three years ago Mayor Parrott managed to get a community development grant from the Federal Government to dig two wells and upgrade 36 houses, some with dirt floors, and about half without plumbing. Residents like Nettie Royster and Mary E. Lewis still have toilets in their backyards, and a few others like 84-year-old Hunter Taylor still do not have indoor plumbing.
But it turns out that the septic system is not adequate for the new plumbing, and the town often smells of human waste. ''People come out here from Raleigh, and they can't believe it's so different,'' said Mrs. Parrott. ''We haven't caught up with the times yet.''
Even so, the farther one gets from Raleigh and Durham, the better Stovall looks, as the fringes of the Research Triangle give way to the desperate poverty of Eastern North Carolina, which rivals the poorest areas in Mississippi and Alabama. A report in May by two groups working with the rural poor, the North Carolina Rural Communities Assistance Project and the North Carolina Rural Economic Development Center, says the percentage of people living without adequate indoor plumbing in Gates County, in the eastern part of the state, is the same as in Lima, Peru. $1 Billion for the Basics Similarly, the report, which was based on 1980 census data, said almost 250,000 North Carolina residents live without complete indoor plumbing, and more than $1 billion is needed to finance water and sewer projects in rural North Carolina alone.
Almost half the state's 6.5 million residents live in rural areas where, according to the North Carolina Rural Economic Development Center, poverty, unemployment and low educational levels are much more common than in the cities.
''North Carolina's situation is like where you can't see the forest for the trees,'' said Billy Ray Hall, president of the development center.''The trees, our colleges and universities, our natural resource base, our historical leadership give a positive image. But the more you look at the state, the more you see the underside.''
Most worrisome is that the poverty often co-exists with some of the state's successes. North Carolina led the South in attracting low-paying manufacturing jobs, changing it from a state of small farmers to one dominated by small manufacturing plants. The evolution has given the state both the nation's highest percentage of people employed in manufacturing and the lowest manufacturing wages.
 
Wages Below Poverty Line
According to a study by Donald Tomaskovic-Devey, a sociology professor at North Carolina State University, 30 percent of all jobs in the state, including 42 percent of the jobs held by women and 44 percent held by blacks, pay annual wages below the poverty level for a family of four, $12,675 in 1989. He found that one in six households where at least one person was working reported not having enough money at some point in the last year to buy the food the family needed.
''I see a lot of my kids' parents who are part of the working poor, both working full-time jobs and still poor,'' said David Diamont, a State Representative who is a high school history teacher in Surry County, in the northwestern part of the state. ''A 16-year-old in my fourth-period class sees the $6.10-an-hour wage at the textile mill job as a way to put money in his pocket right now, but 10 years from now he's still going to be in the low-wage job with no skills and no future.''
Some experts say the low-wage, high-pressure manufacturing jobs in fields like textiles or poultry processing affect health care statistics like the infant morality rate.
''In North Carolina we have one of the highest rates of working mothers in the nation,'' said Brenda McKinney, a physician's assistant with the public health department in Surry County. ''What these women are doing is working in industry in the mills where they have piecework, and they have to produce a certain amount of work a day or they're penalized, even if they leave to go to the doctor. I see it everyday: 35 percent of our prenatal appointments do not show up either because of transportation or because they couldn't get off work.''
 
Dealing With the Problem
The figures on infant morality and S.A.T. scores received substantial publicity around the state this year and were seen as a major embarrassment. The state has put together special groups to deal with both problems, and officials say hitting bottom may have been the jolt the state needed.
''When those numbers came out last year it shocked people,'' said Bob Etheridge, the State Superintendent of Public Instruction, adding that the scores would help speed education changes already under way. ''People in North Carolina are very proud people. This is a good state with a strong history in education and economic development, and I think we've seen people rally together in a way maybe we haven't seen since the 1960's.''
But some critics say the state's problems are not just anomalies that slipped by, but in some ways are reflections of the growth strategies of the state and the South. Paul Luebke, a sociology professor at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro who recently wrote ''Tar Heel Politics: Myths and Realities,'' published this year by the University of North Carolina Press. says the state's reputation for progressive government is overly generous. For instance, he said North Carolina had always followed a formula for growth emphasizing its elite universities over public schools, which brought with it built-in disparities.
 
Equity Priority Is Lacking
''There's a basic idea of equity as a priority of public policy that's lacking throughout the South,'' he said. ''The New South development strategy has always been based on a kind of trickle-down economics, and North Carolina is an outstanding example of that.''
Others say North Carolina made perhaps the only choices available earlier in the century, when it lured low-wage industry that helped modernize a poor state. But like the rest of the region, it is now finding that an ill-educated work force is no longer sufficient inducement when companies can open plants in Mexico or Thailand. That means that although the successful, education-intensive areas are likely to remain among the nation's growth centers, North Carolina faces new obstacles in bringing up its lagging areas.
''The low-wage, development strategy, which made Southern states overall competitive in luring jobs over the last two or three decades, just doesn't have a future,'' Mr. Tomaskovic-Devey said. ''North Carolina played that game first and maybe best, but the game is over.''

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
East-West Berlin, a Boomtown in the Making

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN, July 1

 BODY:
On both sides of the crumbling remnants of the Berlin Wall, signs of an economic boom are everywhere, a direct result of the merger of the East and West German economies.
Seventy yards from the Brandenburg Gate, Yamaha has opened a showroom to sell sleek, polished motorcycles and electronic organs to the more prosperous East Germans of tomorrow.
On Kurfurstendamm, West Berlin's Fifth Avenue, there is construction galore, and developers are rushing to change their residential building permits to office permits to cash in on the unification boom.
The still-unfinished Dom Hotel in East Berlin is seeking to rent out luxury 1,000-square-foot offices to Western companies for $9,000 a month -more than 100 times the rents under Communism. Rents for prime office space in West Berlin have jumped 60 percent since the wall opened in November. 
Not only is a united Germany destined to become an industrial power, dominating Western Europe's economy even more than West Germany has, but Berlin seems well on its way to becoming the economic epicenter of Europe. Indeed, a reunited Berlin of four million people will, by itself, have an economy as large as the gross national product of Portugal.
''Everyone seems obsessed about what's going on in this city,'' said Jurgen Bischoff, head of the Berlin office of Jones Lang Wooten, an international real estate firm. ''We have Japanese companies coming in, and we have American developers looking around for the first time.''
 
The Mark's Growing Importance
To be sure, reunification is fraught with uncertainty, especially for East Germans who worry that neither their jobs nor their enterprises will survive in the harsh, yet promising capitalist era.
Still, a united Germany will clearly be the foremost economic power in both Western Europe and Eastern Europe. With Germany's larger stature, the importance of the mark in the world's currency markets will grow.
Unification will also make Germany's industrial giants even stronger in the long term, although for a few years non-German companies may find it easier to compete with the Germans because German industry will be preoccupied with expanding into the East.
East Germany's economic output is estimated to be around 10 percent of West Germany's, and the united Germany will have a gross national product of more than a trillion dollars a year. Fusing the two Germanys will produce an economy that is more than 25 percent larger than France's or Britain's. With East Germany's economic output expected to double in the next 7 to 10 years, Germany's lead will grow even larger.
''After the transition period, the German economy will be bigger and stronger,'' said Meinhard Miegel, director of the Institute for Economics and Social Policy in Bonn. ''The German economy will have greater volume, greater selling power, greater exporting power.''
 
East Europe a German Market
West Germany also stands to gain the most economically from the opening up of Eastern Europe. The Federal Republic already accounts for two-fifths of the West's trade with Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland and Bulgaria - and that is before East Germany's booming trade with those countries is included.
''Germany will be the major economic power in Eastern Europe,'' Mr. Miegel said. ''Eastern Europe will be primarily a German market.''
The German mark is already the anchor currency in the nine-nation European Monetary System, and Austria, Belgium and the Netherlands have pegged their currencies to the mark. The mark has become the leading hard currency in Hungary and Czechoslovakia. What is more, East Germany's trade links with the Soviet Union and West Germany's pledge of aid to Moscow will help establish the mark as the most important Western currency in the Soviet Union.
Some economists say that as a result of the European Community's push to adopt a single currency, the mark could someday become the currency of the community's 320 million people. ''If you accept that Europe will be a much more integrated market in a decade's time, whichever currency becomes its official currency will be a very big rival to the dollar,'' said Richard Reid, chief European economist for UBS Phillips & Drew in London.
 
Germans Disclaim Power
Many Germans grow quickly defensive with all the talk about German economic might. They say that a united Germany will be powerful, but just one among many countries in Europe, and that it will be Europe, not Germany, that is the superpower. A united Germany will have 78 million people, and they say it cannot possibly dwarf France, Britain or Italy, each of which has more than 55 million people.
''Eighty million people are not enough to be a superpower,'' said Norbert Walter, chief economist at Deutsche Bank.
Nonetheless, lingering fears that a unified Germany will be too dominant are causing many Europeans to call for accelerating the process of European integration in order to submerge Germany more deeply into Europe and to create a European Germany, rather than a German Europe. Integration, they contend, would make Germany more like California, the first, most populous and most economically powerful among equals, but still an equal.
Unification certainly raises fears among some non-German companies, which are worried that German corporate giants will quickly expand to become overpowering competitors. Still, many Germans point out that other nations should generally benefit from German industrial strength.
Indeed, other Western countries put pressure on West Germany for years to speed up its sluggish economy to help pull Europe - and the world - along. So now, reunification promises to turn West Germany into a fast-moving locomotive for Europe's economy in the early 1990's, growing at a brisk rate of 4 percent a year, many economists predict. There are also fears that this higher growth will lead to higher inflation.
 
Plenty of Business Seen for All
''Reunification will add a full percentage point to West Germany's annual economic growth,'' said Manfred Melzer, an economist with the German Institute for Economics in West Berlin. The Germans also predict that reunification will produce a second German economic miracle in East Germany, which will import $25 billion more in goods a year than it would have without reunification. All the cars, computers and cameras the East Germans import will come from many countries, not just West Germany.
Moreover, analysts say that since German industry is already operating near full capacity, unification will leave plenty of business to go around for French, British and American industry.
''Since the West Germans are already close to full resource utilization, they will have to import a lot of resources to help East Germany,'' said Paul Horne, European economist for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''That will help France, the U.K. and other Western countries increase their exports.''
Accordingly, the next few years could provide non-German businesses with a window of opportunity to compete against the Germans - and to expand in Germany and Europe. But once the decade-long process of rebuilding East Germany is complete, the companies of a united Germany could well emerge as more potent, more competitive forces.
 
Fears for the Long Term
''In the short-term the Germans will be very busy taking care of East Germany,'' said Carlo de Benedetti, chairman of Ing. C. Olivetti & Company S.p.A., the Italian office machine and computer concern. ''What we should remember is that ultimately we will have to compete with competitors that are bigger.''
Indeed, West Germany's muscular corporate heavyweights are already trying to use unification as a vehicle to grow even bigger and stronger. Deutsche Bank A.G., West Germany's largest bank, hopes to open 250 branches in East Germany and capture 20 percent of consumer deposits within the next three years. The Frankfurt-based bank is investing more than $500 million to expand in East Germany and as a result could quickly increase its assets by more than $10 billion.
''It's an additional market of 16 million people,'' said Georg Krupp, director of Deutsche Bank's East German operations. ''In the long term that's very important.''
Volkswagen A.G., which boasts that it is No. 1 in auto sales in Europe, plans to increase production 10 percent by investing $2.9 billion in a 250,000-car-a-year assembly plant in East Germany. Mannesmann, a company based in Dusseldorf, that is Europe's largest machinery-making group, has signed letters of intent with 30 East German companies to establish different types of cooperation.
''We have a broad range of activities, and in virtually every sector there is a partner for us in the G.D.R.,'' said Friedrich Schunder, a Mannesmann spokesman.

LENGTH: 927 words

HEADLINE: Higuey Journal;
Brief Voyage to a Better Life, or a Watery Death

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HIGUEY, Dominican Republic

 BODY:
For Jose Castillo and his small band of friends, a shimmering life of comfort and fast money lies just across the narrow, perilous strait that separates this country from Puerto Rico.
Undaunted by the regular newspaper accounts of the deaths of hundreds of would-be emigrants whose bodies have washed up on beaches or simply disappeared at sea - not to mention their own failed attempts to reach Puerto Rico - they still prepare for the day when they can afford yet another moonlit trip in a small, badly overloaded boat.
''My family tells me I am crazy,'' said Mr. Castillo, a stocky, fast-talking 28-year-old truck driver. ''But life is easier in Puerto Rico. Those who return say there are plenty of dollars over there.'' 
 
Rapidly Growing Wave
Mr. Castillo wishes to join the rapidly growing wave of clandestine emigrants from this country of seven million, many of them people willing to risk their savings and their lives to make their way to Puerto Rico, often continuing from there by plane to the mainland United States.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service does not release estimates of the numbers of illegal immigrants from particular countries living in the United States, but officials of the agency say 5,341 people of Dominican nationality were arrested in this country in 1989, far more than from any other Caribbean country.
That is more than double the number of Dominican repatriations in 1987, and is more than 10 times the number of Haitians returned to their country from the United States by the immigration service.
While the thousands of poor, sun-lashed Haitian boat people stumbling onto south Florida's beaches in the early 1980's drew national attention, this wave of Dominican illegal immigrants has gone largely unremarked.
Those who make it to Puerto Rico, avoiding disaster at sea or arrest on arrival, often establish themselves without difficulty on that island or make their way by plane to the mainland United States with little risk of detection, Dominicans and United States immigration officials say.
 
No Routine Customs Check
Because Puerto Rico is a United States commonwealth, immigration officials say, they are not allowed to make the routine customs checks that would ferret illegal aliens out from the planeloads of passengers between the island and the mainland.
Instead, the immigration service polices the Puerto Rican coast, where its agents arrest many Dominicans, like Mr. Castillo, for repatriation. Most are jailed by the Dominican authorities for leaving the country illegally until they can pay a $68 fine.
For many, that penalty seems small compared with the pain of a 60 percent inflation rate, high unemplyment and low wages.
Mr. Castillo and a friend who had been in a grocery-cafe in this small, somnolent town recounted three failed attempts to move to Puerto Rico. The truck driver indicated all the while how little the fines and dangers affected his determination to go.
''I had to try for something better,'' Mr. Castillo said. ''Life here is too difficult. On my last trip, in January, I went with $10 in my pocket. There were 54 of us on the boat. Many of the others came with nothing.
''I'll go as soon as I get enough money for the boat,'' he added, referring to the cost of the passage - $275 and up, depending on the quality of the boat, with no guarantees of arrival. ''I won't wait to save up any pocket money.''
 
Three-Month Wait for a Boat
Several people who had tried the trip said the waiting list for a spot on a boat, most of which are operated by professional traffickers, can be as long as three months. When the chance comes, few turn it down.
Mr. Castillo's friend, Jesus Santana, whose mother made her way to Puerto Rico in by boat in 1980, seemed no less determined.
''We had lots of problems last time,'' said Mr. Santana, a 28-year-old driver employed by a motorbike taxi service whose $10 daily earnings are divided with the owner. ''We lost all of our money. We were arrested on the beach in Puerto Rico. And we spent a week in jail here before my family could pay the fine.''
''I think about the danger of the yolas, how they are overloaded and take on water,'' he said, referring to the wooden boats, while he leaned on his motorbike in the shade.''But I think of a better life too.
''Nobody likes to talk about it,'' he said, ''but if they had the money, everyone here would try to go - at least all of the young people.''
If many people are reticent talking about the sea journey to Puerto Rico, even as they contemplate the trip for themselves, perhaps it is because of the high toll in human lives.
At Boca de Yuma, a fishing village of a few empty dirt streets that sits on the azure southeastern coast, comment on the traffic to Puerto Rico is sparse. The lure to go is made stronger at Boca de Yuma and other places in the east by the clear reception of Puerto Rico's numerous radio and television stations, which serve up tempting images of material abundance and cosmopolitan sophistication that many find hard to resist.
Earlier this year, a boatload of voyagers, including several from Boca de Yuma, disappeared at sea. No one knows what happened, or how many died, but a half a dozen bodies floated back onto a beach here near where the boat was launched.
Juan Julio Santana, 30, a fisherman, repainted his boat in bright reds and greens as he talked about the voyagers. ''We have an idea why people go,'' he said. ''There is nothing but misery in this place. No work, no opportunity, not even electricty.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jose Castillo, center, and his friends still dream of emigrating from the town of Higuey in the Dominican Republic to Puerto Rico, despite the perils of the clandestine boat voyage and the failure of their last attempt. (Howard W. French/The New York Times); map of Dominican Republic showing location of Higuey (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Construction Fades as Boom Loses Its Vigor

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
So many new towers are rising on the West Side of Manhattan that it is hard to believe the boom is over. But the construction workers who form lunchtime knots on the sidewalks and gather beneath the scaffolding know better.
''I'm thinking about going into a new career,'' said John Colwell, a carpenter from Long Island who is working in a 26-story office building on West 47th Street.
Such uncertainty would normally be unheard of this time of year, which is supposed to be the busy season for New York City's construction industry. But after a decade in which they filled in the skyline, adding nearly 50 million square feet of office space - enough room for nearly 200,000 office workers - and 106,000 units of housing, some of the hard-hat workers at the building sites that pock the West Side are worrying about where or even when they will be working next. 
 
Hit Late by Economic Slowdown
According to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, construction employment in New York City declined from 124,000 in September 1989 to 117,000 in April 1990, with about half of the drop due to seasonal variation and about half to the downturn in construction. And experts expect the falloff to continue over the next few years.
The economic slowdown that radiated from Wall Street was late to hit the construction industry, which has had to import workers from out of the region to help with the $18 billion in new construction that went up in the city in the 1980's.
About a dozen office buildings were completed in 1987 and 1988, many spurred by zoning incentives on the West Side, and eight more, with a total of nearly five million square feet of space, are expected to be finished this year.
But only a total of three buildings are scheduled to be completed next year and the year after. And with office vacancy rates in Manhattan at 15 percent, the highest level in years, and lending institutions tightening credit requirements, the pipeline might stay dry for a while. ''There's some talk of one or two projects,'' said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York. ''But I think it's unlikely anything is going to start in the next 6 to 18 months.''
Matthew P. Drennan, a professor at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University, who tracks the New York region's economy, projects a 5,000-job decline in 1991 and an additional 4,000-job drop the next year. Given all the out-of-state license plates he said he has seen at city building sites, Professor Drennan wonders about the impact of the decline in new construction on local workers, although he says those who rely on rebuilding may be hit harder.
 
'Sitting on Their Hands'
Inside the building trades, the view seems downbeat. Raymond O'Kane, assistant to the president of the New York City Council of Carpenters, estimated that a quarter of the 30,000 carpenters were already ''sitting on their hands, waiting to go to work.''
''If they end up doing what they did in the 70's,'' he said, ''they'll drive cabs, be bartenders or get some business cards printed and finish basements.''
In feast or famine, the building trades have occupied a special niche not just in the city's economy but also in its culture and its politics. Just watch the officeholders and would-be officeholders jockey for position at a Labor Day parade.
In the last decade, construction has grown faster than any other segment of the city's economy except business services. Since 1978, according to the Real Estate Board, construction activity has generated $772 million in city payroll and sales taxes. But the drop in construction jobs now comes even before the industry has fully recovered from the dismal slump it had in the 1970's. After hitting a peak of 139,000 jobs in 1962, construction employment dropped to a low of 64,000 in 1977.
 
'A Roller-Coaster Industry'
''It's a roller-coaster industry,'' said Samuel I. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. ''And as they're finishing things, they see there's no tomorrow.''
Peter J. Brennan, president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of New York City and New York State, said the downturn would hurt workers in some specialties more than others. Electricians, plumbers and painters can always repair or renovate existing buildings - called ''dirty'' jobs, as opposed to new or clean construction - and there will be opportunities for carpenters too, although not as many as now.
In contrast, he said, those who mainly build new office or apartment towers - ironworkers, concrete workers, sheet-metal workers, machinists, operating engineers and steamfitters - could find jobs scarce, at least for a while. Many of the unions representing those trades, Mr. Brennan notes, have large apprentice programs, so people trying to enter the industry will be hurt, too. ''You can't bring young people in and train them for no jobs,'' he said.
There are now about 16,000 apprentices in the various unions, about 7 percent of whom are women and 40 percent of whom are members of minority groups, Mr. Brennan said. He and others speak proudly of those programs and the efforts the unions have made in opening up the industry.
But last year Thomas R. Bailey, a research scholar at the Conservation of Human Resources Project at Columbia University, concluded that during the 1980's the number of black construction workers actually fell. Paradoxically, he found that there was more progress in the hard times of the 1970's, perhaps because the issue of racial discrimination in the industry was more of a public concern then.
For those who made the transition, a construction job has been a ticket to the middle class. Mr. Ehrenhalt said the average earnings of those in the construction industry nearly doubled between 1980 and 1988, to about $35,000 a year.
 
Some Commuters
Some New York City construction workers live in the suburbs and commute to the city, although Mr. Colwell, a carpenter for 18 years, said that lately he has seen fewer of them on his trains. At building sites along and around Broadway, he and others speak of business cycles and ripple effects as they try to assess what the economy holds in store for them.
''Once we get slow, everybody else gets slow,'' Mr. Colwell said. ''Housing starts drop, and that means people are no longer spending money. And then the auto industry is hurt.''
Ray Dean, a steamfitter working on the new Embassy Suites hotel at Seventh Avenue and 47th Street, said he was disappointed with what he clearly regarded as an anti-development attitude at City Hall - a view commonly heard at construction sites and union halls. He singles out Mayor David N. Dinkins's opposition to the construction of a garbage incinerator, a project that would have employed a lot of steamfitters.
''I don't know how bad it's going to get,'' Mr. Dean said. ''This company might send me to another job, or I might get laid off.''
Union leaders hope that Donald J. Trump will somehow put his empire back together and build his city on the Hudson and that the Columbus Center project will overcome legal challenges. But they are mostly counting on public, not private, work to sustain their members in lean times.
 
City Housing Program
There is the city's $5.2 billion housing program, although much of that, the union leaders say, is going to nonunion workers. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has scaled back its rebuilding plans for Kennedy International Airport, and it is far from certain how much money the Metropolitan Transportation Authority will have to continue its efforts to restore commuter lines and the subways.
But bilions of dollars will be spent rebuilding the highways, bridges and sewer lines, and the city's School Construction Authority will spend $4.3 billion to build 50 new schools and 30 annexes and remodel 70 others, all in five years.
And in April, New York State finally acquired most of the land for the 42d Street redevelopment project, first envisioned a decade ago. The four skyscrapers will range in height from 32 to 57 stories, comprise 4.1 million square feet of space and require about 16,000 construction workers to build.
But if those four buildings are the future, the present lies a few blocks away, at the Avenue of the Americas between 45th and 46th Streets. There, still only partially sheathed in pale rose granite, stands Americas Tower, a 48-story monument to uncertainty. Work stopped in December, with the tower 75 percent finished, when the developers failed to obtain a construction loan and began battling for control of the project.
''If the market had been better,'' said Mr. Spinola of the Real Estate Board, ''they wouldn't have had the argument.''

HEADLINE: Reading Test Scores Decline For 9th and 10th Graders

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
The spring 1990 reading and mathematics achievement test scores for the New York City public schools show a sharp decline in reading scores among ninth and 10th graders, but otherwise are virtually unchanged from last year.
''Over all, this is boring news,'' said Robin Wilner, the board's executive director for the Division of Strategic Planning, Research and Development. ''Basically, the scores are flat. We are seeing no significant year-to-year change.'' 
The systemwide test scores, being released today, are the first since Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez took office in January. He said that while he was pleased that scores hovered around the national median - which means that half of students are at grade level and half are not - that the system needs to do better.
In reading, 48.1 percent of the 436,654 students tested in grades three through 10 scored at or above grade level. Last year, 49.2 percent did. Most grades showed only small performance changes. But among ninth and 10th graders there were drops of 6.2 and 5.1 percentage points respectively. Ms. Wilner said school officials did not yet know what these scores mean, but would be investigating.
 
Tougher Reading Standards
This was the second year that a new and tougher set of reading standards was used. The older standards, developed in the 1981-82 school year, had resulted in highly inflated scores for city students over the last few years.
In mathematics, 56.3 percent of 418,385 students tested in grades two through eight scored at or above their grade levels, compared with 56.2 percent last year. The largest increase was 6.1 percentage points for students in grade two and the largest decrease was 9.2 percentage points for grade five.
Robert Tobias, director of the Office of Research, Evaluation and Assessment, said the higher mathematics scores in the lower grades seemed to indicate a need for a strong push at higher grades.
 
'Curriculum Development'
''Clearly, we are doing a better job in second, third and fourth grades,'' Mr. Tobias said. ''There was a lot of curriculum development work in the seventh grades and they're beginning to approach the national norm. Where we have to do better is the higher grades.''
Reading scores are the most widely used indicator of how well students, their schools, and ultimately the entire system are performing, and Mr. Fernandez said he was concerned about the sharp drops in ninth and 10th grade reading scores this year. Last year 52.5 percent of ninth graders read at or above grade level, as did 60.8 percent of 10th graders. That is compared with 46.3 percent and 55.7 percent respectively this year.
''Everything we are doing in the redirection of the primary grades is to improve this,'' Mr. Fernandez said. ''There is some indication we have to do something different in the middle years. We're still hovering at the median and our task is get above that. I'm convinced reading is the key.'' Degrees of Reading Power ''The danger is in getting complacent,'' Mr. Fernandez said.
The reading examination is called Degrees of Reading Power. The individualized test scores, like the math scores, were sent home to parents in the last two weeks. Citywide, only fifth and 10th graders as a whole read at or above grade level. In other grades, most students read below grade level.
Ms. Wilner said the test scores will probably also have implications for the board's promotion policies. An analysis this year of pupil achievement in reading from 1986 to 1989 shows that the reading scores of students who are older than standard age are much lower than those who are the right age for their grade.
Among sixth graders, for example, 71 percent of standard-age students read at or above grade level, compared with 42 percent of over-age students.
 
More Females Than Males
''Clearly, the students who are being held back are not doing as well,'' Ms. Wilner said.
The reading score analysis also revealed that more females than males scored at or above grade level in grades three through seven. In grades eight, nine, and 10 more males scored higher. Morever, for eighth, ninth and 10th graders the percentage-point difference between the sexes increased as the grade level increased.
There was an increase this year in the number of students exempted from the math or reading test because of limited English proficiency, both because there were more student not fluent in the language, and because the state education department expanded the critieria for the exemption. Translations for the math test are available in Spanish, Chinese, Haitian-Creole and French. This year, 17,989 students (4.3 percent) took translated tests, compared with 14,746 (3.5) last year.
As always, there was a wide variation in test scores from district to district, although individual district scores in math and reading varied little from last year. The range was from the low of 29.7 at or above grade level in reading in District Five in Harlem to the high of 79.2 in reading and math at District 26 in Bayside, Queens.

HEADLINE: Insurers Brace for Debate On How Industry Operates

BYLINE: By ERIC N. BERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 1

 BODY:
In advancing a bill last month that would subject insurance companies to Federal antitrust laws, the House Judiciary Committee has set the stage for a long and bitter debate about the pricing and availability of insurance coverage.
Passage of this measure to repeal an antitrust exemption that was adopted in 1945 would overturn the way the insurance industry operates, but industry experts say it is not clear how the changes would affect consumers.
The complex debate can be distilled into a single question: Has the McCarran-Ferguson Act of 1945 -which shields insurers from prosecution under the Federal antitrust laws - limited the availablity of insurance and kept premiums artificially high?
The consumer groups who are leading the attempt to repeal McCarran-Ferguson think so, while insurers and their trade-group representatives argue that the impact of the law has been badly overblown.
The industry also contends that a Federal law is unnecessary because their products and prices are already regulated by the states. But consumer groups say the states have widely varying rules and standards of enforcement. 
Oddly the two sides, which disagree strenuously on the issue, cite the same evidence to reach their conclusions.
For example, insurance executives argue that the industry is brutally competitive, citing the nearly 1,500 underwriters nationwide in the property-casualty business alone.
But Stephen Brobeck, executive director of the Consumer Federation of America, maintains, ''A truly competitive market could not sustain such a large number of players.''
Similarly, insurers note that prices for auto policies vary widely, especially in large cities, demonstrating just how cutthroat that business is. Consumer groups respond that if auto insurance were cutthroat, premiums would be falling, not rising, and would tend toward a single price.
The two sides even disagree about whether the exemption insurers enjoy is unusual. Craig A. Berrington, general counsel of the American Insurance Association, a trade group, notes that farm cooperatives, utilities and sports teams all enjoy some form of antitrust immunity.
But Edward Correia, a visiting professor of law at Northeastern University who studied the issue as a Congressional staff member, argues that insurers have a far broader exemption. Not only can they avoid prosecution under the Sherman Act, he said, but insurers are also not subject to Federal consumer protection laws and to the scrutiny of the Federal Trade Commission.
''Even if the biggest insurance companies in the country got together in a hotel room to fix prices, there is nothing the Justice Department could do about it,'' Professor Correia said. ''No other industry enjoys that privilege.''
 
Support of State Lobbyists
The McCarran-Ferguson Act became law largely because of the support of state lobbyists. States feared that if insurers were made subject to Federal antitrust laws, the Federal Government would soon take control of all aspects of insurance regulation, imperiling states' ability to collect taxes on insurance premiums. So the states joined forces with insurance lobbyists to push the law through.
The House bill, which has not been scheduled for a vote in the full chamber, would outlaw price fixing and allocating regions or customers. It would also limit the areas in which insurers can collaborate. A similar bill is pending in the Senate Judiciary Committee.
Consumer groups have no quarrels with some of these joint efforts and some collaborative practices may remain legal. For example, insurers commonly agree on the language in their insurance contracts and the risks they are covering. And reinsurers, who buy parts of policies from insurance companies to help them spread the risk, regularly team up to serve individual clients.
But consumer groups object to the way insurers set prices. Some disapprove of insurers' banding together in what are called ''joint associations'' to underwrite complex risks. One example of this is the assigned-risk pool, in which most large auto insurers compare their experiences in covering bad drivers and together determine premium levels.
Consumer groups say McCarran-Ferguson has enabled insurers to act like a cartel, convening to restrict supply and to set prices artifically high.
These critics say states are partly to blame because of their overall lax approach to pricing. Insurance regulation differs by state and by type of coverage. Only three states - Texas, Massachusetts, and North Carolina - set rates for auto policies. Of the remaining 47 states, roughly half require insurers to submit rates for approval, while the rest do not regulate auto rates at all.
Similarly, for homeowner's insurance policies, only about half the states require prior approval of rates, and the rest have no rate regulation. Business insurance rates are generally not regulated.
''Historically, the only strong, adequately funded insurance department has been New York's,'' Mr. Brobeck of the Consumer Federation said. ''I've heard the industry refer to the thousand-pound gorilla and all the spider monkeys.''
 
Studies Are Questionable
Many of the studies on the impact of McCarran-Ferguson are old or viewed as questionable since they were paid for by partisan groups. No one appears to have conducted a thorough study of the insurance market in California, which in 1988 repealed its antitrust exemption for insurers.
But the research tends to support the industry's view.
Scott Harrington of the University of South Carolina notes that in liability insurance for business the top four companies - American International Group, CNA Insurance, Aetna Life and Casualty and Chubb - have about a 31 percent market share. In auto insurance, he says, the big four - State Farm, Allstate, Farmers Group, and the Nationwide Insurance Companies - have about a 40 percent share.
''Most economists would regard that as low,'' he said of the concentration in the industry.
One study done 10 years ago found no difference in auto insurance rates between Illinois and surrounding states. At the time, auto insurance companies in Illinois were not covered by the McCarran-Ferguson Act because that state was the only one in the country that did not regulate auto insurance premiums.
At the heart of the pricing discussion are the rate bureaus, in particular, the Insurance Services Office Inc. in New York, the industry's largest rate bureau. Founded in 1971 and owned jointly by such giants as the Hartford, the Travelers and Aetna, the Insurance Services Office helps insurers develop the language in insurance contracts and gathers and analyzes data on the payment of claims. Most important, the I.S.O. has published a list of suggested premiums, to which many smaller insurers have adhered.
Consumer groups argue that the I.S.O. is the principal vehicle through which insurance price fixing occurs. They were not appeased when the rate bureau recently decided to stop publishing suggested premiums because the I.S.O. still provides critical guidance to insurers on how to set their rates.
''The bottom line is that the I.S.O. enables joint pricing of insurance, and that translates into higher rates,'' said J. Robert Hunter, president of the National Insurance Consumer Organization, another consumer group in Washington. He estimates that if McCarran-Ferguson is repealed, auto rates will fall by as much as 19 percent and premiums for homeowners' insurance would drop by about 12 percent.
But insurers disagree. They note that in the line of insurance that consumers seem most angry about -auto coverage - many of the industry leaders, including Allstate and State Farm, do not even subscribe to I.S.O.'s information services and therefore set prices independently.
Executives at I.S.O. say that if the organization were done away with, many small insurers that depend on its data could go bankrupt by setting premiums too low, thereby diminishing competition.
''We permit more companies to operate, not fewer,'' said Mavis A. Walters, an I.S.O. executive vice president.
While insurers and their critics disagree sharply on what would happen if McCarran-Ferguson were repealed, the issue is critical to residents of New York and New Jersey. In those states, roughly 25 percent of drivers participate in the assigned-risk pool for bad drivers. Most experts agree that the assigned-risk pool would be dismantled if insurers lost their antitrust exemption.
''Although it is not clear which way rates would go, the impact would be significant,'' predicted Charles A. Bryan, a New York-based partner in the insurance group at Ernst & Young, the accounting firm. ''The whole mechanism for insuring these drivers would be thrown out the window.''

HEADLINE: Leading the Enigma Called Xerox

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
An enigmatic person may be provocatively appealing, but unfortunately for the Xerox Corporation's relations with Wall Street, an enigmatic company is usually seen as just plain annoying.
As Paul A. Allaire prepares to take over the chief executive's office from David T. Kearns at the company's Stamford, Conn., headquarters next month, Xerox enjoys a reputation as a model corporate citizen and is admired for its award-winning programs to improve product quality. And Mr. Allaire has been doing his best to spread enthusiasm for Xerox's vision of the future, which is built around the company's plans to create devices that combine the capabilities of copiers, printers, computers and facsimile machines.
 
Surprises and Complications
On Wall Street, though, the small band of analysts who still follow the nation's 21st-largest industrial company seem preoccupied with how hard it has been to project Xerox's performance since it branched into financial services, adding numerous surprises and complications to its balance sheet. And they grumble about how unrewarding an investment Xerox has been for most of the last 20 years. 
Wall Street wants to know which Xerox Mr. Allaire will lead: The one that lost key portions of its copier market to foreign competitors or the one that seized much of them back by designing better products and cutting manufacturing costs by 50 percent? The Xerox admired for research achievements, including the first personal computer, or the one that let other companies build and dominate markets based on them? The Xerox that has courted investors with a large, dependable dividend or the company that has piled up losses and debts in its bungled effort to diversify into insurance, leasing, real estate and investment banking?
Analysts anticipate strong leadership from Mr. Allaire, 51 years old, an electrical engineer by training who joined the company as a financial analyst in 1966 after getting a master's degree in industrial administration at Carnegie-Mellon University. He has been president and chief operating officer since 1986.
 
Shares Peaked in 1972
But it will take more than personal respect, which the 59-year-old Mr. Kearns has also enjoyed, to overcome Wall Street's accumulated irritation with the company. Xerox's shares peaked at $172 in 1972, a time when its name had become synonymous with copying. Last week, they closed at $46.875, their lowest level since 1985.
''Xerox has a track record of screwing up, so it's hard to bet against them doing it again,'' said B. Alex Henderson, who follows the company for Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.
Most analysts still following Xerox are specialists on the electronics and photography industries who are leery about their ability to dissect what is happening in the financial services segment. ''I'm predicting zero earnings from the entire financial business this year, but there's really no way to forecast,'' Mr. Henderson said. ''Basically, the financial side is unfathomable.''
Roughly a third of Xerox's $17.63 billion in revenue and $704 million in net income last year came from its financial businesses. But most of the financial businesses' profits came from gains in the investment portfolio held by Crum & Forster, the insurance subsidiary, and that source of income is expected to drop sharply this year. The company took a $400 million write-off early this year to cover expected real estate losses and some analysts fear further write-offs may be needed to cover reserve shortfalls at Crum & Forster.
 
Debt on the Balance Sheet
The growth in financial services has also piled billions of dollars of debt onto Xerox's balance sheet. The leasing business in particular relies far more heavily on borrowing than Xerox's traditional manufacturing. Xerox's debt-to-equity ratio at the end of last year was a hefty 64 percent; without the financial services group, it would have been 33 percent.
The uncertainties attributable to Xerox's financial services business might not bother Wall Street so much if the outlook for its traditional business were brighter. Growth in the company's document-processing business, which includes copiers, computer work stations and printers and the software to link and operate such equipment, has been steady but slow. Analysts fret that even a slight recession could lead to a sales downturn.
To be sure, Xerox's decade-long drive to modernize products and manufacturing, which helped it win the Commerce Department's Malcolm Baldrige quality award last year, appears also to have helped finally halt the slide in operating margins. But those margins, which were more than 20 percent in 1975 before the Japanese onslaught in the low end of the copier business gathered steam, are now a modest 5.5 percent.
 
Benefits From Revamping
Margins should begin to improve this year. The company is now getting the efficiency benefits from a revampin announced in late 1988 that scaled down electronic-typewriter production, phased out production of a proprietary work station in favor of marketing units made by Sun Microsystems Inc., and shut down manufacturing lines for medical equipment. Those moves reduced 1988 pretax earnings by $275 million.
Xerox is also helped by the switch from its older Series 10 copiers to the new and popular Series 50 models. Still, it is hard to imagine margins will ever approach those Xerox enjoyed when it owned a near-monopoly in the copier market.
In addition, rapidly changing office environments put pressure on Xerox for more aggressive product innovation. Analysts are worried, for example, that although Xerox has identified color copying as a probable growth area, it has let Japanese companies like Canon and Ricoh take the lead in marketing products.
 
Beaten to the Market
''Xerox says it will be ready when the market is ready, but the Japanese don't wait for that,'' said Peter Enderlin, who follows Xerox for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''They try things and are established as the market leader when it emerges.''
The Japanese have also beaten Xerox to market with early versions of the likely successor to today's copier: a computerized device that makes electronic instead of photographic images of documents. In theory, such devices could store, alter and combine documents, print them out, fax them and move them among work stations, as well as copy them.
Xerox's first challenge is to prove that it can outperform the Japanese in developing such technology, not to mention American competitors like the International Business Machines Corporation, the Digital Equipment Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company. All of them have moved into the processing of images and documents from their strongholds in computing. Xerox's first multifunctional machine is likely to be introduced in October.
 
I.B.M. Executive Recruited
In readying such machines for market, Xerox must balance demands for speed, quality and ease of use against cost. Xerox signaled its seriousness when it recruited William Lowe from I.B.M. in November 1988 to head the project to develop multifunctional machines. (Mr. Lowe had managed I.B.M.'s entry into the personal computer business.) But analysts saw the move as only one step in the right direction. ''You need to come up with something that customers have to have, not just a great technology demonstration,'' said Mr. Enderlin, the analyst.
Mr. Allaire and other senior Xerox officials were unavailable for interviews when this article was being prepared. But there is no doubt they understand the company's skeptics.
 
Plans to Sell Insurance Lines
Melvin Howard, the executive who ran the financial segment, announced his early retirement on April 2, the day it was announced that Mr. Allaire would succeed Mr. Kearns. Since then, Xerox has announced its intention to stop selling all standard personal property and casualty insurance coverage, which accounted for 11 percent of Crum & Forster's business, and sell its domestic third-party financing operations, which include leasing, loans to equipment purchasers and financing for other companies involved in restructuring.
At a meeting in early June for analysts who represent mutual funds and other major stock purchasers, Mr. Allaire said that any new investments in financial businesses would have to come from money generated in those businesses and that trimming financial services would continue to the point that whatever remains is profitable. And he hinted that even the profitable pieces might go, saying that he had already set up a special committee led by Mr. Kearns to review the company's involvement in financial services.
A decision to get out of all financial services other than financing purchases of Xerox equipment would square with Mr. Allaire's reputation. ''He seems to have a great concern with the nuts and bolts of operating the business,'' Mr. Enderlin said, ''and, as an engineer, more personal interest than Kearns in technology,''
 
Xerox Official Gets Fund Post
Melvin Howard, the executive who led the Xerox Corporation's troubled expansion into financial services, has been named president of the Management Asset Corporation, a Westport, Conn., investment management firm.
Mr. Howard, who is 55 years old, ended a 20-year career at Xerox on May 1, after Paul A. Allaire was named to succeed David T. Kearns as chief executive on Aug. 1 and the company began to pull back from its involvement in financial services. Mr. Howard had been vice chairman at Xerox.
Management Asset manages a number of corporate pension funds, a mutual fund and a hedge fund.

HEADLINE: Stocks Outperform Expectations

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The performance of stocks in the second quarter turned out to be less gloomy than many financial analysts had predicted. In spite of sluggishness in the economy, many financial analysts said the market's performance had exceeded expectations.
''The second quarter did a lot better than the first,'' said Byron Wein, chief market strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''Consumer nondurables and health-care issues did extremely well in the second quarter. The market seems to believe that either earnings will be better than expected or that interest rates are going to be lower.'' 
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 173.48 points in the quarter, gaining 6.41 percent to close at 2,880.69 on Friday. Among the broader market indexes, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 5.32 percent, to 358.02, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index was up 4.62 percent, to 195.48. Meanwhile, the American Stock Exchange composite index was down only one-tenth of a percent, to 361.21, and the composite index of over-the-counter stocks was up 6.1 percent, to 462.29.
 
'New Kind' of Buyer
''Even though interest rates are lower than they were at the beginning of the quarter and there is still a great deal of caution on the part of investors, it seems that you're getting a new kind of public buyer in the stock market,'' said Michael Sherman, the chief market strategist for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ''He's not geared to short-term performance, but rather geared to an investment on a long-term basis. At the end of the first quarter, the advice many investors were getting was to reduce their equity positions.''
Kenneth M. Spence, the director of technical analysis for Salomon Brothers Inc., said the better performing stocks had one thing in common: ''visibility of strong earnings over the next 6 to 12 months.'' He added that stocks in the financial and more cyclical industries, like steel or construction, came under selling pressure. He said the stocks of cyclical industries had trouble because the companies were unable to pass on cost increases to consumers.
The big winner on the New York Stock Exchange was the Foxboro Company, a Massachusetts-based industrial controls company that agreed a week ago to be acquired by Siebe P.L.C., a British safety products and engineering company, for $52 a share, or $655 million.
On news of the agreement, Foxboro's stock soared $12.875 last Monday, to $51, and almost 1.2 million of its shares were traded. By Friday, the stock had more than doubled from the beginning of the quarter, to $51.375, from $20.25.
Foxboro had received a number of inquiries from potential suitors in the month before the announcement.
Another top performer on the Big Board was Oakwood Homes, a manufacturer of mobile homes and an operator of mobile home parks. The company, which is based in Greensboro, N.C., reported record sales and earnings, a result of its introducing a revamped line of mobile homes, company officials said. The company's stock rose 55.7 percent, or $4.25, in the quarter, closing Friday at $11.88.
 
General Development Plunges
The leading declining stock on the Big Board was the General Development Corporation, a big developer of planned communities in Florida. The company filed a petition for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. General Development cited an inability to secure additional short-term financing. The filing followed the company's guilty plea for violating Federal mail fraud laws. The developer later agreed to pay more than $80 million to certain homeowners over 25 years. Its stock fell 84 percent during the quarter, closing at 94 cents.
Another big declining stock on the the Big Board was the Tonka Corporation, the Minnesota company that manufactures and sells toys and games under the Tonka, Kenner and Parker Brothers brands. The company, which reported net income of $7.7 million last year, said its level of orders had deteriorated in the first half of the year, adding that it was uncertain if it would post a profit for the year. Tonka's stock fell 51 percent for the period, ending the quarter at $6.25.
On the American Stock Exchange, the top performer was Lazare Kaplan International Inc., a diamond merchant controlled by Maurice and Leon Templesman. The company was also the Amex's top performer in the first quarter. Its sales and earnings have expanded with its expansion in Japan and elsewhere in the Pacific region. Its shares soared 83.1 percent for the quarter, or $12.25, to close at $27.
Another big Amex winner was OEA Inc., an aerospace and automotive products company based in Denver. The company is a leading maker of a device that ignites the inflator in vehicle airbags. Its stock has been helped by increases in airbag orders from the automobile industry. Federal law requires auto makers to install either airbags or automatic seatbelts in new models. OEA's stock rose 56.4 percent, or $11, for the quarter, closing at $30.50.
The largest declining stock on the Amex was the First Connecticut Small Business Investment Company, an investment concern that makes loans and furnishes equity capital to small businessees, primarily on the East Coast. The company has been hurt by depressed conditions in the New England real estate market. It recently announced that it was omitting its dividend. Its shares tumbled 58.6 percent in the quarter, to $7.625, closing at $5.375.
The biggest gainer among the over-the-counter stocks was the Y & A Group, an electrical engineering consulting firm. The company has expanded rapidly through internal growth and acquisitions. It reported record earnings of $221,000 for the first quarter, on record sales of $2.7 million. The stock was spurred by analysts reports, predicting that the company's sales would double this year to about $20 million.
Another big gainer among the over-the-counter stocks was Summit Technology Inc., a maker of lasers used to correct vision disorders. The Boston-based company intoduced a photochemical laser for treating farsightedness. The laser, which does not use heat, leaves the eye tissue intact, the company said. Summit Technology's stock more than doubled, closing the quarter at $17, up from $8.375.
 
Washington Bancorp Tumbles
The biggest losing stock among the over-the-counter issues was the Washington Bancorporation, a holding company for three bank subsidiaries, including the National Bank of Washington.
The company received an offer from an investor group, which was withdrawn after Washington Bancorp announced a $5.7 million first- quarter loss. The stock tumbled 82.3 percent, or $11.94, closing at $2.56.
According to Media General Financial Services, 733 Big Board stocks gained for the quarter, 748 were lower and 55 were unchanged. On the Amex, 219 issues were up, 278 were down and 23 unchanged. Among the over-the-counter issues, 992 were up, 1,021 were down and 92 unchanged.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
Times Are Tough For U.S. Builders

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
THE big new scare for the already sluggish American economy is coming from the construction industry, particularly home construction. Building loans are hard to get, customers are scarce and the unemployment rate among the nation's construction workers is 10.3 percent, higher than in any other industry.
Even successful builders, like Frank Wimer, president of the Wimer Construction Company of Pittsburgh, are feeling the pinch. Mr. Wimer built 12 suburban homes last year, selling them as they were built at prices upward of $300,000. But now he has five more under construction and none has been sold yet, a rare and unnerving experience for Mr. Wimer. ''I am not going to start more homes until I sell these,'' he said. 
His caution means that Wimer Construction's 1990 output will be, at best, only eight or nine homes - a 25 percent decline from last year. Mr. Wimer's behavior helps to explain why single-family home construction across the nation plunged from January through May to an annual rate of only 900,000 building starts, down from one million in 1989. Not since the recessionary early 1980's has home building been so weak.
Still, Mr. Wimer is luckier than many other builders. The nationwide surge in defaults on real estate loans has made lenders extra wary about financing anyone who is not a good credit risk. With 42 years as contractor, Mr. Wimer's two long-time lenders, the Landmark Savings and Loan Association and the Pittsburgh National Bank, continue to give him loans. But they charge him more.
''We used to get construction loans without upfront fees, but now we have to pay 1.5 percentage points,'' he said. In addition, the interest rate that Mr. Wimer pays on loans has risen to an annual rate that is two percentage points above the prime rate, or a total of 13 percent. Until this year, Mr. Wimer paid only 1.5 percentage points over prime.
The hard times did not pop up overnight. The construction of offices and other commercial buildings began to decline in 1988, and soon afterward apartment construction also shrank sharply. Both were victims of overbuilding in the 1980's and a backlog of unsold units. But the building of single-family homes remained robust, and this category is the industry's largest, representing 30 percent of all construction.
Then last fall, single-family home construction began to collapse, with building starts declining by 10 percent since October. The Northeast and the South accounted for most of the fall. ''The only thing that had held the construction game together was single-family housing and now it, too, is in the junk pile,'' said George A. Christie, chief economist for the F. W. Dodge division of McGraw-Hill Inc., which collects industry data.
Many explanations are offered for the hard times. The post ''baby boom'' generation is providing fewer home buyers. The sluggish economy has made people concerned about job security and therefore reluctant to go into debt for new homes. And the savings and loan crisis has been hugely destructive, on two counts.
The main one is that savings institutions are a principal supplier of construction loans. Not only have 1,000 of these lenders failed and disappeared, but a law enacted by Congress in August greatly restricted the amount that a savings and loan can lend to a single developer.
The builders could turn to other lenders, like insurance companies and pension funds. But Francis H. Schott, chief economist at the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, notes that insurance companies seek longer lending periods than those provided by construction and mortgage financing. And pension funds often restrict construction and home loans to 5 percent of their portfolios.
Aside from the credit crunch, the Federal Government is trying to sell tens of thousands of homes and other buildings, an effort that depresses already-weak real estate prices and helps to kill the demand for new construction. The Government acquired the property from failed savings and loan companies that had originally seized the buildings from borrowers who had defaulted.
Inevitably, the construction industry's troubles will show up as weakness in the gross national product. The G.N.P. measures the national wealth that is created through the production of goods and services. The construction industry, with five million workers, accounts for 7.5 percent of this wealth creation, and as current construction is completed - without new building to replace it - construction's contribution to G.N.P. will shrink.
Stephen S. Roach, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company, estimates that the construction slump will result in a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in the G.N.P. in the second half of the year, a not inconsiderable hit at a time when the G.N.P. is growing at an annual rate of less than 2 percent.
Could the construction slump tilt the economy into recession? Most economists do not think so. But given the credit problems and the big supply of unsold homes (an eight-month backlog, according to a Goldman Sachs estimate), the construction industry is likely to remain a weak sister for months to come.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Lower Rates Seen for Second Half

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Credit market participants and analysts say they are optimistic that interest rates can decline further in the final six months of the year.
Their enthusiasm is tempered by the fact that earlier predictions of a first-half drop in rates fell flat. Yet conditions that often accompany a rally in the bond market seem to be falling into place.
Inflation fears are fading, after pushing bond yields up above 9 percent for a brief period in the spring from just under 8 percent at the end of 1989. The economy is plodding along at a 1 percent to 2 percent rate of growth and seems disinclined to accelerate to a faster pace anytime soon. 
In addition, President Bush made it plain last week that he thought spending cuts and tax increases to cut the Federal budget deficit were in the nation's best interests. Mr. Bush's comments were sweet music to the bond market, a tune it has long been waiting to hear.
Even though the size of the deficit as a percentage of gross national product shrank during the latter half of the 1980's, ''the deficit reduction we did have was never viewed in a serious light by the financial community, because tax increases were never considered,'' said Richard M. Kelly, president of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, primary dealers in Government securities.
''Improvement in the prospects for meaningful deficit reduction adds to an already constructive environment for fixed-income securities,'' Mr. Kelly said.
 
Policy Committee Meets
The market could get further encouragement this week from the Federal Reserve Board. The policy-making Open Market Committee begins two days of talks in Washington today.
Most analysts said the Fed is not likely to take any immediate action to reduce interest rates, despite all the recent positive developments. But with some action on the deficit in the works and the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, scheduled to testify before Congress in mid-July, pressure is rising on the Fed to move quickly.
''Although increased fiscal restraint will bias the Fed toward an easier posture, any signs of renewed stirring in the economy will stay its hand,'' Richard B. Berner, an economist at Salomon Brothers, noted in the firm's weekly ''Comments on Credit.''
 
Employment Data Will Be Critical
''In this context,'' Mr. Berner added, ''the upcoming employment report will be more critical to the near-term direction of monetary policy than progress, or lack thereof, on the budget accord.''
David Wyss, chief financial economist at Data Resources Inc., the economic consulting firm, said that like a good poker player the ''Fed won't do anything until they are pretty sure a budget deal will pass.''
''But they may have to do something earlier than that if they see a soft employment report, which could happen.''
The June employment figures are due to be released by the Labor Department on Friday. Economists said another weak report would be particularly telling, because the survey period for June is five weeks rather than the usual four.
The Government has made the task of estimating the job figures more difficult because in June it dismissed many of the temporary census workers it had hired earlier in the year.
Excluding the Census workers, most analysts are projecting that nonfarm payroll employment rose between 125,000 and 165,000 last month after a census-adjusted gain of 17,000 in May. Analysts at Salomon Brothers point out that an increase of that magnitude would be the first significant gain in four months.
If the experts are right, and long-term interest rates fall significantly from their current level of about 8.40 percent, the drop would be met with thunderous applause in the debt-strapped corporate sector.
Robert A. Schwartz, a vice president and senior financial economist at Merrill Lynch, said that more than $42 billion worth of corporate debt with coupons of 10 percent or higher could be called during the current quarter.
A drop in long-term interest rates to 8 percent or lower would prompt a surge of refinancings, he said.
''The drop in rates we had during June prompted a nice deal flow,'' Mr. Schwartz said. ''But if rates get to 8 percent I think you will see a real surge in new financings.''
 
Option to Refinance
Generally, corporations would choose to refinance callable debt if rates are betweeen one percentage point and one and one-half percentage points below the level at which the securities were originally issued.
In 1986, the last time interest rates dropped substantially, $40 billion worth of callable debt was refinanced, Mr. Schwartz said.
''I don't expect to see anything of that magnitude, but a lot of short-to-medium term debt issued in the 1982-to-1985 period would see significant cost savings'' if rates fell to 8 percent or less.

INDUSTRY: SIC6211 SECURITY BROKERS, DEALERS, & FLOTATION COMPANIES (67%);
