HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New Dailies Proliferate in Spain as Ads Surge

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MADRID

 BODY:
Although newspaper circulation has remained stagnant in Spain since the 1930's, publishers have been rushing to start new dailies in a scramble to tap the booming advertising market here.
''Spaniards don't read newspapers,'' one senior Government official said, noting that Americans buy four times as many newspapers per capita than Spaniards. ''But this doesn't seem to put off publishers.''
Last year, El Mundo and El Independiente raised the number of national newspapers to eight. In May, El Sol, started with an investment of $30 million, joined the fray. 
Meanwhile, established newspapers are spending heavily on modernization, and more dailies are planned.
 
Spain's Ebullient Economy
The main explanation for such growth is Spain's ebullient economy. Advertising is booming, with total spending growing by about 25 percent a year since 1986. Nearly a third of this ad spending, or $2.2 billion in 1989, goes to the nation's newspapers, which print less than 3.3 million copies daily.
This advertising bonanza has spilled over into the glossy weeklies. Filled with social gossip and scandal stories, Hola, Interviu, Tiempo and Tribuna attracted a total of $1 billion in advertising revenue last year.
Indeeed, international media entrepreneurs, from Rupert Murdoch to Robert Hersant of France, are now awakening to the Spanish market.
But another factor is at work. Some Spanish financiers and business executives have concluded that newspapers and magazines are useful arenas in which to conduct political and economic battles. By investing very quietly in some publications, they have insured that their views do not go unnoticed.
 
Extraordinary Turmoil
So with television and radio also being buoyed by inflated advertising revenues, the Spanish media is going through extraordinary turmoil and prosperity. ''Obviously, everyone wonders when the bubble will burst,'' a Spanish journalist said.
The upsurge in Spanish publishing began after the death in 1975 of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, whose dictatorship insured that newspapers were not worth reading. In 1976, El Pais appeared and rapidly became Spain's most influential daily. Soon afterward, the magazine Cambio 16 gave birth to the daily Diario 16.
By the mid-1980's, with democracy well installed in Spain, newspaper executives began focusing more on economics than politics. Spain's entry into the European Community set off a burst of growth; the middle classes started spending heavily and advertising surged.
Today, three newspapers that survived the Franco era - La Vanguardia, Ya and ABC - are back on their feet. Three business dailies are fighting for an audience that may number only 100,000. And a total of 110 newspapers are being published.
 
Ambitious New Venture
El Sol, which took its name from a newspaper closed by Franco in 1939, is the most ambitious new venture. ''This is a long-term project with enough investment to win both market and credibility,'' said Jose Antonio Martinez Soler, its editor. ''We're not interested in sensationalism. We want to be serious, but not boring.''
Mr. Martinez Soler said El Sol, owned by German Sanchez Ruiperez, a leading book publisher, plans to focus on social change. ''Spaniards are no longer obsessed by politics,'' he said. ''They want to know about ecology, health, alcoholism, the quality of life and so on.''
To win readers, El Sol has initiated what it calls the ''plastic bag,'' which is distributed with its Sunday issue. It contains two magazines, a cooking course and an English-language course. The bag's cost is covered by an advertisement from a local department store.
Several weeklies are also providing their readers with gifts. Cambio 16 has been providing a small novel each week; Tiempo and Tribuna have given away videotapes of highlights of World Cup soccer games, as well as tape-recordings of purported ghosts in a Madrid palace, and Panorama has offered a video of an exhibition of Velazquez paintings.
 
Lure of Sensationalism
Still, a number of publications often resort to sensationalism to attract readers and thereby gain advertisers. ''In supposedly serious media, the wives of certain local personalities take up more space than the revolutions in Eastern Europe,'' lamented Juan Luis Cebrian, the founding editor of El Pais.
El Pais, though, still stands above the crowd. The newspaper, owned by Jesus de Polanco's Prisa Group, has the largest circulation in Spain, reaching 300,000 daily and about 800,000 Sunday.
No less significantly, it has maintained a high standard of journalism that some newcomers are aspiring to follow.
''You have to remember that most papers here are elitist by definition because there are so few readers,'' Mr. Martinez Soler of El Sol said. ''I want to start with the dominant class and then go down. There's no point in producing a newspaper for people who don't read.''
 
Growing Foreign Presence
Given the appearance this year of three new private television channels and the continuing popularity of radio, there remains a question of whether newspapers will continue to gain readers. But the growing presence of foreign investors suggests that this may not matter.
Mr. Murdoch's News Corporation has bought 25 percent of the Z Group, which owns several dailies and national magazines; Mr. Hersant has acquired 25 percent of the group that includes Cambio 16 and Diario 16; The Financial Times owns 35 percent of the business daily Expansion; and Dow Jones & Company has a share in Estructura, which publishes a business daily and weekly.
For them, advertising is key. As a share of gross domestic product, ad spending in Spain ranks second in the world after the United States and, in absolute terms, fourth after Britain, West Germany and France within the European Community.
But Mr. Cebrian of El Pais worries about the direction of the Spanish press, especially the deepening involvement of Spanish financiers and businessmen.
''The media feed on the values of the society in which they live,'' he said. ''The dominant ethics in Spain today are the ethics of profit.''

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
A 2d-Quarter Rebound for the World's Markets

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
What goes up must come down, and vice versa. And that is just what happened in the world's stock markets in the second quarter.
Many of the top performers of the first three months of the year - including Austria, West Germany and Norway - all tumbled into the second division during the second three months. And the cellar dwellers of the first quarter - New Zealand, Sweden, Spain, Britain and even Japan - all moved up. 
The one consistent performer was Mexico, up 32.6 percent in local currency (28.7 percent in dollar terms) in the second quarter, after a 22.4 percent surge in the first quarter. The stock market rallied on the strength of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's economic program and the debt-reduction agreement with Mexico's commercial bankers.
 
A Kinder Quarter
Over all, the second quarter was much kinder to stock markets around the world. As a whole, world stock markets were up 4.4 percent in the second quarter, compared with a 14.6 percent decline in the first, according to the Financial Times world indexes in local currencies.
For American investors abroad, a weakening dollar added to the gains abroad. When translated back into dollars, the gains in the world's stock markets were 6.7 percent, compared with a 17.7 percent decline for the first three months.
''The first quarter was so bearish,'' said Gavin Dobson, president of Murray Johnston International in Chicago. ''There was a surfeit of bearishness at the time,'' he added, arguing that this realization helped the rebound in the second quarter.
Despite the reversals in the second quarter, for the first six months of the year the lineup of markets in the Financial Times world indexes changed little.
Eight of the 10 leaders in the first quarter - Mexico, Austria, Norway, Hong Kong, Singapore, Italy, West Germany and Denmark - are still among the top 10 in gains over six months. The new arrivals are Sweden and Switzerland. Europe Outperforms U.S. Over all, world markets fell 8.1 percent in terms of local currencies. The United States, which was up 1.1 percent, was outperformed by Europe, which was up 6 percent in dollar terms, and by 14 other markets. But in terms of its own currencies, Europe was up only seven-tenths of a percent.
In Austria, the 9.9 percent decline in the second quarter in local currency (8 percent in dollars) and the 4.3 percent percent drop in West Germany (3 percent in dollars) were mostly because of concern about the impact, both in cost and higher interest rates, of the economic union of East and West Germany, which took place yesterday. But the two markets rallied some in the last two weeks, and for the year Austria is No. 2 on the Financial Times list of 24 countries, with an increase of 38.5 percent (40.7 percent in dollars). West Germany is in ninth place, with a jump of 6.3 percent (8 percent in dollars).
Several factors accounted for the second-quarter gains: Rebounds often occur after sharp declines; some local economies showed improvements in interest rates and inflation, and some benefited from foreign investment.
 
Spain Up After Decline
Spain was up 17.4 percent in local currency (24.8 percent in dollars) in the second quarter after an 18.9 percent decline in the first quarter. Spain's market was helped by a huge shift of foreign investment as managers looked for alternatives to West Germany. Some progress on inflation also added to the attraction of the market.
Italy and Hong Kong also benefited from foreign investment, which helped push up the Milan bourse by 8.8 percent (10.6 percent in dollars) and the Hong Kong market by 9.6 percent (9.9 percent in dollars). Italy declined 1.5 percent in the first quarter, while Hong Kong was up 3.3 percent. Hong Kong got special help as the anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre in June passed without problems and President Bush extended special trade benefits to China.
Switzerland was another beneficiary of foreign investors looking for a hot market. The market was up 8.8 percent (14.9 percent in dollars), after falling 7.6 percent in the first quarter. Richard Finch of James Capel Inc. in London said that the Swiss rally, which came in May, was helped by the expectation that interest rates had reached a peak and that inflation would decline.
Sweden, which fell 10.2 percent in the first quarter, jumped 25.7 percent (27.6 percent in dollars) in the last three months, led by foreign buying of leading stocks like L. M. Ericsson and Alfa-Laval. But the Government, which has been struggling to impose a tough economic program, faces possible labor unrest.
In Norway, where the Oslo market rose 14.7 percent in the first quarter, the decline in oil prices dragged the shipping sector down, and the market fell by 2.6 percent (two-tenths of a percent in dollars) in the second quarter. For the year, however, the market is still up 14.3 percent in local currency (17.7 percent in dollars). Like Sweden, Norway faces some labor troubles.
 
A Move to Stabilize Currency
Britain's stock market, which rose 5.4 percent (11.6 percent in dollars) after a first-quarter decline of 8.3 percent, rallied mostly on the back of the Thatcher Government's decision, when inflation is low enough, to take the pound into the European Monetary System. It is a move that should make the currency more stable and mean that inflation has been brought down to a reasonable level.
A rally in New Zealand of 5.7 percent (7.4 percent in dollars) in the second quarter may not continue because elections are due by October. But the current Government's economic policy is taking hold, which is improving the longer-term outlook for the market.
Japan set the tone of the first quarter with its 30.3 percent decline (37 percent in dollars) that threatened to, but did not, drag down other stock markets with it. In the second quarter, a strengthening yen helped the market rebound by 5.2 percent (8.7 percent in dollars), leaving it down 21 percent for the year.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
Soviet Effort for Patent Law Reform Gaining Momentum

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
Amid efforts by the Soviet Union to liberalize its stagnant economy, a seemingly quixotic movement to adopt a Western-style patent law is gaining momentum.
Proposals have been put forward to give people and private corporations exclusive rights to their inventions for 20 years from the time they apply for a patent. In the process, the plan would reverse doctrines dating back to the Revolution of 1917 that allow state enterprises to appropriate almost any technology and offer only token compensation in return.
''If we want to make our economy free, if we want to build business, we must bear some responsibility'' for protecting inventions, said Edvard P. Gavrilov, a professor at the Moscow Institute of the National Economy and president of the All-Union Patent Law Association, a national association of patent experts. He added: ''I cannot steal your watch. Why should I be able to steal your idea?'' 
 
Effort Begun in 1985
As early as 1985, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev expressed support for overhauling the Soviet patent system, Professor Gavrilov said. While the issue had not received high priority amid the many economic and political changes, the State Committee on Inventions and Discoveries, which oversees the patent system, recently organized a committee to make recommendations. That committee is led by Mikhail Gordisky, head of Soyuzpatent, an arm of the Soviet Chamber of Commerce.
Of particular importance to Western companies, the proposals would do away with provisions of current law that deem some fields, including pharmaceuticals and chemical processes, simply unpatentable.
The measure received a push last month in the trade agreement signed here by President Bush and President Gorbachev.
 
Pledge to Sign Treaty
As part of a deal to obtain most-favored-trade status with the United States, the Soviet Union pledged to sign an international treaty governing copyrights and to provide patent protection along the lines of Western laws. The proposed measure is expected to be considered later this year by the Supreme Soviet, the nation's parliament.
The proposal also has strong advocates among Soviet patent experts, who argue that a new law would help attract Western capital and technology and enable the Soviet Union to make better use of its rich scientific research. Compared with Japan and West Germany, for example, the Soviet Union has few inventions patented in the United States.
Milton Wayne, a patent lawyer in New York who has worked on Soviet patent issues for 15 years, said: ''The research they do is first class in some areas. The problem they have is that they don't know how to exploit it properly.''
 
Areas of Patent Strength
The strongest area of Soviet patents has been in heavy industry, particularly steelmaking, Mr. Wayne said. And only last week, E. I. duPont de Nemours & Company, received approval from the United States Food and Drug Administration to market ethmozine, a drug for treating irregular heart beats. Du Pont licensed that drug in 1974 from the Soviet Government.
The advocates of patent reform acknowledge that, with the Soviet economy in its worst crisis in years, they face a steep barrier of indifference. ''I am afraid most of our leaders consider it of little importance,'' Professor Gavrilov said. ''There are many other burning issues to be considered. The specialists have to push - can I use the word lobby? - to include this legislation on their agenda.''
In theory, the Soviet Union has long offered patent protection. In practice, protection for inventors is all but nonexistent. In addition to those fields that are not regarded as patentable, the law denies patents to anybody who develops a technology that has any relationship at all to work that person is doing for the Government.
 
Practice of Awarding Certificates
In lieu of a patent, the Government awards most people an ''inventor's certificate,'' which assigns the rights to an invention to the Soviet Government and to any state-owned enterprises that want to use it. Inventors are legally entitled to compensation, but Professor Gavrilov said the sums rarely exceed a few hundred dollars.
Although the law theoretically lets inventors choose whether to apply for a patent or a certificate, 80 percent of all inventions receive certificates.
Under the proposed legislation, most technology would be patentable, including genetically engineered micro-organisms and cell cultures. Inventors would be able to sell their patent rights or assign them to their employers in much the same way that company employees assign their rights in Western countries.
In drafting the legislation, Soviet trade and patent officials have carried on lengthy discussions with experts at the Office of the United States Trade Representative and the United States Patent and Trademark Office. The American team was led by Jules Katz, deputy United States trade representative.

HEADLINE: Gregory Vistnes Weds Jessica Primoff

 BODY:
Jessica Lynn Primoff, the daughter of Arlene Kelvin of Bayside, Queens, and the late Melvin Primoff, was married yesterday in White Plains to Gregory Scott Vistnes, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lars Vistnes of Los Altos, Calif. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman and the Rev. Pamela Blair, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Mansion at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel. 
Mrs. Vistnes, a graduate of Brandeis University, earned a Ph.D. in economics at Stanford University, as did her husband. She is an economist at the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research of the Public Health Service in Rockville, Md. Her father was a lawyer and an accountant. Her mother is a librarian at Hendrick Hudson High School in Montrose, N.Y.
The bridegroom, a graduate of the University of California at Berkeley, is an economist in the antitrust division of the Justice Department in Washington. His mother, Carol Vistnes, is a fund-raising coordinator at the Children's Health Council in Palo Alto, Calif. His father is a professor of surgery at the Stanford University Medical Center in Palo Alto.

PUB-DATE: July 2, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 15, Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 801 words

HEADLINE: Gorbachev's Last Chance - Democracy

BYLINE: By Roman Szporluk; Roman Szporluk is professor of history at the University of Michigan.

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Mich.

 BODY:
For more than five years, Mikhail Gorbachev has preached the gospel of democracy. Starting today, with the 28th Communist Party Congress, he must begin to practice it or risk losing his remaining power base.
The time when a great reformer -a solitary czar-liberator - could dictate events is over. Mr. Gorbachev must now evolve into a great reconciler, negotiating his differences with the reformist forces emerging in the republics. At the center of this effort must be a reconciliation with his nemesis Boris Yeltsin, the president of the Russian Republic. 
Mr. Gorbachev initially had hoped to avoid this sort of politicking by using the Communist Party as his principal instrument in transforming the Soviet Union. Yet, as the recent congress of the Russian Communist Party dramatically underscored, the party has emerged as the center of opposition to reform. Indeed, in all likelihood the democrats will be forced to leave the party. Despite their rising and open hostility to their nominal leader, the anti-reform forces are unlikely to oust Mr. Gorbachev in the party congress -though they may have the necessary votes to do so. The more intelligent hard-liners know that a return to the Stalinist model would provoke violent resistance in the cities and would be a disaster for Soviet foreign relations.
In these circumstances, it has been widely suggested that Mr. Gorbachev simply give up his party posts and continue his reforms by running the state machine as President. But, as he is well aware, the new state machine is too weak - and the party is still too strong - for this to happen. The professional bureaucrats who dominate the party apparatus would continue their successful efforts to undercut economic reform.
The reformist democrats, for their part, have proven they know how to win elections. But they have trouble translating their electoral triumphs into control over city hall. They have a strong voice - though far from a majority - in the Congress of People's Deputies and the Supreme Soviet, and somewhat more influence in Russia than in the other republics.
But nowhere - not even in the liberal hotbeds of Leningrad and Moscow - have they yet established effective control. Anti-reform Communists not only direct the party apparatus but dominate in the middle and higher ranks of the state machine.
Fortunately, in this cacophony of political forces lie the seeds of a potent, progressive coalition. Mr. Gorbachev's task at the party congress is to begin the process of forging a strong alliance with the reformist elements, personified by Boris Yeltsin.
Mr. Yeltsin was elected by democrats and liberals in Moscow and Leningrad and moderate patriotic elements in the provinces. This same constituency - which Mr. Gorbachev fumbled away in clumsy attempts at old-style domination - has emerged in all the republics.
If they are to gain the power to govern effectively, however, these emerging reform movements need Mr. Gorbachev's support. They also fear the hard-line alternatives to him.
Mr. Gorbachev, who has alienated just about every faction, needs the reformers' support if he is to maintain power and carry through his dream of westernizing his country.
In addition to mending fences with Mr. Yeltsin, therefore, Mr. Gorbachev must strike a deal with reformers in all the republics: self-rule in return for their support of his future efforts at reform.
What sort of self-rule should he offer? In the Baltic states, the people will be satisfied by nothing short of independence. Mr. Gorbachev should recognize the inevitable and agree to work out a plan for autonomy.
But independence is not necessarily the rallying cry in all the non-Russian republics. Many, such as the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Kazakhstan would probably agree to remain within an overhauled Soviet Union that granted self-rule within some sort of confederation or commonwealth.
Mr. Gorbachev also should remain head of both the state and the party. Combining the two roles should allow him to pursue his reform program by gradually dismantling the governing functions of the party and, where necessary, replacing them with democratic structures.
For the current, fractured state of affairs Mr. Gorbachev has nobody but himself to blame. By refusing to share power, he has alienated his natural constituencies. Perhaps even more damaging is his ongoing conflict with Mr. Yeltsin. His attempt to prevent Mr. Yeltsin's election was a terrible political mistake.
Ironically, Mr. Gorbachev seems slower than his opponents to adjust to the vast changes he has wrought. By virtue of his celebrity status, he continues to exercise great influence. But to maintain his standing, he has to realize that the diffusion of power that he engineered has irrevocably changed Soviet politics.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 3, 1990

SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 3; National Desk

LENGTH: 2971 words

HEADLINE: Economic Pulse; Southern California;
Test for Peace Dividend: Boom or Bust in California

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Southern California, perhaps more than any other region, offers a clear test of the American economy's capacity to convert from military to peaceful purposes.
For years it has been the center of the nation's aerospace and weapons industry, seemingly invulnerable to the economic vicissitudes that in the 1980's hit the once-booming economies of Texas and then the Northeast.
But an economic slowdown of uncertain proportions and duration has gripped this region in response to the easing of the Communist threat in Europe. And it comes against a backdrop of other problems in recent years, including growing congestion, soaring housing prices and increasingly costly environmental rules that have made this region less competitive for industry.
A crucial question is whether it can make up for lost business by taking advantage of the growing worldwide demand for commercial aircraft and expanding its space exploration industries. 
 
Pentagon Spending Peaked
Pentagon spending here peaked three years ago, and deeper reductions have caused recent announcements of layoffs by the region's major military contractors - including the Lockheed Corporation, the Northrop Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation - shaking confidence throughout California and sparking debate over whether such industries and their workers can readily shift to other work.
Aerospace and high-technology industries in the five-county Los Angeles basin - which embraces Los Angeles, Orange, Ventura, Riverside and San Bernardino counties - employ nearly 420,000 people, or 7 percent of the region's 6.2 million jobholders, double that of the rest of the country. And in San Diego to the south, with the largest military presence in the country, one-fifth of the county's annual output of goods and services, or gross product, depends directly on military procurement and salaries.
 
Signs of a Downturn
While few economists here contend the region is sliding into a recession comparable to the Northeast's, there is a growing perception that the era is over when Southern California could rely on a laissez-faire business ethic leavened by good climate, balmy beaches and proximity to the Pacific Rim and Latin countries. The unrelenting optimism of the booming 1980's has turned into caution for the 90's.
Signs of the difficulties are apparent along the coast from Santa Barbara to San Diego. Retailers complain that sales are flat, permits for new home construction have plunged, banks are tightening credit rules, unemployment rates are creeping up and the superheated housing market has stabilized, with prices falling in some areas as home sales drop.
In addition, an unexpected slowdown in the growth of tax revenue has forced Los Angeles to impose new taxes, like a 10 percent levy on people who park in lots and garages, and to cut municipal spending.
California is far less dependent on military spending than it was during the Vietnam War, after which it suffered a much more severe recession than the rest of the country. The military's contribution to the state's gross product has dropped to 8 percent this year, from 15 percent in 1968. But the state's more diversified economy is now hobbled by the effects of huge growth - high housing costs, costly smog-control rules, traffic congestion, deteriorating schools, crime and drug abuse - that have made it more difficult to attract and retain industry.
 
'Everything Points To Slower Growth'
While Northern California shares many of the problems plaguing the Los Angeles basin, the situation is more pronounced in Southern California simply because of its large population.
''Everything points now to slower growth in California and Los Angeles,'' said David G. Hensley, director of California forecasting at the University of California at Los Angeles Business Forecasting Project.
''It is true we have moved away from defense,'' Mr. Hensley said, ''but we must take into account the other negative things that have developed - traffic, crime, costs, pollution, environmental regulations. Defense cuts in this environment will have a different effect than 20 years ago. People underestimate the importance of that segment.''
Mr. Hensley predicts that job growth in the state will drop from its recent rate of 500,000 new jobs a year to 300,000 this year, which would be the slowest rise since 1982.
Jack A. Kyser, chief economist at the Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce, said: ''All this is making people think they've got to do a good old-fashioned job of economic development. Before, we ran by remote control; growth just happened. Some of the impact of the aerospace layoffs has been soft so far, by attrition. But as we go along, we'll see more and more outright layoffs, and that is very unnerving. People are very concerned.''
The latest blow came in early June when McDonnell Douglas, grappling with delays and losses in its new MD-80 passenger jet and with falling Pentagon spending for warplanes, announced budget reductions that were expected to add another 10,000 layoffs to the 7,000 workers it already planned to let go from its Southern California plants.
Mr. Kyser estimates that the Los Angeles basin suffered a loss of 12,500 high-paying jobs in aerospace, electronic components, navigation and other high-technology fields in 1989 and predicts a loss of 15,000 more this year.
 
Tumultuous Years, Then the Downturn
The slowdown comes after what was probably the most tumultuous decade in California since the Gold Rush. Los Angeles boomed. Spurred in large measure by the military buildup under the Reagan Administration and the success of the 1984 Olympic Games here, the area blossomed well beyond its origins in the entertainment industry. By 1988, the Department of Defense was spending a fifth of its budget, $57.2 billion, in California.
The largest share went to Southern California, where factories cranked out fighter planes and began work on Stealth bombers and Star Wars projects. Those programs, in turn, spawned a galaxy of more than 10,000 subcontractors. In 1986, the Los Angeles basin accounted for 5.6 percent of the jobs in the United States, but nearly 15 percent of the jobs in military areas.
The basin's economy was further stimulated by a surge in foreign and domestic migration to the region. In the last decade, its population grew at more than twice the national rate, to 14.1 million from 11.5 million, making it larger than any state but California, New York and Texas. At the same time, the region added 1.3 million non-farm jobs, a 27 percent increase, though its manufacturing base has been slipping in recent years.
The commercial ports of entry here became the nation's main funnel for cars, trucks, stereos and other products from Japan, South Korea and the rest of the Pacific Rim. International trade tripled in value over the decade, to $101.4 billion in 1989, making Los Angeles the second busiest customs district after the New York-New Jersey area, with $117.8 billion in 1989.
The once-sleepy downtown of Los Angeles exploded with a construction boom, with Japanese interests owning 30 percent of the skyline's newer structures. In the last decade, construction permits were issued for $15 billion worth of office buildings and nearly $9 billion for industrial buildings in the Los Angeles area.
Meanwhile, housing prices spurted. The median price for new detached houses rose to $369,000 by mid-1989, from $152,000 in mid-1986, and today only about one in seven households can afford to buy a median-priced home in Orange and Los Angeles counties.
 
Tremors in Europe Shake West Coast
But the tremors caused by world events have shaken the region. Among the projects under scrutiny by Congress and the Bush Administration are the C-17 cargo plane meant to ferry American troops to Europe, which is being developed by McDonnell Douglas in Long Beach; the Stealth bomber, which is being built by Northrop, and Star Wars research.
Also vulnerable are the Long Beach Naval Shipyard, with 4,000 workers, the Los Angeles Air Force Base, with 3,000 jobs, and the Aerospace Corporation in El Segundo, a kind of high-technology research organization for Government military security that employs about 3,000 people.
In all, 10 military bases and installations have been marked by the Defense Department as candidates for closures or staff reductions.
Lockheed, with its contracts for the Stealth and the P-3 antisubmarine craft running down, announced it would lay off 2,000 to 2,500 workers and would move its Aeronautical Systems Company to Marietta, Ga., with a loss of another 4,500 aircraft jobs in the Burbank area. Northrop said it would cut 2,700 jobs in the area because of likely Federal cuts in the Stealth program.
And San Diego was shaken in June when Defense Secretary Dick Cheney proposed eliminating 20 ships, or almost one-fourth of the Navy fleet stationed there, including 11 of the 15 nuclear-class attack submarines based there.
While most of the layoffs among military contractors have not yet begun, effects are already apparent. The unemployment rate for Los Angeles County was 5.4 percent in April, up from 3.7 percent a year earlier. The Southern California Gas Company, serving 56 percent of the California population, says new gas hookups are running 10 percent below last year.
 
Retail to Realty, A Softer Economy
''Retailers throughout California have seen fairly soft sales for the last several months,'' said E. Harlin Smith, a vice president of Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., a Los Angeles-based company with 43 Broadway Southern California department stores in the region. He said sales from February through May were up a negligible six-tenths of a percentage point, as against an 8.6 percent increase a year ago. Sales tax receipts in Los Angeles are growing by only a third of normal this year.
The real estate market has also cooled. ''For the moment, California has priced itself out; the average guy cannot afford to buy anymore,'' said Michael S. Salkin, senior vice present of the real estate division at First Interstate Bank of California in Los Angeles. ''There needs to be a pause so incomes can catch up.''
Both Mr. Salkin and John Oliver Wilson, senior economist for the Bank of America, see no overall appreciation in California real estate this year.
In April, the median resale price of a single-family home in California dropped 2 percent from the previous year, to $197,107 from $201,034, according to the California Association of Realtors, with much sharper drops in high-priced coastal areas like Santa Barbara, which fell 8 percent. Permits for construction of new single-family and multifamily housing dropped by 29 percent in April, as against 1989, according to the Construction Industry Research Board.
Commercial vacancy rates in downtown Los Angeles are about 15 percent and rising, and they are running about 20 percent in some parts of Orange County, as against the national average of 21.3 percent. Mr. Salkin said banks are taking a ''good hard look'' at new building projects.
But few expect a fall in real estate like that in New York. ''At the end of the day, California continues to be tremendously popular,'' Mr. Salkin said. ''Land is scarce. We do not see a debacle.''
The crucial question is whether the reductions in military spending will precipitate the kind of downturn brought on by the contraction of the securities industry in New York.
Southern California suffered a body blow two decades ago when the Vietnam War ended. Employment in the state's aircraft and missile industries dropped by 120,000 jobs in four years, and unemployment rates swelled to three percentage points above the national average, drastically slowing migration to the region.
 
Despite Cutbacks, Some Sign of Hope
But many analysts argue that the region is far more diversified and far less dependent on the military today, with fewer than 4 percent of jobs directly dependent on the Pentagon. ''Over all, I see a slowdown in areas impacted by defense cuts, but those are isolated areas,'' said Mr. Wilson of the Bank of America. ''But we are not talking about a shakeout like the late 60's or early 70's.''
C. Lance Barnett, chief economist for the California Department of Commerce, said the local economy will be buffered by strong demand for commercial aircraft, electronics and space and communications products. ''While caution is warranted, we are not in imminent danger,'' he said.
A recent study by the Southern California Association of Governments was also confident. It calculated that if military spending continued at current levels, the region would create 1.26 million new jobs by 1995. Then it assumed that the spending was cut back to 1980 levels by 1995, a cut of about $90 billion nationally, or about one third. Under this scenario, it found that the region would create only 100,000 fewer jobs that it would have otherwise. And, it went on, if the ''peace dividend'' were shifted into space programs, the region could wind up adding 65,000 more jobs than the 1.26 million expected by 1995, even though 70,000 military-related jobs would vanish.
But others are much less optimistic. While the region is more diversified than ever, Mr. Hensley of the U.C.L.A. Business Forecasting Project wrote recently, ''We believe there is a risk of being too smug about California's prospects.''
He compares the California aerospace industry to the securities industry in New York, which has shed more than 25,000 jobs in the last two years.
''In the end,'' Mr. Hensley said, ''we may learn from the case of New York that a fairly small industry can have a lot of leverage even in a big, well-balanced economy. For California, which has more of its economic resources tied up in the military than New York does in the securities industry, the lesson should be that our 'crash' has not occurred yet, i.e. our unique vulnerability, which has been and remains defense cuts, has not been tested in twenty years''
No one yet knows how deep the cuts will be. But in a computer simulation based on an economic model of California, assuming declines in military spending at 2.9 percent in 1990, 9.6 percent in 1991 and 11.5 percent in 1992, Mr. Hensley concluded that the gross state product of California would fall by $7 billion, taxable sales would drop by $3.16 billion and there would be 151,000 fewer jobs than would otherwise be expected. He has also predicted that net migration to the state would drop sharply, from more than 400,000 last year to 250,000 in 1992.
Mr. Hensley's bearish views find some support in the aerospace industry. Stephen E. Chaudet, vice president for public affairs at Lockheed, where 39,000 of its 80,000 employees work in California, said that the cutbacks would have ''serious ramifications'' for the region and that he saw little to keep top aerospace workers employed for now.
''California has the potential to lose a lot of highly skilled and hourly employees,'' Mr. Chaudet said.
Lockheed is trying to replace some of its lost military business with a proposal to modify Boeing 747 passenger jets at two hangars at Norton Air Force Base, which is to be closed.
But union leaders are not optimistic about finding new jobs for the unemployed.
''The prospects are pretty bleak at this point,'' said Don Nakamoto, spokesman for District 722 of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents 5,000 workers at the Lockheed plant in Burbank. which is to be shut, starting with 1,000 layoffs this month.
 
Living Cost Soars, Style of Life Falls
Further clouding the economic outlook, Southern California has become a costly and difficult place to do business. The typical house costs 215 percent of the national average, and some workers are forced to commute 70 miles each way. In fact, there has been a steady flow of longtime Southern Californians to other parts of the state and region that are cheaper and less congested.
Also, California is on the cutting edge of environmental regulations. This year, 34 new anti-smog rules are to be imposed in the Los Angeles basin, many of them putting expensive new burdens on manufacturers. For instance, the Douglas Aircraft Corporation, a subsidiary of McDonnell Douglas, spent millions of dollars to build special hangars in Long Beach to control fumes while painting aircraft, and then almost ended up not being able to use them because the smog-control authorities said the hangars did not adequately control the fumes.
The ultimate question is whether military contractors can convert to peacetime pursuits. Mayor Larry Agran of Irvine, in Orange County, has proposed having contractors build a $250 million, four-mile monorail in the city.
Ruth Galanter, a member of the Los Angeles City Council, has established a committee to explore the creation of an electric-car manufacturing industry, with backing from the machinists union. The San Diego Econonomic Development Corporation has been working with a group called Dollar for Dollar and with local military contractors trying to find commercial applications for their skills.
But such efforts in the past have largely failed. After the Vietnam War, Lockheed tried to diversify into education and computer services, Rohr Industries of Chula Vista tried building subway cars and the Grumman Corporation of Bethpage, N.Y., tried to build city buses.
''We all failed,'' said Harry R. Biederman, an economist who retired recently after 35 years with Lockheed here. ''Defense engineers are brought up in an environment not like the commercial one.''
He added that under military contracts, they had become accustomed to spending too much money on products to make them commercially competitive.

LENGTH: 1282 words

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
East Germans Find Shelves Full And Opt for Food, Not Frivolities

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST BERLIN, July 2

 BODY:
East Germans took their new West German marks for a trial spin today, hunting through stores newly stocked with Western goods, but for now they appeared mostly to be just looking.
The East Germans' practical approach heartened officials who had feared an inflationary shopping spree as the West German currency was adopted in the East with the economic union that went into effect on Sunday.
Checks around East Berlin and reports from other cities indicated that East Germans used their money to buy things that they had planned to buy for some time, or to stock up on food.
On a tour of shops in Leipzig, the West German Economics Minister, Helmut Haussmann, said, ''I am impressed by the entrepreneurs who switched supplies overnight, and by consumers and customers, who did not fall into a buying orgy with the D-mark but studied and checked out the situation.''
Reacting in part to the smoothness of the monetary union, West German stocks, especially blue chips, and the mark itself ended the day higher in trading. The mark, buoyed by the anticipation of tax increases in the United States, closed at 1.6538 to the dollar, up from 1.6715 on Friday. 
''To sum it up: optimism for a new German capital market,'' said Klaus Belling, a dealer on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange.
 
Political Progress
On the political front, officials in Bonn and East Berlin began work on the final push to full political unity, which Chancellor Helmut Kohl hopes to achieve in December with all-German elections.
That push gained momentum today with the announcement by the governing Christian Democrats in East Germany that all-German elections should be held on Dec. 2.
Gunther Krause, the parliamentary floor leader of the Christian Democrats, said the elections would be preceded by voting in East Germany on Oct. 14. That vote would restore the five states that existed in East Germany before the Communist Government abolished them, meeting a requirement for unity in the West German Constitution.
Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, the Christian Democratic leader, said on Sunday that all-German elections could take place by the end of the year. But first, he said, East Germany would have to restore a federal system through a vote. And the military status of the unified country would have to be agreed on by the four World War II Allies - Britain, France, the Soviet Union and the United States.
Members of the governing coalition in East Berlin, which includes Foreign Minister Markus Meckel's Social Democrats, opened meetings to discuss the next ''state treaty'' with Bonn, which will deal with the legal, political and practical arrangements for unity.
In Bonn, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, a strong advocate of holding elections in December, said in a televised interview: ''We want to achieve German unity this year. We want to vote in an election this year.''
 
'Big Choice' Now
At the huge Centrum Kauf am Alex department store on Alexanderplatz in East Berlin, almost entirely restocked with Western goods, the biggest sellers were television and video sets, refrigerators, athletic shoes and children's toys.
''Everybody is buying the one thing they've been missing a long time,'' said Gabriele Sandhop, who came to Centrum with her daughter Claudia. ''For example, we've been looking for shoes for my daugher. She needs especially big shoes, and we could never find anything before. Today, we came here and there was a big choice.''
East German goods were either missing or lost in the abundance of Western wares. Many had been sold in clearance sales last month, and many others were simply deemed incapable of competing in price or quality. Those that were still on sale were drastically reduced to match the Western goods. A television set that once cost 6,000 marks, or about $3,600, stood on sale for one-tenth that amount.
 
'A Lot More Joy'
At the toy department, a saleswoman, Hannelore Vogt, described with a smile how a couple asked for a bicycle for their 7-year-old son. ''I said, 'I'll go see if we have any left,' and immediately I realized that of course we have many left,'' she said. ''It was a mechanical reaction from the old days, when we just distributed goods until they ran out.''
Despite the crush of customers, Mrs. Vogt said, it was much more fun to work. ''We came to work with a lot more joy,'' she said. ''In the old days, all we did was go back to the storeroom and see if we have one. Now we can give advice. We can help people.''
The combination of pragmatism with a touch of self-indulgence was evident at Das Internationale Buch, a large bookstore. Thrillers by Stephen King were doing well, but so were ''how to'' books - ''How to Apply for a Job,'' ''Rent Laws A to Z,'' ''How to Start a Business'' and the like.
With so large a new market opening up, advertisers were quick to seize on East German themes. One television ad for coffee said: ''The revolution of last fall continues. Here are our revolutionary new coffee prices.''
For all the smoothness of the first shopping day of economic union, there were also the first harbingers of the tensions expected when East German companies begin failing or laying off large numbers of workers. Estimates have ranged to as many as two million unemployed by year's end.
 
Things Go Smoothly
About 20,000 supporters of the East German metal workers union held brief work stoppages to back the workers' demands for a two-year guarantee of their jobs and wage increases.
Another brief warning strike was also reported at the Ludwigsfelde auto-parts plant south of East Berlin, where workers are demanding a shorter work week and higher pay. In East Berlin, 66 coal dealers protesting the lifting of state subsidies briefly blocked four loading points.
East German workers on average earn 60 percent less than West German workers, and the discrepancy is likely to become a source of contention now that the West German mark is common to both states. Until the end of the year, however, East German rents, public transport and energy prices will remain frozen at their former low levels, lifting the spending power of East Germans.
But on balance, the first day of economic union seemed to hearten officials.
''There are all the reasons now to expect that the new currency in the G.D.R. is being used with thought,'' said the West German Government spokesman, Dieter Vogel. The Government had watched ''with great satisfaction how calmly, almost routinely, the distribution of D-marks passed in the G.D.R.''
Officials said 3.4 billion marks were withdrawn in the first day of monetary union. At the same time, Rudiger Wrede, director of the new Deutsche Bank branch in East Berlin, said many East Germans had opened savings accounts with 10,000 to 20,000 marks.
 
Filling the Larders
Most of the first-day purchases were reported in grocery stores. Supplies had become ever scarcer in the days leading up to monetary union as shops sold off East German products and customers stocked up at old prices, and for many this was the day to check out the new prices and refill their larders.
Staples like bread, potatoes, milk, meat and sausage, subsidized under Communist rule, were more expensive, sometimes four times more. But products like chicken, butter, vegetables and fruit were cheaper.
The initial buying patterns substantiated studies that said East Germans would probably first buy cars, then vacations and then electronic equipment like television sets, stereos and video players.
''What we hope is that after all that they may want a new kitchen,'' said Gottfried Frauenstein, director of the Profit Center furniture store in East Berlin.

HEADLINE: Rebel Forces in Liberia Surround the Capital and Begin an Attack

BYLINE: y CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Rebel forces began a major assault on Liberia's capital, Monrovia, today, and have cut all the main roads into the city, a senior Bush Administration official said.
''The battle of Monrovia has begun,'' said Herman J. Cohen, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs. ''It is serious. The rebels have effectively surrounded the city and they are moving toward the inside of Monrovia.'' 
Mr. Cohen also said that the Government of President Samuel K. Doe was concentrating its efforts on survival.
Mr. Cohen said a representative of Economic Community of West African States was trying to mediate a settlement to avert a bloody battle in the heart of the city. The representative, he said, ''expressed some hope the talks might resume.''
 
Diplomatic Discussions
A second Administration official monitoring events in Liberia said Vice President Harry S. Moniba and other officials of the Doe Government were meeting with United States diplomats at the American Embassy in Monrovia. They were discussing ways of removing General Doe from the country and seeking a settlement to the fighting.
But the official added, ''The march of military events seems to be outpacing the efforts at negotiation.''
The Reuters news agency reported that most of the members of General Doe's Cabinet and other senior officials have fled the country, while the President appears to have remained in his fortified mansion in Monrovia surrounded by about 500 special troops. Commerce Minister John Wisseh McClain, General Doe's speech writer, reportedly tried but failed to board an aircraft leaving the country.
Talks between the Government and the rebels in Freetown, capital of neighboring Sierra Leone, broke down last week when the rebels refused to continue. The fighting began in December, when 150 guerrillas of the National Patriotic Front, headed by Charles Taylor, crossed the border into northeastern Liberia. Since then, the rebels, whose numbers have increased to several thousand, have pushed the Government forces out of virtually all the northeastern and north-central parts of the country.
The rebels, who have reportedly received training and financial support from Libya, have taken many important economic objectives, including the country's important iron mines, the Firestone rubber plantation, and Buchanan, the second-largest city.
 
Reports From Monrovia
Reports from Monrovia itself were few and vague due to the cutting of telephone and telex lines, but there were indications that at least one army base on the edge of the city was in flames. Rocket, artillery and automatic-weapons fire reverberated from the eastern suburb of Paynesville, while frightened people streamed out of the capital, according to pooled dispatches from journalists in the city and local radio broadcasts monitored from the neighboring Ivory Coast.
The rebels moved into the capital this morning in a two-pronged attack from the northwest and the east. Some Government troops fled from the fighting, jumping into pickup trucks heading downtown, and Mr. Cohen said there was no sign that the army was effectively resisting. Lieut. Gen. Henry Dubar, the army chief of staff, resigned over the weekend.
Mr. Taylor, who has accused General Doe's Government of brutality and large-scale corruption, has promised a thorough political house-cleaning but has equivocated about his intention to hold national elections. The war has been fought mostly along tribal lines, with members of the Krahn and Mandingo ethnic groups, who hold most high positions in the Government and army, battling the Gio and Mano tribes. Both the rebels and the Government forces have been accused of brutal attacks on civilians during the fighting.
The peace talks, held at the United States Embassy in Sierra Leone, failed when General Doe refused to accept a rebel demand that he resign unconditionally. The Liberian President promised not to run for re-election in January and offered to include the guerrillas in an interim government, but the rebels refused to continue the talks. In response to the offensive, General Doe repeated his peace offer on radio today. #4 American Ships The United States Navy has deployed a four-ship task force off the Liberian coast to evacuate about 800 Americans still living in the West African country. American officials in the last few weeks have expressed concern that forces of either side, particularly those of General Doe, were undisciplined and could go on a rampage. There were reports today that drunken soldiers were commandeering cars and extorting money from civilians.
Mr. Cohen said the Navy ships ''are ready for an emergency evacuation if necessary.'' But, as of Monday evening, he added, ''we don't have any reports of Americans being harmed or asking to leave.''
The United States has had close relations with Liberia since it was colonized and founded by freed American slaves in the early 19th century. American installations in the country include a navigational station that guides ships and aircraft across wide areas of the Atlantic Ocean, and two communications relay stations, one that transmits the Voice of America and the other that handles diplomatic and intelligence traffic for nearly all of Africa south of the Sahara.
Mr. Cohen said the Voice of America station is already behind rebel lines, but remains unharmed. He said, so far, the rebels ''have been disciplined and correct.''
Government forces control the area where the diplomatic and intelligence station is situated, and it also remains undamaged, Mr. Cohen said.
 
Abuse Is Reported
Mr. Cohen was less sanguine about human rights in Monrovia. He said United States officials were receiving reports of the abuse of civilians, carried out along tribal lines, by both sides. Such violence, he said, included beatings and shootings.
Washington has had a sometimes close, sometimes difficult relationship with the Doe Government since it took power in a bloody 1980 coup, which resulted in the execution of President William R. Tolbert and other members of the deposed Government. The Reagan Administration was critical of the executions and later of the Doe Government's corruption. But between 1980 and 1985, the Administration granted Monrovia $500 million worth of military and economic aid.
The relationship began to sour after accusations that the Doe Government tampered with election results in 1985, leading to a succession of Congressional aid cutbacks. This year, Liberia received no military aid and just $10 million in food and other humanitarian assistance.
Still, the Bush Administration was reticent about cutting all ties to the Doe Government. In February, two American military advisers were dispatched to a northeastern combat zone in an effort to improve the Liberian Army's human rights performance. Based on the advisers' counsel, some officers were transferred, but American officials have privately admitted that the army continued to abuse villagers.

HEADLINE: Poorest Countries Seek Increases in Aid

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 2

 BODY:
As the world's seven richest nations prepare for their annual economic summit meeting, to be held next week in Houston, the 42 poorest nations are knocking at the door to tell the haves what the have-nots would like to see come out of that exclusive gathering.
Last week the Foreign Ministers of Bangladesh, Somalia, Sudan and Togo, representing the so-called least-developed nations, visited Washington and gave President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d a list of requests before flying to Tokyo to do the same to the Japanese Government.
Not suprisingly, the poor countries -countries where the average citizen earns less than $500 a year - are seeking additional aid, debt relief and the chance to sell more to the industrial world. But the demands are perhaps more urgent this year because they come after the poorest of the poor failed to achieve the goals they set themselves for the 1980's, including 7 percent annual economic growth rates and an end to illiteracy. 
 
Delegation's Travels
Earlier in June, the delegation made similar calls in Paris, Bonn, London and Rome - four of the capitals that will be represented at Houston - as well as to the United Nations in Geneva, the European Commission in Brussels and representatives of the Nordic countries in Stockholm.
On Saturday, two days before the summit conference opens, former Prime Minister Bettino Craxi of Italy is expected to lend his support for more generous debt relief when he presents Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar in Geneva with a report commissioned by the United Nations on the third world's crushing debt burden.
''As the summit approaches the least-developed countries are doing everything to put our concerns before the seven, to tell them things are desperate,'' Bangladesh's Foreign Minister, Anisul Islam Mahmud, the delegation leader, said in an interview here before the group went to Tokyo.
 
Concessions Wanted
The poorest nations are urging the seven to persuade the rest of the industrialized world to grant them further concessions at the second United Nations Conference on the Least-Developed Countries, which opens in Paris on Sept. 3.
Foreign Minister Mahmud reported that the seven were showing ''interest and sympathy for our requests'' but were avoiding hard promises before the Houston meeting. ''Secretary Baker said he will do his best but he was not specific,'' he said.
Mr. Mahmud said the seven are preaching a new development doctrine to the poorest countries these days, telling them that if they want Western help they must become more democratic and respect human rights.
This view, which has been gaining ground among development economists, holds that autocratic third world governments often hamper overall national development by following economic policies that favor the Westernized elites that support them.
 
Skills of Ordinary People
A democratic approach is said to spread resources more evenly, seeking to raise the skills of ordinary people so they can improve their own living standards.
''The elites have hijacked development,'' said Mahbub ul-Haq, a Pakistani economist who earlier this year produced a United Nations report classifying countries by the level of ''human development'' they have achieved.
Mr. ul-Haq's report said 20 of the 25 developing countries with the lowest level of human development are African dictatorships.
The trickiest demand by the world's poorest countries is for the seven richest to respect a longstanding pledge to give the very poorest countries aid equivalent to 15-hundredths of a percent of their own wealth each year and to reach this target by 1995.
Most summit participants - Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Canada -are sympathetic since they have either reached this target or are close to it.
But the United States, which opposes aid targets, directs only four-hundredths of a percent of its gross national product to the poorest countries; Japan gives them about the same.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 591 words

HEADLINE: A Better Idea on Tax Credits

 BODY:
Both the House and Senate have approved expansions of a wonderful but little-known anti-poverty weapon called the earned income tax credit. This income supplement helps working parents with low wages by reducing their income taxes or, if they owe no tax, by paying them cash.
The program now totals about $6 billion yearly. The Senate would raise the earned income tax credit, or E.I.T.C., only for families with children under age 4, at a cost of $3 billion, and spend an additional $7.5 billion on other tax subsidies - all over five years. The House version would adjust for family size, increase credits for families with children under age 6, and would cost $18.5 billion over five years above present expenditures. 
The E.I.T.C. is the best means available to the nation for lifting the working poor out of poverty. The House bill recognizes this more profoundly and generously than the Senate's, and should prevail.
The earned income tax credit is paid only to poor parents who work, thereby discouraging welfare. A full-time worker would need to earn about $6.50 an hour to lift a family out of poverty. In 1991 the minimum wage will rise to $4.25 an hour, leaving a gap of $2.25 for the E.I.T.C. to fill.
The current E.I.T.C. is worth at most 50 cents an hour. The House bill would roughly double that amount, still leaving a typical family well short of the poverty threshold.
If Congress tripled the E.I.T.C., a minimum wage worker would earn about $5.75 an hour. In combination with day care, medical and other Federal subsidies, that would be enough to push many single-earner families out of poverty.
Expanding the E.I.T.C. much further becomes prohibitively expensive, according to David Ellwood of Harvard University. The problem is phasing it out once the family's income rises above poverty. If Congress tries to control costs by phasing it out quickly, it would discourage families from working longer or for higher wages.
The upshot is that the E.I.T.C. by itself cannot end poverty among working families. But it can be tripled, which would be well beyond what the House, let alone the Senate, has so far proposed.
The Senate bill spends too little money on the E.I.T.C. in part because it spends too much on other, less effective tax credits. It would create a refundable tax credit to offset the cost of medical insurance for the working poor. The goal is admirable, but the plan is flawed. This credit would encourage employers to shift more of their health care expenses onto their low-paid workers. The money is better spent on the E.I.T.C.
Another provision in the Senate bill would make partially refundable the existing dependent care tax credit. Thus poor families that owe no tax would receive a cash payment to offset part of their day care expenses. This is a good idea. Yet most poor families would be better off if the money were spent instead on a higher E.I.T.C. For one thing, its benefits are protected against inflation while the dependent care credit is not.
Even with a substantial E.I.T.C., poverty would remain sickeningly prevalent. Nearly three-fourths of poverty-level families with children have no parent working full time. These families are beyond the E.I.T.C.'s reach. And there are other problems. Almost 40 percent of E.I.T.C. payments were sent to ineligible families; and an unknown percent of eligible families don't even know how to apply.
None of these problems are insurmountable. The E.I.T.C. is already a good program. The House bill would make it a whole lot better.

HEADLINE: The Editorial Notebook;
Rich Argentines Confront Capitalism

BYLINE: By DAVID C. UNGER

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
There's no visible privation in the Barrio Norte, Buenos Aires's 300- square-block district of European elegance and conspicuous consumption. But there's plenty of anxious discussion about President Carlos Menem's tough economic policies.
His Government has pledged to sell off state enterprises, squeeze public employment, deny aid to failing private companies, raise prices for basic services and balance the budget. Some of these policies at last seem set to take hold. 
Rich and influential Argentines, the beneficiaries of 60 years of governmental largesse, feel as threatened by such measures as their poorer cousins do, but for different reasons. Ordinary people worry about day-to-day economic survival. The affluent risk losing a life style that most upper middle class New Yorkers would envy -country estates, foreign vacations, first-class restaurants. Less than 1 Argentine in 100 lives so well, but that still amounts to well over 100,000 people, most with residences in the Barrio Norte.
Argentina has many businessmen, but few entrepreneurs. The plain-spoken owner of a large cattle ranch expressed a typical attitude: ''The private businessman can't be expected to know what to do without the Government telling him what it wants, and then helping him do it.'' But in sophisticated urban circles, people recognize that such paternalism, having bankrupted a thriving state, cannot continue. Of course, every businessman would much rather be the last beneficiary of a bailout than the first example of a free-market bankruptcy.
The biggest question now is whether President Menem will be tough enough to resist the special pleas of failing businesses.
He needn't worry much about resistance from the political opposition, but he gets plenty of pressure from within his own Peronist Party, traditional protector of the special interests.
His political style is less than reassuring. While his predecessor, Raul Alfonsin, was given to clear, sometimes blunt declarations of principle, Mr. Menem prefers to bargain, and sometimes to procrastinate. But such blurring of potential conflict may be just what Argentina needs at this difficult moment in its evolution toward democratic stability.
And Mr. Menem has managed to persuade some highly credible independent figures to join his team. These include two first-rate non-Peronist economists, Javier Gonzalez Fraga, who now heads the Central Bank, and Domingo Cavallo, the Foreign Minister.
Mr. Menem has also favorably impressed the Bush Administration and won its strong support. Mr. Bush is scheduled to visit Buenos Aires in September, the first U.S. President to go there since Eisenhower. Argentines expect much concrete U.S. help. Relations between Buenos Aires and Washington are better than they've been for a very long time and U.S. advice is eagerly sought on issues from economic strategies to the latest computer techniques for combating white-collar crime.
It's still far from clear whether Mr. Menem will persevere with his economic plans, and beyond that, whether they will succeed. But for a change, there's some basis for optimism. Mr. Bush is right to encourage it.
DAVID C. UNGER

HEADLINE: Who Won Cold War? Japanese and Germans.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A. M. Rosenthal is unhappy about Mikhail S. Gorbachev's suggestion that we not argue over whether the United States or the Soviet Union won the cold war (column, June 10). The real point, however, is that both lost. Both countries produced a military-industrial complex that pre-empted capital and technical and scientific talent and made respectable, in the name of patriotism when all else failed, a degree of waste and incompetence tinged with corruption that sapped the economic vitals of their societies. It proved contagious.
The main cause of the Soviet industrial crisis is that nearly all their goods come out of such a production system. Their television sets cost 700 rubles (about 3.5 times the monthly wage of a worker), but they are similar to the $640 toilet seats and $6,000 coffee makers of our military sector.
The difference is that we have imported what we needed to the tune of a cumulative goods deficit of more than $900 billion in the last seven years, for which we pay by foreign debt and selling assets. Now that we have run down our food reserves (our main exports), one wonders how much longer we can go on like that.
The victors, as far as economic big-power status defines victory, are West Germany and Japan. They won the cold war, simply by not wasting the resources of creative, industrious societies on the treadmills of the arms race and occasional ''small'' wars.
 
JOHN E. ULLMANN
Hempstead, L.I., June 10, 1990
 The writer is a professor of management at Hofstra University.

HEADLINE: The Lip-Reading Slogan Aside, Mr. Bush Deserves Some Applause

BYLINE: By Walter F. Mondale; Walter F. Mondale, the former Vice President, was Democratic Presidential candidate in 1984.

DATELINE: MINNEAPOLIS

 BODY:
As the individual who is sometimes credited with making the biggest political mistake of the 1980's by saying -on no less an occasion than my acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention -that I would raise taxes, I take a special interest in how our President and members of Congress now struggle with the issue of taxes and the Federal deficit.
We have gone through a decade of dissembling about the fiscal condition of our nation. In 1980, the total Federal debt was $914 billion. Now, it is $3 trillion and rising. Our annual net interest payments on the Federal debt were $52 billion in 1980. They are now nearing $200 billion, accounting for 15 percent of the annual budget. 
The budget deficit for the 1991 fiscal year - including the annual cost of bailing out the savings and loan institutions - is projected to surpass $200 billion.
President Bush now confronts the undeniable reality that spending cuts alone cannot meet the requirements of the Gramm-Rudman law, which limits the 1991 deficit to $64 billion.
When in 1988 George Bush, the candidate, said, ''Read my lips: no new taxes,'' he was not quite leveling with the public. But now George Bush, the President, has begun to learn the difference between campaigning and governing.
We should give the President credit for his statement last Tuesday about the need for ''tax revenue increases.'' He had the courage to change his mind, to acknowledge the truth about our nation's troubled finances, to ''think anew,'' as he admitted at his press conference on Friday. He is being honest about what is required to get our deficit under control.
The President should also be given credit for resisting the tremendous pressure from many of his Republican colleagues to sacrifice our nation's fiscal responsibility to a short-sighted campaign slogan. Mr. Bush may now show the Presidential leadership needed to launch a bipartisan attack on the deficit.
There is also a matter of basic public trust at stake. The public is fed up with the hypocrisies and tricks of modern political campaigns. A recent poll found that 40 percent of Americans say they didn't think President Bush ever meant it when he made his promise of no new taxes.
For the last 10 years, we've had a fiscal politics of evasion. Nobody -Democrat or Republican - has wanted to deal with these issues. The Republicans haven't wanted to give up a good campaign slogan. The Democrats have been terrorized by my landslide defeat in 1984. Ever since, there has been a bipartisan evasion of the deficit issue, because it requires facing up to taxes.
Nobody wants to accept paternity for a tax increase. But it is the future of our country - our future generations - that is harmed by the failure to deal with these problems.
Our politics have entered a new era, the age of the marketeer. Just as bad money drives good from circulation, marketing strategies are driving honesty and substance from politics. The marketing experts have our leaders practicing the politics of irrelevance and avoidance.
On our country's important education issues, candidates now seek advice from pollsters, not from educators. On our tough environmental issues, they go to media managers, not scientists. In dealing with the Federal deficit, they depend on political consultants, not on economists.
On the advice of the marketeers, our leaders are blowing in the wind of momentary public opinion. They inspect their polling and focus group data to decide what issues they'll talk about and what ''spin'' they'll put on them. So we get ''perception management'' from candidates rather than honest debate and bold ideas.
Our leaders conclude that if they talk at any length or in any detail about important issues, they're in trouble. In the 1984 campaign, for example, I tried to talk honestly about reducing the deficit. My opponent, who read the polls, declared that the deficit would disappear by reducing taxes. His dangerous policies resulted in our nation living on borrowed money we cannot afford. Now, our Federal deficit is a disgrace.
We might learn something important from the new and inspiring leaders in Eastern Europe - people like Vaclav Havel, Adam Michnik and Bronislaw Geremek. They speak about the vital importance of ''living in truth.'' The totalitarian system taught them in brutally clear terms about the corrupting and demoralizing effects of a government that refuses to tell the truth. Hoping the instinct for truth was not extinguished by Communism, these leaders now struggle to restore the people's trust in their government and society.
May this hard-won lesson from Eastern Europe be an inspiration for our own challenges here in the U.S.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Get Gorbachev Moving

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
The weather is pleasant and things look the same. There's no highly charged sense that once again, as John Reed wrote about Petrograd in 1917, these are days that will shake the world. Mikhail Gorbachev is doing his best to keep his comrades from rocking the boat, trying to keep the Communist Party and the country together.
But these are days that are moving the world, days of profound confusion. The one thing sure is that things won't be the same again even if there isn't a sudden divide to mark the new from the old, even if nothing dramatic happens, because standing still isn't possible any longer. 
When he launched reforms at the 27th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party four years ago, Mr. Gorbachev said technology was the key. His country had stagnated for lack of technology, he announced, and now he was going to stir it up and get it moving into modern times.
All the evidence indicates he had no idea of how much further and deeper he would have to go, and that even so it wouldn't be enough to take decisions. Getting rid of the ''command system'' requires something else to organize people if they are to produce, and the something else, the mysterious market and the consensual base of democracy, don't create themselves overnight.
Now Mr. Gorbachev is leading his party at its 28th Congress. He had himself made President of the country and is in the process of transferring power from the closed, rigid party system to the Government.
The party may or may not split here, or change its name, or plod on losing the disgusted young and the talented. This Congress is the last of the old type, nonetheless, and he is trying to acknowledge that without upsetting the die-hards. He wants the center, but it's crumbling.
When he was in Washington last month, I asked one of his advisers which way Mr. Gorbachev would go if the party broke into two or more. The answer was that it depended who provoked the split. If the ''radicals,'' which in current Moscow jargon means the impatient reformers, walk out, he would stay with the remainder to coalesce a center-right. If the ''conservatives'' make the challenge, meaning old-liners who say the real trouble is only lack of discipline, he would stay to form a center-left. Obviously, he prefers avoiding the choice.
That means avoiding other choices. The talk is about ''the meaning of socialism'' and ''the role of the party,'' and words serve to postpone admitting that much has to be dumped. But there is no more reason to think buying time will make things easier.
Living conditions are still getting worse. Even polls reflect the huge pessimism. There is still fear, but a different kind. People are not afraid to speak up, and they say anything. But they are afraid of what's ahead, no longer convinced that change means improvement after awhile.
That loss of momentum is costly. Now, Chancellor Kohl of West Germany wants the West to provide a vast cushion of credits to keep Mr. Gorbachev afloat on his current ambiguous course. It makes sense that Mr. Kohl offered some $3 billion from Bonn alone for short-term needs.
The unity of Germany and its coming absorption by NATO has left the Soviets gasping for time to digest the difficult but unavoidable shock. In this case, Bonn wouldn't be buying time, which just isn't available. The Soviets would be selling it, and the money helps ease the inevitable.
The big package, $15 billion to $20 billion from Europe, the U.S. and Japan, is something else. The Russians deny they asked for it, though Mr. Kohl says he knows they want it. It's supposed to be divided between short-term, to pay pressing bills, and long-term, to support real economic overhaul, but the proportions haven't been specified.
More important, neither have the plans. President Francois Mitterrand of France seems to be giving Mr. Kohl enthusiastic support to make up for his initially sour line on Germany, closing the diplomatic gap. But his argument that the money will assure the reforms isn't a good one.
There is certainly a psychological need for the Soviet people to feel they are on the right road and that the West is prepared to be generous - if they keep going, not if they stall.
President Bush will be taking this up at the Houston summit meeting. He should stick with the old principle that time is money, and wasting it is no gain. Then Mr. Gorbachev would have another good reason to shove the hangers-on who want to stand still, damn the remaining Stalinist torpedoes and order full speed ahead for his bewildered people.
