HEADLINE: At BAM Opera, Confidence Amid the Crises

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL

 BODY:
The Brooklyn Academy of Music ended its second opera season on an upbeat note the other day with the final performance of Mark Morris's admired dance version of Purcell's ''Dido and Aeneas.''
While all might have seemed business as usual, however, it was hardly that. The academy's operatic initiative has weathered a number of crises that might have scuttled it.
Now, the impact of the Northeast's economic slowdown on fund raising, and possibly the lack of operatic expertise on the academy's staff, seem to have dampened hope for new opera productions initiated by the academy itself. But Harvey Lichtenstein, the academy's president and executive producer, is still moving confidently ahead, with a variety of imports planned for the next several seasons. 
BAM Opera was intended to offer interesting operas or innovative productions as a full-scale, highly professional alternative to the city's two big companies, the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City Opera.
The venture got under way with a flash in the spring of 1989. There was Verdi's ''Falstaff'' from Peter Stein, the West Berlin director, and the Welch National Opera. Peter Sellars, the best-known American avant-garde opera director, recycled his combination of Bach contata arias and Kurt Weill's ''Mahagonny Songbook.'' And William Christie, the American early music specialist, brought in his Paris Opera production of Lully's ''Atys.''
 
Unraveling Plans
Prospects looked bright. Matthew Epstein was artistic director of the project, and he seemed to offer a rare blend of operatic expertise and interest in operatic innovation. There was much talk of home-grown productions for the future. And a partnership was announced with the Metropolitan to produce two seasons of exotic repertory in productions at the academy conducted by James Levine and directed by Mr. Sellars.
But most of that brave planning has seemed to unravel. The season did open as scheduled with a theatrically ambitious production of Mozart's ''Finta Giardiniera'' by the Theatre Royale de la Monnaie of Brussels. But Mr. Epstein resigned, unhappy over budgetary constraints and what he called administrative amateurishness by the academy's staff.
Then the Met deal collapsed when the Met thought anew about its $1.5 million fund-raising goal for the collaboration, the constraints on its own independence and perhaps in some quarters the genuinely radical nature of the project. Mr. Sellars' planned production of Wagner's ''Tannhauser'' from Chicago fell through for budgetary and casting reasons. Teresa Stratas indefinitely postponed a Weill evening, saying she hadn't had time to master the music.
Even ''Dido and Aeneas,'' for all its critical acclaim, was more dance than opera, with Mr. Morris and his Brussels company miming the action with Nicholas McGegan, the Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra and the singers in the pit.
 
On Its Own Without the Met
In the middle of this operatic ''Gotterdammerung'' sits Mr. Lichtenstein. But unlike the weary god Wotan, he sounds remarkably sanguine about the future of BAM Opera.
''We have regrouped,'' Mr. Lichtenstein said the other day from his Brooklyn office. ''Our basic premises remain the same. We're committed to the project and we think we can bring it off handsomely without the Met. And I'm happy to say we've held onto almost all of the grants we raised jointly with the Met.''
Mr. Lichtenstein's plans for his third opera season, in 1991, seem intended in part to prove that he can accomplish by himself almost exactly what he was to do with the Met.
Those plans had originally included the American premiere in May, 1991, of the new Sellars/John Adams opera, ''The Death of Klinghoffer,'' about the terrorist attack on the liner Achille Lauro and the murder of one of its passengers. That premiere is still to take place at the academy, except now Kent Nagano, who will lead the world premiere in Brussels in March, will conduct the Brooklyn Philharmonic instead of Mr. Levine leading the Met orchestra.
Another Met/Brooklyn production was to have been Gluck's ''Orfeo ed Euridice'' directed by Mr. Sellars. Mr. Lichtenstein said he was close to concluding a deal to import a notable staging of that same opera in February by Harry Kupfer, director of the Bayreuth Festival's current ''Ring,'' and his Komische Oper of East Berlin, with the countertenor Jochen Kowalski as Orfeo.
The third 1991 production will probably be ''The Black Rider,'' a dark comedy by Robert Wilson, the theater artist; Tom Waits, the rock composer, and William S. Burroughs, the novelist. ''The Black Rider'' was first staged this spring by the Thalia Theater in Hamburg, West Germany.
An alternative or additional possibility for 1991 is a version of Puccini's ''Turandot,'' by the Folksoperin of Stockholm, which Mr. Lichtenstein says is theatrically original and which Mr. Epstein opposed as musically inadequate.
 
New Version of Rameau Work
For 1991 or 1992, Mr. Lichtenstein would like to bring in a new William Christie production, staged by Alfredo Arias, of Rameau's lavish opera-ballet, ''Les Indes Galantes,'' scheduled for its first performances this month at the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France.
Other plans, or hopes, include a Wilson staging of Wagner's ''Parsifal,'' which will be first seen in Hamburg next season and which is already set for Houston in 1992. That would be for the spring of 1992 or 1993 in Brooklyn, with a hybrid Hamburg-Houston cast and Dennis Russell Davies conducting the Brooklyn Philharmonic.
Projects under consideration also include a reworking of a Colin Graham production of Berlioz's ''Beatrice et Benedict,'' seen originally in St. Louis; a Peter Stein/Pierre Boulez production of Debussy's ''Pelleas et Melisande,'' scheduled for the Welch National Opera; a possible Beethoven ''Fidelio'' co-production with Bonn, where Mr. Davies is the city's music director, staged by Mr. Sellars; the Chicago Lyric Opera production of William Bolcom's forthcoming opera, ''McTeague,'' staged by Robert Altman, the film director, and conducted by Mr. Davies, and a zarzuela, or Spanish operetta, that Peter Brook is planning for Spain and Paris in 1992.
 
Budget Gap of $700,000
Mr. Lichtenstein's budget for a three-opera season is $2.3 million, with $600,000 already in hand and an expected box office of $1 million. He says he should be able to close the remaining $700,000 gap without too much trouble.
The main loss for the future would seem to be much hope for new opera productions conceived in Brooklyn. That is partly a matter of economics. But Mr. Epstein, when he resigned, protested strongly that the academy's staff was insufficiently professional in operatic matters to undertake such ambitious ventures.
Although Mr. Lichtenstein is aware of economic realities, he defends his staff's administrative and fund-raising abilities. He also argues that he will still be able to fulfill his mandate through imaginative imports.
''I have no pride of authorship, in terms of doing something first,'' he said. ''The important thing is for significant work to be seen in New York.''

Companies
Forstmann Little agreed to buy General Instrument, a leading supplier to the cable TV industry, for $44.50 a share, or $1.6 billion. The buyout is Forstmann Little's second this year, after nearly two years in which it did not complete a single deal. [Page D1.] 
Ralph Ingersoll left the newspaper business in the U.S. for Europe. He acquired newspapers aggressively in this country over the past decade but has been under mounting financial pressure. [D1.]
Philips will take a $1.44 billion charge against earnings and eliminate about 10,000 jobs in Europe as part of an effort to revive its loss-ridden computer and electronic-components divisions. [D1.]
Lotus sued two California software companies, Borland International and the Santa Cruz Operation, accusing them of copyright infringement. [D1.]
Ratners Group will acquire Kay Jewelers for about $410 million in stock, it announced in London. [D4.]
Southland filed with the S.E.C. to revise the terms of its exchange offer to restructure its outstanding public debt. [D13.]

A slowdown has gripped Southern California as its aerospace industry tries to adjust to a less militaristic world. [A1.]

The Economy
The Government will hold an international auction in late September, via satellite, for properties worth more than $1 million each that were acquired from insolvent savings and loans, Administration officials said. [D5.]
The nation's economy continued to expand in June for the third straight month, according to a report by the National Association of Purchasing Management. [D5.]
The construction industry remained in a slump in May as spending dropped 0.4 percent for its second straight monthly decline, the Government said. [D5.]

HEADLINE: Group Tries to Think Like the Fed

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOLEDO, Ohio, July 2

 BODY:
As the Federal Reserve's top policy makers met today in Washington, 31 business people and economic analysts convened at the grand old Toledo Club to imitate - and thereby fathom immediately - the thinking of the people who determine the nation's interest rates and availability of money.
This is the Parallel Fed, a five-year-old exercise in experimental economics that focuses on monetary policy. This day the Toledo group concludes that the Federal Reserve's powerful policy group, the Open Market Committee, is likely to tilt toward an easing of policy. If so, it would be the Fed's first move to actively lower rates since just before Christmas. 
 
'Prepared to Follow'
The official Fed, its emulators declared in a statement, will ''maintain the current degree of restraint on bank reserves, but lean toward greater ease if further signs of economic weakness begin to appear.'' The Fed will ''be prepared to follow market interest rates down with the Federal funds rate if market rates continue this trend,'' the statement added.
The Federal funds rate is the interest banks charge each other on overnight loans and is the principal benchmark for short-term interest rates in general. The Fed can strongly influence the funds rate by increasing or decreasing the amount of money that banks have available to lend above their required reserves.
Both groups meet on the same day eight times a year - the official Fed session this time continues into a second day on Tuesday - but the Open Market Committee's decisions are not scheduled to be disclosed until late August.
The Parallel Fed's record appears to be enviable. It correctly predicted in December, for example, that the Fed had decided to relax monetary policy, though it did not come quite as soon as the Toledo group expected.
This means that when William J. Hudson, a business consultant in suburban Maumee, Ohio, and his Parallel Fed group have done a good job of putting themselves in the shoes of the 19 men and women meeting on Constitution Avenue, they and their customers gain a decided edge in business and in financial markets.
What sets the Parallel Fed apart from the vast army of Fed watchers is its rigorous effort to simulate the actual meetings of the Open Market Committee. That includes not only meeting on the same day but also trying for a similar diversity of viewpoints and generating what is hoped to be similar group dynamics, or what Mr. Hudson calls ''hubbub.'' Mr. Hudson runs the group with partners John F. Minor and Jonathan Harsch.
Unlike the Shadow Open Market Committee, a long-established group, the Parallel Fed shuns prescriptions of what the Open Market Committee should do and concentrates entirely on divining what it will do. The shadow committee has a strong academic representation and is oriented toward a monetarist ideology, which says the amount of readily available cash mainly determines economic activity.
Mr. Hudson, a 6-foot 10-inch agricultural specialist and economist, started the Parallel Fed in 1985 while working for the Andersons Investment Services Corporation, a privately held Ohio company involved in grain and other businesses.
 
Wanted to 'Empathize'
''I wondered if I could combine economic fundamentals with a reading of the so-called pulse in some kind of live setting which would parallel the Fed and which would give participants both a learning experience and a leg up on their own business competitors,'' Mr. Hudson said. He added that he wanted to ''empathize with the charter and roles of appointed officials, as opposed to criticizing them from a remote and comfortable distance.''
Mr. Hudson acts as chairman for the meetings but he does not imagine himself to be Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, nor do any other Parallel Fed members play the roles of individual Fed governors and regional bank presidents that sit on the Open Market Committee.
''That would make the thing too complex,'' said Mr. Minor, who acts as vice chairman and whose economic analysis seeks to replicate that of the Fed's large and perhaps unparalleled research staff. Attempts at psycho-economics would only ''get you off track,'' he contended.
Still, group members say they learned some lessons. One is that the real Fed thinks more like bankers than like business executives and seems to have delayed its December 1989 easing by a few weeks to help the banking system shore up its profits before having to cut interest rates.
Another is that Mr. Greenspan is not so quick as Paul A. Volcker, his predecessor, to shift policy. The Parallel Fed has also learned not to rely too much on the latest economic figures because they are so frequently revised.
At today's session, which ran slightly longer than the usual one and a half hours, were people from Marathon Oil, Toledo Stamping, Chrysler, Owens Corning Fiberglas and the brokerage house of Prescott, Ball & Turben. They offered the perspective of their various industries as well as anecdotal nuggets like a report of a conversation with a salesman of corrugated cartons who said orders were sagging and he was under strong pressure ''to try to drum up new business.''
 
Seen as a Harbinger
That statement was regarded as a harbinger of general economic conditions because so many goods are shipped in cardboard cartons.
But with no part of the economy really vigorous and some, like consumer spending and construction, in decline, there was little doubt among Parallel Fed participants today that their Washington counterparts would decide that an easing of monetary policy was in sight.
But they do not think such a move is imminent and President Bush's indication last week that he would accept higher taxes was not thought likely to have impressed the makers of monetary policy in Washington.
While the Fed's tools are strong, they are relatively few and Mr. Greenspan seems to have a strong reluctance to move before absolutely necessary. ''They're probably going to be very cautious about easing now because when they do it,'' said Mr. Minor, ''they'll find themselves out of ammunition.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of the Parallel Fed met in Toledo, Ohio, yesterday about the same time the Federal Reserve's top policy makers were meeting in Washington. The Toledo group seeks to fathom the thinking of the people who determine U.S. interest rates and the availability of money. (Blake J. Discher for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Savings Debacle: How Safeguards Failed;
A Blend of Tragedy and Farce

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Behind the collapse of the nation's savings and loan industry is the story of how the public and private safeguards intended to insure the financial health and integrity of the savings system failed.
The professionals - accountants, appraisers, auditors, directors and Government examiners - manning the chain of accountability in the savings industry were overwhelmed by the sweeping deregulation of the 1980's and the changes it brought. Some were confused by the new rules, others were lulled into complacency by Federal insurance on deposits, and some were willing to approve questionable practices as long as they were paid handsomely.
American Savings and Loan of Stockton, Calif., was a case in point. According to Philip W. Maher, an appraiser at the California institution, the practices there during the mid-1980's at times seemed like scenes from a Peter Sellers comedy. 
For example, when its management guaranteed they had ''looked at'' the appraisals on loans, they meant they had seen the book shelves that held thousands of bound documents, not the actual appraisals, many of which were false or inflated, Mr. Maher said in a sworn court declaration. He had raised questions about the practices.
The cost of the slipshod and suspect work at American Savings has since become painfully apparent. In 1988, it was declared insolvent, the largest savings institution in the country to fail, and is expected to cost the Federal Government billions of dollars.
The breakdown of the industry's controls is a key reason why the savings crisis grew unchecked for years and why the bailout has become so expensive, costing the nation's taxpayers as much as $500 billion over the next three decades. The generous Federal insurance on savings deposits and Federal guarantees on mortgage-backed securities mean that the industry's troubles became the Government's problem.
Professionals stood at each checkpoint in the savings system, supposedly responsible for giving independent and expert advice. For example, appraisers were to provide unbiased estimates of property values; outside accountants were to scrutinize the financial statements of savings institutions; in-house auditors were to oversee a system of internal controls; state and Federal examiners were to evaluate a savings unit's safety and soundness. And outside directors' were to oversee, independently, an institution's managers.
Yet at the savings and loans that collapsed, experts increasingly see a common pattern.
''The breakdown of safeguards was pretty much across the board of those thrifts that were in trouble,'' said Fred E. Case, who retired recently from the graduate business school of the University of California at Los Angeles, where he was a professor of real estate.
William J. Crawford, who until recently was California's chief savings and loan regulator, traced the breakdown in standards in the industry to an uncritical acceptance - so much in fashion at the time - that regulation meant inefficiency and that free-market policies would work to everyone's benefit.
 
'Wasn't a Free Market'
''They all got caught up in this thing of the free market, but it wasn't a free market,'' Mr. Crawford said in an interview. ''The Government was insuring the deposits. It wasn't entrepreneurialism, it was high fliers operating with the public's money. There was no diligence.''
And sharp scrutiny seemed less pressing because the economy was booming. ''Nobody paid much attention, there was euphoria in the markets, everybody made a ton of money,'' said Frederick W. Wolf, the former assistant comptroller general of the General Accounting Office, who is now a partner at the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse.
 
The Decontrol
Broad Safeguards Were Abandoned
The deregulation of the savings industry allowed fundamental changes in the ownership and investment policies of these traditionally conservative institutions that help explain the industry's collapse. In essence, decades-old structural safeguards were abandoned in the rush to a free-market philosophy.
Until the 1980's liberalization, a savings and loan was required to have at least 400 shareholders, a rule intended to limit the influence of developers, who saw the institutions as ''milk cows,'' as Dr. Case put it. The directors of an institution, in theory, acted as a further check.
But in 1981, on the theory that banks enjoyed a similiar status, , the Federal Home Loan Bank Board permitted savings and loans to be owned by only one shareholder. The year after that the board provided further incentives for developers when it allowed owners to invest less of their own money and use real estate rather than cash as the basis for their investment.
By 1982, every dollar of capital -the real estate or cash contributions made by owners - was a license to raise $33 in federally insured deposits. Previously, Congress had raised the level of insured deposits to $100,000 from $40,000.
 
Mortgages Sold
The new, liberalized rules also made possible increasingly sophisticated and risky investments. In the mortgage-backed securities market, fueled by the expansion of other Federal guarantees, savings and loans sold off mortgages to Wall Street firms, freeing funds for more ambitious investments. The investment banks pooled the home mortgages and sold them as securities to investors, part of the 1980's trend of ''securitization.''
But as savings institutions increasingly pulled back from their traditional business of making long-term loans to home buyers, the links between borrowers and lenders were eroded. The dictum of ''know your borrower got lost,'' Mr. Crawford said.
The broad regulatory changes led to a subtle shift in the balance of power. For example, savings and loan directors, even those inclined to be independent-minded, did not understand the sophisticated new financial transactions well enough to question the wisdom of the more aggressive investment practices. So more power accrued to managers, many of whom had ties to developers or securities firms.
''If directors don't know about complicated instruments, they have to rely on financial data and reports from internal auditors and accountants,'' Mr. Crawford said.
''One of the best thrift safeguards is to have the internal auditor report to the board, but I found this lacking at most associations,'' said Dr. Case, who is co-author of a 1988 book, ''Where Deregulation Went Wrong,'' for the United States League of Savings Institutions.
 
The Breakdown
Auditors Cleared Ailing Institutions
The principal tool in determining whether a company is solvent or in trouble is the financial report, which must be scrutinized and approved by independent accountants. As the savings and loan crisis grew, all too frequently reports on ailing institutions failed to accurately portray their financial condition.
Last year the General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress, found that outside audits of 11 Texas savings institutions had reported a cumulative net worth of $44 million even though the savings and loans, at the time they were seized by the Government, had a total negative net worth of $1.5 billion.
In California, Mr. Crawford found a similiar situation; 29 of 31 insolvent savings and loans had clean audits before they were taken over by the Government.
The G.A.O. found the auditing problems significant enough to refer six unnamed firms to professional and regulatory agencies for possible disciplinary review. In addition, Federal regulators have sued a dozen accounting firms for savings auditing failures, including Coopers & Lybrand, Grant Thornton, Ernst & Young (the firm created by the merger of Arthur Young & Company with Ernst & Whinney), and Deloitte Touche (created by the merger of Deloitte Haskins & Sells and Touche Ross).
 
Some Cheerleaders
To be sure, some accounting firms steered clear of the savings and loan industry. Others raised so many questions that they lost clients. But in a echo of changes taking place in the industry, a significant number, Mr. Crawford said, became cheerleaders in their pursuit of clients.
''When I came into the business in 1974, the hero or king was the smartest, the most independent person, the one who could say no,'' said Thomas R. Bloom, the bank board's chief accountant in 1987 and 1988. Mr. Bloom, now a partner with Kenneth Leventhal & Company, added that ''by 1984 the salesman became the hero of the profession.''
Faulty appraisals also figured prominently in the savings crisis.
In December 1985, the House consumer and monetary affairs subcommittee found that virtually every failed savings and loan used appraisals to overvalue collateral and make bad real estate loans look secure. A report of the committee in 1986 found significant appraisal deficiencies in 800 out of 3,200 federally insured savings institutions.
''Faulty and fraudulent real estate appraisals,'' the report concluded, had ''contributed directly to the insolvency of hundreds of the nation's financial institutions and have helped cause billions of dollars of losses.''
 
The New Rules
Equity Created 'Out of Thin Air'
Many experts say that the real fault in savings and loan accounting lay not with the auditors but in the Federal accounting rules under which the industry operated.
In the early 1980's, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and Congress put into place a set of rules one Congressional committee found to be so permissive that it called them ''accounting gimmicks.'' Mr. Bloom, the former bank board accountant, said they ''masked the troubles in the industry.''
''They created equity out of thin air, with incredible rationalizations,'' said Donald J. Kirk, a professor of accounting at Columbia University's Graduate School of Business who was head of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, a private rule-making group, in the early 1980's.
One bank board rule, called loan loss deferral, allowed savings institutions to sell losing loans to Wall Street firms and write off the loss over the life of the loan rather than against that year's profits. This rule served to hide the growing financial problems of the industry and, according to Martin Mayer, a financial writer who is working on a book on the savings crisis, ''made the collapse of the industry inevitable.''
 
'We Need an Understanding'
When Federal regulators visited the accounting standards board to explain some of the Government's accounting changes, they were accompanied by a representative of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, another private group that provides guidance to the profession. Mr. Kirk remembers their joint message: ''The industry is in trouble, we need an understanding of the predicament.''
Mr. Kirk says that the incident showed that the accountants' institute was too sympathetic to the industry, which was a big client for many accounting firms.
The standards board opposed the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's accounting changes. The president of the accountants' institute told Congress last year that the profession had also raised some objections to the loan loss rule and other bank board changes.
Mr. Bloom is among those who question whether the institute has taken adequate disciplinary action against large accounting firms involved in questionable savings and loan audits. A spokesman for the institute said the case of the six accounting firms that the G.A.O. referred sixteen months ago for possible disciplinary action was still under review. Four of the cases have been deferred because of suits by the Government, he added.
One of those cases, said an accountant who asked not to be identified, involves the audit of the Western Savings Association in Dallas by Arthur Young, the firm that is now part of Ernst & Young. Last March, Federal regulators sued Ernst & Young for $560 million for failing to detect and report huge losses at the association, which was seized in 1986. The suit contends that the firm gave Western a clean bill of health in 1984 and 1985 when it had a negative net worth of $100 million and $200 million, respectively, in those two years.
Commenting on the suit, an Ernst & Young spokesman blamed regulators, for putting ''boxcar-sized numbers in the lawsuit to deflect the focus to the accounting profession of their own failure to regulate.''.
 
The Cutbacks
Rise in Examiners Was Rejected
While they do not exculpate the accounting firms, many experts note that the supervisory and examination staff of the bank board failed to keep up with either the complexity of the industry or the growth in the Government's deposit insurance liability.
In his book on the savings and loan scandal, ''The S&L Insurance Mess,'', published last year, Edward J. Kane, Reese Professor of Banking and Monetary Economics at Ohio State University, emphasized that in 1983 and 1984, precisely the years in which associations began taking riskier investments with insured deposits, the number of Federal Home Loan Bank Board examiners began to shrink. Between 1984 and 1986, Mr. Kane wrote, hundreds of savings institutions were not examined. Edwin J. Gray, the former chairman of the bank board, said in an interview that in 1984 he sought to increase the number of examiners but was told by White House budget officials that a rise was contrary to the Administration's deregulatory philosophy, even though the salaries of examiners are paid out of industry funds.
''The White House attitude that you do what the marketplace allows and we won't oversee you very strongly, that was a fundamental mistake,'' said Frederick D. Wolf, the G.A.O.'s assistant comptroller general until last year.
As for the states, which had responsibility for savings associations they chartered, they followed the Federal lead in relaxing regulations.
Yet the deregulation was coupled with huge increases in Federal guarantees for deposits and mortgage-backed securities, while the capital requirements for owners were reduced. These changes significantly altered the burden of risk in the industry.
''You had the socialization of loss, if there was a loss, and the privatization of profit, if there was profit,'' Mr. Crawford said.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 4, 1990, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the breakdown of safeguards in the savings and loan industry included one accounting firm erroneously in a list of firms that have been sued by the Government over their auditing of failed savings institutions. Coopers & Lybrand has not been sued by the Government. As auditor for a private financial company, the firm was sued by an Oklahoma savings and loan that did business with the financial company. The Government inherited this suit when it assumed control of the Oklahoma savings and loan.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
Most Want U.S. To Pay the Bill

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
A LARGE number of Americans say they would gladly exchange their health-care system for one in Canada, which is entirely financed by the Government.
Surveys by The Los Angeles Times in March, NBC last year and Louis Harris & Associates in 1988 all showed that majorities of at least 61 percent of those polled favored a comprehensive national health plan. In the Harris poll, respondents chose the Canadian way in preference to both the American approach and the British system of Government-controlled doctors and hospitals. The choice in The Los Angeles Times poll was between the American and Canadian systems only. 
Canadians go to their own doctors, who practice independently but are all in the system. All medical bills are paid with tax money.
The surveys worry employers and insurers. Many employers believe that higher taxes would outweigh their savings under a Canadian-style system (although American auto makers with plants in Canada have not found this to be so). And health insurers fear that their business would be decimated if the Government took over. But health-insurance experts say the Canadian system is not really the issue and that most Americans know little about either its strengths or its weaknesses.
''The issue is financial insecurity,'' said Robert J. Blendon, chairman of the Department of Health Policy and Management at the Harvard School of Public Health. Even people who have health insurance worry that their coverage may be cut back or eliminated and that they may be unable to afford medical care, he said in an interview. Americans pay 26 percent, on average, of their own health-care bills. At least 16 percent do not have either private or Government insurance.
''When a lot of people think about health care, they see a dollar sign, they see risk, they see catastrophic danger,'' said John Erb, a managing consultant in New York with Foster Higgins, an employee benefits consulting firm. In a new study of the public's feelings about health care, Dr. Blendon, along with Robert Leitman, a senior vice president with Harris; Ian Morrison, an economist with the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif., and Karen Donelan, a Harvard research associate, looked at 10 countries. They found that the degree of satisfaction with the system was highest in Canada, followed by the Netherlands, West Germany, France, Australia, Sweden, Japan, Britain and Italy. Satisfaction was lowest in the United States. The United States and South Africa are the only major industrial countries that do not have Government-paid health-care systems.
But the low approval rating and widespread preference for Canada's system did not mean that Americans were dissatisfied with their doctors and hospitals, or even that they believed national spending on health care was too high, the researchers said. ''Rather, this response indicates the high level of public frustration with our current health financing arrangements,'' the Blendon group said in Health Affairs, a quarterly journal.
Businesses of all sizes are also frustrated, said Karen Berg Brigham, health-care policy manager with the United States Chamber of Commerce. They have all been hit by rapidly growing health costs, and many small employers have had difficulty getting affordable coverage. In a survey last winter of 1,101 small-business executives for the Chamber of Commerce, 21 percent said the United States should adopt a Canadian-style system, while 56 percent opposed the idea and 23 percent were undecided.
But Ms. Brigham said the demonstration of interest in the survey should not be seen as an endorsement of Government health insurance. She noted that many foreign systems were largely financed by payroll taxes. ''This is of great concern to business, especially small businesses, she said. ''The payroll tax is one of their largest costs.'' ''The majority of employers would find their costs increasing under a Canadian system,'' said Mr. Erb of Foster Higgins. ''But for Rust Belt manufacturers with huge numbers of retirees who have expensive health-care needs, spreading the risk to the Government might lower an employer's costs.''
The health insurance industry has also found that people are concerned about losing their insurance, said Edward Neuschler, director of policy studies with the Health Insurance Association of America, a trade group. But in a survey last year for the insurers by the Roper Organization, the overwhelming percentage of respondents ''were pleased with their current coverage and benefits,'' he said. The insurers group has proposed changes in state laws and a privately financed reinsurance plan to make it easier for small-business employees to get and keep affordable coverage.
The Blendon article said the United States spent $2,051 per capita on health care in 1987, or 28 percent more than Canada, which was second with $1,483. Sweden was next, at $1,233; then France, $1,105; West Germany, $1,093, and the Netherlands, $1,041. Australia spent $939; Japan, $915; Italy, $841, and Britain, $758.
But the Canadians also have problems with health care. Costs are rising as rapidly there as in the United States, said Mr. Neuschler of the Health Insurance Association. And when Americans are told that Canadians often must wait for long periods for certain complicated operations, like a coronary bypass or hip replacement, ''they do not at all like the notion,'' he said. Indeed, Americans are largely uninformed about the Canadian health system, Dr. Blendon said. He added, ''If it weren't for the high costs in the U.S., the world would probably be discussing why Canada is so expensive.''

HEADLINE: Foreign Debt Of U.S. Rises

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
The United States sank deeper in debt in 1989, the Commerce Department reported today, as the nation's overall deficit with the rest of the world swelled by 25 percent, to $663.7 billion.
Until 1985, the year it became the world's biggest debtor nation, the United States was a creditor country, and as recently as 1983 had a surplus of $89 billion in its dealings with other countries. 
But at the end of 1989, United States assets abroad totaled $1.412 trillion, while foreigners owned assets in the United States worth $2.076 trillion.
At the end of 1988, United States -owned assets abroad were valued at $1.266 trillion while foreign assets in the United States were $1.797 trillion for a net United States debtor position of $531 billion.
The Commerce Department annual report indicated that foreign direct investment in the United States climbed by 22 percent, to $400.8 billion in 1989.
 
Investments abroad by the
United States also increased from 1988 levels, but by a smaller 12 percent, to $373.4 billion.
For the first time, the Commerce Department included a cautionary note with the report saying that there may be a ''misstatement'' of the size of the United States foreign debt.

HEADLINE: Global Auction Set for Some Savings Unit Assets

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
The Government will hold an international auction in late September, via satellite, for properties worth more than $1 million each that were acquired from insolvent savings and loan institutions, Administration officials said today.
The officials said that potential buyers from Japan, Britain and Canada had expressed the most interest in the properties.
''We think it will be a good way to move certain properties, and at a good price,'' said David C. Cooke, executive director of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which oversees the savings and loan bailout and will conduct the auction.
''If the Japanese are interested in real estate in Arizona, it's better than the Government carrying this property,'' he said in an interview. 
 
First of Its Kind
Foreign investors have bought such property in individual sales, but this will be the first international auction. It will involve 98 properties with a total assessed value of $341 million. Only commercial properties will be for sale, including hotels, motels, office buildings, ''strip'' shopping centers and ''maybe a golf course,'' said John Karlson, Resolution Trust's assistant director for real estate marketing.
The foreign auction centers will be in London, Tokyo and probably a Canadian city. ''If a European buyer is truly interested, he'll be able to go to London,'' Mr. Karlson said in an interview. Other cities may be added, he said, noting that ''with the satellite linkup, you can go anywhere.''
The auction will also be held in 8 to 10 American cities. It was previously announced that there would be a national auction. The auction will be conducted by the Auction Company of America, of Miami.
Foreign investors have already acquired some Resolution Trust properties, including the Hyatt Grand Champion Hotel in Indian Wells, Calif., which Japanese buyers acquired for $66 million.
The satellite presentation will include videotapes of the properties, Mr. Karlson said, and brochures will also be provided. But he said he expected that potential buyers would send representatives to inspect the properties. ''People don't buy real estate without looking at it,'' he said.
 
A Big Inventory
Resolution Trust has sold $2 billion worth of property, but still has an inventory of 35,908 properties with a book value of $14.9 billion. Though no specific list has been released, the agency's holdings include coal and uranium mines, ranches and pasture lands, 162 golf courses, oilfields, marinas and boat yards, athletic clubs, garages, parking lots and mobile home parks. Still, 84 percent of its total inventory is made up of residential properties, mainly in Texas.
The auction comes as public opinion polls indicate widespread concern about the acquisition of assets by foreigners. The Government reported last month that foreign investment rose to a record of $2 trillion last year, up 12 percent from 1988.
Supporters of foreign investment say it provides money to finance the Federal budget deficit and helps support the stock market, while providing jobs, management skills and technology.
Critics contend that the United States has become overly dependent on foreign capital, which could lead to an erosion of political and economic independence as decisions affecting Americans are increasingly made abroad.
 
A Congressman's Viewpoint
Representative Charles Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, a member of the House Banking Committee, called the international auction ''a two-edged sword.''
''On the one hand we want to maximize the amount of dollars that come into the Treasury, and sell the properties for the highest amount possible,'' Mr. Schumer said. ''In the past, the R.T.C. has not reached out to a wide-enough circle.
''On the other hand, it's a shame that because of the capital shortage and the low savings rate in America, many of these deals that will make someone money will go overseas.''

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Government Bond Gains Are Global

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
WITH economies less than exuberant in most parts of the world, the last three months provided the holders of international government bonds with the best performance since 1987.
According to the J. P. Morgan government bond index, all 11 government bond markets it follows had positive returns in the quarter, ranging in local currencies from a low of 1.34 percent in West Germany to a high of 5.16 percent in Italy. In the United States, the gain was 3.34 percent.
Those figures may provide scant comfort to money managers, since in some countries the second-quarter rallies failed to offset the first-quarter tumbles, which came amid fears of inflation in Europe and Japan. 
''Interest rates had begun to rise in the first quarter quite a lot, and they began to fall in the second quarter,'' said Victor S. Filatov, the head of J. P. Morgan's bond index group. ''That's true in all markets, except the Netherlands and Germany.''
To a certain extent, the Federal Reserve gets some of the credit for the rally. As the United States reported a succession of statistics showing that the economy was slowing, the perception grew that the Fed was likely to ease. That was important both for pushing United States rates down and for creating confidence that foreign central banks would not have to raise rates further to keep them competitive.
Over all, the global government bond market saw a gain of 3.29 percent in the second quarter, in local currency, and of 4.66 percent in dollars. The latter figure reflects the fact that the dollar declined during the period against every major currency.
Those total-return figures include the gain, or loss, on government bond prices, plus interest payments. In Germany, the positive return reflected the fact that prices did not fall far enough to offset the interest payments.
The last time global bond markets did better, on a dollar basis, was in the final three months of 1987, when central banks around the world eased policies dramatically in the wake of the October 1987 crash. Then, the global government bond market recorded a return of 11.97 percent in the quarter, according to J. P. Morgan.
The return figures from country to country are not strictly comparable, since they are based on the actual government bonds outstanding. In the United States and Britain, there is a greater reliance on long-term bonds, which are much more volatile than short-term ones. Britain, with an average maturity of outstanding bonds of 8.7 years, is the most volatile bond market, while Italy, with an average maturity of just 3.3 years, has shown the least volatility, according to the J. P. Morgan figures.
Because the bonds being measured are government issues, where there is no risk of default, the bonds can benefit from a slowing economy that might raise questions of credit quality for some corporate issuers. Keith Johnson, the co-head of economic research for J. P. Morgan, said evidence of a possible slowdown of economic growth in Europe aided some bond markets in the second quarter.
The worldwide rally in government bonds played a role in the improving stock market performances around the world during the quarter. But to the extent that bond market rallies simply reflect weak economies, they can also have negative implications for corporate profits.
As if to emphasize that the dangers of slow growth still affect companies, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that only 65 companies announced dividend increases in June, down from 88 in the same month of 1989 and the lowest for any month since November 1971, when 54 companies announced increases.
 
Shearson's 'Uncommon Values'
More evidence that retail investors are in a mood to buy stocks was provided yesterday when Shearson Lehman Hutton released its latest list of ''uncommon values.''
Shearson has been putting out such lists, with 10 stocks, on the first trading day of July for 42 years. Of the 10 on this year's list, six rose more than $1. Fred Fraenkel, Shearson's research director, said that it was too early to tell just how much volume the list had generated, but that, over all, it was clear that ''retail investors are buying more stocks than they were a year ago.''
A year ago, when Shearson put out its last list, the reaction was subdued in the extreme. Then only one of that year's 10, Marriott, gained $1 on the first day. As it happened, Marriott was the worst of the 10 over the next year, falling 36 percent. That did not keep the list from rising 16 percent, compared with 12.6 percent for the S.&P. 500. The star was Amgen, which rose 80 percent. The picks that rose at least $1 yesterday were Acuson, Adobe Systems, Cable & Wireless, Contel, Johnson & Johnson and Unum. The three with smaller gains were Interpublic Group, Newell and Nord Resources. Schlumberger, down 37.5 cents, was the only loser on the list.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Encouraging Environment Expertise

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
A PROFESSOR at Tufts University, Anthony D. Cortese, thinks he is one of a kind - the first at any university to hold the title of dean of environmental programs.
His main task is to incorporate environmental awareness and responsibility into every part of the curriculum through the newly established Environmental Literacy Institute.
In an interview in New York recently, he said, ''My job now is to develop academic programs in all schools at Tufts to turn out the experts we need in engineering, science, governmental policy and management.'' Tufts has 7,800 students in its various schools, which encompass engineering, liberal arts, medicine, dentistry, veterinary medicine, nutrition and international diplomacy. 
Just a few miles from Boston, in Medford, Mass., Tufts has well-known neighors like Harvard University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Boston College, the University of Massachusetts, Boston University and Northeastern University. None has an environmental dean nor such a comprehensive environmental program. The impetus for it came from Jean Mayer, a leading nutritionist who is the president of Tufts.
Allied-Signal Inc. has provided $150,000 to sustain the program for two years, and Dr. Cortese said last week that the Environmental Protection Agency had made a similar grant.
Dr. Cortese said of the program that ''it is a matter of re-educating the faculty about the environment.'' In turn, he added, they are expected to educate the students at Tufts.
At a recent seminar, Dr. Cortese provided 24 faculty members selected from the various Tufts schools and departments with a reading list, reprints of articles and copies of talks about adding environmental knowledge to their classes.
Each faculty member receives $2,000 for participating in the program, which calls for them to do creative course revisions this summer to include environmental issues. They will present revised curriculums to the faculty and to the dean at the end of the summer. Then, in the fall, they will try out the new course material on the students.
''We have asked the professors to write articles about the revisions to be published in scholarly journals in their individual fields to inspire others,'' Dr. Cortese said, ''It is critical that we act now,'' he said, explaining: ''The population of the world will double in the next 40 years, and industrial output will increase by three or four times from today's level. Degradation that will occur in the environment will be enormous. My feeling is that the people who will be making decisions about the environment are graduating from colleges today. So they need teachers who can educate them and stress the connection between their studies and the environment.''
While environmental connections appear logical in courses like economics, accounting, science, engineering and medicine, they can also be relevant in liberal arts courses, including English literature and history, Dr. Cortese said. ''Why not include Henry David Thoreau's 'Walden' and Rachel Carson's 'The Silent Spring' in literature courses?'' he asked.
As for ancient history, he said that a cause of the decline of the Roman Empire was the wide use of lead water pipes, as well as lead goblets for wine. Acid from the wine caused lead to leach out, and lead poisoning can be debilitating and lethal.
In modern history, he pointed out, there was the sad example of the Aral Sea, in the Soviet Union, which used to be the world's fourth-largest inland sea. In recent years, its water has been overused to irrigate cotton crops. ''In 35 years,'' he said, ''the Aral has beeen reduced to the sixth-largest inland sea in the world. It has lost 40 feet in depth, and the commercial fishing industry has gone, along with 60,000 jobs associated with fishing.''
With better environmental knowledge, he said, such episodes could have been prevented.
As for other colleges and schools organizing a center like his, Dr. Cortese said that ''it will not be cost effective.'' So once the Tufts faculty has been trained, the program will be offered to professors at other universities, to high school teachers and to representatives of developing nations.
Dr. Cortese, who received both a bachelor's degree in civil engineering and a master's degree in environmental engineering from Tufts, later earned a doctorate in environmental science from Harvard University's School of Public Health in 1976.
Before he joined Tufts as a professor of environmental affairs in 1984 at Dr. Mayer's request to organize a center for environmental management, he served for six years as commissioner of the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection. Before that he was with the Environmental Protection Agency in Washington. In both posts he learned much about industrial polluters.

HEADLINE: Toyota Leads Quality Survey

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 2

 BODY:
The Toyota Motor Corporation's Cressida sedan had the lowest number of problems reported by car owners in an influential survey of quality conducted each year by J. D. Power & Associates.
Toyota dominated the survey results, which were released today by the automotive market research firm in Westlake Village, Calif. The company had Corolla, Camry and Lexus models also listed in the top 10.
The survey enumerates the problems new-car customers report within the first three months of ownership. Consumer experience in the first few months after purchasing a new car ''sets the stage for owner satisfaction,'' said David E. Whiteside, publisher of the report.
Two Mercedes-Benz models were in the top 10, as were two cars made by the Nissan Motor Company.
The only American car listed among the 10 most trouble-free was the Buick LeSabre, made by the General Motors Corporation, which ranked sixth this year, down from second place a year ago.
A compact pickup truck made by the Mazda Motor Corporation led the light-truck category, but American-made vehicles fared better in this group. The Ford Motor Company's Ranger pickup and Bronco II sport utility vehicle ranked No. 5 and No. 9, respectively, while Chevrolet's S-10 pickup ranked No. 8.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Mark and the Pound Advance Against the Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The mark rose in foreign exchange markets yesterday, the first day of trading after the monetary union in East and West Germany over the weekend. Demand for the British pound also remained strong.
The support for the mark and pound put pressure on the dollar, which declined to levels not seen since 1988 against those currencies, traders said. Gold prices rose. Timothy Burton, a trader for the Harris Trust and Company in Chicago, said dealers were buying marks and sterling at the expense of the dollar. 
He said the smooth distribution of marks to East Germans, starting on Sunday, was helping the mark, while sterling was supported by relatively high British interest rates and increased speculation that Britain would soon be joining the European Monetary System.
The dollar traded at 1.6515 German marks in New York, down from 1.66065, and at 1.6580 marks in Europe, down from 1.6653. The last time it traded at those levels was in early 1988, Mr. Burton said.
In London, the pound was at $1.7635, up from $1.7450 late Friday. A pound fetched $1.7715 in New York - an 18-month high, Mr. Burton said - up from $1.7490 Friday.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 151.40 yen, down 1.45 yen from the finish last Friday. It traded at 151.25 yen in London, and at 150.91 yen in New York, down from 152.10 yen Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.3965 Swiss francs, down from 1.4150; 5.5450 French francs, down from 5.5795; 1,212.75 Italian lire, down from 1,219.75, and 1.16175 Canadian dollars, down from 1.16335.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Friday, were: 1.4030 Swiss francs, down from 1.4155; 5.5635 French francs, down from 5.5945; 1.8650 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8737; 1,217.00 Italian lire, down from 1,222.50, and 1.1616 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1657.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery traded at $358.80 an ounce, up 90 cents from late Friday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold of $357.85, which was up 35 cents.
Gold traded in London at $357.55, up from $353.25 bid late Friday. The Zurich price was $357.80, up from $352.00 late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold traded at $357.15, up $5.
Silver prices also strengthened. On the Comex in New York, silver for current delivery traded at $4.935 an ounce, up from $4.887 Friday. Silver rose in London to $4.95 from $4.84.

HEADLINE: MANDELA HOPEFUL ON BRITISH TALKS

BYLINE: By SHEILA RULE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 3

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela expressed optimism today about the prospects of narrowing his differences with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher over economic sanctions against South Africa, and backed off from comments that had suggested that Britain should negotiate with the Irish Republican Army.
On the first day of a two-day official visit, Mr. Mandela met Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd for lunch to discuss the prospects for resolution of South Africa's racial conflict. After the meeting, Mr. Hurd told reporters that he had emphasized to Mr. Mandela that Britain was ''anxious to do everything we could to help without interfering in South Africa's affairs.''
Mr. Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, said, ''I stressed the historical ties between Britain and South Africa and expressed the hope that these ties would be strengthened.'' 
 
A Strenuous Tour
The congress leader, nearing the end of a strenuous tour that has covered Western Europe and the United States, said he was ''optimistic'' about his talks with Mrs. Thatcher, scheduled for Wednesday. They are expected to discuss at least two issues - the congress's refusal to renounce the use of force against the Government and the continuation of international economic sanctions against South Africa, backed by the congress as a means to press the Government to end apartheid.
Britain has condemned the use of violence and been criticized by Mr. Mandela for easing some sanctions, including a ban on new investment in South Africa, in the belief that President F. W. de Klerk should be encouraged to reach a settlement.
Mr. Mandela suggested that there was a possibility of narrowing the gap between the two positions and said: ''There are some points of difference. That does not worry me.'' Controversy Over I.R.A.
But the issue of economic pressure was overshadowed today by the controversy surrounding remarks Mr. Mandela made in Dublin on Monday that appeared to suggest that Britain should open unconditional talks with the Irish Republican Army, which has been trying to force Britain out of Northern Ireland. Britain has said that it would not consider talks until the group lays down its weapons.
In reply to an I.R.A. question at a news conference, Mr. Mandela said: ''People are slaughtering one another when they could sit down and address the problems in a peaceful manner.''
Mr. Mandela said later that he had been misinterpreted after criticism from all of Britain's main political parties and both liberal and conservative newspapers. In a meeting today with 150 British Members of Parliament, he insisted that he had been speaking about conflict in general and not specifically about Northern Ireland.
 
$7 Million Raised in U.S.
By The Associated Press
Nelson Mandela raised more than $7 million for the African National Congress in his eight-city tour of the United States, according to figures provided by tour organizers.
Organizers said most of the cash should reach the congress because many meeting places and equipment used by the tour were donated or supplied at a discount. Expenses have not been subtracted from the income.
In Boston, planners raised about half their $1 million goal. But in New York, fund raisers said between $1.75 million and $2 million had been raised, about double their goal.
In Atlanta, projections were for roughly $400,000, while about $300,000 was raised in the Miami area. In Washington, about $150,000 was raised. Income in Detroit was estimated at $1.4 million, and preliminary numbers from Los Angeles were $1.7 million and from Oakland, Calif., $900,000.
The proceeds are to be deposited in a fund for the congress controlled by the American directors of the tour, led by Roger Wilkins, a professor at George Mason University and the trip's chief planner. The money will be used to finance 14 offices in South Africa for the African National Congress, a spokeswoman said. The remainder will go toward housing and education.

HEADLINE: Liberian Rebels Close In on City Center

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
Liberian rebel forces were reported to be advancing slowly toward downtown Monrovia from the suburbs of the Liberian capital today in street-to-street fighting against Government forces. A senior Bush Administration official said the Liberian President, Samuel K. Doe, was ''in deep trouble right now.''
''The heavy fighting is continuing,'' said Herman J. Cohen, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, who is in contact with the United States Embassy in Liberia. ''Shooting is going on near the St. Paul River Bridge, showing that the fighting is getting into Monrovia.'' 
Mr. Cohen would not predict when Mr. Doe might fall or choose to accept an American offer to help him find sanctuary outside the country, but he said ''the end game is near.''
The National Patriotic Front guerrillas led by Charles Taylor, a former official in the Doe Government, began their assault on the capital early Monday. Attacking from the east and northwest, the guerrillas were reported to have cut off the three major exit roads. The reports could not be confirmed. Most communications links from the capital have been cut since early Monday, making reports from the battle zone sketchy and sporadic.
 
Resistance Stiffens a Bit
Mr. Cohen said the guerrillas were able to advance as quickly as they have in the past few weeks because ''the size of the army has shrunk due to desertions.'' But he said that as the rebels move closer to the heart of the capital and encounter Mr. Doe's elite units, Government resistance is beginning to stiffen.
An official acknowledged that it is possible that the troops, who are mostly members of the Krahn and Mandingo tribes, are fighting better because they fear retribution from the rebels, who are mostly Gio and Mano tribesmen. The seven-month civil war has accentuated ethnic hostilities.
Another Administration official said the Government could last ''days, not weeks.'' But he stressed that it was not certain that Mr. Taylor would take power.
''We have reports of internecine fighting in Taylor's political wing,'' the official said. ''There are five guys going around Monrovia saying they are in charge.''
Mr. Cohen said the Bush Administration favors a diplomatic initiative by the Economic Community of West African States, which has a representative in Monrovia trying to restart peace talks that broke down last month. The mediator has proposed an interim government, excluding both Mr. Doe and Mr. Taylor, to organize elections as soon as possible.
 
Doe Aides Seek His Removal
Bush Administrations officials said that Vice President Harry Moniba and three senior legislators met with American diplomats at the United States Embassy on Mondy to discuss ways of removing Mr. Doe, but that the talks did not continue today. Mr. Doe has refused to resign.
Reuters reported from Monrovia today that Mr. Doe had agreed in principle to resign if his safety and that of his Krahn tribe could be assured. Mr. Doe reportedly made his decision after Mr. Moniba and other ranking officials urged him to step down.
But a State Department official who monitors Liberia said: ''We can't confirm that. We have heard his cronies say that but that is second- or third-hand stuff.''
Four American warships carrying 2,500 sailors and Marines continue to ply waters off Liberia's coast in case President Bush decides to evacuate the remaining 800 American residents or protect American installations.
An Administration official today indicated that there was a one-in-four chance the Marines would land, a lower estimate than he gave a few weeks ago.

HEADLINE: Lima Journal;
What's Hawked at Curbside? Dolares

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
With his white jogging shoes padding on the pavement, Fernando Pantigoso loped alongside a slowing car and offered the day's special - the United States dollar at 65,000 intis.
''Dolares, dolares,'' he said. It was a June day, and he was flashing the tools of his trade - a pocket calculator and a stack of bills.
Traffic intersections in many third-world cities offer an ambulatory bazaar of goods ranging from coat hangers to papayas. In Lima, the curbside service offers dollars. 
Much of the currency constantly flashing through hands here left the United States to pay for cocaine shipments from Colombia and Peru. Without this steady infusion of drug money - about $1 billion a year - the inti would probably trade at half its street-market value.
 
Fear of Holding Intis
With the inti's value shrinking by 1 percent a day, Peru's economy has spawned a new profession - thousands of so-called cambistas offering instant exchange.
The trade is profitable. Three years ago, Mr. Pantigoso left his $8-a-week job in a furniture factory to join his wife and three brothers working the same street corner in Miraflores. Today, on a good 12-hour day, Mr. Pantigoso clears $20 profit.
Fueling the constant trading is a fear of holding intis for even an hour longer than needed.
''In the final stage of hyperinflation, people reject the local currency,'' said an American economist here. He noted that by the time Alan Garcia steps down from Peru's presidency on July 28, prices will have gone up 1 million percent during his five-year tenure. #2 Streets, 1 Cambista ''By law, the inti is the means of exchange,'' the economist said. ''But people only keep enough intis to cover daily transactions.''
So in a ritual often strange to newcomers, young men and women can be seen throughout Peru standing on street corners, flashing pocket calculators in the faces of passers-by.
''I was in Churin,'' Lucho Davila Mendoza, another cambista here, said of a hamlet in the Andean foothills. ''There were two streets and one cambista.''
With a blue-jean pack filled with money strapped securely over his chest, Mr. Davila works the same street corner with Mr. Pantigosoa in the affluent Miraflores neighborhood. Business is so good that 12 cambistas now work the corner - double the number two years ago.
 
Business Cards, Steady Clients
The corner fruit-and-candy vendor recently started trading dollars. The children peddling American cigarettes and cartons of cheap Chilean wine hope to move up to dollars when they grow up.
Reflecting the new stability of inflationary instability, Mr. Davila has started handing regular customers a salmon-pink business card. It is printed with two dollar signs, his street-corner address and his radio paging telephone number.
''I have clients on all these floors,'' Mr. Davila said, waving expansively to high-rise office buildings rising above heavily trafficked Jose Pardo Avenue.
Mr. Davila, a former clothing salesman, works across the street from the nominal competition - the local branch of a state bank, Banco de la Nacion.
''The state workers cash their paychecks, and then come straight across the street,'' he said between making sidewalk trades. ''During the week, people exchange what they need for the day - $20 for groceries, $10 for the movies.'' #5-Million Inti Notes No one knows how many dollars flow through the cambistas' hands. The best guess is that they change a large part of the annual $1 billion in drug money that goes through Peru, with the money coming directly to the capital from the chief coca-leaf growing area in the Upper Huallaga Valley.
People involved in the street practice say that while the dollar is freely convertible here, the street trading is illegal because the cambistas pay no taxes. At the outset of the Garcia Government in July 1985, they say, some arrests were made. But now the practice is tolerated. Street changers say their biggest fear is not the police but holdup men.
Seven floors above the street, Angel Vicente Sebastianelli, one of Mr. Davila's regular customers, said in an interview in his office, ''I never keep intis around.''
''Tomorrow, the inti is worthless,'' said Mr. Sebastianelli, a printing executive. ''One of my nephews has papered his bedroom wall with 10-inti notes.''
Indeed, inflation has made Peru a land of impoverished millionaires.
El Comercio, a local newspaper that disapproves of Mr. Garcia's habit of printing money to paper over budget shortfalls, takes morbid delight in publishing the sordid details of each monetary issue.
According to the newspaper, 800 billion intis in 100,000-inti notes arrived here in early June from a Mexican printing press.
With a 5-million note expected here by the end of August, the cambistas admit that inflation may be getting out of hand.
''These calculators only show eight digits,'' Mr. Davila said. ''I may have to buy a 10-digit calculator.
In early June Peruvians elected a new President, Alberto Fujimori. During the campaign, Mr. Fujimori vowed to create ''a hard currency that has parity with the North American dollar.''
On the Miraflores street corner, several cambistas said they voted for Mr. Fujimori. But they were confident that he will not spoil business.
''Politicians make promises, promises,'' Mr. Pantigoso said, sipping an apple juice in a neighborhood grocery store. ''They don't fulfill them.''

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
German Unity by Year's End Now Almost Certain

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, July 2

 BODY:
The East German Government's decision to call for all-German elections on Dec. 2 now makes it almost certain that Germany will be reunited by the end of this year, West German Government officials say.
In the six weeks since Chancellor Helmut Kohl came out in favor of turning West Germany's federal elections into an all-German poll, the idea has steadily gained ground in both Germanys and among all major parties.
Finally on Monday night, on the day after economic union went into effect, the East German governing coalition formally agreed to seek all-German elections on Dec. 2.
 
Completing Reunification
A democratic national election would be the first since 1932, and it would complete the process of reunification that began with the opening of the Berlin wall on Nov. 9 and took a major step forward on Sunday with the merging of the German currencies and economies. 
The East German Government also agreed to reconstitute the states that existed before Communist rule and to hold state elections on Oct. 14. The re-establishment of the five former states is necessary to meet the condition for joining West Germany under Article 23 of the West German Constitution. The article empowers any German state to join the Federal Republic.
East Germany's proposal is certain to be welcomed by the West German coalition when the coalition and the Cabinet Committee on German Unity meet on Wednesday, a senior official in Mr. Kohl's Government said. Bonn has made clear its preference for all-German voting in December, but the formal proposal had to come from East Berlin, since it is East Germany that must initiate the process of joining the West.
Under the options now being considered, the Germanys would formally unite either just before or immediately after the election. The West German Constitution calls for a government to be formed within 30 days after an elections, so if the election is held on Dec. 2, a new government will most likely be in place by the New Year.
 
First Session by Christmas
Volker Ruhe, the secretary general of the Christian Democratic party in Bonn, said he hoped that the first all-German Parliament would be convened by Christmas.
The East German Government set two conditions to the election. One was that the two Germanys agree on a second treaty harmonizing the two states' political institutions and laws, including those affecting property rights. The first state treaty was the one that went into effect on Sunday, merging the economies of the two Germanys. Officials in East Berlin said talks on the second treaty would start on Friday.
The second condition was that the Germanys reach agreement with the four World War II Allies - the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France - on the international and security aspects of German unification. The Allies are in the process of negotiating with the two Germanys in the so-called ''two plus four'' talks.
The central problem has been the Soviet Union's resistance to ceding the control it has had over East Germany without some compensation for the economic and security loss.
One issue has been Moscow's reluctance to let a united Germany stay in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and Moscow's insistence for a limit on German military power.
 
Size of United Army Discussed
Mr. Kohl met today with his Foreign and Defense Ministers, Hans-Dietrich Genscher and Gerhard Stoltenberg, to discuss the size of an all-German army. The combined strength of the military in the two Germanys is now about 600,000 men, and figures for the future have ranged from the 200,000 proposed by Moscow to the 400,000 suggested by Mr. Stoltenberg.
Participants in the ''two plus four'' talks have said they expect to reach an agreement in time to present it to the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe for endorsement in November. That would clear any foreign obstacles to unity in December.
A spokesman for the East German Government also reported today that the coalition had agreed to set a 5 percent hurdle for the all-German elections. That would match the West German voting rule under which only parties that receive 5 percent or more of the vote would gain representation in Parliament.
The issue has been a major source of contention. East German rules set a 3 percent threshhold, and the difference could determine whether the reformed Communist party, the Party of Democratic Socialism, and the right-wing German Social Union - a sister party of the Bavarian Christian Social Union - enter the all-German Parliament. Both parties could probably take 3 percent of the East German vote, but neither is likely to take 5 percent of an all-German vote.
 
Split in Kohl's Coalition
The question split Mr. Kohl's coalition, since the Christian Social members wanted to keep the 3 percent limit. All other parties but the Communists wanted the 5 percent limit, each for a different reason.
Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats have no interest in giving the Christian Social Union a foothold in East Germany.
On the left, the Social Democrats have sought a 5 percent hurdle to keep the Communists from siphoning seats away from them.
The liberal Free Democrats of Mr. Genscher have also wanted the higher hurdle to insure that smaller parties do not dilute the liberals' longstanding role as the centrist force without which neither of the major parties can form a majority in Parliament.
The Party of Democratic Socialism predictably assailed the December date, arguing that it had been ''dictated by Bonn'' and would make unity a ''premature birth.''

The unification between the East and West has made new cars immediately available to East German buyers, who formerly had to wait several years for cars. (Agence France-Presse)
