HEADLINE: American Freed in Ecuador Savors Home and the Town That Saved Him

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., July 3

 BODY:
After 61 days in captivity in the Colombian jungle, Scott Heimdal has returned to the Illinois city that passed collection plates and held bake sales to raise $60,000 to free him.
In the wee hours this morning at his parents' home, shortly after his arrival at the Peoria airport, Mr. Heimdal, a mining worker who will turn 28 on Thursday, spoke calmly of his ordeal. A Budweiser in one hand and a Marlboro in the other, he told of being constantly on the move, of eating monkey and armadillo and of living in daily fear of being caught in the crossfire between his guerrilla captors and the Colombian army.
He showed his family the small machete the guerrillas gave him to cut through the jungle and the spoon he chiseled out of root because the half-dozen guerrillas guarding him had only one spoon among them. And he recalled the moment he was taken captive on a river on the Ecuador-Colombia border, when the guerrillas killed the paddler of his canoe and wounded another man in the party. 
 
Delight in a 'Gringo'
''Are you a gringo?'' Mr. Heimdal recalled one guerrilla's asking him at gunpoint in Spanish.
When Mr. Heimdal replied, ''Yes, I am,'' he said the guerrilla said, ''Good, then you're kidnapped.''
''I wasn't afraid,'' Mr. Heimdal said last night. ''I wasn't nervous. I just couldn't believe I was being kidnapped.''
He said the guerrillas, from a Maoist Colombian group known as the P.F.L., treated him well. They even got him an antifungal cream for trench foot, for which he was seeking medical treatment when his canoe was seized. They expressed sorrow that their action had hurt his family and told him they were just following orders.
Before his captors released him to the Ecuadorean national police, they gave Mr. Heimdal what he called a ''going-away party,'' singing revolutionary songs and giving him Colombian pesos worth $400.
Mr. Heimdal said he had no idea that his hometown had scrambled to rescue him.
Many of the people who spent a feverish three days last month trying to raise the $60,000 cheered Mr. Heimdal at the airport Monday night, decorated the family's white-shingled bungalow with red, white and blue bunting and stopped by to tell Mr. Heimdal that they had been praying for him.
''You want to thank people,'' he said, ''but how do you say it and what do you do?''
Mr. Heimdal spent his first hours back in Peoria satisfying a few cravings, like eating potato chips and his sister Linda's pasta, and recounting for his family his two months in captivity.
He spent his first night back home sleeping in the basement on the hammock he had used in his captivity. After so many nights on the hammock, he was unable to fall asleep on a mattress.
This morning, after a breakfast of steakburgers and doughnuts, Mr. Heimdal went to get his hair cut. He plans to see a doctor in a few days for the residual sores and swelling from the trench foot.
In Washington, the State Department said Mr. Heimdal had been interviewed by Ecuadorean and American officials before he left for the United States.
''He was debriefed by both the Ecuadorean security police as well as our embassy down there,'' said one official, adding, ''We really didn't learn anything that we didn't know.''
The State Department said that the investigation remained in the hands of the Ecuadorean officials and that Washington planned no independent action.
 
City Rallies Round
Mr. Heimdal was working for Iminco, an American mining concern in Ecuador, when he was abducted April 28. He then became a rallying point for a city that set aside its own troubles to win back a native son.
Peoria is still rebounding from the loss of hundreds of manufacturing jobs in the last decade and an unemployment rate that hit 17 percent in the mid-1980's. But when residents heard that Mr. Heimdal's family lacked the money to pay his ransom, they turned out by the hundreds to help.
Mayor James Maloof made a public plea that each household in the city of about 125,000 people donate $1. Children set up lemonade stands. People held garage sales and car washes and set up booths at a parking lot to collect dollar bills. Some laborers showed up in work clothes with hatfuls of change, and apologized for not bringing more.
The city raised $60,000 in a little over three days. But shortly after the money was wired to a bank in Ecuador, the kidnappers told the Heimdal family through an intermediary that the $60,000 was just a down payment and that they actually wanted $600,000.
 
Response to a Mother's Plea
Mr. Heimdal's parents - Roy, a kitchen cabinet salesman, and Marge, a nursing home worker - then went to Ecuador to try to convince the guerrillas that they had no more money.
''I told them that I am not rich,'' Mrs. Heimdal said. ''I told them, 'My riches are my children, and right now you have one of my riches.' I told them I wasn't going back to the U.S. until I could take my child back with me.''
Her plea, the behind-the-scenes work of an unnamed intermediary and the guerrilla group's history of releasing its hostages unharmed led to the freeing of Mr. Heimdal last Friday evening.
''All I could do was cry,'' Mrs. Heimdal said, recalling that night. ''Everything came so close to going wrong. My husband and I just held each other and cried and cried.''
She called her son's release ''better than the day my children were born.''
 
Ending to a Nightmare
Back home, residents were preparing banners and streamers for Mr. Heimdal's arrival and planning a homecoming picnic on Saturday.
''A lot of people felt he shouldn't have been down there in the first place,'' said Gary Olson, a Peoria disk jockey who helped raise money for the ransom. ''But people were relieved just to see him get off that plane. It's a happy ending to a nightmare.''
Roy Heimdal is still in Ecuador and is scheduled to arrive here tomorrow with his son's Ecuadorean fiancee, Sandra Durango. A delay in getting Miss Durango's visa prevented them from flying home with Scott and his mother.
The Heimdal family, which has received further contributions since Scott's plight became known, said it planned to use the unspent money to create a fund for families of other hostages.
And Mr. Heimdal said that he planned to return to Ecuador someday - but that he was through with gold mining.

Mr. Heimdal was working for an American mining concern in Ecuador when he was kidnapped on April 28 by guerrillas. (Fred Zwicky for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Half of Cities in U.S. Say Revenue Fails To Cover Spending

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
More than half the nation's cities and towns expect spending to exceed revenue in the current budget year and two-thirds of the municipalities say budget problems are worse than a year ago, according to a survey released Monday.
The survey of 576 municipalities by the National League of Cities, whose membership is open to cities and towns with populations of at least 10,000, found the budget pressures greatest in the Northeast, where the regional economy is in a slump. Five of six cities and towns surveyed in that region reported that their financial problems were worse than a year ago. 
A majority of municipalities in the South, the Midwest and the West also reported that budget strains were greater this year.
Over all, 54 percent of the municipalities surveyed said they would be spending more than they took in during the current year and 68 percent said their budget problems were worse than they were a year ago.
 
Cities Also Turn to Taxes
Leaders of the organization said a major factor in the growing municipal budget problems was the lack of help from Washington.
''We see this as a crucial time for national leadership,'' said Donald Borut, the league's executive director.
As President Bush and Congressional leaders seek an agreement on a deficit-reduction plan likely to include some form of higher taxes, the survey showed many cities were also looking for more revenue.
Forty-one percent of those surveyed have raised local property taxes and 76 percent have increased fees and other charges, the League of Cities said.
Just over half, 51 percent, reduced the rate of spending growth and 39 percent contracted certain services to outside companies to cut costs, the survey found.
Mr. Borut called the results ''a warning signal about stresses on our local revenue systems, about our ability to maintain important services and about the consequences of unfunded mandates and the continuing withdrawal of Federal and state participation in providing vital services.''
The league's board of directors plans to meet next week with Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, before the league makes its suggestions on deficit-reduction priorities.
Last month, Mr. Rostenkowski told another municipal organization, the United States Conference of Mayors, that cities were unlikely to get any additional help from Washington.

HEADLINE: Humanitarian Aid for Romania Is Best

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Daniel N. Nelson's description of the June 13 violence in Bucharest (''Romania Needs Help, Not Sanctions,'' Op-Ed, June 19) as a clumsy attempt by an inexperienced government to restore public order, underestimates President Ion Iliescu's intelligence and resolve.
Although acts of civil disobedience and fascist uprisings might look equally dangerous to the new Romanian Government, we can hardly believe it mistook one for the other. Mr. Iliescu surely understands that his National Salvation Front owes a good part of its electoral victory to four groups of voters: the unproductive (military, police, Government apparatchiks); the inefficient (workers and bureaucrats from subsidized branches of the state economy); the ill informed (from areas where the opposition was not allowed or not able to campaign), and the afraid (in areas where former Communists still maintain iron-fisted control).
On June 13, Mr. Iliescu enhanced his position with all these groups. He showed ordinary citizens what they should be afraid of if they join the opposition. He reneged on a pledge to the student protesters to establish an independent television station. He gave his blue-collar supporters, the endangered species of the promised conversion to a free-market system, a new and patriotic ''law and order'' mission. Finally, Mr. Iliescu reassured the Romanian establishment that no opposition party or economic program will be allowed to threaten its power and privileges. 
Under these circumstances, the United States Government should be very reluctant to extend economic aid or encourage private investments in Romania. As the front's power results from the skewed allocation of Rumania's economic output in favor of selected classes of supporters, we risk subsidizing Romania's miners and secret policemen with American tax and savings dollars.
We can help the Romanians more by dramatically increasing humanitarian aid to that country. The primitive health-care system is being overwhelmed by an exploding acquired immune deficiency syndrome epidemic, and malnutrition is rampant. If the Romanian Government wants to dispel America's suspicions, it should allow the independent television station the student protesters demanded. Our Government could even consider legally subsidizing it, through National Endowment for Democracy grants, for example.
Then Mr. Nelson's theory of growing pains as an explanation for the June 13 crackdown would be more credible.
 
ANDREI CERNASOV
 Long Island City, Queens, June 20, 1990

HEADLINE: Town Built on Indian Land Lost Its Chance to Plan Ahead

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''The people of Salamanca, a railroad town in western New York that had been illegally established on Indian land, received leases to rent the property, each lasting 99 years'' (front page, June 11). ''Hoping to make up for the inflationary decades they spent collecting 1890's rents, the Seneca have set the price of a new lease at $800,000 a year. They have also asked for an immediate payment of $60 million to make up for the in-equities of the original lease.'' 
In 1969, the leaders of the Seneca Nation had the wisdom to see that the pending expiration of the leases -still more than 20 years in the future - could have a devastating effect on the economy of Salamanca and the region well before the actual time of expiration. Lenders, who have to look 20 and 30 years down the road, were even then beginning to withhold the long-term financing needed for investment and economic stability.
To resolve the problem while there was still time to avoid real damage, the Senecas asked the newly founded school of architecture at the State University's Buffalo campus to study the situation and try to fashion a practical yet just solution. As a first-year graduate student, I was the leader of the student team that worked on the project, under faculty direction. I believe the Senecas commissioned conventional real estate evaluation elsewhere.
We came up with an answer that seemed to work for everyone. Rather than set the rent based on the value of the land (whatever that means), we decided to determine what new rent the residents and businesses of Salamanca could afford - an approach based on more justice than the Senecas had received under the original lease. Using census data, we analyzed the income of residents and businesses leasing Seneca land. For businesses, we determined a range of typical rents by business type. For residents, we applied the principle that rent should be 25 percent of income (Federal guidelines today call for 30 percent). The new rent, using this approach, would have been $200,000 in 1970, and would have escalated by some index, to be determined by all parties.
We recommended that the Senecas use some or all of the proceeds of this increased rent to establish a joint economic development body for the region. We suggested investing in new small industries and developing a tourist industry based on the natural beauty of the area and the special native American understanding of the natural environment.
Apparently, Salamanca did not accept the proposal. The $800,000 rent being proposed by the Senecas is roughly equivalent to the 1969 figure, but the city's 20-year economic decline in the face of the expiring leases may mean that it is no longer affordable.
 
ROSALIND S. PAASWELL
 Chicago, June 21, 1990
 
The writer, former Chicago first deputy commissioner of economic development and acting commissioner, is in private development.

HEADLINE: Picnics: Declaring the Spirit of a People

BYLINE: By DENA KLEIMAN

 BODY:
IT is a meal for our times - providing at once a respite from frenzy even as it affords the opportunity for social tolerance. It is the picnic. And on this Day of Independence, there is perhaps no more appropriate way to celebrate.
''The picnic is a testament to our diversity,'' said H. Douglas Sessoms, a professor of leisure studies at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.
No longer reserved just for special events, picnics seem to have become imbedded in the American psyche - as symbolic of this nation's craving for natural beauty as it is of its appreciation for individual difference. With wide appeal that cuts across all economic, social, ethnic and age barriers, the picnic in its myriad incarnations and interpretations has - despite these days of otherwise harried meals and frazzled nerves - surprisingly held its own. 
''Picnics are alive and well,'' said Merle Van Horne, an outdoor recreation planner with the National Parks Service in Washington. Although there is no formal picnic lobby and picnics generally do not elicit great waves of public passion, he said, ''millions upon millions do it.''
Picnickers no doubt are the last to worry about such things. But sociologists and others say consuming a meal in a natural setting away from the home has such universal appeal because it taps a vast array of impulses, ranging from a yearning to return to nature, to a need to escape from the heat, to a desire to break out from everyday routine. Indeed the hectic nature of modern life, some say, has enhanced the picnic's allure.
''I think the picnic is directly proportional to the degree people have been alienated from nature,'' said John Gillis, a professor of social history at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J. He adds that since modern life is so disconnected from nature today, the picnic has finally come of age.
Eating informally in an outdoor setting would have been abhorrent in the 17th and 18th century, Mr. Gillis said. ''It would have been associated with animals and the lower classes. It took centuries to get off the ground. To see whole populations squatting in the dirt would have been shocking.''
Indeed (as there are no doubt theories about every other spontaneous social phenomenon known to man) a whole school of thought has developed on the subject - that given the pace of modern life and the disconnection of contemporary families, picnics have assumed an important function.
John Kelly, a sociologist at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, for example, has determined that picnics have emerged as an important ritual to the perpetuation of the extended family.
''You get dad and the kids away from the television set,'' Mr. Kelly said. ''When family members have other obligations at other times, a picnic provides the chance to set aside a certain number of hours to help build family relationships.''
George Armelagos, an anthropologist at the University of Florida at Gainesville and an author of ''Consuming Passions: The Anthropology of Eating,'' (Washington Square Press, 1980), says that in this ever changing world, the picnic has emerged as a harbor of stability.
''Picnics help anchor us,'' Mr. Armelagos said. ''We get to take our time and enjoy ourselves. We get to idealize our bucolic notions of what life was like before.''
Keith Pension, a consultant living in Bryn Mawr, Pa., for example, frequently organizes elaborate picnic gatherings for her family and friends. ''When you spend most of your life being fairly formal, a picnic is a wonderful chance to be informal,'' Mrs. Pension said. ''Everything from what you wear to what you sit on, to what kind of food you can serve, to what kind of conversation. It's a wonderful excuse to be silly and stuff things in your mouth with your fingers.''
The picnic has come a long way since its beginnings. Initially a formal gathering of the privileged of 18th-century Britain, the word picnic was derived from the French ''pique-nique'' (''piquer,'' to pick, and ''nique,'' a small thing) and connoted a pot-luck-style supper. Eventually the term was reserved for communal meals held outdoors but were still for those wealthy enough to organize a foray into the country.
Today, in large part because of the accessibility of public parks, public transportation and the automobile, the picnic is readily available to nearly all segments of society. According to a recent study by the United States Department of Agriculture's Forest Service, more than 54 percent of all Americans over the age of 12 have gone on at least one picnic in the past year and in that pursuit have spent some $5.2 billion on travel, lodging, food and equipment.
There is no set menu or etiquette to the modern-day picnic or indeed any rigid definition of what a picnic is, although there are those who hold strong opinions about what a picnic is not.
''The porch is not a picnic,'' said Mary Ellen W. Hern, who has written extensively on the history of the American picnic and is a fan of the outdoor meal. ''It has to be away from your house. I think part of the magic of the picnic is the spirit of adventure in leaving your house.''
Mr. Von Horne of the National Parks Service agrees that a backyard barbecue or a supper on the patio is not a picnic. ''Clearly to go on a picnic means just that - to go,'' he said. So, then, where do Americans go to picnic? In a word: Everywhere - from Riverside Park in New York to Golden Gate Park in San Francisco. From the shores of Lake Michigan to the sands of Daytona, Fla. From the cliffs of the Grand Canyon to the plains of Kansas. From the beaches of Cape Cod to the rocks of the Painted Desert.
Picnic styles are as diverse as their locations, ranging from fast food tailgates at football games to makeshift barbecues in public parks, from formal caviar and champagne suppers on fine linens at outdoor concerts to to arroz con pollo along the banks of urban rivers, and even peanut butter and jelly sandwiches at the beach.
Just ask Rob Schulte, the grocery manager at Vons of Boulder City, Nev., a supermarket at the entrance to the Lake Meade National Recreation Area, where these days, he says, ''the place is packed with people buying every kind of hot dog, hamburgers, ribs, chicken, buns, ketchup, mustard, pickles, mayonnaise, pop, beer, chips, fried chicken, apples, grapes, you name it'' to take into the park.
Or ask Arthur Stewart, an official at Gateway National Park in Brooklyn, and he will tell you about how many of the six million annual visitors come to the park laden with food, blankets, hammocks and their own grills. Or ask Pat MacNichol, a spokesman for Winterthur, a museum in Wilmington, Del., which every year sponsors an annual picnic contest, and she will tell you about the preparations for the event including costumes and meals such as gingered leg of lamb, couscous, crostini, smoked salmon, pears and raspberry tarts.
Richard Huhn, the director of parks and recreation at Grosse Pointe Farms Pier Park on the outskirts of Detroit, said that on holidays the park's 120 picnic tables are always packed and there are never enough small red wagons to help picnickers move their provisions from their cars to the tables.
Judy Hurford, a nurse and resident of Grosse Pointe Farms, plans to be with her family today at Pier Park to celebrate Independence Day. ''For us it's a whole-day event,'' she said, explaining that she, her husband, Richard, who is an attorney, and their 12-year-old son, Patrick, will join several other families from her community for a day of swimming and volleyball and a meal of barbecued chicken, pasta salad and brownies.
''Sure, it's a lot of work,'' Mrs. Hurford said, adding that she does not need a holiday to picnic. ''We could just as easily eat the stuff at home. But we pack it all up and go through the hassle because we enjoy it.''

LENGTH: 1655 words

HEADLINE: And Thank God It's Wednesday?

BYLINE: By CAROL LAWSON

 BODY:
FOR many Americans, today is like a firecracker that fizzled in mid air.
A one-day holiday that falls smack in the middle of the work week is a big letdown, to say the least, to a citizenry that has come to view long holiday weekends as an inalienable right.
Never mind that most of the nation's workers can sleep late or go fishing or play with their children, and get paid for it. The disappointment of a midweek holiday is enough to make otherwise mature adults - people who run big businesses, operate on human brains, rock the cradles of the nation's future - act like school children whose recess has suddenly been canceled.
''Wednesday!'' exclaimed Samuel Bishop, a computer programmer in Denver, his voice slashing at the very word like a militant cursor. ''What is the point of Wednesday?'' The point is that when Congress relocated Washington's birthday and most other national holidays to Monday in 1971, it did not tamper with Independence Day. As a result, the Fourth of July is always the fourth of July, whenever that might be. And that has not been a Wednesday since 1984. 
Last year, July 4 conveniently fell on Tuesday, which a great many workers interpreted as cause to take off Monday, as well. Even when the holiday falls on the weekend, most Americans are off from work on the nearest Friday or Monday.
''But Wednesday?'' asked Sandra Gordon, a restaurant manager in Coral Gables, Fla. ''What do you do with Wednesday?''
At least one psychologist has seen the thought of a Wednesday holiday cause an outbreak of anxiety. ''This is all I have heard about for the last two weeks,'' said Dr. Herbert J. Freudenberger, a clinical psychologist in New York. ''Patients feel irritated about not having a long weekend, but they also feel guilty at the thought of taking off Thursday and Friday when others will be in the office: How will it look to the boss?''
But not everyone is intimidated by the boss. ''They all tried to wangle something,'' Barbara Rosenman, a Chicago office manager, said of her staff's often successful attempts to make the holiday somehow grow.
According to a recent survey of 535 companies by the New York Chamber of Commerce and Industry, 95.7 percent planned to close today only. Some workers are going along with that. But others, in New York and elsewhere, have added vacation days to one or both ends of the holiday.
Dr. Robert B. Raiber, a Manhattan dentist who had been hoping for five weekdays to spend windsurfing in Connecticut, closed his office today for only three days. He made that decision in a highly democratic fashion: he polled his patients.
''I didn't know what to do,'' Dr. Raiber said. So, for two days he asked his patients, just before turning on his drill, how they planned to deal with the Fourth of July.
''The majority said they would be away Thursday and Friday,'' said Dr. Raiber, who was not pleased with the results: ''I know a lot of people who are taking the whole week off.''
Pamela Willenz is in that category, having scheduled a vacation for this week. Ms. Willenz, who works in the public affairs department of the American Psychological Association in Washington, is relaxing in a rented beach house.
But even more meaningful to Ms. Willenz is the fact that since a national holiday occurs during her vacation, she will receive credit for one more day of vacation later in the year.
Susy Davidson, who has to go to work tomorrow, is thinking positively: she pretended that last night was Friday. ''On Fridays I go out with friends and don't worry about getting up in the morning,'' said Ms. Davidson, the food editor of Food and Wine magazine. ''Best of all, there will be another Friday at the end of the week.''
A Los Angeles lawyer said he was going to work as usual, even though his firm is officially closed today. ''I can guarantee,'' said the lawyer, who requested anonymity, ''that somebody will be working in nearly every law firm in the country.''
If this year's Independence Day is not ideal for many workers, it is not any better for their bosses. ''A midweek holiday is very disruptive,'' said Martin Lefkowitz, an economist with the United States Chamber of Commerce in Washington. He explained that employers generally view workers as ''less productive'' the day before a holiday. Moreover, absenteeism goes up on the days just before and after a holiday.
The airlines aren't thrilled either. ''Business travel is off, and the holiday travel is not as strong as it could be.'' said Tim Smith, a spokesman for American Airlines.
''If the airline industry had to pick one day for a holiday,'' Mr. Smith added, ''Wednesday would be the last pick.''
Americans will not be similarly inconvenienced again until the year 2001, the next time July 4 falls on Wednesday. Next year the holiday will be on Thursday, which means that it will spill over to Friday for much of the nation. Once again, Americans will let freedom ring in the style to which they are accustomed. HEADLINE: For Poles, Baseball And Rotary Foster American Dreams

BYLINE: By GABRIELLE GLASER

DATELINE: WARSAW, July 3

 BODY:
On Wednesday nights, the Rotarians meet at the Doctor's Club. On Tuesdays and Thursdays, Little League ballplayers practice at a sports field in a Warsaw neighborhood. And on Fridays, the Lions' Club gathers in the dining room of a suburban office building.
It was not so long ago in this country that American products and inventions were pleasures only to be enjoyed in secret. But in Poland today, you can hardly walk down the street without hearing Madonna, bumping into a teen-age skateboarder or seeing a hamburger stand. 
In Western Europe, the United States is often scorned as the international purveyor of fast food and plastic. But to Poles emerging from the drab half-century of Communist rule, the United States remains a dream: a place where the phones work, the stores are full and everyone has the job he wants. And groups like the Little League or the Rotary Club, emblems of small-town Americana, are seen here as important components of the American Dream.
George Bin, a 20-year-old who lives in Warsaw, describes himself as a Mets fanatic, a love that developed when he lived in New York as a child in the mid-70's while his father taught in the New York area for two years. Now the Mets fan coaches the city's 30 Little League players.
''It's American,'' he said, so parents want their children to join in. ''Maybe they think their kids will look like American movie stars if they play, I don't know.''
He went on: ''Americans have pretty nice muscles. Poles don't look so great because we eat a lot of greasy food. They look at themselves and think, 'I don't want my kid to look like me, all flabby.' And they're out there cheering just like any parent in America.''
Of perhaps more significance to Poland's economic future are the business clubs, which planners hope will someday become a hotbed of entrepreneurial spirit.
''What we hope these groups will do is teach people skills we have forgotten, like working efficiently,'' said Mieczyslaw Fudali, a chemist and vice president of one of Warsaw's two Rotary clubs, which are sending 35 young adults hoping to go into business to the West for study and internships later this year.
''Communism robbed us of coping with our own problems,'' he said. ''In Rotary we take affairs into our own hands. We vote on things. We discuss before deciding. It's democratic.''
About 20,000 groups, ranging from book clubs to swimming clubs, have formed since last summer. Talks between Solidarity union leaders and Communist Party officials a year ago led to the legalization of organizations outside the Communist Party, as well as to a new Government in which Solidarity has a part.
''It is natural for people to collectivize, but after 40 years of Communism they are eager to join narrow groups that have a specific goal,'' said Jan Woroniecki, who is another vice president of Rotary in Warsaw.
''One party controlled everything, from shops to schools,'' said Mr. Woroniecki, who is the Polish diplomat who oversees the country's relations with the United Nations. ''Now we are trying to take control of small things. In America this is quite common. You call it 'creative problem-solving.' ''
Mr. Woroniecki said the Rotary club is trying to arrange for Polish nurses, of which there is a surplus in this country, to be temporarily sent to Western European countries or the United States in exchange for modern medical equipment and supplies, which Poland needs badly.
The Lion's Club, founded in Poland a year ago by Andrzej Ziaja, a Polish businessman, has similar overall goals. ''Our members are excited to be doing things for others that can be seen, instead of the state,'' he said.
Poland's ties to the United States are longstanding and well-known. Of the 39 million Poles in the country today, according to Government figures, at least one in three has a relative in the United States.
Many Poles point proudly to Tadeusz Kosciuszko and Kazimierz Pulaski, Polish officers who contributed to the American War of Independence.
Evidence of Polish admiration for the United States is everywhere. At the Warsaw headquarters of LOT, the Polish national airline, customers can get a drink at the O'Hare bar, named after Chicago's international airport, a destination for millions of Poles with family members in that city. At one Pewex, the state-owned hard currency store, a wine stand decorated with American flags and red, white and blue bunting bears the name ''California Wine Saloon'' (though most of the wine sold there comes from New York). Another stand, decorated to look like an old country store, complete with a fake-wood facade, is called ''Old West.'' It sells Snickers candy bars, Marlboro cigarettes and Russian vodka.
''Well,'' shrugged Teresa Mucha, the store's manager, ''people don't buy too much of the Russian vodka, but they do love Marlboros.''
Polish Little League was founded in 1987 by Stanley Kokoszka, a Polish-American from Willimantic, Conn., who started organizing the game here in 1987, after a trip as an educational consultant for the State Department.
''Everywhere there were ragamuffins out doing nothing except selling postcards to tourists,'' said Mr. Kokoszka, who is back in Poland for the summer to work on strengthening the Little League. ''I noticed soccer fields all over the place, but nobody was playing on them. And I thought to myself, wouldn't it be great for these kids to have baseball?''
Mr. Kokoszka proposed Little League teams to Poland's Communist leaders by predicting the growth of baseball worldwide. ''I told them that pretty soon, baseball would be an Olympic sport just like soccer, and that kids would need to know how to play if the Poles wanted to compete. Even Cubans play ball, I told them. That did it. They bought it.''
Now, six cities have leagues. About 300 boys and girls 6 to 12 years old play, Mr. Kokoszka said.
The United States Embassy has a library of American books and magazines. Romana Mrozowska, the chief librarian there, said many of the 140 Poles who visit the library each day see the United States as welcome relief from two of its historical foes, Germany and the Soviet Union.
''I don't think many Poles ever wanted to read 'enemy literature,' '' said Mrs. Mrozowska, who has worked at the library for 30 years. ''The books and language of America have always been special in Poland, even in the worst of times. But now I can't keep things on the shelves.''
John R. Davis Jr., the United States Ambassador to Poland who has been posted in Warsaw for seven years, said much of Poland's attraction to the United States was a result of its economic success and political system.
''Poland is probably the most pro-American country in the world,'' Ambassador Davis said. ''We are big, far away and friendly, something their neighbors haven't always been.''

HEADLINE: DE GUSTIBUS;
An American Takes Aim At Reign of Dry Italian Pasta

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT

 BODY:
UNLIKE most foods, when it comes to pasta, fresh is not always better. And with dry, factory-made pasta, imported usually is better than domestic. Until now.
Whether to use fresh or dry pasta depends on the recipe. Some dishes, like those bathed in cream, are best suited to fresh egg noodles, while others, like linguine with clam sauce and other southern Italian specialties, are better with dry pasta. Excellent fresh egg pasta can be made at home or purchased. As for dried pasta, domestic products generally lack the silken feel, uniformly golden color, rich mellow flavor and, once cooked, the proper al dente texture of many imports from Italy, especially from the Abruzzi region.
Coming up with a domestically produced dry pasta as good or better than the finest from Italy was the challenge that tempted Richard Thompson after 12 very successful years in the oil business - crude, not olive. In 1982, he switched to the pasta business, and in late 1988 the spaghetti started rolling out of his American-Italian Pasta Company's new $50 million factory in Excelsior Springs, Mo. 
Mr. Thompson, 38 years old, a native of Colorado Springs, Colo., said he grew up ''eating spaghetti and meatballs about once a month.'' But he became seriously interested in pasta while he was drilling oil wells in North Dakota in the 1970's.
''The land I was exploring for oil was in the middle of the best durum wheat fields in the country,'' he recalled. Semolina, the coarsely ground flour preferred for dry pasta, comes from hard durum wheat. ''At the time I was paying royalties to farmers for the mineral rights, and I went around digging up their fields.
''During the time I was in the business I saw the price of oil go from $10 a barrel to $40 a barrel and decided that it was time to get out,'' he said. ''In trying to figure out what to do next, I kept coming back to those wheat fields and to the idea of pasta.'' Mr. Thompson was convinced it was a good business to be in. Consumption has nearly doubled to 18.5 pounds per person annually since 1975, according to the National Pasta Association, a trade group in Arlington, Va., and is expected to reach 30 pounds per person by the year 2000.
Mr. Thompson spent four years traveling around the country to learn all he could about domestic pasta. ''Then it became evident that I had to go the source and find out why Italian pasta was better,'' he said. He spent the best part of two years in Italy studying the pasta business there.
''I asked the Italians how they would improve their pasta if they could, and they told me that it could be done by hand-selecting the finest durum wheat, milling it yourself and monitoring the production from start to finish.'' The Italians also told him it would be impossible to do that in Italy because wheat purchasing is too centralized. But that type of control is precisely what Mr. Thompson eventually accomplished.
Like a winemaker contracting with grape growers, Mr. Thompson buys the hard spring wheat directly from farmers, mainly in North Dakota, selecting it field by field. Instead of bulldozing their fields, as he did in the oil business, he nows pay them a premium to grow the best wheat.
''We have complete control and can segregate the different kinds of durum wheat, such as hard amber and amber,'' he said. Other pasta manufacturers buy their wheat in bulk at the Minneapolis Grain Exchange, where such selectivity is impossible.
The company has its own rail cars to transport the wheat to Excelsior Springs where it is kept in separate silos, according to type, so that different lots, some with more gluten, others with better flavor or deeper color, can be blended. The plant has its own mill and computerized equipment for utmost consistency.
''We chose Excelsior Springs not only because it is America's heartland and because the air is clean and the water is very pure,'' he said. ''The quality of pasta depends on the raw materials and if you can control those, you make better pasta.'' He pointed out that unlike in Italy many pasta manufacturers in the United States are in large cities, where the air quality and the tap water used to make the pasta are not as good as they should be.
Because of the quality of the ingredients, the company's top-of-the-line pasta, Pasta LaBella, is a deep golden color with a velvety sheen and satin finish, free of roughness and the speckles that result from the impurities in the flour or from poorly mixed dough. And when cooked and drained it is much less sticky than most commercial pasta. It has a distinctively mellow flavor and keeps a deliciously toothsome texture. It's priced at $2.50 a pound, two to three times as much as domestic pastas and more than most Italian brands.
Pasta LaBella is carried by the Kroger chain throughout the Midwest and will eventually be distributed nationally. The company also makes private-label pasta for a number of other supermarkets, including the Master's Choice brand sold at A.&P. and Food Emporium stores. The private-label pasta, priced at no more than $1 a pound, is of a similar high quality. Pasta LaBella will only be sold in specialty food stores or at supermarket deli counters, rather than the regular pasta section. The company also produces all the pastas sold by Sysco, the nation's largest distributor of food service products.
Unlike many brands of domestic pasta, all the pasta produced by the American-Italian Pasta Company consists of 100 percent durum wheat, without any soft wheat flour added. There are no American rules governing the kind of wheat used in making pasta, as there are in Italy.
Soft wheat flour, which is easier to handle and usually used for making fresh egg pasta, makes dry pasta softer, starchier and stickier. It also reduces the cost. Mr. Thompson points out that when pasta boils and foam forms, that is the excess starch rising in the water. ''You see very little of it with my pasta,'' he said, adding that the starchiness is why many American cooks routinely rinse the pasta after cooking.
Even delicate strands of angel hair, which, when drained, often have a maddening tendency to glue themselves into a single mass, stay manageable and separate with Pasta LaBella and Masters Choice brands.
Since 1967, Italian law has required that dry pasta be made with 100 percent durum wheat. But in 1988 the European Economic Community ruled that pasta could be made using soft wheat flour and that Italy had to permit its importing.
''Italian producers screamed about that because it's cheaper pasta and they were afraid of the market being flooded with inexpensive imports,'' said Lucio Caputo, president of the Italian Wine and Food Institute in New York. ''The reality is that no market for such inferior pasta has developed in Italy.'' Dr. Caputo added that Italian manufacturers are now organizing a consortium to monitor quality and affix its label on pasta made according to its standards.
In May, Mr. Thompson decided to show his American pasta to the Italians at Cibus, a major trade exhibition in Parma, Italy. Since then Ugo Carmela, a pasta and bread shop in Parma, has placed an order for 25 cases of his pasta, and the company is negotiating with Despear, a chain of 400 food stores. ''It's definitely an affirmation,'' Mr. Thompson said. ''A newspaper in Milan was outraged at the Italian companies that gave me the information to make it possible.''
While smaller than Borden, Hershey Foods and CPC International, this country's three major pasta producers, Mr. Thompson's company is already the country's largest privately owned pasta manufacturer. By the end of the year production is expected to reach an annual rate of about 160 million pounds of dry pasta in 25 cuts, from the finest angel hair and tiny orzo to thick twists of fusilli and broad ribbons of lasagne. The plant also makes five kinds of noodles, four of them with eggs and one without. Mr. Thompson now eats pasta every day.
The Pasta LaBella brand, which is just becoming available in the New York area, will be sold at Balducci's, 424 Avenue of the Americas at Ninth Street, and the Wainscott Produce Market, Montauk Highway, Wainscott, L.I. It is packed in handsome, clear cellophane bags trimmed in black that have won the Gravure Association of America's award this year as the best-designed food package.
''We decided to go with the plastic package because it sealed the product more securely than a box yet allows the buyer to see it,'' Mr. Thompson said. ''If you have good legs you might as well show them off.''

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Saks Hasn't Met Its Goals In First Half, Memo Says

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
The first-half performance of Saks Fifth Avenue has fallen short of its own projections and those of its new owner, a confidential memorandum shows.
Saks's profit totaled $26.3 million in the first half, according to Investcorp International, the Mideast financial concern that completed its acquisition of the large fashion retailer on Monday for $1.5 billion. Investcorp had projected profits of $33 million, while the retailer itself had expected $32 million.
The figures, first reported by The Wall Street Journal, are included in a memorandum Investcorp has distributed to banks that participated in the purchase of the 45-store fashion retailer. Profit comparisons with last year are not available. Saks was sold to Investcorp by B.A.T. Industries of London, which also recently sold Marshall Field & Company, the Chicago department store chain, to the Dayton Hudson Corporation. 
In the memo, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, Investcorp paints a dour picture for Saks's 23 stores in New York City, the Middle Atlantic States, the Northeast and the Midwest through 1995. Those sales have been projected ''with a very conservative outlook, given the current economic environment in these regions,'' the memo says. It continues, ''Our assumptions therefore assume zero to slightly negative real growth rates through 1995.''
The disappointing first-half profit and the sober sales expectations raised some question in financial circles yesterday about whether Investcorp may have overpaid. ''The high price Investcorp paid for Saks is typical of the problem of the 1980's, now continuing into the 1990's, that acquisition prices have been disproportionate to the value of the companies bought,'' said Gilbert Harrison, chairman of Financo Inc., a New York merger-and-acquisition specialist.
''Purchasers sometimes become so enthusiastic that they overestimate the growth of the target companies and develop projections that are unattainable.''
Investcorp added in its memo to the banks: ''We are particularly conservative with the New York City main store, which accounted for 22 percent of 1989's sales. Based on comments made by management that the store's performance has been flat so far this year, and given the contraction in the financial services sector, weaker tourism and general economic problems being experienced by the city, we projected only 1.1 percent growth this year and 2 percent in 1991.''
 
Cutback on Expenditures
In capital expenditures, Investcorp said it was planning to reduce outlays sharply over the next five years so that by 1995 expenditures for both new stores and renovations would total $23.2 million, compared with $97.3 million in 1990.
''For our projection purposes, we eliminated all future new stores for which capital commitments have not already been made,'' Investcorp said. ''Our assumption is that new store proposals in the future would have to meet more stringent economic tests than may have been applied by Saks's management in the past.''
The new owners of Saks said that they had cut two renovation projects, delayed a third and reduced other miscellaneous capital expenditures that management had projected. ''As a result,'' they said, ''our projected capital expenditure figures for 1990 through 1994 total $233 million, or $200 million less than management's projections for the comparable period.''
Investcorp told the bankers that Saks under its ownership would have a business plan calling for slow store expansion, a focus on existing stores, lower store operating expenses, reduced corporate overhead and building Saks's ''Folio'' catalogue business. With that strategy, Investcorp said it expected Saks sales to grow from $1.44 billion in 1991 to $1.78 billion in 1995, or from $415 a square foot of selling space to $495 in that period.
Saks's sales in 1989 were $1.24 billion, Investcorp said. The financial concern said it had set conservative projections for the Saks stores on the West Coast, ''based on historical, comparable growth and the fact that it is the home region of Nordstrom, one of the company's strongest competitors.'' It added, ''Nevertheless, Saks is expected to place greater focus on this region from 1990 onwards, resulting in comparatively higher anticipated sales growth.''
But three areas of the most promising growth, Investcorp said, are the Southern and Texas regions for Saks, as well as the ''Folio'' catalogue business.

HEADLINE: Scarce Metal Hits $7,000 An Ounce

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, July 3

 BODY:
The price of rhodium, a little-known but environmentally important precious metal, soared by $1,000, to a record $7,000 an ounce today, and some analysts expect the metal to climb higher before speculative pressures subside.
A member of the platinum metal group, rhodium is a primary ingredient in automobile catalytic converters - cylindrical ceramic blocks, structured like honeycombs, that are chemically treated and coated with platinum, rhodium and other precious metals. They convert the harmful car exhaust gasses of carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides and hydrocarbons into carbon dioxide, water and nitrogen.
 
Cuts Nitric Oxide Pollution
Rhodium's specific role is to reduce nitric oxide pollution, and as more stringent environmental laws have been passed, the amount of the metal used has grown. About 80 percent of rhodium output is used for making catalytic converters. Chemicals, electronics and glass use the rest. 
The price run-up this year has been attributed to a supply shortage, caused by production problems at a large South African refinery. More recently, stockpiling by nervous industrial users has added to those pressures, the analysts said.
The price of rhodium doubled between the end of 1989 and last week, moving from $1,746 an ounce in December to $3,425 last Wednesday - and then doubled again in just six days to reach today's record.
Growing global pressures for legislation to reduce the level of nitric oxide from car exhausts are expected to keep rhodium demand high, the analysts said. In a tight market, they added, this will keep the price up.
''The metal has no foreseeable substitute, and it is impossible to predict when the bubble is likely to burst,'' said John Taylor, a mining analyst James Capel & Company, a London brokerage. [Gordon Bassett, an analyst with Johnson, Matthey North America Inc. in Philadelphia, cited an ''inflexible'' supply and some short-term production problems as the chief reasons for the run-up. ''But there's been a bit of a snowball effect lately,'' Mr. Bassett said.
''There has been some extra strong buying from Japan, which we think is just inventory building. But that has spilled over into the market and caused something of a panic.'' [Johnson, Matthey North America is a unit of Johnson, Matthey P.L.C., the London concern that is the world's largest rhodium trader.] The current shortfall is accentuated because most of the world's rhodium production of 330,000 ounces a year is committed to long-term contracts between producers and industrial users. Only 30,000 ounces to 60,000 ounces are freely traded, and no futures market exists in the metal.
Despite the price increase, the analysts said automobile buyers need not worry. The amount of rhodium used in catalytic converters is minuscule. ''Even at $7,000 an ounce,'' Mr. Bassett of Johnson, Matthey North America said, ''there is only about $60 worth of rhodium in the average car.''
 
Discovered in 1803
The metal was named by William Hyde Wollaston, an English chemist and physicist who first extracted it in 1803, after the Greek word for rose, ''rhodon,'' because of the rose color of a number of its compounds. But in its pure state, rhodium is spongy and has a silver-white color.
Rhodium began its record-setting ascent last November, when production problems arose at a new refinery owned by Rustenburg Platinum Holdings Ltd. in Bophuthatswana, South Africa. The refinery is managed by Matthey Rustenburg refiners, which is jointly owned by Rustenburg and Johnson, Matthey P.L.C. Rhodium is found within platinum and extracted by a complex process.
Increased output from the South African platinum operations of Lonrho P.L.C., the British conglomerate, is expected to make up most of the shortfall, while Impala Platinum Holdings Ltd., another South Africa company, will also benefit, the traders said.
Other producers like the Soviet Union and Canada have not yet been able to fill the gap, because it takes about six months to extract and refine rhodium from the platinum-bearing ore, Mr. Bassett said. Soviet producers, however, are using higher rhodium prices to get agreements on longer-term contracts and increase their hard-currency earnings.

HEADLINE: Oil Activity Has Shifted From U.S.

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
For the first time, oil companies operating in the United States are spending more to look for oil abroad than at home, and most of their production and reserves are outside the United States, Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm, said yesterday.
The shift, which happened last year and is intensifying, comes as oil imports have reached nearly 50 percent of United States consumption. With less focus on domestic exploration, imports will continue to rise because oil wells do not pump forever. Domestic production has fallen 17 percent, or 1.8 million barrels a day, since 1986, Arthur Andersen noted, predicting that it would drop an additional 400,000 barrels a day this year. 
Some experts said the study might understate the extent of the decline in the American oil industry. ''We've got only 900 drilling rigs running, and they're not in exploratory regions,'' said Michel T. Halbouty, a geoscientist in Houston. The rigs, he added, were making new wells in existing fields to raise production, not to find new oil.
 
Low Prices Cited
''It's inevitable,'' said Theodore Eck, an economist at the Amoco Corporation. ''There's not much you can do in North America at low oil prices.'' He added that if prices rose, domestic drilling would pick up. But if prices increased sharply, he said, tax differences between this country and others would make drilling here relatively more attractive.
In addition, the United States has many older fields that are known to have substantial amounts of oil, but the oil is difficult to recover and can be pumped only at a higher price.
One new technique, known as horizontal drilling, is just now coming into its own because of improved technology. [Page 46.] Gas Outlays Domestic About 60 percent of Amoco's oil exploration and production budget is spent abroad, Mr. Eck said, although its natural gas expenditures are overwhelmingly domestic.
Domestic drilling and production are declining, oil company executives agree, because the United States is a ''mature'' oil province, much more thoroughly drilled and pumped than the rest of the world, and because some areas have been ruled off limits for environmental reasons, which seldom happens abroad.
In its study, which is conducted annually, Arthur Andersen surveyed 236 oil companies that file disclosure statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Nearly all are publicly traded companies that are nominally American-owned, but three are foreign, with trading in this country in American depository receipts, a surrogate for stock. They are the British Petroleum Company. which owns Sohio; Royal Dutch/ Shell, which owns Shell, and Broken Hill Proprietary, an Australian company.
For the last five years that the survey has been conducted, domestic spending in the group has exceeded foreign outlays, but last year, of the $39.2 billion spent, 55.9 percent, or $21.9 billion, was spent abroad. The domestic figure was up by 7 percent from 1988; the foreign figure by 20 percent.
Victor A. Burk, managing director of oil and gas industry services for the accounting company, said that the acceleration of the shift was surprising and that the turn toward investment in foreign exploration was even stronger this year.
 
About 60 Percent of Output
The companies represent about 60 percent of the oil produced in this country, he said; an additional 15 percent is ''royalty oil'' that is paid to the Government or private landholders in exchange for permission to drill, and 25 percent is drilled by private companies or individuals.
Last year the companies surveyed found 52 percent as much oil as they pumped in this country, the highest level since 1985.
Oil industry experts are divided on whether a shift to foreign investment is necessarily bad news.
''It does represent an increase in activity by the United States industry, even though some of it is in other countries,'' said Mr. Burk, of Arthur Andersen. The activity is not only in the oil companies themselves, but also in the companies that manufacture drilling equipment or provide oilfield services, he added. Also, if the major oil companies go abroad to look for oil, that leaves more opportunities for smaller companies to look domestically, he said.
 
Economic Security an Issue
But Mr. Halbouty, the Houston-based geologist, said that as domestic production declined, national economic security became an issue. ''Right now, you don't care about it; you drive up, you get your gasoline, and you move on,'' he said. ''But we're going to find ourselves one of these days in gasoline lines that will make the 1973 debacle look like a Sunday picnic.''
Others say that oil-exporting countries have a much stronger interest in the economic stability of their customers than they did during the embargo in 1973. Several members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, where oil reserves are increasingly concentrated, have invested in refining and marketing operations in this country, for example, and would be hurt if supplies to the United States were limited.
Among the factors that may be important to the pattern of oil investment in the future are the changes in Eastern Europe, experts say. Some of the most promising prospects are in areas that are interested for the first time in the participation of American companies, experts say. This would tend to draw investment away from other areas.

HEADLINE: Rebates Are a Reason for Vehicle Price Increases by Big 3

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 3

 BODY:
With sales sluggish, the Big Three domestic auto makers recently announced midyear price increases, a move that illustrates the curious economic logic that governs the pricing strategy in Detroit these days.
Even though the market for new cars is weak, Ford, General Motors and Chrysler have all opted to entice customers through continued rebates. Extra revenue from price increases is used to offset the costs of cash rebates and discount financing.
''The pricing strategies of the Big Three are largely fictitious,'' said Ronald A. Glantz, an analyst with Dean Witter Securities in San Francisco. ''They raise the price on a vehicle by $50 or $60 one week, and increase the incentive by $100 the next.'' An Inescapable Cycle? In fact, for the Big Three, the cycle appears to have become inescapable. Consumers now seem to require rebates before they will buy. 
On Monday, the General Motors Corporation raised prices between $66 and $165, and increased the destination charge by $10. The Chrysler Corporation's price increases, which also took effect on Monday, range from $60 to $160. Both companies followed the Ford Motor Company's move on June 18 to raise prices between $58 and $134.
The increases on most cars and trucks sold by Ford, G.M. and Chrysler may eke out a little more revenue from a weak market. Raising prices now may also blunt the effect of higher prices when new cars are introduced in the fall, analysts say.
 
Imports Take Same Course
Although higher prices on imported cars probably will not show up until fall, several Japanese and European auto makers have begun offering rebates of their own and have followed - in some cases, even exceeded -the Big Three's price increases.
The cycle of higher prices to offset rebates does not necessarily harm the competitive position of the auto companies, industry experts and economists say, since competitors are doing the same thing. But car dealers say many customers are baffled by the array of rebates and financing incentives.
''Rebates have muddied the waters and made determining the true price of a car incredibly complex,'' said Lance Ealey, an automotive specialist with McKinsey & Company, a consulting firm.
 
Customers Seem Hooked
Chrysler was the first to offer rebates on cars, in the early 70's. The plan was viewed by analysts and competitors as a shrewd marketing move, and other companies soon followed suit. But by the mid-80's, analysts say, customers were hooked and the car companies saw their sales fall off sharply whenever rebates ended.
''The consumer very quickly learns to look for rebates, and it doesn't take long to see demand dry up between one rebate period and the next,'' said James R. Taylor, a professor of marketing at the University of Michigan Business School.
Car companies, fearful of losing customers to rivals, are unlikely to break the rebate habit soon.
''Even if auto sales boom next year, we'll still have incentives,'' Mr. Glantz said. ''There are three dozen auto manufacturers out there, and unless they all go cold turkey I don't see how they can give up incentives.''
The manufacturers do have ways to raise revenues without adding significantly to a vehicle's base price. One pricing game Detroit plays involves making popular options standard equipment, which lifts the manufacturer's revenues on a vehicle. Customers are compelled to buy the special packages, while the manufacturers use the base price - minus the equipment - to promote their new models as only slightly more expensive than last year's versions.
As a result of this trend, pursued throughout the 1980's, the least expensive cars now carry significantly more equipment than they used to, and they cost more.
 
Japanese Prices Up, Too
While the American car companies have historically moved first to raise prices, the Japanese have generally followed suit in the last few years, keeping their car prices within one or two percentage points of competing American models. The Toyota Motor Corporation, the Honda Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company typically limit themselves to lifting prices once a year, usually in the fall when most new models are introduced. Sometimes they delay price increases until the end of the year, seeking the promotional advantage that comes from comparatively low sticker prices in the first months that new models are on sale.
In the past, the Japanese had shown a willingness to limit increases, with the objective of grabbing a larger share of the market. The most notable instance was the mid-1980's, when the value of the Japanese yen rose against the dollar, making goods produced in Japan more expensive in the United States.
 
Opportunity to Gain Share
While the Japanese did raise prices, they resisted pressure to keep up with the strengthening yen, even though their profits suffered.
Some analysts contend that domestic auto makers, by failing to cut their prices then, passed up an opportunity to improve their competitive position.
''The mid-1980's was a unique period in time when the domestic auto makers could have seized a gigantic comparative advantage,'' said Maryann N. Keller, an analyst with Furman Selz Mager Dietz & Birney in New York. ''The opportunity was there to open up a price differential so big that the issue of higher Japanese quality could have been obliterated by the vastly lower price of most American cars.''
 
Oldsmobile Rebates
LANSING, Mich., July 3 (Reuters) - The General Motors Corporation said today that its Oldsmobile division would offer a $1,500 rebate to buyers of 1991 Oldsmobile 88 models in certain areas of the United States. The areas include New York, New England, Washington, Chicago, Minneapolis, St. Louis, San Francisco and Los Angeles. The program runs from Wednesday until Aug. 2. The new incentive is in addition to a rebate of $1,000 on the Cutlass Ciera, $2,500 on the Toronado and $1,000 on the Silhouette mini-van. These incentives are available nationwide through Aug. 2.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
College Tuition: A Better Idea?

BYLINE: By Peter Passel

 BODY:
THE problem: The earnings gap between those who went to college and those who did not has never been greater. Yet tuition subsidies for all but the poorest students have become scarcer than Taittinger in Teheran. Loans at market-rate interest are generally available to students who need them. But not surprisingly, the children of financially pressed parents are loath to begin their working lives burdened with tens of thousands of dollars in education debts.
The Economic Policy Institute's solution: self-financing Government loans for anyone who wants one, with repayment linked to future earnings and collections piggybacked on regular income taxes. 
The proposal, written by Barry Bluestone, Alan Clayton-Matthews, John Havens and Howard Young for the liberal Washington policy group and detailed in the summer issue of The American Prospect magazine, is sure to receive a respectful reception across the political spectrum.
As the liberal economists acknowledge, ''income-contingent'' loans for higher education were first suggested by Milton Friedman, the conservative economist. Yale University experimented with the concept in the 1970's. And a version drafted for the Democrats by Robert Reischauer, now the head of the Congressional Budget Office, was hailed as the rare serious idea floated in the know-nothing swamp of the 1988 Presidential campaign.
But the innovative feature of the Economic Policy Institute's proposal - the use of Social Security revenues as the multibillion-dollar source for the revolving tuition loan fund - is bound to meet resistance. Most economists applaud the notion of investing in ''human capital'' to ease the burden of paying for the baby boom generation's retirement, but few politicians seem ready to accept the budgetary consequences of diverting the Social Security surplus to productive uses.
In 1963, say Mr. Bluestone and company, college graduates earned an average of 50 percent more than high school graduates. By 1987 the gap had widened to 80 percent. All told, the economists estimate, a college degree increases the present value of the average individual's lifetime earnings by $500,000.
From this perspective $60,000 to $90,000 in tuition and living expenses looks like an excellent investment, even considering four years' worth of lost earnings. Government grants, subsidized loans and private scholarships pay most of the way for poor students with the drive to excel. But the children of the middle class must often borrow to cover their costs. And many, particularly those contemplating poorly paid work like teaching, are reluctant to leave school yoked to a huge debt.
Mr. Bluestone's Equity Investment in America program would not ease the average burden of college loan debts. But by making the payment rate a percentage of taxable earnings for 25 years, the plan effectively pools the burden of college costs and limits the obligation of the relative losers in the income lottery. A nurse, for example, who borrowed $20,000 and was earning $25,000 a year would pay back about $1,600 annually - much less than a bank would charge. A lawyer, by contrast, who borrowed the same amount but was grossing $50,000 a year would pay twice as much.
Debt collection, the Achilles' heel of current college loan programs, would not be a significant problem. Payment would be calculated on regular income tax forms and regular withholding would apply. Like other tax evaders, those who cheated would face the Internal Revenue Service's wrath.
The stickier issue is where to get the seed capital for the loans. The economists guess that in the year 2010 some nine million students would be using the program and, calculated in 1990 dollars, cumulative liabilities would exceed $600 billion.
It would make economic sense to tap the Social Security trust fund for the cash. A heavy investment in education would, presumably, increase productivity and average wages, making it easier for future generations to pay for the baby boomers' pensions. And the huge sums needed would hardly strain the resources of the trust fund: At its peak, the education debt would represent less than half the assets of the Social Security system. What is more, the self-financing feature of the plan would guarantee that the money would be available when it was really needed for pensions. By the year 2040 the education fund would be in the black.
But economic logic does not necessarily mix well with political logic. Hundreds of billions diverted to education loans would represent hundreds of billions unavailable for deficit reduction - or, for that matter, aircraft carriers or farm subsidies or food stamps. The ultimate question, then, is the one Washington has been ducking since the big Reagan tax cuts: Do elected officials have the will to encourage productive investment at the expense of personal consumption. Anyone taking bets?

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Up 2.1% in May

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
Orders received by the nation's factories climbed a healthy 2.1 percent in May, the Commerce Department reported today, but the $5 billion rise was mainly attributed to higher production by auto makers worried about a possible strike this fall.
While the rise to a seasonally adjusted $240.98 billion confirmed other information showing strength among manufacturing industries, analysts cautioned that it was strongly affected by car manufacturers building up inventories.
''This is likely a buildup in anticipation of a work stoppage in the auto industry,'' said Norman Robertson, chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh. ''So these numbers may look stronger than they really are.'' 
 
Buildup Seen Continuing
Auto makers are expected to continue building stocks during the summer months in preparation for a possible September strike by the United Automobile Workers union.
The May increase in orders followed a revised 2.1 percent decline in April, instead of an earlier reported 2.3 percent fall.
Excluding transportation equipment, which includes automobiles, factory orders rose by eight-tenths of 1 percent in May after a one-tenth drop in April, the Commerce Department said.
A key component of factory orders, durable goods orders, rose by 4 percent in May after falling 4.1 percent in April. Durables are items like refrigerators and automobiles that are designed to last at least three years.
By contrast, orders for nondurables were unchanged in May after rising by two-tenths of 1 percent in April.
 
Work Week Raised Index
Last week, the Commerce Department said its index of leading indicators, which forecasts the economy's direction six to nine months down the road, was up by eight-tenths of 1 percent in May in a sign that the economy should continue to make gains.
But economists cautioned that the index rose partly because of a longer workweek since Detroit was unwilling to hire new workers with contract negotiations approaching.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said on Monday that the economy expanded for a third straight month in June. The report by the managers, who represent a cross-section of industrial companies, was seen as a sign that a deterioration in manufacturing activity seen late last year and early in 1990 was ending.
Transportation equipment orders jumped by 10.1 percent in May, after a 13.2 percent fall in April. Within that category, orders for aircraft and parts increased by 12.1 percent in May after 27.7 percent fall in April.
Shipments of motor vehicles and parts were up in May by 12.3 percent, after a 6.1 percent April drop. In the case of automobiles, shipments correspond to orders.
The Commerce Department said motor vehicles accounted for about half of the overall gain in May factory orders. Though new-car sales have been weak, manufacturers are expected to build up stocks in order to have products to offer for sale in the event of work stoppages by union employees.
 
Other Categories Cited
Cynthia Latta, senior financial economist with DRI/McGraw Hill Inc. in Lexington, Mass., noted that other categories of products also had order increases. ''The report is dominated by the gain for autos, but not limited to them,'' she said, so it bolsters the purchasing managers' view that the manufacturing sector is in a recovery.
Orders for electrical machinery increased by eight-tenths of 1 percent in May after a 4.4 percent rise in April, while non-electrical machinery orders were up by 3.5 percent after declining by 3.7 percent in April.
Military orders for capital goods, another volatile category, rose by 19.2 percent in May after increasing by 4.8 percent in April. Excluding military orders from both months, total factory orders rose by 1.5 percent in May after decreasing by 2.3 percent in April, the Commerce Department said.

HEADLINE: Banks With Stakes in Borrowers Are in Spotlight

BYLINE: By ANISE C. WALLACE

 BODY:
The eagerness shown recently by many bankers to restructure the debt of RJR Nabisco Inc. has put the spotlight on an unusual feature of the leveraged buyout phenomenon: banks that own equity stakes in their borrowers.
A total of 20 banks, including Bankers Trust, Citicorp, First Chicago, Manufacturers Hanover, Security Pacific and Wells Fargo, have invested their own capital in the Kohlberg, Kravis Roberts & Company buyout fund that bought RJR in 1989.
With RJR now trying to restructure its balance sheets by borrowing money to buy back some bonds and pay off some debt used to finance its $25 billion privatization, some of these banks are in the position of lending money to a company they indirectly own.
 
Growth in Buyout Funds
While such interlocking relationships among bankers and borrowers are thought to stabilize the financial markets in Germany and Japan, they were unheard of in this country until the mid 1980's, when buyout funds grew popular. Such funds take over a company by buying a small equity position with their partners' funds and then borrowing large amounts to buy the rest, using the target company's assets as collateral. Not only have banks lent the funds huge amounts to finance such takeovers, they have also bought shares in the funds themselves, making them part owners of the companies the funds buy. 
Critics say such relationships are potential conflicts of interest. They worry that banks, in an effort to prop up their investments, might throw good money after bad by giving highly leveraged companies in which they own an interest preferential treatment, shutting out other borrowers.
Such a ''closed loop,'' said Robert E. Litan, senior fellow at the Brookings Institution in Washington, is ''difficult for new companies to crack.''
 
Effect on Productivity
Depriving corporations of credit, these critics say, could ultimately hurt America's competitiveness. ''As a general rule, I don't think it's a positive element for the economy,'' said Samuel L. Hayes, a professor of investment banking at the Harvard Business School. ''A corporate policy that is driven by lenders' preoccupations is not best for productivity.''
But some bankers said this week that these interlocking relationships had not caused them to compromise their lending standards or to jeopardize their capital positions. Several said that their lending and investment decisions were made by two different groups within the bank.
''It's bad business practice to tie one to the other,'' said Gerald Rosenfeld, a managing director of merchant banking at the B.T. Securities Corporation, an affiliate of Bankers Trust that handles equity investments. It has invested in the Kohlberg, Kravis fund, but lending activities are handled by the parent company.
Bankers Trust is one of the lead banks in the syndicate arranging $2.2 billion in fresh loans for RJR. Another banker, who asked not to be identified, said that his bank and others were eagerly joining the syndicate because of their confidence in the company.
 
Federal Guidelines Met
Bankers also point out that their investments in individual companies through buyout funds are within Federal guidelines that prohibit bank companies or their affiliates from owning more than 5 percent of the voting stock of any company or more than 25 percent of the nonvoting stock. Because these investments are not publicly disclosed, it is unknown how much banks have invested in funds.
Through their venture capital arms, banks have invested their own capital - not depositors' funds or trust accounts managed for clients -in smaller funds other than Kohlberg, Kravis. These include those managed by Morgan Stanley & Company and Forstmann Little & Company.
They have been attracted not only by the huge returns of the equity partnerships, but also by the fee income they derive from making loans to the funds for their buyouts. Indeed, in recent years, financial intermediaries like Kohlberg, Kravis have become important customers for banks. $30 Billion in Loans Since Kohlberg, Kravis was formed in 1978, for example, it has borrowed about $30 billion from banks to buy 36 companies. (It also used $24 billion in high-risk, high-yield ''junk bonds.'') As a result, banks have collected at least $350 million in fees for financing these buyouts, estimated Christopher L. Snyder Jr., president of the Loan Pricing Corporation, a research firm in New York.
In 1988 alone, several of the banks that were leaders in lending to highly leveraged companies collected more than $150 million each in such fees, said James M. McCormick, president of the First Manhattan Consulting Group, a consulting firm to banks.
''Without the existence of these intermediaries, there wouldn't have been those tremendous fees,'' Mr. McCormick said.
One banker said yesterday that the chance to earn these fees prompted his institution to invest in the Kohlberg, Kravis buyout fund several years ago. The bank believed investing would help it win some of the lucrative lending business generated by Kohlberg, Kravis transactions.
''It's relationship-building,'' said this banker, who works for one of the biggest lenders to buyouts. ''These are good customers of ours.''
