HEADLINE: Dow Rises 12.37 in Sluggish Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks advanced yesterday for the fourth straight session, but with many traders and investors stretching their Fourth of July holiday, activity continued sluggish and is expected to remain so at least until Monday.
The Dow Jones industrial average, lifted by computerized buying programs, rose by 12.37, to 2,911.63. But volume stood at only 130.1 million shares, down slightly from 130.2 million on Monday. Advancing issues outweighed declining ones, 834 to 650, and 70 stocks reached new highs. 
Birinyi Associates, the Manhattan-based research firm, said that a brief computerized selling program close to 3 P.M. knocked nearly three points off the Dow but that two quick buying programs, including one almost exactly at the 4 P.M. close, raised the Dow by nearly 8.5 points.
 
Dow's Strength Questioned
The analysts argued that with trading thin it was difficult to assess the lasting power of the Dow at current levels, but the blue-chip index now stands less than 25 points from the record 2,935.89 set a month ago.
Maintaining that stocks might be moving higher because bond yields could be moving lower, Peter J. Canelo, investment strategist at Bear, Stearns & Company, said, ''The stock market's been doing better because the bond market's been doing better, and the bond market's been doing better because the indicators of inflation have been coming down.''
Asked about the chances of action from the Federal Reserve Board, he said, ''It's not clear that the Fed's going to move short-term interest rates lower immediately, unless the employment numbers coming out Friday are a lot weaker.''
Mr. Canelo said Bear, Stearns expected no change, which he called ''a pretty soft reading on the economy.''
One reason why the Fed might not take action, he said, is a weak dollar and rising gold prices. ''The dollar has been pretty weak in the past four or five days,'' he said, ''and gold prices are picking up.''
Philip Morris, which is moving heavily into the food business, led the New York Stock Exchange's most-active list, rising by 7/8, to a 52-week high of 48, with 2.6 million shares changing hands. Two weeks ago, it agreed to pay $3.8 billion for 80 percent of Jacobs Suchard, the Swiss coffee and chocolate producer.
General Electric, which rose by 5/8, to 71 1/8, in heavy trading, also set a 52-week high during the day of 71 3/8. Merck, which rose by 5 last week, rose by an additional 1/2, to 87 1/2, and then climbed to a 52-week high, of 88. The stock closed at 87 5/8, up by 5/8. Primerica also reached a 52-week high, of 35 1/2, before closing at 35 1/4, up by 3/4.
But the Dow transports fell by 3.65, to 1,140.51, with AMR down by 1 1/8, to 63, and the American President Companies down by 1 1/4, to 21 1/8, after reaching a new low of 20 3/4.
In the wake of a rise in gold prices, Newmont Gold rose by 1 5/8, to 43 7/8, and Newmont Mining, which owns 90 percent of Newmont Gold, rose by 1 1/2, to 45 1/4. ASA, with big South African interests, rose by 3/4, to 46 3/8.
 
Mentor Graphics Off $4.375
Mentor Graphics, a computer electronics company based in Beaverton, Ore., fell by 4 3/8, to 17 5/8, on nearly 5.7 million shares, leading the active list in the over-the-counter market after forecasting disappointing profits for the second quarter.
Microsoft, the software company with headquarters in Redmond, Wash., fell by 1 3/4, to 72, also in heavy trading on the Nasdaq. Robert Therrien of Paine Webber called the stock ''unattractive.'' He said he expected Apple Computer to win a copyright lawsuit against the company. Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., remained unchanged at 44.
Foremost, which insurers mobile homes and recreational vehicles, fell by 4 1/2, to 25 5/8, reaching a low of 25 1/2, after saying it had ended an unsuccessful six-month search for a buyer.
In other gauges, the Nasdaq composite index fell by 0.28 point, to 461.76. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose by 0.62 point, to 360.16, and the American Stock Exchange's market-value index rose by 0.53 point, to 360.67.

HEADLINE: Bank Fund and C.D. Yields Are Lower for Fifth Week

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were off slightly for the week ended yesterday. It was the fifth consecutive drop.
Of the 10 largest markets in the country, New York, Boston and Washington still offer the highest average yields on bank C.D.'s.
At the Treasury Department's regular weekly bill auction on Monday, interest rates were up slightly from the previous week. The auctions influence what many banks pay on money market accounts and certificates of deposit. The average discount rate for a new three-month bill rose by 4 basis points, to 7.78 percent, while the six-month bill rate increased by 3 basis points, to 7.67 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percantage point. 
 
New York Rates
The weekly survey of New York area banks and savings institutions by The Bank Rate Monitor showed an overall combined average rate decline.
Money market accounts were down the sharpest, to an average 6.39 percent from 6.43 percent, while three-month certificates and six-month certificates were both down a basis point, to 8.02 percent and 8.11 percent, respectively.
Among commerical banks, a money market account was unchanged at 6.34 percent, as was a six-month C.D., at 8.02 percent. A three-month certificate dropped a basis point, to 7.92 percent.
Yields at savings institutions fell more, with a money market account down 8 basis points, to 6.44 percent. Three-month certificates fell a basis point, to 8.12 percent, and six-month certificates dropped 2 basis points, to 8.20 percent.
Among 20 large banks outside the New York market, the average yield for a money market account was down a basis point, to 6.45 percent, while six-month certificates also fell a basis point, to 7.73 percent.
Rates at some of the country's large credit unions were mostly down a basis point. Money market accounts slipped to 6.66 percent. Rates for six-month certificates of deposit were 8.04 percent, one-year rates were 8.21 percent and five-year ones 8.31 percent. Two-and-a-half-year certificates dropped 2 basis points, to 8.26 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Session Lower As Rise in Pound Continues

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower yesterday in quiet pre-holiday trading, while the British pound continued to gain strength on worldwide markets.
Currency dealers attributed the dollar's decline partly to technical factors, as well as sterling's strength. 
Demand for the pound has increased in recent days amid widespread speculation that the currency will enter the European Monetary System's exchange rate mechanism.
In a speech at London's Institute of Economic Affairs on Monday, Karl Otto Pohl, president of the German Bundesbank, said he expected Britain's entry soon.
 
Sterling Is Higher
Sterling rose to $1.7800, from $1.7635, in London, and to $1.7765, from $1.7715 Monday, in New York.
The mark also gained against the dollar. The dollar fell to 1.6509 marks in Europe, from 1.6580, and to 1.6505, from 1.6515 Monday, in New York.
The mark has remained firm in foreign exchange following the monetary union in East and West Germany over the weekend.
In Tokyo, where the trading day begins, the dollar rose to a closing 151.68 Japanese yen, from 151.40 yen Monday. It was quoted at 151.15 yen in London, and at 151.00 yen in New York, up from 150.91.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's quotes, included: 1.3930 Swiss francs, down from 1.3965; 5.5400 French francs, down from 5.5450; 1,211.00 Italian lire, down from 1,212.75, and 1.16245 Canadian dollars, up from 1.16175.
Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Monday, were: 1.6509 West German marks, down from 1.6580; 1.3930 Swiss francs, down from 1.4030; 5.5400 French francs, down from 5.5635; 1.8578 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8650; 1,210.50 Italian lire, down from 1,217.00, and 1.1622 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1616.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
For Eastern Europe, U.S. Teachers

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
At first glance the people queued in front of Pan Am's ticket counter at Dulles International Airport looked like college students headed for a summer biking tour through England or France. A closer look suggested otherwise: their duffel bags bulged with English textbooks and Shakespeare anthologies, and their destination was Budapest.
For the first time, Eastern European governments are opening their classrooms to large numbers of American English instructors, including these 121 Peace Corps volunteers, who left in mid-June for Poland and Hungary. They were the first delegation to Eastern Europe in the Peace Corps's 30-year history. 
''It's a great way to dip our toes into history,'' said Alison Truitt of Denver, a 1989 Stanford University graduate in international relations who is headed for Hungary. ''It will be fascinating to be a witness of the changes in their political, economic and cultural systems.''
These volunteers are not alone in their mission. More than 600 English-language instructors, mostly recent college graduates, are planning to teach in Czechoslovakia, Poland, Hungary, Bulgaria, Romania and East Germany in the fall.
 
An Explosive Demand
''The demand is exploding,'' said Donna Culpepper, the United States Information Agency's branch chief for academic exchanges in Europe. ''The Eastern European countries would like four or five times the numbers of teachers we can send.''
Most students are traveling as part of privately financed projects, like those sponsored by the American Federation of Teachers' Education for Democracy International program, and the Charter 77 Foundation, a Czechoslovakian human rights group that is sending 80 college students and recent graduates to teach conversational English in Czechoslovakia this summer.
''I'm looking forward to being a firsthand witness to history,'' said John Shea of Arlington, Va., a May graduate of George Washington University who majored in international affairs and who will work in yet another program, Education for Democracy U.S.A., a grass-roots group based in Mobile, Ala., that is sending 300 teachers abroad.
Many others are angling for teaching jobs in Eastern Europe, including 80 graduating seniors from Georgetown University who went to Czechoslovakia last May.
Such efforts have been discouraged by American and Eastern European officials because most countries have their own teacher certification requirements. Opportunities for uncertified and inexperienced people without a plan of action are likely be limited. About half the Georgetown students are still seeking teaching positions.
 
Caution on Having Plan
''Without some sort of plan you are likely to be forgotten or ignored,'' said Helena Fierlinger, a program coordinator for Charter 77 who was born in Czechoslovakia.
Programs like that of the Peace Corps are giving volunteers intensive language and cultural instruction abroad this summer before they begin working in elementary and secondary schools and in teacher training colleges in September. Most teachers will live with families and receive $75 a month, commensurate with local living standards; room and board are paid by the government.
''Despite the pay cut, it seemed like a good idea,'' said Phyllis Stafford, 73 years old, of Indian Harbor Beach, Fla., a widow who taught high school English for 14 years and is the oldest Peace Corps volunteer in Hungary.
She and fellow volunteers loaded their bags with the works of Hemingway, Faulkner and occasionally Kurt Vonnegut.
Many also stuffed their luggage with quintessentially American commodities not readily available in Eastern Europe, like Frisbees and Nerf footballs.
 
Wanted: English Instructors
Peace Corps officials say Eastern Europe's political leaders have pleaded for English instructors.
''Among the emerging democracies, there's a uniform thirst for English language instruction,'' said Paul D. Coverdell, director of the Peace Corps. ''As these countries reach out and engage in the world, they need the English language to close the decades spent without commerce or communications with the West.''
Mr. Coverdell said the English-language training program would eventually expand throughout Central and Eastern Europe. On June 25, the Peace Corps signed an agreement to send 22 volunteers to teach English in Czechoslovakia in the fall. For the future, plans include training in small business development and environmental protection, Mr. Coverdell said .
Meanwhile, six Princeton University students are spending the summer starting student debating leagues in Poland, Hungary, the Soviet Union and Vietnam, among other countries. Their group, Global Student Response, was founded last year; it is devoted to promoting democracy and human rights and is financed with $4,500 from the university.
''Until now, holding a debate was a foreign concept for most Eastern European students,'' said the group's president, Stephen Wunker of Coral Springs, Fla., a Princeton senior majoring in international affairs. ''They haven't had any exposure to these types of democratic traditions.''

HEADLINE: U.S. Banks Cut Global Business As Rivals Grow

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Once the pacesetters for global expansion in the financial industry, American banks are retreating from foreign markets, losing business and stature to competitors from Europe and Japan.
The reduction in operations abroad is greatest in Europe, despite predictions of an economic boom there. The European economy is expected to expand as the 12 member nations of the European Community drop their trade barriers in 1992 and the economies of Eastern Europe respond to more liberal trade and investment rules.
Yet bankers say they are pulling back because they do not make enough money abroad. ''We will remain in the same 20 European countries we are in now, but the staffing will be leaner,'' said Thompson Swayne, the head of the Chase Manhattan Corporation's corporate finance group on Europe. He said Chase hoped to create specialized teams to handle different projects and still offer a full range of products. 
Whatever the reason for the retreat, the banks' strategy has led legislators, regulators and even some bank executives to worry that American banks will be outgunned even in the United States by larger foreign competitors. Foreign banks already hold 25 percent of the bank loans to businesses in this country.
''It is important that we not be dependent on foreign banks to provide financing for American corporations,'' said Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency and the nation's top regulator for nationally chartered banks.
The danger of declining into a sec-ond-rate banking and financial power is growing, he said, adding, ''We don't have very many banks right now who have as part of their long-term strategic plan the intention of being truly global.''
And Gary Parr, an investment banker at Wasserstein, Perella & Company, said: ''I worry that American banks have become too inward-looking. As the big banks in Europe consolidate, they will reach a size where they will be too big for American banks who are strong in a region of the country but nowhere else.''
American bankers found a gold mine in Europe in the early 1970's. The American practice of calling on corporate customers was novel in Europe, and it brought in a lot of business. But the European market is now vastly more competitive: European banks have adopted American sales techniques, and large corporations have learned to play one bank against another to obtain lower interest rates on loans or to bypass banks altogether and borrow in the securities markets.
 
Difficult Markets
Among smaller European companies, where a bank's profit margins on loans would be fatter, American banks have found it difficult to make headway. For the same reason, foreign banks have a hard time reaching such companies in the United States - the ties between small companies and their local bankers are not easily broken.
While Citibank, J. P. Morgan, BankAmerica and Chase Manhattan continue to operate large foreign networks, the American banking system as a whole is moving away from foreign markets. In addition to Europe, American banks have sharply reduced their presence in Latin America, as the region's economy weakened and many governments piled up huge debts with their foreign bankers.
The largest American banking company, Citicorp, is only the ninth largest in the world, after six Japanese and two French companies. The next largest American company, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, is 32d. Ten years ago, Citicorp was the world's largest banking company, BankAmerica was No. 2 and Chase No. 13, according to IPCA Ltd., a firm in London that analyzes the banking industry.
 
Statistics of Decline
At the end of 1988, 132 of the large American banking companies monitored by the Federal Reserve Board had 849 foreign branches, down from 163 of such banks with 917 branches overseas in 1984. The decline in the foreign assets of American banks has been even sharper, dropping to $275 billion at the end of 1988, a 19.8 percent decline from $343 billion in 1981.
Many bankers say the data for 1989, which are not yet available, will show further declines in branches and foreign assets.
American banks have also suffered steep drops in credit ratings - a serious matter for companies that rely on their financial strength to attract depositors. The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Wachovia Bank and Trust Company of North Carolian are the only American banks that hold a triple A long-term credit rating from Moody's Investors Service, a company that assesses the creditworthiness of companies. Six Japanese banks have the top rating, as do four French, four West German, three Swiss and two British banks.
 
Value of Triple-A Ratings
Having a triple-A credit rating is important in attracting the business of large corporate customers, like companies seeking letters of credit.
With slimmer pickings in foreign markets, many American banks have reduced or ended their operations overseas.
Wells Fargo & Company, the nation's 11th-largest banking company and one of the most profitable in the late 1980's, has eliminated all foreign offices. At one time Wells Fargo had a network of more than 20 offices in South America, Asia and Europe.
The Continental Bank Corporation, based in Chicago, and the Chemical Banking Corporation of New York have sharply cut their European lending business. They now concentrate on foreign exchange and securities trading in London and Frankfurt. Chemical has closed or sold its offices in Paris, Madrid and Milan.
 
Cutbacks at Chase
Among the handful of banks that have maintained large foreign networks, Chase Manhattan remains in 54 countries, but has pulled out of 22 countries in recent years. After cutting its overseas staff by more than 4,000 since 1986, primarily through the sale of banks in Belgium and the Netherlands, Chase last week announced plans for additional staff cuts in its foreign offices.
BankAmerica sold its majority share of Banca d'America e d'Italia in Milan, a profitable unit that was one of the largest consumer banking operations in Europe owned by an American bank. At the time, BankAmerica was in deep trouble from high expenses and bad loans.
Citicorp, the largest American bank holding company, is the only one expanding its international operations in both consumer and corporate banking. Citibank's strategy is to reduce the dominance of the bank's American activities in corporate banking, reducing its vulnerability to downturns in the American economy, and sharing in the rapid growth of countries that are in the early stages of industrial development.
 
Some Lack Resources
Other major American banks may admire Citibank's strategy, but they lack the resources to try it.
In consumer banking, Citicorp has 700 offices in 11 European countries, a more diverse base than any European bank. It is beginning to install automatic teller machines in West Germany, and plans to expand to a 1,000-office European network doing business with 5 percent of the more than 130 million households in Europe, up from its current share of about 3 percent. In Japan, Citibank is the only American bank trying to break into the consumer market, and it recently gained access to a Japanese network of more than 20,000 automatic teller machines.
While American banks try to pare their staffs and concentrate on high-profit deals, like mergers and acquisitions, many banking analysts say the cutbacks will inevitably result in lost business.
''Banks can keep enough staff overseas to bid for different corporate finance deals, but there has to be some business they will lose when they are no longer on the scene to take clients to dinner and build relationships,'' said Ronald Mandle, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
 
Not Enough Profit
Richard Simmons, the vice chairman of Chemical Banking, said the large wholesale loans that were the specialty of foreign offices ''did not produce enough profit to compensate for the risk.''
Now that many of Chemical's European offices are closed, the financing of American exports to foreign buyers is more difficult except for the very largest companies, he said. Such business is hard to conduct, Mr. Simmons said, ''if you do not have a someone on the scene who speaks the language and can review the financial statements of an importer.''
John F. McGillicuddy, chairman of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, said recently that large regional banking companies that have prospered by sticking to consumer and small business customers in their home region should begin developing international banking skills.
''If they don't, they will find not only that their growth factor is being restricted, but they will have an increasingly difficult job of maintaining the base of business they have at hand,'' he said.
 
New Regulations Urged
Executives at many of the nation's largest banks see the shrinking size and tarnished image of American banks as proof that the existing system of bank regulation in the United States should be scrapped in favor of something more favorable to American banks.
''You cannot be strong overseas if you are not strong at home,'' said Thomas C. Theobald, the chairman of Continental. To be stronger at home, he said, the American banking system needs a huge dose of consolidation, to eliminate much of the duplicated efforts among banks.
''There can still be lots of small community banks, but there are just too many banks which are large at home, but not big enough to compete overseas,'' Mr. Theobald said. He expects a wave of mergers to reduce the number of large banks by more than a third.
The wisdom of merging large banks to remain competitive internationally has been recognized in many foreign markets. The combination of Amsterdam-Rotterdam Bank and Algemene Bank Nederland, the two largest banks in the Netherlands, is one example, as is the announced merger of the two largest banks in Denmark, and recent combinations in Spain.
In Japan, which already has the world's six largest banks, the combination earlier this year of the Mitsui Bank and Taiyo Kobe Bank may be the first of other mergers. Isamu Koike, general manager of the Industrial Bank of Japan's New York branch, said recently that Japan had 155 banks, but ''from our perspective this is still too many banks.'' He added, ''The period of consolidation of the Japanese banking industry is knocking at the door.'' Morgan, J. P. First Wachoviad (wachovia b & t)

HEADLINE: ERA OF FREE TRADE TO BEGIN IN BRAZIL

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRASILIA, July 4

 BODY:
Breaking with decades of protectionism, Brazil's new Government has decided to open the nation's economy, the eighth largest in the West, to imports and free trade.
Computers, cars, raw materials and machinery will soon be able to enter the Brazilian market tariff-free, Zelia Cardoso de Mello, the Minister of the Economy, told reporters here today. Tariffs are now as high as 105 percent, but by 1994 they will reach zero for raw materials and 20 percent for most manufactured goods.
The move is the second major shock that Brazil's new President, Fernando Collor de Mello, has administered to the economy. On March 16, the day after taking office, he announced drastic changes that included freezing nearly two-thirds of the money in circulation in an effort to slow inflation, which was running at about 2,000 percent a year. A quick, sharp recession resulted, and prices plummeted. The inflation rate is now down to about 10 percent a month. 
The change on tariffs is intended to combat inflation by using competition to make goods less expensive and to end some monopolies in Brazilian industry.
In a first step last week, Mr. Collor cut tariffs on textiles and reduced requirements that many manufactured goods contain locally made compo-nents. He also ordered that import permits be issued within five days.
''It's fantastic - the consumer goods market here is enormous,'' David B. Atkinson, a representative of the Inter-American Development Bank, said here today.
 
A Striking Change in Policy
The change in policy is striking in Brazil, Latin America's largest market and a nation where industries have flourished for decades in a cocoon of high import barriers. Searching for precedents, Brazil's press has harked back to 1808, when a Portuguese regent fleeing Napoleon's occupation of Iberia declared that Brazil's ports were open to ''friendly nations.''
''The Collor Government moved Brazil from its position as one of the world's most closed economies to a nation with its doors wide open to the first-world economies,'' Brazil's leading newspaper, Gazeta Mercantil, said on Monday.
The trade initiative coincides with a wider movement to reduce trade barriers in Latin America.
President Bush, speaking at a gathering of Latin American ambassadors in Washington last week, called for a free trade zone in the hemisphere. Talks are under way between the United States and Mexico for an opening of borders.
On Thursday, Mr. Collor is to visit neighboring Argentina, where he is to call for cutting in half a 10-year period established for creating a regional free trade zone. Brazil's President said recently that he wants a common market in place with Argentina by the time he leaves office in 1995.
On visits to Brazil in recent weeks, United States trade officials have been so impressed by the new Government's commitment to free trade that Washington has dropped a series of restrictions on Brazilian goods. Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, has dropped Brazil from a watch list of potentially unfair traders and has lifted 100 percent punitive duties on a list of Brazilian goods.
 
Plan to Recognize Patents
Smoothing two trade issues of long-term concern to the United States, officials here say they plan to submit bills to Congress by the end of August to recognize pharmaceutical and software patents and to open Brazil gradually to computer imports.
Denouncing the ''senseless nationalism'' of past governments on the computer issue, Miss Cardoso predicted that Brazilian computer companies would enter into joint ventures with foreign companies.
Behind the new drive to open the country to imports is a spreading realization that this nation of 140 million people is falling behind other industrializing countries in growth and productivity.
Brazilians were recently shocked by a study of 10 leading industrial third-world nations by the International Institute for Management Development in Geneva. Ranked by industrial productivity, Brazil placed ninth - ahead of only India.
''The only way to train our business class is to submit them to competition,'' Mr. Collor told Brazilian newspaper editors here on Tuesday.
 
Mixed Results So Far
Brazil's 40-year-old president has had mixed results on other economic fronts since taking office.
By freezing bank accounts holding almost two-thirds of the money supply, Mr. Collor was able to depress demand sharply and bring monthly inflation down from 84 percent in March to 10 percent in June.
But most of the money has leaked back into circulation. One negative legacy is a deep distrust of banks. By one count, savings deposits in Brazilian banks dropped from $41 billion at the time of Mr. Collor's inauguration to $17 billion today.
Skepticism has also grown. In a survey by the DataFolha polling organization, the percentage of respondents rating Mr. Collor's Government ''good or excellent'' had plummeted from 71 percent at the time of the inauguration to 36 percent in late June.
In late June, a separate survey of Sao Paulo business executives, found that only 33 percent believed the ''Collor Plan'' was working.
For Mr. Collor and his young economic team - most of his advisers are in their 30's - progress has come slowly on attacking the root of inflation, the Government deficit.
To date, the President is about halfway toward his goal of cutting the civil service by about 25 percent, or 360,000 people. But the savings will be small until he can win - in the courts or in Congress - relief from laws limiting the dismissal of civil servants and requiring that laid-off civil servants be paid full salaries.
 
Privatization Difficulties
In another area, it is proving more difficult than expected to sell state companies into private hands. Officials recently cut in half a goal to sell 10 state companies by the end of the year.
Congress has thrown up legal roadblocks, and banks and insurance companies are fighting a central bank proposal that would force them to buy certificates that are redeemable only for shares in state companies.
Today, Miss Cardoso scaled back an original estimate of a 2 percent budget surplus this year to 1 percent.
Much of the inflation here is psychological - what Miss Cardoso today called ''the historical memory'' of 10 years with annual inflation over greater than 100 percent.
''Many Brazilian companies do not know how to set prices - they wait for the lead of the Government,'' an American banker in Sao Paulo said on Tuesday. After freezing all prices in March, the Government has freed most goods except for basic food items, vehicle fuel, cigarettes and pharmaceutical drugs.
To break the inflationary psychology further, Mr. Collor also hopes that foreign imports will force Brazilian monopoly producers to keep their prices down.
Miss Cardoso limited her comments today on the foreign debt to one ambiguous statement: ''Under our new view, the foreign debt has stopped being a deciding variable for economic policy, but an adjusting variable.''
In clearer language, the Minister of the Economy last week told the Sao Paulo news magazine Isto E, ''We have decided that the foreign debt impasse will not block the country from modernizing.''

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
24-NATION GROUP EXPANDS AID PLAN IN EASTERN EUROPE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, July 4

 BODY:
Foreign ministers from 24 leading industrial nations agreed today to expand their economic aid program for Poland and Hungary to include the emerging East European democracies of Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Yugoslavia and East Germany.
The decision did not involve any specific monetary pledges by the so-called Group of 24, which was established a year ago to coordinate aid to Eastern Europe. Rather, the officials agreed to consider aid requests from the four East European countries, assess what technical and financial assistance programs each donor nation is prepared to offer, and then meet again to hammer out a coordinated program of support.
Today's action may have been more important for the political signal it sent than the economic one. 
 
Political Criteria Used
Economic assistance from international institutions like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund has customarily been granted on the basis of purely economic considerations. But the 24 declared that the four East European countries were being aided because they had initiated not only certain minimum free-market economic reforms but also democratic political changes.
The statement said Romania was excluded because of the violent manner in which demonstrations in Bucharest were stifled last month by the Government of President Ion Iliescu.
The Group of 24 includes the 12 members of the European Community, seven other European countries, the United States, Japan, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. It was set up to coordinate assistance to Poland and Hungary to help them make the transition from planned economies to the free market.
 
Issue of Aid to Moscow
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said at a news conference that the donors had agreed that for now the problems of the Soviet economy were too great, and its political and economic reforms too slight, for the group as a whole to consider assistance to Moscow.
But in closed sessions, Italy, West Germany and France spoke in favor of immediate economic support to the leadership of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. While Mr. Baker reiterated Washington's opposition, he also said more explicitly than before that the Bush Administration would not oppose any country that wants to aid Moscow now.
Mr. Baker, who represented the United States at the conference today, said five American criteria had been agreed to as conditions for the coordinated economic assistance: adherence to the rule of law, respect for human rights, the introduction of multiparty political systems, the holding of fair and free elections, and the development of market-oriented economies.
''These criteria send a clear message to reformers and old thinkers alike,'' Mr. Baker said. ''Western assistance is designed to support fundamental political and economic reform. Its purpose is not to maintain the status quo or to revert to problems of the past.''
 
Opposes Pentagon View
Two weeks ago Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said the West should not be funneling economic support to Moscow as this would only subsidize the Soviet armed forces. In sharp contrast, Mr. Baker said today, ''If that is something other countries want to do at this point in time, and believe that is the proper course to follow at the time and think that the assistance will be put to good use, it is not our place to try and build opposition to that.''
The total assistance pledged to Poland and Hungary by the donor group now amounts to roughly $14 billion in direct aid, loans, credits, forgiven debts and technical assistance programs, with the United States contributing $938 million of that over the next three years.
The group's aid program is separate from that of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which was established by the United States, Japan and the European Community on May 30. With initial capital of $12 billion, the bank's charter stipulates that 60 percent of its credits be channeled to East European private business or state enterprises designated for privatization.
The group that met here today has the same membership as the Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, but is not formally affiliated with it.
In December, the Group of 24 agreed in principle to consider expanding aid to other East European countries in addition to Poland and Hungary, provided that their new governments met some minimum democratic and free-market conditions.
Today, Frans Andriessen, vice president of the European Commission and chairman of the conference, said, ''The evolution of the political and economic situation in Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and the German Democratic Republic provides a sufficient basis for the extension to them of coordinated assistance.''
 
Inclusion of East Germany
While it is assumed that the unification of Germany will overtake and make unnecessary any assistance program for East Germany, the foreign ministers felt it was important, for consistency's sake, to acknowledge that democratic reforms had taken place there.
Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee on Europe, is drafting a bill that would provide about $500 million in 1991 for economic assistance to Eastern Europe, including the Soviet Union if the Administration so chose.
Today's decision to expand aid to the four East European countries marked the first tangible expression of the Bush Administration's policy dealing with Eastern Europe on the basis of ''democratic differentiation.'' Under this policy, countries will be granted aid and support to the degree that they undertake reforms and respect human rights.
This explains why Yugoslavia, a nonaligned country that has not undergone fundamental political change, was included in the East European aid program, while Romania, which ousted President Nicolae Ceausescu only to replace him with another less-than-democratic regime, is being excluded.
Mr. Baker noted that Romania had ''not yet met the conditions required for G-24 support,'' adding, . ''The Iliescu regime's complicity with the miners' violent repression of demonstrators, and the arrest of the political opposition, raises serious questions about its commitment to democratic reform and basic human rights.''
 
Bush Sets Terms for Soviet Aid
KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., July 4 (Special to The New York Times) -President Bush said today that a reduction in Soviet military spending like that suggested by Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze could open the door to greater economic aid from the West to Moscow.
Pausing on the 18th hole of a Fourth of July golf game near his vacation retreat, Mr. Bush was asked about the speech by Mr. Shevardnadze on Tuesday in which he said the Soviet Union spends one-fourth of its budget on the military. ''I hope that given the changes in the world, they'll be able to curtail that defense spending some,'' Mr. Bush said. ''And if they do,'' he added, ''I think it would be much easier for the West to give them certain kinds of economic assistance.''

HEADLINE: Planning Is Begun on South Africa Aid Bank

BYLINE: By JOHN KIFNER

 BODY:
Nelson Mandela and the Rockefeller Foundation have begun to plan the creation of a South African development bank to change the country's white-dominated economy through foreign investment.
The development bank - an idea broached by the Rockefeller Foundation's president, Peter Goldmark, at a meeting with Mr. Mandela and American business executives in New York last month - would begin operations should a peaceful agreement be reached to establish a democratic government in South Africa.
It would be modeled along the lines of the World Bank and the new Bank for European Reconstruction and Development, which is aiding post-Communist Eastern Europe. 
 
'Talking About Billions'
''The germ of an idea has now at least become a seedling,'' Mr. Goldmark said yesterday in a telephone interview. ''The idea is to design it, establish it and then activate it when a democratic South African Government is in place.''
Mr. Goldmark and Frank E. Ferrari, the senior vice president of the African-American Institute, a private group that supports stronger ties between Africa and the United States, flew to London on Monday to meet with Mr. Mandela, at his request. Mr. Mandela had been taken with the proposal when Mr. Goldmark raised it at the meeting last month in the World Trade Center.
A core working group composed of Thabo Mbeki, the African National Congress foreign secretary, and Thomas Nkobi, the party's treasurer, and Mr. Goldmark has been set up to work on the proposal. Mr. Goldmark said the Rockefeller Foundation would provide technical assistance.
Money would come both from national governments and from the private sector, said Mr. Goldmark, who said ''a lot of people got in touch with me'' after he raised the bank proposal at the World Trade Center meeting.
''In order to make an impact, we'd have to be talking about billions,'' Mr. Goldmark said when asked about the scale of the project.
''The key to this vehicle would be investment for the sake of economic growth and investment to create a more equitable economy,'' he said.
Added to the popular acclaim Mr. Mandela received during his American tour, the proposal for a development bank would appear to bolster his political capital in negotiations with the white South African Government of President F. W. de Klerk.
Mr. Mandela has had a number of meetings with South African and American business executives, in part to allay fears that a future government would nationalize much of the economy. Mr. Mandela has insisted that the country's wealth must be divided more equitably, but he has also said, as he did at the World Trade Center meeting, that the A.N.C. has ''no blueprint'' for how this is to be done.
 
'Encourage Human Development'
Mr. Mandela has also said that less than 10 corporate conglomorates control 90 percent of the shares on the Johannesburg stock market and that more than 80 percent of South Africa's land is in white hands. He has said such ''excessive concentration of wealth'' on the part of a few must be redressed.
Mr. Goldmark said yesterday that reports indicated that per-capita white income was on the order of $10,000 a year while black per-capita income was less than $1,000.
Mr. Goldmark said the development bank could help build South Africa's infrastructure, providing, for instance, roads that would then improve the economy as a whole. The bank's investments could ''encourage human development,'' he said.
''Much more work has to be done, but the start is there,'' said Mr. Ferrari of the African-American Institute. ''Everything is contingent on a political settlement.''

HEADLINE: Amid Praise, Mexican Chief Draws Fire on Rights

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 1

 BODY:
As a candidate for President in 1988, Carlos Salinas de Gortari promised that he would modernize the Mexican economy and usher in an era of true democracy.
A quarter of the way through his six-year term, Mr. Salinas has more than exceeded expectations on the first count but has yet to convince Mexicans that he is sincere about the second.
Mr. Salinas continues to draw praise abroad and at home as a visionary boldly restructuring the ailing Mexican economy and willing to negotiate a free trade agreement with the United States. But he and the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, are facing a growing chorus of complaints about electoral fraud, human rights violations, intimidation of critics of the Government, unpunished police abuses and a generally imperious governing style.
Mr. Salinas's approach was described by a Mexican historian a few months ago as ''perestroika without glasnost,'' and the phrase instantly entered the political lexicon here. 
 
Ruled Since 1929
In his defense, supporters of Mr. Salinas say no Mexican president in modern times has done more to open up the country's political system. Still, the comparison to the Soviet Union is not accidental. Like President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Mr. Salinas faces the task of dismantling a political apparatus, born of a violent revolution, that makes virtually no distinction between the party and the state.
The PRI has ruled Mexico without interruption since 1929, and until last year had never been forced to acknowledge defeat in a gubernatorial election. Party bosses like 90-year-old Fidel Velazquez, a former milkman who has run the Mexican Labor Federation for more than 50 years, have prospered under the status quo and do not welcome the sweeping political and economic changes their 42-year-old President has proposed.
Indeed, it appears to have been much easier for Mr. Salinas to offer limited concessions to the opposition than to tackle the comprehensive reform of his own party.
''I definitely believe that the Government and the PRI are not willing to undertake a democratic reform because they are afraid of losing power,'' said Rodolfo Gonzalez Guevara, leader of the Critical Current, a small but outspoken dissident faction within the governing party. ''The PRI needs to change, but it cannot, because it is not an independent political party. It is registered as a political party, but it is run like a government agency.''
 
Government-Paid Campaign
Despite Mr. Salinas's declaration that ''the era of virtually one party rule is over,'' for instance, the opposition state government in Baja California Norte has made public documents showing that the PRI received $10 million from the Government to pay for its campaign.
Mr. Salinas has also forced three state governors to resign, a display of executive authority unmatched since 1947. To political analysts here, one of the implications of the action was that despite the President's repeated calls for ''transparent'' elections, PRI leaders who cannot deliver the vote will suffer the consequences, since all three men headed states which voted overwhelmingly for the opposition in the 1988 presidential election.
Barely a month after taking office in December 1988, the President won praise by sending in the army to arrest the corrupt head of the Oil Workers' Union and also forcing the resignation of his equally disliked counterpart at the powerful Teachers' Union. But Wayne Cornelius of the Center for U.S.-Mexican Studies at the University of California at San Diego, argues that in both cases ''these bosses have been replaced by more servile leaders who lack credibility and a broad base of personal support among the union membership.''
Other union leaders who stand in the way of Mr. Salinas's economic modernization program have been visited by members of his Cabinet and informed that their names do not appear on the registry of taxpayers. According to Mexican officials and foreign diplomats here, these labor bosses have been told they can either quietly go into retirement, in which case their large outstanding tax obligations will be forgiven, or stay on and face criminal charges.
 
'Decision-Making Style'
''Whatever accomplishments Salinas has engineered in support of political modernization, his decision-making style contradicts his own definition of political modernization,'' said Roderic A. Camp, author of ''Intellectuals and the State in 20th Century Mexico'' and a leading American expert on Mexican politics. ''His decision to use executive authority, sometimes with military force, raises the significant question of whether or not Salinas is sacrificing the ends for the means.''
The central issue of Mexican politics, though, continues to be the integrity of the vote and the willingness of the Government to abide by expressions of the popular will. Nearly every major state and local election held since Mr. Salinas took office has been marred by charges of vote fraud, leading opposition parties to conclude that Mr. Salinas is intent on preserving the privileges the PRI has enjoyed.
''When one talks of reforming the PRI, that includes electoral reform,'' said Mr. Gonzalez Guevara, a veteran party functionary. ''The PRI has spent 60 years in power because it controls the elections.''
To many of Mr. Salinas's critics, the seeming contradiction between his image as an economic reformer and his apparent reluctance to crack down on political skullduggery by the PRI has a simple explanation. Though he has brought down tariffs, sold off money-losing state companies, liberalized foreign investment rules and renegotiated the foreign debt, the economic benefits of those actions have yet to trickle down to the party's traditional constituency of peasants and workers, whose increasing dissatisfaction with the Salinas program would normally find expression at the ballot box.
 
Reservations on Business
''If the PRI follows its current economic line, which I think it is going to do because it is the President's economic project, it is going to be very difficult to win clean elections and for workers to vote for the party,'' Mr. Gonzalez Guevara argued.
Others within the PRI have reservations about Mr. Salinas's courtship of the the business class. Even former President Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, who handpicked Mr. Salinas as his successor, was recently moved to sound a cautionary note. ''We cannot have a blind faith in the market, in private enterprise and in businessmen as regards distribution of wealth and social justice,'' Mr. de la Madrid said in May.
But Mr. Salinas can afford to ignore such carping because public opinion polls indicate that he is vastly more popular than the party he heads. Though disputed official returns showed him winning only 50.7 percent of the vote in the 1988 election, Mr. Salinas's approval rating since taking office has run well above 70 percent. The PRI, in contrast, has the confidence of less than one-third of the population, and often ranks with the police as the institution most disliked by Mexicans.
One Mexican political analyst likens Mr. Salinas to ''a vampire, sucking the life out of the party'' and growing stronger as the PRI grows weaker. The country is rife with rumors that Mr. Salinas intends to extinguish the PRI. Under this scenario, the PRI would be renamed the National Solidarity Party, in the process gaining a new image and structure that would leave little role for the ''dinosaurs'' who oppose Mr. Salinas's economic program and have blocked his efforts to groom young ''modernist'' candidates for next year's crucial mid-term elections.
 
An Internal Debate
This internal debate may be resolved as early as September, when the party's 14th national assembly is expected to implement many of Mr. Salinas's reforms. Asked if the PRI will remain the PRI after the party congress, Mr. Salinas was noncommittal.
''The PRI will be what the PRI decides,'' he declared. The party, he added, ''is engaged in a process of dialogue and transformation that is not easy for it; however, this process is as indispensable as it is inevitable.''
''If the PRI wants to remain in power democratically,'' he continued, ''it must change and adjust itself to the new circumstance of competition.''

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, who has succeeded in modernizing the economy but has not yet convinced Mexicans he will strive for true democracy. (Paul Conklin)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: MEXICO (99%); UNITED STATES (90%); 

STATE: CALIFORNIA, USA (90%); 

CITY: SALINAS, CA, USA (90%); MEXICO CITY, MEXICO (79%);

HEADLINE: Talks in Taiwan Urge a Popular Presidential Vote

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 4

 BODY:
After five days of strenuous national debate, a national conference on this island's future concluded today with a call for popular presidential elections.
The endorsement of popular elections by the 150 delegates seemed to give a considerable lift to proposals that would restructure Taiwan's political system along much more democratic lines in coming years. President Lee Teng-hui had chosen all the delegates and given them a mandate to grapple with the intensely emotional question of Taiwan's future.
It was the first time that the Government and its opponents had openly discussed on a public stage some critical questions about Taiwan's future. They included: Should the nation revise its Constitution or draw up a completely new one? Should the Government adopt a presidential or parliamentary system? How should the 20 million people on Taiwan build economic links with 1.1 billion Chinese on the mainland? 
''This is a fantastic thing,'' said Kang Ning-hsiang, a prominent member of the Democratic Progressive Party, the opposition group. ''To bring all these people together to talk about our future is the greatest political event.''
With bells ringing every so often to signal the end of a speaker's floor time, delegates stood up one by one on podiums to state their views on various issues. The conference delegates included a student, a Mongolian, a Tibetan, a handful of previously jailed dissidents, and Chinese scholars from the United States.
The conference has no legal authority, and so it is not clear how their conclusions will be carried out.
''Everyone feels a little funny,'' said Jaw Shau-kong, a legislator from the governing Nationalist Party and a delegate to the conference. ''This is outside the legal system.''
The agreement on popular presidential elections was the most important decision at the conference. Currently, the President is elected through the National Assembly, an electoral college that is made up mostly of elderly men, who purport to represent constituencies on mainland China.
 
Charter Revision Proposed
While they agreed on presidential elections, delegates were divided on whether citizens should elect the President through an electoral college or bypass that step and hold direct elections.
The delegates also debated ways to restructure the island's legislature, which has passed only one minor law in its current session, which ends in a few weeks. President Lee and other Nationalist leaders have indicated that Taiwan needs a constitutional overhaul, but that that may not be easy to achieve.
In one move that will make Parliament more democratic, Taiwan's highest court ruled recently that those aging legislators - unelected in decades - must resign by the end of next year. Opposition members want an earlier deadline.
President Lee said in March that he would revoke within about a year the Government's 40-year-old declaration of ''Communist rebellion'' on mainland China. Changing that condition, which vests the President with special powers, would require altering Taiwan's Constitution, and there was no consensus on how to revise it.
The opposition party is demanding that the Government scrap the Constitution and write a new one. And while the party's voice has been more influential than its 30,000 membership would suggest, it is not clear that it has much support on this issue.
Still, delegates agreed that constitutional changes are inevitable and some hoped the conference would deepen the sense of urgency.
''We can keep the momentum of reform, and not just of the Constitution,'' said Ma Ying-jeou, a Nationalist Party delegate and Cabinet-level official. ''The party structure has to be democratized to cope with new constitutional democracy.''
Probably the most delicate and emotional issue of the conference focused on Taiwan's policy toward mainland China. During the last couple of years, relations between China and Taiwan have warmed dramatically.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
NATO Leaders Gather, In Search of a Purpose

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 4

 BODY:
When President Bush and the 15 other leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization gather in the palace of Lancaster House on Thursday morning, they will begin the most crucial summit meeting since the alliance came into being 41 years ago.
NATO, formed at the height of the cold war to reassure the weakened nations of Western Europe that the United States would stand firm with them against intimidation or attack from the Soviet Union, has lost its original premise.
The Soviet Union is grappling with an economy in chaos and a political system in turmoil; the Warsaw Pact, set up as Stalin's answer to NATO, is collapsing; and the former Eastern European satellites are edging into a more Western orbit.
East and West Germany, divided along the front lines of East-West confrontation, united economically last Sunday and plan to unite politically after all-German elections on Dec. 2.
 
Preserving Peace and Stability
So over the next two days, the NATO leaders have set themselves the task of transforming their alliance, reassuring the Soviet Union, and each other, that a united Germany will not endanger the peace and stability that prevailed during the four decades of its division. 
Mr. Bush will be among the last to arrive on Thursday morning, a few hours before the meetings start. According to diplomats involved in the preparations, he and the others will agree formally to abandon the NATO strategy of ''forward defense'' that positions American and German forces against possible Soviet attack from East Germany, because neither the threat nor the forces to resist it have their former strength.
They will try to leave NATO's reliance on nuclear deterrence of attack intact, but less threatening than the strategy of ''flexible response'' that has been in effect since 1967. According to American diplomats, they may agree to let President Bush invite President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to address a high-level NATO council meeting in Brussels this year or next.
And they will try to lay down guidelines for a new Atlantic charter that they hope will be as lasting and effective as the North Atlantic Treaty that Ernest Bevin, Dean Acheson, Robert Schuman and other leaders signed on April 4, 1949, to reassure a tense and frightened Western world.
 
A Change in Purpose
NATO will describe itself as no longer a defensive military alliance but a political organization engaged in building East-West structures of peace, diplomats say, building on Article 2 of the 1949 treaty pledging the signatories to ''the further development of peaceful and friendly international relations.''
Now, as four decades ago, the allies will look to the United States to help insure their security in the new European era that dawns after German unification, once its terms are agreed upon between the Germans and the United States, Britain, France, and the Soviet Union and discussed in Paris at the 35-nation summit meeting of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe in November.
But this time, the Soviet Union is also looking to the alliance for reassurance that NATO is prepared to let Moscow prove that it can become a partner in European security instead of the main military and nuclear threat against it.
 
German NATO Membership
Soviet leaders say the security conference framework is the best way to do this, and both European and American diplomats say that NATO will make a large gesture toward it in the communique, partly because of pressure from West Germany and its closest European ally, France. West German officials believe that whether the Soviets finally drop their objections to letting a united Germany belong to NATO will depend significantly on what the allies say to the world here when they end the summit talks at mid-day on Friday.
On its eve, President Bush proposed a NATO declaration that the alliance would use nuclear weapons only as a last resort. Some in Britain and France fear that such a pledge would weaken the alliance's nuclear deterrence at a time when the Soviet Union, however distracted, is still the largest nuclear military power in Europe.
But the European allies have already welcomed Mr. Bush's announcement, also in the letter, that American short-range nuclear artillery shells will be withdrawn from West Germany, since they will no longer have targets once Soviet forces withdraw from East Germany.
The West Germans are proposing that the 16 NATO countries, together or separately, pledge non-aggression with the seven Warsaw Pact countries.
 
Warsaw Pact's Future
The main objection to a joint NATO-Warsaw Pact declaration, for instance, is that NATO should not tie itself too closely to the Warsaw Pact because that alliance is clearly already dead.
''There's a difference between a deathbed marriage and a marriage to a dead person,'' said Francois Heisbourg, director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies, noting that Hungary's newly elected parliament voted a week ago, 232 to 0, to leave the Warsaw Pact by the end of 1991 because it has no reason to exist.
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's reservations about declaring that nuclear arms are weapons of last resort stem from her belief that such a pledge would weaken their deterrent effect, her advisers say.
One of Mrs. Thatcher's aides said this week that when she saw Mr. Gorbachev in Moscow last month, he backed off his earlier calls to eliminate all nuclear weapons from Europe and agreed that small numbers of them on both sides could play a stabilizing role.
''It would be better,'' this adviser said, ''to have a declaration pledging to negotiate the numbers of short-range nuclear weapons down to the lowest possible level, as quickly as possible.''
In May, the United States said it would be prepared to open such negotiations with Moscow as soon as an agreement had been reached on reduction of United States and Soviet conventional forces in Europe, the subject of negotiations in Vienna.
But there are other worries that will be in the background as the allied leaders confer, dine with Queen Elizabeth II in the glitter of Buckingham Palace on Thursday night and hammer out their declaration of purpose in Lancaster House on Friday morning.
They worry about the United States. If Washington and Moscow agree on troop reductions in Vienna, the Soviets will come down to only 195,000 soldiers stationed in Poland and East Germany, with considerable pressure to withdraw all or most of those soon after German unification. Will the United States be prepared to keep 225,000 troops here after that?
 
Size of German Army
And they worry about West Germany, which some of its allies fear is already going ''soft'' on defense. Preparing for the NATO summit meeting, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Cabinet argued but could not agree on how much to reduce the size of the future all-German army - from the present West German level of more than 400,000 to 300,000, or closer to 250,000, as the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, recently suggested, according to one NATO diplomat.
Mr. Kohl has been pressing for a Western commitment to offer the Soviet Union economic and financial aid to rebuild its economy, but he is now expected to make his big push on that next Monday and Tuesday, when he, Mr. Bush and other leaders of the world's seven largest industrial democracies meet in Houston.
''What we really are concerned about,'' one NATO official said, ''is whether the Germans will tolerate any foreign forces at all after they get unification. If they then move to kick out the British, Belgian, French, Dutch and American forces, and they might, then we have no alliance at all, and the European Community would be torn apart.''

HEADLINE: LIBERIAN OFFICER IS SAID TO DESERT

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
The chief of President Samuel K. Doe's personal security force deserted today as Liberian rebel forces fired captured artillery and mortars at Government positions and inched closer to the center of Monrovia, the capital, United States officials said.
The officials monitoring cable traffic on the Liberian situation from Washington said that the official, Gen. Charles Julue, commander of the 800-member Executive Mansion Guard, had reportedly fled by land, arriving in neighboring Sierra Leone. They said that once his departure becomes widely known to the rank and file in the struggling Liberian Army, the Government would probably collapse.
A senior State Department official said General Julue's defection ''is a sign that the will to resist is crumbling.'' A second State Department official said the end of the seven-month civil war seems near. 
President Doe met today with the American Ambassador, Peter De Vos, at the presidential mansion to discuss the crisis and an American offer to take him out of the country. An American official said Mr. Doe had neither refused nor accepted the offer.
 
An Offer of Asylum
Togo has privately offered Mr. Doe asylum. The United States has not offered him refuge, primarily because it has an extradition treaty with Liberia.
The American officials speculated that General Julue left his post because as the prospect of a rebel victory grew, so did the chances of his being killed by the rebels for his leadership of attacks on members of the Gio ethnic group following a failed 1985 coup against President Doe.
The rebel forces, led by Charles Taylor, have held General Julue responsible for the deaths of hundreds of people, a State Department official said.
The civil war has been fought along ethnic lines, with Government forces dominated by members of the Krahn and Mandingo tribes, and Mr. Taylor's forces consisting mainly of members of the Gio and Mano ethnic groups. General Julue and most of his palace guard are Krahns, as is President Doe, who was said to remain in the palace, only three miles from the fighting.
 
Divisions in Rebel Ranks
The officials in Washington also reported that even as the rebels gain ground, divisions in their ranks were appearing. Prince Johnson, a former rebel commander, holds a vital iron mine 50 miles north of Monrovia with 200 guerrillas and says he opposes both Mr. Doe and Mr. Taylor.
Reports of the fighting from Monrovia remain skimpy because local telephone and telex lines have been cut.
Herman J. Cohen, the Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, said his reports from the United States Embassy in Monrovia indicate that the guerrillas had captured a multiple rocket launcher and were deploying the weapon along with mortars in an attack on Elwa Junction, one of two routes onto the peninsula on which downtown Monrovia is situated.
There was also heavy fighting reported in the eastern suburb of Paynesville, the western suburb of Brewerville, on both sides of the St. Paul River Bridge, and on the Ring Road freeway on the outskirts of the capital.
 
'Only a 10-Minute Drive'
Mr. Cohen said President Doe has still not responded to American offers to help him leave the country safely. ''He can send a messenger to our embassy any time with his answer. It is only a 10-minute drive,'' he added.
The United States Government is backing a mediation effort sponsored by the Economic Community of West African States, which has called for peace negotiations and the installation of an interim Government excluding both Mr. Doe and Mr. Taylor. The proposed interim Government would lead the country until national elections.
Mr. Doe has refused to step down, although he has agreed not to seek re-election.
While Pentagon officials have quietly spoken in favor of Mr. Taylor, the State Department has insisted that it favors neither side in the Liberian conflict. The Administration has long complained about human rights abuse and corruption under the Doe Government, but it has also expressed concern about Mr. Taylor, whose forces it says have received aid and training from Libya.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Samuel K. Doe of Liberia. The head of his personal security force reportedly deserted yesterday, bringing his Government closer to collapse. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Houston Ballyhoos Its Rebirth, Again

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 4

 BODY:
For Mayor Kathryn Whitmire, the Economic Summit of Industrialized Nations, to be held here next week, is ''probably the biggest thing to happen in Houston since the Johnson Space Center came to town.''
For Henry de La Garza, president of his own public relations concern, the summit conference is ''magic, simply magic.''
For Ben F. Love, retired chairman of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc., the city's biggest financial institution, it is ''an opportunity to tell the world we survived our economic problems and that we have a lot to show for it now.''
This city of booms, busts and unbridled boosterism has converted the act of staging the conference into a rite of passage. Like most of the 15 previous such meetings, the one that begins here Monday may prove to be a footnote or less in world history. But for Houston, it is an occasion to proclaim itself a city reborn. 
 
Force of 12,000 Volunteers
Elsewhere, world fairs and olympic games have been used to ballyhoo municipal grandeur, but rarely has a city tried to make so much of an event that officially lasts only 48 hours. So far 12,000 volunteers have offered their labor and about $10 million has been contributed in cash and goods to make the meeting a drama fit for a global audience.
The message repeatedly announced by the business leaders, the news media and much of the political leadership is that Houston is back on its feet after the catastrophic oil price recession of the 1980's and that it is ready once again to engage in the economic competition it relishes.
The city hit bottom in 1987 and then started coming back almost as fast as it had gone down. For two and a half years now, employment has grown at a faster rate in Houston than it has nationwide. The recovery, fueled by the growth in refining and chemical plants and the emergence of non-energy industries, was crowned this spring when the city's unemployment rate dipped below the national average for the first time in eight years.
The world will hear these sunny statistics only for the few days the leaders of Britain, France, West Germany, Italy, Canada and Japan join President Bush here because he chose to hold the event in the city he calls his hometown. In the two other years when it was the turn of the United States to be host to the annual meeting, it was held in Williamsburg, Va., and in Puerto Rico.
Brazen self-promotion is very much in character for Houston. Yet amid all the hoopla, there are also clear signs of how much the city has changed as a result of its economic roller-coaster ride and how much it is still undergoing a very uncharacteristic process of self-examination.
 
The Recovery
Getting in Tandem With the Country
''Until recently the public perception of the recovery seems to have lagged behind the recovery itself,'' said Barton A. Smith, chairman of the economics department at the University of Houston, ''because it seems that many people are only now accepting in their own minds what has been clear in the indicators for some time.''
Given what the city has been through, a degree of caution is understandable.
In the five years after oil prices crashed in 1982, Houston lost about 225,000 jobs, about an eighth of the total work force. Since mid-1987 it has regained about 80 percent of them. During the economic bust, property values dropped by 30 percent or more. Even though house prices in some neighborhoods scored double-digit gains last year, the real estate market has not fully recovered for the most part.
 
'A Delicate State'
Forecasts of steady, if moderate, growth have become a matter of consensus among economists and have won the confidence of the public.
Rents in the central business district downtown are on the rise, to an average of about $15 a square foot, and in the past year tenants have begun occupying the last of the near empty skyscrapers that became a symbol of the city's decline. But not all areas and all groups have made a complete turnaround.
''The economy is still in a pretty delicate state as far as a lot of people are concerned, because they are still hurting,'' said El Franco Lee, a black Harris County Commissioner who represents inner-city areas. He was speaking of the black, Hispanic and Oriental people who live the old city wards close to downtown.
The recovery, and its limitations, are perhaps most visible in the swaths of subdivisions and shopping malls that are strung along freeways for as much as 50 miles from downtown. Work crews are swarming over many low-rise apartment complexes that had deteriorated until grass broke through the parking lot asphalt. Investors are repainting, rehabilitating and renaming them on the assumption that Houston will once again become a mecca for ambitious young people.
 
Vacancy Rates Are Down
A recent market survey by Coldwell Banker Commercial Real Estate Services found that vacancy rates for downtown office space had dropped to about 17 percent from 32 percent.
The Houston economy changed so rapidly in the 1980's that its future is necessarily uncharted. The most dramatic change involves a move away from dependence on the exploration, production and transportation of oil and gas.
As a result, the Houston economy has become more like that of the rest of the country. There is some disagreement among the experts, however, as to whether the down years might have given Houston a competitive advantage.
Ray Perryman, director of the Baylor University Forecasting Service, predicts that the Houston economy will ''expand at a quicker rate than the U.S. and Texas over the next two decades.'' He attributes this in part to a comparative advantage in labor and real estate costs, which dropped with the city's economy. On the other hand a recent study by the Federal Reserve Bank found that if forecasts for a national slowdown prove true and the expansion of the petrochemical industry plays itself out as expected, ''Houston's economic expansion will slow down.''
 
THe Leadership
Changing Times, Changing Faces
Houston's past does not necessarily offer clues as to where it is going. While most major cities were born of a confluence of history and geography, Houston was founded as an unlikely real estate scheme. It is an invented city that continually reinvents itself.
Once a cotton town, then a rail center, Houston mushroomed into a metropolis after World War II under the aegis of oil men, and it bore the stamp of entrepeneurs devoted to the idea that low taxes and minimal interference by government would assure prosperity from private business.
During the 1970's and 1980's an entire generation of domineering figures passed from the scene, like Gus Wortham and James S. Abercrombie, with the economic collapse quieting those not stilled by death.
 
'Broadened the Base'
Mr. Love, who served as banker to many of the city's economic giants, said: ''I think we now have a much stronger city because we have broadened the leadership base. During the downturn we saw that we were not invincible and that we could not withstand the tests without drawing on all our resources.''
The conference has provided one sign of how much the leadership has been democratized. Representatives of minority groups make up one-fifth of the 270-member Host Committee. Although that percentage is less than half the minority share of the city's population, it is still a notable figure in a city once dominated by white males.
Mr. de la Garza, the son of Mexican immigrants, said: ''Ten years ago it would have been inconceivable that someone like me would have been asked to participate in something like the Host Committee. When I got the call, I just thought how proud my parents would be.''
With the passing of the old leadership, old ideas have suddenly been challenged. The most important of those ideas is that local government should play little role in determining how land is developed. That dogma has left Houston the only major city in the United States with no zoning system.
 
Re-Evaluating Old Beliefs
''Changes in public opinion have created a willingness to re-evaluate traditionally held beliefs and to look at what's been done elsewhere, like zoning,'' said Mayor Whitmire, who during her re-election campaign last fall dismissed any possibility of a zoning system here but a few months later appointed a committee to study the issue.
The impetus to re-examine some basic premises has come from two very different directions.
A few major developers like Gerald D. Hines, who has left his mark with giant commercial projects in this city and around the country, like the Norwest Center in Minneapolis, have begun to assert that the lack of restrictions on land use could slow future growth. These critics cite the uncertainties inherent when an investor has no way of knowing whether the land next to his office tower might be occuped by an industrial plant.
 
The Future
Is It Time to Say What to Build?
Homeowners, primarily of the working and middle classes, have been the other source of complaints about the lack of controls.
John Mixon, a law professor at the University of Houston, helped stimulate the zoning debate this year by creating a proposal for zoning on a neighborhood basis that would not require sorting out the entire hodgepodge that is Houston.
''With the bust,'' he said, ''the illusion of constant mobility vanished for many homeowners who realized they could not pick up and move if their neighborhood went downhill because they could never sell their houses and break even. As a result, people started realizing they had to protect what they owned.''
 
Covenants Among Landowners
Across most of the city the only regulation on land use is through deed restrictions, private covenants among landowners that have proved expensive and difficult to enforce. As a result a growing number of neighborhood groups have begun to complain about their inability to prevent invasions by fast food shops, small warehouses and apartment complexes.
Since 1988, prices have climbed by nearly 10 percent in distant Houston suburbs where developers enforced restrictions on the use of land in communities developed under master plans, according to a survey of neighborhood property values by Mr. Smith. Values rose even more in the few communities within the city limits that are incorporated villages with their own land-use rules. In areas with free-for-all development, prices rose from 1 to 5 percent.
 
'Step Back and Decide'
Although the issue is far from settled, a number of the city's leaders who once fought zoning now agree with Mr. Love that ''we are in a real estate lull now, and so it is appropriate to step back and decide whether zoning would help the next round of building.''
The stakes in the zoning debate go beyond real estate. The relationship between public and private powers could be reshaped as the city tries to decide how to insure a quality of life that keeps it attractive and growing.
When the leaders of the industrialized democracies come to Houston next week, they will find a city that is reborn but that is now deciding what it wants to be when it grows up.
 
 
HOUSTON AT A GLANCE
 
History
Houston was founded in 1836 by two brothers from New York, who named their new settlement after Gen. Sam Houston, hero of the Texas war for independence from Mexico (1835-36). The brothers, John K. Allen and Augustus C. Allen, purchased 6,642 acres of land near the juncture of Buffalo and White Oak bayous from the widow of John Austin for $9,428, four months after the defeat of Gen. Santa Anna's Mexican forces at San Jacinto on April 21, 1936. In November 1836 the Republic of Texas selected Houston as its temporary capital. The capital was moved to Austin in 1839.
 
Geography
Houston, the seat of Harris County, is situated on Buffalo Bayou about 50 miles northwest of the Gulf of Mexico at Galveston, Tex. The two cities are connected by the Houston Ship Channel.
 
Vital Statistics
 
Population: 1,728,910*
Rank among U.S. cities: 4th
Per capita personal income: $15,200 a year
Vacancy rate for office space: 28.3 percent in June 1989**
Average high in July: 93.6 degrees
Year of incorporation: 1837
 
*1986 estimate.
**2d highest among 25 largest cities.
