HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Where Right Spin Can Mean You're In

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 4

 BODY:
When President Bush appointed a Washington lawyer named Stephen Potts to the Administration's top ethics post two weeks ago, the choice seemed curious at first.
Although chosen to head the Office of Government Ethics, Mr. Potts had no background in either government or ethics law, and he had not toiled in the Bush campaign.
How did he meet the President?, Mr. Potts was asked.
On the tennis court, he replied. It turned out that while Mr. Potts might not have specialized in conflict-of-interest regulations, he knows a lot about put-away shots, having won five national father-son tennis championships with his son, Deaderick. 
Mr. Bush had recruited another official for his Tennis Cabinet.
As in other things, the President takes his cue from Theodore Roosevelt, who in 1903 built the first White House tennis court, for his daughter, Alice, and then proceeded to monopolize it with mustachioed advisers and pitchers of mint juleps.
''The Tennis Cabinet is supposed to be that coterie which plays tennis with the President and between plays gives him points on people and things,'' Archie Butt, a Roosevelt aide and frequent player, once wrote, adding that the group engaged in more play than work on the court.
Like Mr. Bush, Roosevelt was an aggressive player. When Archie Butt bopped the Rough Rider on the head with a shot one day and began to apologize, Roosevelt waved him off, saying, ''If I hit you, I am not going to apologize, so you just bang away at me as much as you like and say nothing in the fray.''
Mr. Bush likes to take the measure of people on the playing field. As his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, says, ''Subconsciously, at least, he judges people by their competitive attitude on the courts.''
Mr. Bush himself says: ''I'm a great believer that sports can do wonders for friendships and establishing common ground. Have always felt that way. Still feel that way.''
He first met Nicholas F. Brady, his close friend and now Treasury Secretary, on a tennis court.
He met Roger Porter, his domestic policy chief, when Gerald R. Ford, then President, invited the two to the White House for a doubles match.
Mr. Bush became friends with his Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, when the pair joined forces in the late 1950's to win the doubles championship at the Houston Country Club two straight years.
He met David Bates, his former Cabinet secretary and continuing member of the Tennis Cabinet, when Mr. Bates played tennis as a boy with Mr. Bush's son Jeb at the Houston Country Club.
Mr. Bush does not play anymore with Mr. Brady, who had a hip replacement, or Mr. Baker, who has a shoulder injury. But he has made sure his Administration is stocked with plenty of ''A'' and ''B'' players. The Bush racquet club includes Mr. Porter; Mr. Bates; Michael J. Boskin, the President's economic adviser; Gregg Petersmeyer, the head of the Points of Light program; C. Boyden Gray, the President's counsel, and the most talented tennis player on the White House court, Mr. Bush's youngest son, Marvin.
Being a member of Mr. Bush's Tennis Cabinet offers a certain cachet and an opportunity to mention a pet project as the players change ends.
''Once, when I was pressed for time, I mentioned something to the President on the court, and afterward everyone said, 'How did you get to him so fast?' '' Mr. Porter recalled. ''It saved me writing a memo.'' But ordinarily, the advisers know that for this President, tennis is very serious business. Mr. Bush will sometimes call in aides on the pretext of some business of state and then get down to the real point of analyzing recent wins and losses at the White House or at Camp David. He likes to reckon who's coming up and who's slipping and how doubles teams can be rearranged to increase competition.
Sometimes, when other officials are playing, the President will wander down with Millie, the first family's dog, to the First Court, tucked in a garden of shrubbery on the South Grounds, and watch a few games, calling out as he leaves that he expects a full report after the match.
Unlike Jimmy Carter, George Bush does not keep track of who's using the court. He keeps track only of the score.

HEADLINE: All Except the Texas Heat Is Under Rug for Summit

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 4

 BODY:
In the ''war room'' tucked inside a nondescript suite in a high-rise building here, volunteers staff a bank of telephones in front of a wall-size map.
Every day for several months now, those phones have been ringing with urgent reports: trash has been found in spots that might be glimpsed by the dignitaries or reporters who will start arriving here this weekend for the 1990 economic summit meeting.
Each caller's sighting - a trash-strewn vacant lot, an abandoned sofa at curbside - is immediately entered on an official ''waste spotter report,'' which is dispatched to the appropriate district leader. The district leader, in turn, calls the appropriate quadrant leader, who goes to the site and personally inspects the trash. 
The site is then assigned a priority number, based on the nastiness of the mess and the likelihood that an important out-of-towner will see it. A color-coded flag is then placed in the wall-size map, and a cleanup crew is dispatched to cart the trash away. $10 Million Donated Houston is taking the economic summit meeting very seriously.
The event, at which the leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Japan and West Germany will meet with President Bush, will run from Monday through Wednesday. About $10 million in privately donated funds will be spent.
''Houston is already clean,'' said Donald Fitch, who with Limus Jefferson is co-chairman of the Houston Clean Committee. ''We just want to make sure it's the cleanest it can be.''
Carrie Hendrix, deputy executive director of the Houston Host Committee, the group responsible for the logistics of the event, said, ''The eyes of the world will be on Houston for those four days.''
As a result, the city is practically re-creating itself, and not just by cleaning up an estimated four million pounds of trash.
City leaders have urged citizens to plant red and white flowers because the colors show up best on television. The police department has kept 100 badly needed police cars out of service so that they will be new and shiny when they escort motorcades. The county sheriff has spent $35,000 for new uniforms and riot gear to control protests being planned by groups as diverse as the National Organization for Women and the Ku Klux Klan.
 
Charm School for Cab Drivers
Taxi drivers have been given free courses on how to be polite to visitors. The roads have been repaved at Rice University, where the summit meetings will be held, and a fire hydrant there has been moved away from a path where the leaders are scheduled to walk so there will be no unphotogenic tripping or bumping of knees.
There are even attempts to put the best face on the city's brutal, swamplike July weather. Earlier this month Houston planners announced a new slogan that they hope will make a selling point out of 95-degree heat and make delegates forget that walking outside feels like entering a windowless room where a hot shower has been running full force.
The slogan, along with a fluorescent logo and bouncy theme song, is ''Houston's Hot!'' - and a series of 10-second broadcast advertisements tell residents how to respond when visitors point out that fact. A sample answer: ''Yes, Houston is hot. Retail sales are up 7 percent.'' Despite some minor embarrassment when it was learned that a local guidebook to topless bars had been using the same slogan for years, summit meeting officials say they are pleased with their pun. ''It's the ultimate spin control,'' one committee member told reporters.
 
Toning Down the Plans
The enthusiastic approach to the summit meeting began almost immediatly after the announcement last December that Houston had been selected over San Antonio, the first runner-up, to be the host city for the event. Within days, dozens of city institutions had asked to be included in the list of official events.
More than once, the White House has stepped in to tone down the plans. A 25-mile drive to the Johnson Space Center was rejected for logistical reasons, and there was not enough time for an evening of opera and ballet at the Wortham Theater. The only large event that was not deleted was a kickoff rodeo Sunday night, at which stars of the Grand Ol' Opry -which is from Nashville, for goodness sake - will perform.
That announcement caused a battle on the newspaper opinion pages here, with arts leaders expressing outrage that Houston, a great performing arts city, will simply reinforce its stereotype as a cowboy town. To soothe ruffled feelings, the Bushes will give a party on the last night of the meeting, after the other leaders have left, for the more than 10,000 volunteers who worked on the event.
All this and every other tidbit about the summit meeting has been followed avidly here. Much attention has been given to which delegation will be staying at which hotel, particularly the fact that the Japanese requested the lodging already reserved for the Canadians, while the Italians had to settle for their second choice, too, because their favored rooms were already taken by the British.
 
An International Menu
The city's entrepreneurs have staked their claims as well. Jack Jaumo, a wholesale chocolate distributor, is selling candy bars with an ''Economic Summit 1990'' wrapper. The Bistro Vino restaurant is offering a special international menu, including stuffed mushrooms with Italian sausage, French onion soup, spinach salad topped with Canadian bacon and a mixed grill entree with English prime rib of beef, German bratwurst and Japanese chicken teriaki. Dessert, naturally, is apple pie.
With every detail so meticulously attended to and enthusiasm so high, the major remaining question is, will this work? Will Houston secure its image in the eyes of the world?
Dr. Barton Smith, chairman of the department of economics at the University of Houston, has his doubts. The city cannot control what comes across the television screen, he said, and may be surprised by what the world chooses to focus on.
''The media could still come to town and complain about how hot it is,'' he said, ''slogan or not.''
Robin Blut, a spokesman for the Houston Clean subcommittee, an arm of the host committee, disagrees. ''We have made sure that Houston is a picture perfect backdrop,'' she said. ''We don't expect thousands of stories about how Houston is a clean city. But if they don't say it's a dirty city, then we've accomplished our goal.''

HEADLINE: The City Council Passes a Tax Test

 BODY:
New York's City Council has survived its first major test under the new City Charter. Negotiating with a new Mayor, David Dinkins, and without its old partner, the Board of Estimate, the Council approved a $28 billion budget that deals responsibly with the city's weakening economy.
Neither the outcome or the process differed dramatically from the past. The Mayor and his staff exercised the most control, as always, and the Council did not function as the independent branch of government it would like to be. But it's moving in the right direction. 
The new budget, which imposes $800 million in higher tax charges, will mean significant reductions in services. But both the Mayor and Council did a creditable job of preserving critical services despite fiscal restraints and a tight timetable.
City Hall couldn't complete its budget until it knew what Albany was doing, and by the time the state approved its budget - seven weeks late - the city had to rush to meet its June 30 budget deadline. The timing, and a sharp drop in anticipated revenues, limited debate and the city's options.
It was clear from the start that taxes would increase. The package of $800 million in higher taxes, including $263 million in increased property taxes, is necessary if the city means to maintain a decent level of services. Both the Mayor and Council made concessions: the Council agreed to raise real estate taxes higher than it wanted. Mr. Dinkins bought the Council's suggestion for a higher surcharge on the personal income tax.
As expected, the Council restored some services. Mayors always put cuts in their budgets so the Council can win points at home by restoring them. This year the Council put money back for parks, libraries, education, cultural groups and additional police officers.
To its credit, the Council focused on basic services. To its discredit, it forfeited a chance to make some meaningful cuts by proposing such badly conceived ones that they died quickly. The Council leadership also imposed too much secrecy on its negotiations and meetings, often leaving its own members angrily in the dark.
But the Council showed more initiative and responsibility than in its rubber-stamp past, and that gives promise for the future.

HEADLINE: Troubled Times for Architecture Industry

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
The virtual evaporation of significant new construction projects in New York City is deeply hurting the architectural profession, forcing firms to lay off employees, cut their fees, diversify their practices and search for work in other cities and countries.
During the expansive 1980's, architects came to enjoy near-celebrity status, as they remade the city's skyline. Now, they are scrambling for work.
''Everyone is slowing down,'' said Lenore Lucey, executive director of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects. ''Or, if they're busy now, they are looking at slowing down by the end of the year.'' 
 
Vast Construction Site
Many firms continue to work on major office and apartment projects that germinated in the late 1980's. Times Square, for example, still looks like one vast construction site.
But as that work nears completion, 27 million square feet of space in mid-Manhattan is unrented, the market is soft and developers are not starting new towers that would sustain architectural employment. For many firms, the New York City pipeline is empty. Although those in charge of the 42d Street redevelopment effort insist that it will happen, other projects announced with great fanfare in the 1980's seem to be indefinitely stalled - for example, Columbus Center, on the site of the New York Coliseum; Trump City, on the Penn Yards along the Hudson River and South Ferry Plaza, at the Staten Island ferry terminal in lower Manhattan.
''January, February and March were almost still in terms of client action,'' said Richard Carlson, a principal in Swanke Hayden Connell, which traces its origins to 1906. As recently as the mid-1970's, 99 percent of its revenues were generated by New York City projects. Now that figure is closer to 60 percent.
To some extent, architectural offices have always followed the boom-and-bust development cycle in real estate. Whether the situation today is as bad as the economic slump of the mid-1970's, when the city was in its fiscal crisis, is a matter of debate.
Some firms have held their work forces relatively steady. Overall statistics for New York City showed an increase in employment in architectural services through last fall.
 
More Modest Commissions
Many architects are strengthening their interior design, planning, renovation and preservation practices. They are finding work in institutional development and are also accepting more modest commissions than they might have a few years ago.
But even the most optimistic architects, whose practices have remained virtually intact, concede that the profession is suffering. And others are not optimistic at all.
''I would guess right now that there are more unemployed architects in New York than there were in the 70's,'' said Richard Roth Jr., chairman of Emery Roth & Sons, one of the most prominent New York architectural offices for many decades.
''My impression of the industry, in the major offices, is that we've lost between 10 and 15 percent of our employment base in the past year,'' said Martin D. Raab, senior managing partner of Haines Lundberg Waehler, another long-established firm.
Just staying even is proving to be a challenge. ''I'm working harder now than I ever have,'' said A. Eugene Kohn, a founding partner of the 14-year-old firm of Kohn Pedersen Fox. ''It takes a lot more effort to get fewer projects.''
''People like me are spending more time on airplanes because you have to do that to get work,'' said John Belle, one of the founding partners of Beyer Blinder Belle.
If founding partners are working harder than ever, younger people in their offices are really feeling the crunch.
 
'They Tend to Underbid'
''The profession has gotten more cutthroat as people compete for what few commissions come along,'' said Sara Hart, a 36-year-old Columbia-trained architect with wide experience who has been out of work since March, when she was laid off.
''They tend to underbid one another so that the people who are working for them don't make much money,'' she said. ''They are expected to work very hard for very little.''
There is little relief in sight. ''It's a little scary because this is not like it was in the 70's,'' said Peter Samton, a partner in Gruzen Samton Steinglass. ''I don't think the upturn is going to be so significant. I think it's going to be a longer plateau and a slow climb.''
''There's far more product available today than there was when the bust hit in the mid-70's,'' Mr. Roth said. ''What took us out of that bust were the European financial institutions coming into the East Coast - New York, particularly. They ate up all the existing office space, allowing the new boom to take place. I don't see a new leader coming into the New York area.''
 
Shrinking Staffs
As recently as 1986, the Roth office employed almost 100 people. Today, Mr. Roth said, there are about 55 employees. Swanke Hayden Connell's headcount in its New York office has dropped in the last year to 160 from 220 through layoffs and transfers. Haines Lundberg Waehler has laid off about 30 people in the last year, bringing its total to about 230, Mr. Raab said. Gruzen Samton Steinglass has shrunk to about 75 people, from a high point of 85 two years ago.
Meanwhile, the New York office of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, a nationwide giant, has shrunk in the last nine months to about 380 employees from 425, said David M. Childs, one of the partners. But he said the reduction was achieved through ''normal attrition'' and transfers, not layoffs.
''It's hard to predict, day to day,'' he said. ''I'd hate to say, 'Nothing will happen' because in a few weeks, four or five jobs may stop. Right now, we're O.K., and we have a strong backlog of work.'' Among the biggest question marks for the firm is the Columbus Center development, for which Mr. Childs is the design architect.
Not every office has been hit hard recently. Kohn Pedersen Fox avoided layoffs in its permanent ranks by hiring freelancers to work on specific projects, Mr. Kohn said. Although Beyer Blinder Belle is about two-thirds the size it was in the mid-1980's, when it employed 150 people, it has held steady for the last three years. ''Status quo is not too bad for this climate,'' Mr. Belle said.
 
A Tone of Desperation'
''In the past six months, I've started seeing resumes from associates or even partners in smaller firms and people who have had their own firms,'' said Jennie Pocock, the administrative manager at Beyer Blinder Belle. Speaking generally about applicants, she added, ''I have noticed a tone of desperation in their voices, as if they are not just making a career move but are really out of work.''
The classifieds offer little cheer. In the first three months of this year, 447 professional architectural positions were advertised in The New York Times, according to a compilation by the American Institute of Architects. That was a drop of 46 percent from the first quarter of 1989, when 833 positions were listed. The figure stands in even starker contrast to 1988, when 994 positions were advertised and 1987, when 1,464 positions could be found.
Moreover, there seem to be few geographic alternatives. Architectural advertising in Chicago, Cleveland, Minneapolis, Los Angeles and San Francisco has declined for the first time since 1986, the American Institute of Architects noted. It dropped steeply in Atlanta, Boston, Detroit, Philadelphia, St. Louis and Washington.
Employment records kept by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics for New York City do not yet reflect the turmoil. The number of people employed in architectural services in New York City rose to 8,500 during the first nine months of 1989 (the most recent period available), compared with 7,800 in 1988.
 
Interest in Eastern Europe
Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the statistics bureau, said: ''New York is an architectural center. You have firms that have nationwide and international areas of work. It may be cushioning them.''
As an example, overseas projects -in Australia, Indonesia, Japan, New Zealand, Singapore and West Germany - now account for about 35 to 40 percent of Kohn Pedersen Fox's work. The firm has a London office, as do Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and Swanke Hayden Connell, among others. Emery Roth has opened an office in Budapest, reflecting interest in Eastern Europe.
Yet, Mr. Roth sees a limit to the amount of work a New York office can expect to get elsewhere when it is competing with local architects. ''It's very difficult to take your act out of town because the costs of doing business in New York are so expensive,'' he said.
And other cautionary tales abound. Mr. Samton has memories of waiting in 1979 for a $1.5 million payment for an Iranian project. The check came in one week before the Shah went into exile.
''You have to be alert in what you're doing abroad because things can go bad very quickly,'' he said. ''Many, many American firms believe, 'Oh, wonderful, I can now go abroad.' It might look good in the beginning but wait until someone owes you money.''

HEADLINE: Russian Playwrights Discuss Role of Union

BYLINE: By RICHARD F. SHEPARD

 BODY:
It may have something to do with the way theater mirrors life, but the disagreement among a group of visiting Russian playwrights brought to New York's theater district a taste of what's going on in larger Soviet stages these days.
Specifically, there was disagreement about the role of the Soviet Writers' Union, a Government-sponsored association that functions as a catchall for literary people in that country. Half of the visitors in the eight-member group from the Vladimir Arro Writers' Studio in Leningrad are union members, half are not.
Dissension is not unusual in Western theater circles, it is more a way of life. But in the past, formal discussions or interviews with Soviet playwrights were often a matter of silent members listening to one spokesman voice the proper line. 
 
Different Ages and Viewpoints
The visiting playwrights, who indicated that they now preferred to be described as ''Russian'' rather than ''Soviet,'' reflected a significant, if sometimes confusing, division in attitudes. Age appeared to be a factor, with the more senior members more defensive about the union and the younger ones generally more critical.
They are between 30 and 57 years old and represent different viewpoints and statuses and two of the group are actually from other places, one from Ulan-Ude, a city in the Buryat republic in Siberia, and one from the Urals city of Sverdlovsk.
They are guests until this weekend of the New Dramatists, where they have room and board on West 44th Street and are participating in workshops about their craft.
The question of the union, which was once all-powerful in determining the fate and well-being of a Soviet writer, seemed to have become irrelevant, a fact that was important because it indicated how the once monolithic Soviet art structure is being eroded.
 
'I Don't See Any Advantage'
''I was invited to join the union but I declined,'' said Oleg Yuryev, 35, who also translates poetry from English. ''I don't see any advantage to it. It can't give me what I feel is important. It's abnormal to have only one organization representing all levels of writing, like this union.''
''There should be lots of different unions,'' Mr. Yuryev said. ''I and my friends have been trying to build one where we would have workshops and discuss matters of our profession. In Russia now, there are lots of small writers' unions, but they don't get the benefit of Government money.''
Vladimir Arro, the 57-year-old playwright who is the head of the studio that sent the delegation and is the president of the Leningrad branch of the Soviet Writers' Union, is also chief cultural representative of his city. Like the others, he spoke in Russian, which was interpreted by Arnold Bratov, a former writer and director of the Moscow Circus who has settled in New York.
''When things became so political, this led to division in the union,'' Mr. Arro said. ''What happened with the Leningrad union of writers is what has happened in government and it's a mess.''
 
'It's a Question of Money'
He said that circumstances encouraged all writers to be under one heading and added: ''It's a question of money. The union has funds.''
Nikolai Koljada, 33, said he was a union member but did not feel he was getting full value from it. The union, he said, works differently for its different members.
''Some are very well rewarded and people often think I am well off because I belong to it,'' he said.
The union issue was only one that tied into the entire question of government and the arts.
''The most important problem in Russia is not economic but cultural,'' said 45-year-old Aleksandr Obratsov. ''Russia has been separated all these years from its own culture and from the cultures of the world. In Russia there is this problem of financial support, but I think there can be independent, subsidized theater.''
 
The Benefits of Independence
Mr. Yuryev spoke for greater diversity of theater and further relaxation of controls. ''The more independent theater, the better,'' he said. ''There should be lots of producers, lots of different opinions. It's not Gorbachev who is giving away Government money, but local people. Russia has many economic problems that are more pressing and the Government has more important things on its mind than giving money to theater. I think we need more theater cooperatives, private and semi-private.''
Although the state-run theaters are the major producers, the writers in the group said that union membership was no longer a prerequisite to getting a script accepted and that rejection by one theater did not preclude possible acceptance by another.
Marc Galesnik, 33, who in addition to writing plays also edits newspapers, including a humor monthly, told an anecdote that reflected the uneasiness with which low-level decision makers approach their jobs in today's Soviet Union.
''Really things were easier before perestroika,'' he said. ''They gave you money and you did what they wanted. Now it is hard for officials to know exactly what is right and what is wanted. One party leader came to a preview not long ago, to see the show and approve or disapprove. He wasn't really sure. He saw it and then he said, maybe it was all right but shouldn't it have more anti-Soviet views in it.''
The willingness to discuss politics and theater did not extend to a desire to talk about the plays each writer was now working on.
A long silence to a question about the playwrights' works in progress was broken by Mr. Koljada, who observed: ''Every playwright writes only one play. There is only one theme, love and death.''

HEADLINE: Mergers Up In Europe as Barriers Fall

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The lure, and the fear, of 1992 are continuing to drive the pace of mergers and acquisitions in Europe, and more and more they are opening doors that had been closed in the past.
In the first quarter of this year, 357 European companies were acquired by concerns from Europe, the United States or Japan, according to data released this week by Translink's European Deal Review, an organization that monitors such activity. The total value of the deals in which a price was reported was $15.4 billion. The value of 55 percent of the deals was not reported. 
The number of deals was just below the record of 371 in the third quarter of last year but above the quarterly average of 317 for all of 1989. The total value was below the third quarter's $21.7 billion but above the other three quarters, Translink's said.
 
American Acquisitions Slowed
 While European companies were very active, acquisitions by American concerns slowed significantly, Translink's reported.
In the first quarter, American companies were involved in 37 deals, with a total reported value of $747.8 million. This compares with 53 deals, with a reported value of $4.2 billion, in the fourth quarter of 1989 and a total of 182 deals, with a reported value of $15.2 billion, in all of 1989.
The continued high level of acquisitions seems to reflect that the barriers to acquisitions, within the 12-nation European Community and elsewhere, are coming down. The pressure to build ties is forcing an easing of obstacles to takeovers in countries like France and Sweden that have long been hostile to such purchases.
The trend demonstrates that business and economic decisions have moved ahead of politicial or regulatory ones. That is comparable to what happened in the United States in the 1970's as financial markets left regulators breathlessly trying to catch up with their innovations.
''Everyone is bringing down their defenses so that they can buy in the European Community,'' said Mark Dixon, the editor of Translink's European Deal Review. This easing, he said, should make more acquisitions possible and should make more logical business alliances easier.
 
France and Sweden Rank High
France, a member of the European Community, and Sweden, which is not, were No. 1 and No. 3, respectively, in net acquisitions last year. This means that French and Swedish companies bought much more abroad than foreign companies bought in France and Sweden. France's surplus was $6.1 billion and Sweden's was $1.3 billion. The No. 2 position was held by West Germany.
But in the first quarter of the year, France and Sweden were the top targets for acquisitions. In part, this reflects the cross-ownership merger between Volvo A.B. of Sweden and Renault S.A. of France.
French and Swedish companies were also the targets of other deals. France was No. 1 in the number of deals, with 53. Sweden, with 12, tied for ninth with Norway. But that is already more than a third of last year's total acquisitions by foreigners in Sweden.
In another measure of the change in positions, the value of the companies that outsiders bought in France equaled 82 percent of acquisitions by French companies abroad, compared with 43 percent in all of 1989. In Sweden, the ratio rose to 72 percent in the first quarter, from 15 percent in 1989.
 
Active Outside Home Nations
Even with this new spurt of foreign acquisitions in France and Sweden, the two were also first in acquisitions abroad in the first quarter, again helped by the the Volvo-Renault deal. Along with Britain, France and Sweden are spending much more to acquire foreign companies than to buy at home.
For Sweden, it seems the economic ties to the European Community will be well established before the politicial decision is made over whether to apply for membership in the community. But the mood in Sweden -and the economic moves already made - seem to narrow the question to when will Sweden apply, not whether it will do so.
The slowing pace of acquisitions by American companies in the first quarter does reflect a change in attitude about the need to get a foothold in Europe, Mr. Dixon said, describing it as a natural slowing after the activity last year. And he notes that while the deals declined, dropping the United States to fifth in the first quarter from first in 1989, many companies making acquistions were medium sized.
These acquisitions, Mr. Dixon contends, reflect a growing and broader commitment to a role in Europe that goes beyond what huge multinational companies like the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation have already done.
 
McGraw-Hill Moves Quickly
One American company that bought in Europe, and elsewhere, in the first quarter was McGraw-Hill Inc., whose Standard & Poor's Ratings Group bought financial ratings services in Britain, France, Sweden and Australia.
Standard & Poor's wants a foothold in Europe and Australia to take advantage of the growing international market, its president, Leo O'Neill, said. Capital markets outside the United States are growing faster than in the country, and so is the ratings business, he said.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields Post Modest Rise

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were narrowly higher for the week ended Tuesday.
The fixed-income market has been flat for a few weeks as investors awaited the outcome of Government budget negotiations while watching developments in the German monetary unification and in the American economy. ''All three, if they follow their expected scenarios, would lower interest rates,'' said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at Donoghue's. 
Money managers increased to 48, up 5, the number of days tax-exempt securities are held in portfolios. The change may come from their expectations of lower interest rates and a scarcity of new tax-exempt securities.
 
Assets Decline
Assets in tax-exempt funds declined by $300 million, to a total of $75.7 billion. The average seven-day tax-exempt compounded yield increased by a basis point, to 5.46 percent, while the 30-day yield fell by a basis point, to 5.42 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
For investors in the 28 percent tax bracket, the equivalent taxable seven-day compounded yield would be 7.58 percent. It would be 8.14 percent for investors in the 33 percent bracket.
Among tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million survyed by IBC/Donoghue's, the Strong Municipal Money Market fund, distributed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management Inc. of Milwaukee, has been the best-performing fund in the last few weeks. This week the yield was 6.30 percent.
Assets of taxable funds decreased by $4.3 billion, to a total $374.6 billion. Institutional assets fell by $1 billion, to $78.8 billion, while consumer assets dropped by $3.3 billion, to $295.8 billion. The drop in assets was attributed to the flow of money out of the funds into stock mutual funds and certificates of deposit. There was also an abundance of Treasury securities last week.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios rose by a day, to 44. 7.97 Percent Yield Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund rose by a basis point, to 7.97 percent, and the 30-day average yield rose similarly to an identical yield.
Of the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million, the Alger Money Market Portfolio, distributed by Fred Alger & Company of Jersey City, showed the best return with a yield of 8.88 percent.

HEADLINE: Dollar Drops Against Yen in Europe

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: LONDON, July 4

 BODY:
The dollar fell below 150 yen in slow European trading today amid growing speculation that interest rates will decline in the United States.
The dollar closed in London at 149.70 Japanese yen, compared with 150.95 at the close in New York on Tuesday. The United States currency closed at 1.6465 German marks, compared with 1.6505 on Tuesday in New York. 
United States currency markets were closed for the Fourth of July holiday.
 
No Free Fall Expected
In Tokyo, traders predicted the dollar would fall gradually but not dramatically. ''I don't really see the dollar going into a free fall,'' said Akio Nakano, a manager at the Long-Term Credit Bank. ''Sentiment is weak, but the market is cautious. It will be a slow, gradual decline.''
The dollar has been under pressure on expectations of easier credit in the United States. Those expectations were bolstered Tuesday when President Bush said that bringing down interest rates worldwide remained a policy goal.
Lower United States interest rates make dollar-bearing assets less attractive against assets in other currencies that may have higher interest rates.
''The interest rate gap between the United States and Japan is shrinking, and in the long run, this may give the yen the edge to really rally against the dollar,'' said Dai Sawai, a manager at Citibank. ''But the market is still too directionless to say that the dollar and yen have made a clear reversal.''
The currency and stock markets in London and Frankfurt were quiet as many workers left work early to watch a televised World Cup soccer match between England and West Germany.
Among other currencies, the pound closed higher against the dollar, supported by high British interest rates and a growing belief that Britain will soon join the European Monetary System's exchange-rate mechanism. The pound finished at $1.7870, after closing at $1.7765 in New York on Tuesday.
Gold rose $1 an ounce to close at $362.50 in London, its highest level in a month. Gold for August delivery closed at $364.10 an ounce on Tuesday on the Commodity Exchange in New York.

HEADLINE: Should the West Bail Out Gorbachev?;
Yes, Targeted Aid Wouldn't Be Wasted

BYLINE: By Graham Allison; Graham Allison is professor of government at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
When the heads of the leading industrial democracies meet in Houston next Monday, President Bush will face a question he has been trying to avoid: what can the West do to help Mikhail Gorbachev?
Frustrated by the Bush Administration's recalcitrance on aid, Bonn unilaterally extended $3 billion of credits at discount rates. The European Community is discussing a $15 billion aid package. Washington risks not just being left behind but left out. 
Are there initiatives the West could take now that would raise the probability of perestroika's success? Credits are one thing and not to be scoffed at. But there is a more important agenda of actions to assist the Soviet Union's transformation to democracy and a market economy.
The strategy is this. By giving concrete assistance to specific steps toward free markets and democracy, the West can facilitate such actions, create incentives for further steps and offer hope for the longer run. Consider five particulars.
Demonstration projects. These might include model family farms, like the ones now being established in a Dutch-sponsored project to produce vegetables; McDonald's in Moscow, whose imported cattle and seeds for lettuce and tomatoes are several times as productive as Soviet equivalents and whose methods for delivering services mesmerize Muscovites, or American prefabricated housing.
Advanced communications. The Soviet Union is open to the transfer of the technological infrastructure of pluralism: printing presses, xeroxes, personal computers, dishes that receive satellite signals and a high-tech telephone system.
In Moscow, Leningrad, Sverdlovsk and 50 other cities, non-Communist Democratic Coalition candidates won majorities in recent elections. Helping these groups to communicate, learn from each other and publicize their views serves our values and interests. An initiative that would give one million such devices to democratic forces this year could be mounted today.
Managerial and technical training. The best argument in most Soviet policy circles today is ''that's the way Americans do it.'' Flying carpets bearing wise men for a weekend is not the solution. Soviet leaders and policy makers need informed, sustained collaboration with their Western counterparts if they are to tackle issues like the transition to a market economy, privatization of state enterprises, reform of industrial ministries and decolonization.
Joint business ventures. High-visibility national joint ventures would provide substantial financial benefits and capture imaginations. Joint development of underdeveloped Soviet oil and gas reserves could earn an additional $5 billion annually for the Soviet Union within three years and $15 billion annually within a decade. In addition to profits for Western firms, this would also enhance Western energy security, since guaranteed long-term contracts would expand world energy supplies.
Joint environmental ventures. Radiation from Chernobyl fell on the East and West alike. The West can align itself with the march of history by leading a collaborative donation of Western technology to reduce the ongoing destruction of the Soviet - and our common - environment. The essence of such an agenda is to demonstrate in deeds the West's commitment to helping Mr. Gorbachev transform the Soviet Union. Such initiatives could cost $10 billion to $15 billion a year. Split three ways, that would mean $5 billion each for the U.S., Europe and Japan. If that seems large, recall that U.S. taxpayers spent $150 billion last year to defend American security interests in Western Europe. Our Western European allies spent an equivalent amount.
Suppose that President Gorbachev had offered to free Eastern Europe, eliminate the Warsaw Pact military threat, pull Soviet troops back to the Soviet Union and permit German unification - all for a price. What would the West have been willing to pay?
The West has an historic opportunity to invest in developments that advance the slow but real transition of the Soviet Union to economic and political democracy.

HEADLINE: Hospitals Battling Specialists Over Revenues From Testing

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Squeezed by Government and employer efforts to reduce costs, many hospitals are battling with specialist physicians over the revenues generated by advanced testing equipment and life-support machines. Some of the fights over these lucrative procedures are ending up in court.
Hospitals are demanding a bigger share of the money that flows to radiologists, who run million-dollar scanners and imagers. Similar pressures are hitting pathologists, who interpret the torrent of test results from automated laboratories, and anesthesiologists, who assist in surgery and often supervise intensive-care units. When the specialists resist, the hospitals sometimes arrange to give the work to others.
Many doctors are fighting back, arguing that the hospitals' demands are improper and in some cases illegal. The American Medical Association decided at its annual meeting last week to investigate payments that it said were being made by specialists ''for the privilege of serving patients at the hospital.'' 
 
Big Fees and Big Salaries
The strains between specialists and hospitals are a vivid example of the conflicts that have arisen as the pressure grows to slow the growth in medical costs. The Government has been setting increasingly tight limits on what it will pay for medical procedures. And health-care providers are being forced to offer discounts as they bid for the group business of large employers and insurers. To keep their bids low, some hospitals have asked doctors to agree to reduced fees as a condition for hospital privileges.
''Everybody's looking for a piece of that money,'' said Dr. Michael R. Soper, national medical director of the Cigna Corporation's health plans. ''The hospital is looking for a piece of it. We're looking to avoid some of those high fees. Meanwhile, some anesthesiologists and radiologists are making as much money as baseball players.''
 
Fights Go to Courts
Many of the disputes are being fought in lawsuits:
* In Nassau County, L.I., nine radiologists are suing Winthrop-University Hospital, a 548-bed teaching hospital in Mineola. The hospital hired its own radiologists last year and began bypassing the plaintiffs' independent radiology group, which used to do all the hospital's work.
* In Palm Beach, Fla., a jury awarded $19 million to a pathologist who sued American Medical International Inc., a hospital chain based in Los Angeles. Dr. Zbigniew Scheller, the pathologist, said a Palm Beach hospital owned by American Medical had refused to continue his contract, which had granted him a percentage of gross laboratory receipts, and had instead diverted business to other specialists. American Medical has appealed.
* In Fresno, Calif., six anesthesiologists sued the Fresno Community Hospital and Medical Center, asking for reinstatement and damages after the hospital made an exclusive contract with another anesthesiologist. Lower courts decided against the doctors, and they have appealed.
Many specialists used to be salaried employees of hospitals, which included their services in the hospital fee, supplied their equipment and paid the nurses and technicians who assisted them. Their patients were assigned by the hospital.
But in recent years some specialists have set up shop on their own outside the hospital. They continue to work in hospitals under contract, but in the case of radiologists and pathologists they often also run independent businesses that can divert patients from the hospitals and allow the specialists to keep all the money. Radiologists have organized their own centers to conduct $550 CT scans and $1,000 magnetic resonance images, which are computerized methods of diagnosing conditions that might be missed by ordinary X-rays. Pathologists and other doctors have established their own laboratories.
The radiologists and pathologists ''learned how to make a living without the hospital,'' said Jeff Goldsmith, a national health-care adviser with Ernst & Young, the accounting and consulting firm. ''They learned to compete at the same time as retaining the franchise'' in the hospital.
The anesthesiologists have sharply increased their incomes, benefiting from the rising number of surgical procedures requiring their services. In some hospitals, anesthesiologists also supervise the intensive care of critically ill patients.
 
Setting Limits on Payments
For years, the hospitals rarely complained. But now that the Medicare and Medicaid programs and private insurers are setting ceilings on what they will pay for medical treatment, hospitals are seeking new sources of income. The rapidly growing business of running high-technology medical equipment immediately comes to mind. The combined earnings after expenses of specialists in radiology, pathology and anesthesiology were at least $9 billion in 1988, or 4.2 percent of all money spent on hospital care.
''Hospitals are scrambling for whatever they can hold onto,'' said Raymond J. Cisneros, a health-care partner with Deloitte & Touche, the accounting and consulting firm.
The hospitals are insisting on contracts that allow them to dismiss specialists at will, eliminating the protection of a show-cause hearing. With such power, some hospitals have been able to force specialists to pay more for the privilege of practicing in the hospital. In some hospitals, physicians must now pay for the right to manage the radiological equipment and laboratory, just as a franchisee would, and for supplies and the assistance of hospital employees - costs formerly absorbed by hospitals.
In doing so, the hospitals are infuriating many specialists.
''Doctors see the pie shrinking, and they want to establish themselves and earn an adequate living while they take care of patients,''said Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the American Medical Association.
The earnings of salaried physicians grew dramatically in the 1980's after hospitals encouraged specialists on their payrolls to become independent so they could bill patients separately and not be paid out of the set amount that Medicare has established for each kind of illness.
But as medical technology advanced and expensive procedures generated enormous revenues, the hospitals began to notice how much the specialists were earning.
 
Wide Variation in Earnings
An American Medical Association survey indicates that anesthesiologists, on average, earned $194,500 in 1988, which was 69 percent more than in 1981. Radiologists' income rose 71 percent, to $184,600, and pathologists earned $131,000. The average general practitioner, by contrast, earned $94,600 in 1988.
One example of what a specialist can earn involves diagnostic scans with a magnetic resonance imager. The total fee for a scan can reach $1,000, with the radiologist typically receiving $160 to $250 for supervising the procedure and interpreting the images, which usually takes 25 to 85 minutes. The hospital would allot 60 percent of the remaining $750 to $840 to cover capital, operating and maintenance costs of the equipment and site; 10 percent for supplies; 10 percent for technicians, and the rest for overhead.
''The cash flows are enormous,'' said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health-care expert and economics professor at Princeton University. ''The hospitals want rent for the franchise. They say, 'We offer the customer base; shouldn't we get a cut out of that?' ''
No, says Thomas W. Greeson, a lawyer in Washington with the American College of Radiology, a professional group.''The radiologists are just like surgeons and obstetricians who provide individual professional services for individual patients,'' he said. ''They are very much needed by the hospital to meet accreditation and licensure requirements.''
The specialists have become even more concerned since Congress began cutting what Medicare pays for their services. Medicare payments to radiologists, for example, have been cut by 7 percent since 1988.
Dr. Richard H. Stein, a doctor in Vincennes, Ind., who is president of the American Society of Anesthesiologists, said he expects further cuts of ''18 to 20 percent for anesthesiologists and probably radiologists'' under a new system that will pay doctors more for consulting with patients and less for skills like surgery and running scanners.
 
Taking on New Duties
Dr. Stein added that anesthesiologists' incomes had risen with increased workloads. ''A lot of us run the intensive care units, the ventilators,'' he said. ''We are active in pain control, obstetrics, probably doing four or five different jobs.''
While surgeons have the largest incomes - $207,500, on average, in 1988 - the hospitals have not made such aggressive demands of them.
''In today's competitive market, we found hospitals being very sweet to doctors who are in a position to refer patient business to the hospital,'' said D. McCarty Thornton, acting chief counsel to the Inspector General of the Department of Health and Human Services. ''But the same hospitals are being tough with those doctors who are dependent upon the hospital for their flow of business.''
So tough, Mr. Thornton said, that his office is conducting ''numerous investigations'' of hospitals, looking into allegations by doctors that the hospitals are violating anti-kickback rules of Medicare and Medicaid by taking money from specialists to whom the hospitals referred patients.
In the cases under investigation, he said, payments are often ''disguised as a dividend payment, rental payments, consulting and billing fees.'' Mr. Thornton said the criminal cases had not reached the trial stage.
 
Dispute Over a Contract
The Nassau County lawsuit illustrates the basic disagreement between specialists and hospitals. The nine radiologists are seeking compensation for $50 million in losses that the group says it faces because Winthrop-University Hospital signed contracts with new radiologists last year and began bypassing the radiology group, Nassau Diagnostic Imaging and Radiation Oncology Associates.
Nassau Diagnostic Imaging says 165 physicians with privileges at the hospital have ordered in writing that all their radiology work be referred to the group, which was incorporated in 1981 by former employees of the hospital and had an exclusive contract until 1984.
The suit says that by hiring new contract radiologists and assigning much of the work to them, the hospital has ignored these orders and is interfering with a business relationship between the 165 doctors and Nassau Diagnostic.
The hospital has asked the court to dismiss the case. It said it ended the exclusivity agreement with the Nassau group after the group demanded the right to spend more time working outside the hospital and siphoned away patients to its own diagnostic scanning center. The hospital said the group also wanted to ''dramatically decrease its financial contributions,'' which supported the hospital's former radiology residency training program and overhead costs.
The hospital said the 165 physicians' orders interfered with efficient operations. ''In plain English, this case comes down to N.D.I.'s desire for more money,'' the hospital said.

HEADLINE: L.I. Sound Is So Polluted It Faces Long-Term Damage, Scientists Say

BYLINE: By ALLAN R. GOLD

 BODY:
Parts of Long Island Sound are so polluted that it faces severe long-term environmental damage, say scientists, government officials and conservation groups.
Residents have already received a sobering look at what the Sound's future is likely to hold without costly cleanup efforts. In recent summers, sections from the Throgs Neck Bridge east to Port Jefferson, L.I., and Bridgeport, Conn., have become a dead sea, with oxygen-starved waters sometimes fatal to shellfish and devoid of fin fish.
Beaches throughout the 600 miles of coastline have been closed for hundreds of days a year, and sewage pollution has wiped out tens of thousands of acres of shellfish beds. Bathers and boaters from Mystic, Conn., to Southold on the North Fork of Long Island are reporting growing amounts of floating and beached garbage. 
 
Alarming Signs of Deterioration
Although in some ways the Sound is cleaner than it was 20 years ago, the problems are nevertheless alarming signs of a deteriorating overburdened resource.
''Some people have said that Long Island Sound is dead,'' said the New York State Marine and Coastal Resources Director, Gordon Colvin. ''It's not. But it could be sometime in our lifetime.''
Mr. Colvin said major surgery would be required to upgrade water quality in the western Sound, the area nearest New York City. The central Sound should be improved, and the high quality of the eastern has to be maintained, he added.
Decisions in the next 18 months may determine the fate of the Sound. Federal environmental officials and the States of New York and Connecticut are in the fifth year of a six-year study on the oxygen-depleted water and pollution from sewage, toxic substances and floating garbage. The cost for addressing oxygen depletion alone has been estimated at up to $6 billion.
Major changes are contemplated in handling sewage at the 44 plants emptying into the Sound. Controlling street runoff, which is often a witches' brew of toxic chemicals, heavy metals and oil products, is also under consideration. Whatever approaches the study recommends, the cleanup costs will likely cost billions of dollars.
Congress is considering legislation to create a Long Island Sound office in the Environmental Protection Agency. Such a bureau might assure that the cleanups the Sound study recommends were carried out, said the co-author of the legislation, Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of Westchester.
The measure is aimed at complaints in New York and Connecticut that no comprehensive cleanup has been undertaken because management of the estuary falls under so many jurisdictions, Mrs. Lowey said.
In the last 20 years, less untreated sewage and industrial chemicals have been dumped in the Sound. But a host of environmental concerns remain, symptomatic of what many experts consider the fundamental problem.
''There are too many people living too close,'' a lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund, Timothy B. Searchinger, said. Five million people live within 15 miles of the coastline, and 15 million in the drainage basin of the Sound.
 
Under Heavy Use
The waterway is an extraordinary economic and natural resource. Commercial and sports fisheries generated as much as $170 million in revenue in 1987.
But it is being loved to death. Six million people flocked to state beaches on the Sound in 1988, and 750,000 recreational anglers fished the waters. Some 200,000 boats are registered around the Sound, and there are 20,000 slips.
Such activity suggests that the Sound has a formidable constituency. There are dozens of groups in New York and Connecticut calling for additional protection for the Sound, and their voices are rising.
''There's a great concern for action now,'' the coordinator of the National Audubon Society's Listen to the Sound campaign, Jane-Kerin Moffat, said. '' 'We're tired of studies,' people are saying.''
In Audubon-sponsored hearings, hundreds of Connecticut and New York residents spoke of their love for the Sound, wistfully recalling times when fish and shellfish were more abundant and floating garbage was less evident.
 
Cumulative Effects
''It saddens me to see what the Sound has become,'' said Gregory Hlinka, a recreational fisherman and diver from Selden, L.I. The bottom is littered with containers, tires and shopping carts, Mr. Hlinka said at a hearing last month in Port Jefferson.
Many others are speaking out against overdevelopment and the loss of fishing grounds, noting that individual projects with minor effects may have tremendous cumulative consequences.
The issue has been joined in Westchester County, where some residents are fighting a proposed housing complex and marina on Davids Island, off New Rochelle. The proposal could be a test case on developing other unpopulated islands.
The plan calls for 2,000 luxury condominiums, many in four 31-story buildings; an 800-slip marina, a helicopter landing area and a 3,465-foot bridge between the mainland and the 78-acre island.
 
No Oxygen at Hempstead
Opponents say the proposal is out of scale with the surroundings. The high-rises would be the largest in New Rochelle. The critics also contend that the complex would be environmentally destructive. Backers of the plan say that its environmental effect would be minimal and that the economic lift to the sagging city would be substantial.
Western Long Island Sound has the most serious pollution problems. The worst, Federal officials said, is hypoxia, or low oxygen levels.
Just as people need oxygen to breathe, marine animals need dissolved oxygen to survive. When dissolved oxygen falls below a certain level, fish may become ill, die or move to where there is ample oxygen.
In the summer of 1987, extremely low oxygen levels were found between the Throgs Neck Bridge and Greenwich, Conn. At Hempstead Harbor, L.I., no oxygen was found near the bottom and little was at the surface. Trawling in those areas found no fish, and 80 percent of bottom-dwellers like starfish and crabs were dead. Lobstermen reported bringing up dead lobsters.
 
Algae Use Oxygen
Hypoxia can occur naturally, especially in the summer, when the water is warm and cannot dissolve as much oxygen as in cooler months. Researchers are convinced that nutrients like nitrogen from sewage plants and storm runoff are worsening the problem. Nutrients feed the growth of vast amounts of algae, which, when they die, sink to the bottom, where they decompose, using up oxygen.
''There seems to be a trend,'' an E.P.A. official in the Sound study, Kevin Bricke, said. ''We could get a recurrence any summer.''
Mr. Bricke said hypoxia was heads and shoulders above other pollution issues, because it was a Sound-wide problem that no one state or county could resolve. Despite longtime knowledge about the hypoxia, ''it never got the attention it deserved'' in the Sound, he said.
If the situation remains unaddressed, the hypoxia could spread east, said the Connecticut Environmental Protection Commissioner, Leslie Carothers. The western Sound ''may be reaching some kind of tipping point,'' Ms. Carothers said. About half the nutrients are from New York and Connecticut sewage plants, which discharge one billion gallons of waste a day directly into the Sound. More than half the discharge is from four New York City plants emptying into the East River. Forty percent is from Connecticut rivers that carry treated sewage and storm runoff.
Government researchers are studying how to reduce the nutrients. Experiments are under way at Stamford and Norwalk, Conn., and the Tallman Island plant in College Point, Queens. Plants emptying into Chesapeake Bay have been removing nutrients since 1983.

HEADLINE: Justice Department Files Antitrust Suit Against Architects

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
The Justice Department filed a suit today against the American Institute of Architects contending that the professional group unreasonably restrained price competition.
At the same time, lawyers for the department and the institute proposed an agreement that, if accepted by a Federal district judge, would settle the Government's lawsuit.
The institute is a professional association representing 54,000 architects, about two-thirds of the registered architects in the country.
In its suit, the Justice Department invoked the Sherman Antitrust Act, which was enacted in 1890 to break up the industrial monopolies created by the 19th-century robber barons. The act has been successfully applied by the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission against professional associations, including those representing civil engineers, accountants and lawyers. 
Antitrust lawyers outside the Government said the the suit also reflected increased aggressiveness by the antitrust division, now headed by James Rill. Under the Reagan Administration, the division was largely guided by free-market economic theories and was less assertive than in the past.
The Justice Department also used the antitrust act against the architects' group in 1972 in a case involving price quotations on bids. Today's action, which grew out of an investigation begun in the Reagan Administration, represented a much broader complaint of anti-competitive activity, Justice Department officials said.
Justice Department lawyers said they hoped the suit would lead to increased competition in the pricing of architectural services like planning, designing and supervising construction of office towers, hospitals, airports and industrial parks.
''It is certainly important from our perspective to let people in various professions know that competition plays as important a role in the professions as it does in any industry,'' said Robert E. Bloch, chief of antitrust division's section on professions and intellectual property.
 
'No Laws Were Violated'
But a lawyer for the architects' group insisted that price competition already existed in the profession and said the suit would probably not lead to lower fees. ''Our position has always been that no laws were violated and the filing today does not establish that any laws were violated,'' said the lawyer, David K. Perdue, associate general counsel for the institute.
Architects are already cutting fees in New York in response to a virtual evaporation of significant new construction projects, a situation that is having ripple effects elsewhere in the country.
The antitrust division's increased aggressiveness has become apparent in a number of recent cases. Last year it began an investigation into whether some elite East Coast colleges fixed prices in setting tuition. The division has also undertaken a price-fixing investigation into the fares of some of the country's major airlines. And earlier this year, it indicted three dentists in Arizona on charges of illegally setting patient fees. None of these cases have been resolved.
Today's suit charges that the institute entered into an unlawful agreement to prohibit members from engaging in competitive bidding, discounting fees and providing free services. Under the proposed settlement, the institute would not admit wrongdoing but would be prohibited from having a code of ethics whose aim is to discourage competition.
The suit says that from August 1984 to at least February 1985, the architects' group discouraged price competition.
The Justice Department's complaint against the group cited a policy statement adopted by the Chicago chapter that specifically prohibited price competition.
Lawyers for the Justice Department, who declined to elaborate on that evidence, maintained that the institute was legally responsible for the actions of its local chapters. They said in the suit that the group's national officers endorsed the policy statement adopted by the Chicago branch.
The suit said Thomas J. Eyerman, president of the Chicago chapter, was responsible for the distribution of 6,000 copies of the statement to institute members and purchasers of architectural services in seven states.
 
Policy Is Called Short-Lived
''The effects of the conspiracy have been to unreasonably restrain price competition among A.I.A. members in the sale of their services and to deprive customers seeking the services of A.I.A. members of the benefits of free and open competition in the sale of such services,'' the suit said.
Mr. Perdue, the lawyer for the institute, said the policy statement was short-lived. ''It was issued by the Chicago chapter in 1984 on the subject of fees and compensations and it was rescinded within a few months. There was no intention to violate the antitrust act.''
The suit comes as the organization is already under a court order issued in 1972. That order was aimed at allowing its members to submit price quotations on bids for architectural services.
If today's settlement is approved, the institute would be prohibited from issuing any codes of ethics that violate antitrust laws, and each of the group's 280 state and local chapters would be required to withdraw any provisions in their codes that suppress competition.
The institute would also be required to begin a program to insure that it does not renew any anti-competitive practices and would pay the Government $50,000 as partial compensation for the cost of the Justice Department's investigation.

HEADLINE: White House Spurns Expansion Of Nation's Anti-Poverty Efforts

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
After considering a variety of ambitious options, the Bush Administration has decided against proposing any major new program or strategy to combat poverty at this time, Administration officials said today.
An interagency group, convened last year by a senior adviser to President Bush to rethink the nation's anti-poverty efforts, came up with a dozen broad alternatives. But in meetings over the last two weeks, a higher-ranking group, the President's Domestic Policy Council, decided that the options were too expensive or would stir too much political controversy. The council, a Cabinet-level advisory body, concluded that the Administration should simply try to make current programs work better.
A White House official summarized the upshot this way: ''Keep playing with the same toys. But let's paint them a little shinier.'' 
Another Administration official, acknowledging that Mr. Bush had promised ''a kinder, gentler nation'' in the 1988 campaign, insisted that the President was not reneging on his promise.
''We have decided to abjure a glitzy, splashy, high-profile announcement of new programs and a grand new strategy,'' the official said. ''We concluded there were no obvious things we should be doing that we weren't doing that would work.''
 
Signs of Interest
Experts on poverty from outside the Government, whose ideas were solicited when the White House began its quest for a new policy last year, said the Administration had seemed genuinely interested in new ideas for a long-term anti-poverty strategy.
Confidential White House documents show the Bush Administration seriously considered such options as ''large-scale community intervention in high-poverty areas,'' ''expanded family planning services,'' expansion of tax credits for the working poor, creation of a ''new block grant for investment in poor children,'' the establishment of a national minimum child-support benefit and the use of Federal funds to supplement child-support payments by absent fathers.
Other policy options envisioned ''greater uniformity in eligibility rules'' for food stamps, energy assistance and welfare benefits; ''unified check-writing for these programs,'' and consolidation of Government field offices, so poor people could apply for the various types of assistance at one site.
 
Revised Formula Rejected
Under another proposal, the Federal Government would have revised the formula for distributing welfare and Medicaid money, to increase payments to cities and states with the highest poverty rates.
Thirty-two million Americans live in poverty, as defined by the Government, and at least 2.5 million of them are part of an unofficial underclass, said by researchers to include female-headed families and high school dropouts who are chronically unemployed.
Presidents Richard M. Nixon, Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan all proposed major changes in the nation's anti-poverty programs within months of taking office. Bush Administration officials said they wanted to carry out changes made in the Reagan years, including a 1988 law that encourages welfare recipients to find jobs.
The Administration analyzed pros and cons of each alternative proposed by the interagency group. The proposal for more family planning services said, ''In-school clinics can be established in high-poverty areas with high rates of out-of-wedlock births.''
 
'May Cause Political Problems'
The Administration rejected the idea because it ''will cost money'' and would be seen as ''encouraging promiscuity,'' even though the White House said it could also reduce teen pregnancy and the number of single-parent families. The Administration also said the proposal ''may cause political problems among groups that are opposed to birth control.''
Likewise, the White House acknowledged that a major new ''investment in children'' would have a big payoff for American society in the long run, but it shelved the idea after concluding that it was ''not likely to show an immediate reward.''
Under another proposal, Congress would have been asked to establish a statutory ''standard for determining child support payments, typically a fixed percentage of the absent parent's gross income.'' The proposal did not specify the minimum benefit, but noted that an amount of about $3,500 for each child had been discussed.
''Government funding would fill any gap between the minimum benefit and the amount paid by the absent parent,'' the proposal said.
 
'Work Disincentives' Seen
The Administration decided against this proposal after concluding that it would create ''work disincentives for absent parents'' and might require ''significant Federal outlays,'' because many fathers could not ''make a full payment of the minimum benefit.'' Five million women are entitled to child support under court orders, but 25 percent receive nothing from the absent fathers and another 25 percent receive only partial payments.
Although Administration officials could not agree on specific proposals to reduce poverty, they did agree on a theme to link existing programs. The message, as described in papers circulated among Cabinet members, is that ''an effective anti-poverty system must provide 'economic empowerment' for American families, to enable them to participate fully in the mainstream of the economy.''
 
New Head of the Group
The senior adviser who began the search for an anti-poverty policy last year, Dr. William L. Roper, was Director of the White House Office of Policy Development and chairman of the interagency group that conducted the study, the Low-Income Opportunity Board. When Dr. Roper left the White House in March to become director of the Federal Centers for Disease Control, the task was taken over by Richard L. Schmalensee, a member of the Council of Economic Advisers.
Among those who worked on the proposals are Martin H. Gerry, Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services for planning and evaluation; Jo Anne B. Barnhart, Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, who is in charge of the nation's main welfare program; S. Anna Kondratas, Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development; Catherine A. Bertini, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, in charge of the food stamp program; Betsy Brand, Assistant Secretary of Education, and Roberts T. Jones, Assistant Secretary of Labor, in charge of job training programs.
Among the outside experts on poverty who were summoned to the White House for a meeting in September were Isabel V. Sawhill of the Urban Institute, an expert on the underclass; Richard P. Nathan, a moderate Republican who served as a welfare official in the Nixon Administration; Prof. David T. Ellwood of Harvard, a labor economist who has studied the causes of poverty; Douglas J. Besharov, a scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, and Jack A. Meyer, president of New Directions for Policy, a research institute here.
''The White House told us to be creative and said we should not be constrained by day-to-day budget battles,'' Mr. Meyer recalled in an interview. An Administration official said today: ''The members of the Domestic Policy Council wanted to do something about poverty, but we realized we didn't have any cash. We wanted to adopt a set of principles, but couldn't figure out how to convert our enthusiasm to anything concrete.''
''It was fun to think about these things,'' he said. ''But for the time being, we concluded that we don't want to do anything new, that we should just make things work better and give states more flexibility to do demonstration projects, as President Reagan proposed.''
Here is a summary of some of the options devised by the Administration, with written comments from the White House staff:
* The Federal Government could help residents of high-poverty areas establish ''management corporations'' to fight crime, upgrade schools and repair housing. The White House described this as a high-risk proposal, with no assurance of success.
* Washington could allocate a larger proportion of Federal aid to high-poverty areas. The White House said such a change ''could run into serious political opposition from those states and areas that will lose Federal funds.''
* The Government could ''provide financial subsidies to job contractors to match private-sector job openings with people in identified high-poverty areas.'' The White House said such a program ''could be subject to significant fraud.''
The White House acknowledged that an increase in the earned income tax credit would raise ''the standard of living for poor families.'' But it cautioned that such a change ''exacerbates Federal budgetary problems.''

HEADLINE: IRAN'S CHIEF LINKS AID TO BETTER TIES

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, July 5

 BODY:
In what appeared to be a forceful appeal for economic and humanitarian aid from the West, President Hashemi Rafsanjani was quoted today as saying there was a direct tie between foreign aid and improved relations with his Government.
''Kindness affects relations,'' Hojatolislam Rafsanjani said in an interview with Iranian journalists that was published today in Teheran newspapers. ''Whether foreign aid has an effect on relations? Our answer is yes.'' 
Mr. Rafsanjani's comments directly contradict statements made earlier this week by his Interior Minister, and they seem to be yet another signal to the United States and other Western nations that Iran wants improved ties.
The propriety of accepting foreign aid from some of this country's longstanding enemies, including the United States, has been the subject of raucous debate within the Iranian Government in recent days.
 
U.S. Presence in Persian Gulf
The debate was set off by Iran's decision to accept millions of dollars in aid from the West after the devastating earthquake last month in northern Iran, estimated to have left between 35,000 and 40,000 people dead. President Rafsanjani agreed to accept aid from all countries except Israel and South Africa.
In the interview, Mr. Rafsanjani made what are seen here as boilerplate attacks on the United States, describing it as a country that ''goes insane and perpetrates hysterial acts.'' He was referring specifically to the downing of an Iranian passenger jet by an American warship in the Persian Gulf two years ago this week.
Mr. Rafsanjani also called for new efforts by countries on or near the Persian Gulf to force the United States military out of the seaway.
''Certainly the people of these countries are opposed to such presence,'' he was quoted as saying. ''The U.S. presence is only in the interest of a few rulers'' in the gulf who want to insure that the United States ''will remain on their side,'' he continued.
 
'Trying to Open Doors'
But on the question of foreign humanitarian aid, Mr. Rafsanjani indicated that Iran would continue to accept it from virtually all countries, including the United States. As Iran begins the huge effort to rebuild areas of northern Iran ravaged by the earthquake, he said, the aid could only improve a country's relations with Iran.
 
Women's Role in Iran
Mr. Rafsanjani also said in the interview that Iran and Iraq ''are closer to peace'' as a result of the first face-to-face talks between the countries' Foreign Ministers. The talks, which focused on final settlement terms of the eight-year Iran-Iraq War, were held in Geneva this week.
In what appeared to be another sign of important changes within Iran, Mr. Rafsanjani said in a speech today that women should play a much larger role in Iranian politics, religion and the arts.
''We must create a system in society in which we can respond to women's needs,'' he said in remarks to a group of women who are seminary students and athletes. ''In order for society to work more constructively, for our economic wheels to gain speed, we need more women in the work force.''
If Mr. Rafsanjani acts on his words, it could mean broad changes in the way women are treated in this country. Laws imposed after the Islamic Revolution in 1979 have severely restricted the entrance of women into the work force and have hindered the ability of women who are employed to interact with male colleagues.

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran, who said in an interview that international aid for the earthquake victims would have an effect on foreign relations. (Agence France-Presse)
