HEADLINE: Olongapo Journal;
Sailors Can't Paint the Town, So Sin Trade Pales

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OLONGAPO, the Philippines

 BODY:
In this sleazy, honky-tonk town, which grew up out of the huge Subic Bay Naval Base to service it, the effect of new threats by Communist insurgents to kill Americans can be measured in beer.
Three American servicemen were killed in May, one here and two in Angeles, near Clark Air Base, on the eve of exploratory talks on a new United States-Philippine bases agreement to replace the one that expires in September 1991.
Since then, American servicemen have been restricted to the bases or their homes from 7 P.M. to 7 A.M., and the raucous, promiscuous carnival of discos, beer halls, bars, bar girls, massage parlors and short-time hotels has had its plug pulled.
Boy Leonardo is the district manager for San Miguel beer. ''Business is down at least 80 percent,'' he said, gesturing to some of his salesmen, whom he was taking out to dinner for their morale. ''Places buying 100 cases of San Miguel a week are down to a case or two a day.'' 
 
Girls Go Back Home
At least five clubs and discos have already shut down, Mr. Leonardo said, and others are laying off workers or providing three days off a week. ''Some of the girls,'' he said sadly, ''have already gone back to the provinces.''
Fil Rivero, an artist and T-shirt entrepreneur who stocks 1,000 designs that appeal to American military macho (''If the Good Lord made anything better than San Miguel beer and Filipino women, he keeps it for himself''), has now laid off 24 of his 42 employees.
By 7:30 P.M., Olongapo's main strip, Magsaysay Drive, is forlorn. The lights to the State Rock Tavern, the Top Gun Lounge and the Miami Inn still beckon, but most businesses are either shut or empty. Upstairs, in the Hot City disco, young women with numbered pins on their dresses, for better identification by sailors in more normal times, huddle together giggling on the dark dance floor.
The manager of Hot City and its associated Playmate Disco said that times are bad for a staff that normally numbers about 150, including almost 100 ''waitresses'' and ''entertainers.'' The manager, a fleshy, motherly woman poring over her accounts, said that if the curfew wasn't lifted soon, they might have to close down. Who Killed the Sergeant? In Manila, Western diplomats say that leave hours may soon be extended until 11 P.M., in part because of local complaints. Mayor Richard Gordon of Olongapo is convinced the death here on May 4 of Sgt. John S. Fredette, shot near the strip, was a robbery, not the work of the New People's Army, the Communist rebel group. Some senior Western diplomats agree. The Communists did not claim that killing, as they did the deaths of the two Americans shot near Clark on May 14.
But another senior Western diplomat said flatly: ''The intelligence people are absolutely persuaded it was an N.P.A. hit.''
The Communist rebels have broadened their targets to include other Americans, and as a result Peace Corps volunteers have been withdrawn from the Philippines.
Olongapo businessmen see their current problems as but a taste of what would happen to this city of 250,000 people if the American military was forced to leave the Philippines.
 
Priest Rails at Sex Business
''It would be a disaster,'' said Salvador Austria, an optometrist and bar owner who wears four rings and says proudly that ''if American boys happen to fight in my clubs, they don't pay for the damage.''
''Oh, but it would be a blessing,'' said the Rev. Shay Cullen, an Irishman and Columban missionary who has lived in the Philippines for 21 years. ''This city is the most vicious form of human exploitation that can be imagined.''
Father Cullen works with the women and children most vulnerable, he says, ''to the sex trade of demand and supply, controlled by a corrupt, feudal political order dominated by the presence of a huge, U.S. military base that makes the demands.'' Mayor Gordon intermittently tries to get the priest expelled from the Philippines.
 
'The American Way'
''The Seventh Fleet is supposed to defend the American way,'' he said. ''Well, if sexual abuse of children is the American way, I'd like to see what Congress says about it.''
As he spoke, the boom of shells from an American naval exercise echoed off the hills surrounding Subic Bay. ''I'd like the cost of one of those shells for education,'' he said, and then returned to his theme: ''If American parents knew what their boys were up to, they'd be outraged.''
United States Navy officials will not comment on Father Cullen, but say only that they investigate all charges against American personnel and cooperate fully with local authorities.
 
What About Christina
Japan and South Korea outgrew their brothel towns outside military bases, he said; so, in time, would the Philippines. Mayor Gordon's view is similar, but more pungent: ''Now it's Japanese women who are keeping American sailors,'' he said. ''The problem isn't just morality, but poverty.''
Still, opposition to a new bases agreement is founded more on questions of morality and exploitation than those of economics or security, even in a country everyone acknowledges has a navy and an air force incapable of defending its borders.
Christina, 22 years old, is hanging around on the street. Born in the provinces, she has been here four years. She says she sleeps with Americans to support her family. If the bases close, she said, ''I guess I'd go back home and find something to do.''
But what she really wants, she said, is an American sailor to take her to the United States. ''I still hope I can find a guy to take care of me and marry me,'' she said earnestly. ''If the bases are here, I still have a chance.''

Businessmen in Olongapo, outside the Subic Bay base, see the loss of business as but a taste of what will happen if the U.S. military is forced to leave the country. (Steven Erlanger/The New York Times); Map: Olongapo, the Philippines

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
For Bush, Life on the Run Catches Up

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 5

 BODY:
You may find this hard to believe, but President Bush originally wanted to make a day trip out of his visit to London for the meeting of the Atlantic alliance.
Fortunately, it turned into a two-day event, because the strain of life at the gallop seems to be catching up with the man who would be the Environmental President, the Education President, the Fitness President and the Diplomat President.
Despite his vast resources of energy, Mr. Bush seemed exhausted and a bit grumpy today after what should have been just another routine dash across the Atlantic Ocean - a mere six-hour flight through the dead of night across five time zones for a 36-hour meeting to redefine the military structures of Europe.
Confident that he could handle this with his usual verve, Mr. Bush, who is 66 years old, spent five days at his Maine retreat with his usual breakneck round of throwing horseshoes, casting fishing lures, bashing golf balls and careering across the waves in his speedboat. Instead of arriving in London a day before the meeting began, Mr. Bush squeezed in one more golf game on Wednesday morning, and left that night. 
But here, it seemed that the bottomless well of energy had a bottom after all. Mr. Bush got off Air Force One looking tired, eyes puffy and his stride less spry than the ''spring colt'' to which he always compares himself.
The President seemed to be nursing a cold, punctuating Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's opening statement with a raucous sneeze and a loud blast into his handkerchief.
But Marlin Fitzwater, Mr. Bush's spokesman, perservered. He gamely described his boss as ''amazingly spry and energetic,'' and White House aides went back to planning Friday's trip - back west across six time zones to Houston, where he and six other leaders will discuss the changing economic structures of the world.
 
Cooling His Heels
Perhaps it was fatigue, but Mr. Bush seemed to have lost the graciousness he generally shows at the snags and gaffes of summitry. The final straw came at the end of the day's meetings, when he found himself cooling his heels in front of the sternly classical Lancaster House for five minutes while anxious Secret Service agents scurried about hunting for his limousine.
Mr. Bush tried to shrug it off, chatting with a British protocol officer. But he soon dropped the conversation and craned his neck around, pursed his lips, stuck his hands in his pockets and glared at the nearest aide until his car finally appeared.
Mr. Bush walked quickly to the passenger door, clambered aboard and sprawled gratefully in the backseat.
 
A Testy Thatcher
There is something about this sort of high-level meeting that brings out the tart side of Prime Minister Thatcher.
While her colleagues from France, the United States, West Germany and other countries talked of the dawning of a new era, Mrs. Thatcher seemed icily determined to be the voice of caution.
In Lancaster House, the grand house just off The Mall where Charles Sumner and William Lloyd Garrison once tried to persuade Britain to oppose slavery in America, Mrs. Thatcher said she had reread two books to prepare for the talks.
One was ''Fighting for Peace,'' the autobiography of Caspar W. Weinberger Jr., the former Secretary of Defense, who still does not trust the Russians. The other was ''Barbarossa'' by Alan Clark, the story of the German invasion of Russia in 1941.
Mrs. Thatcher read a verse from the preface to the latter book: ''Two things have altered not since first the world began/The beauty of the wild green Earth and the bravery of man.'' Who's Specially Related? For diplomats and reporters covering NATO, the game of the day is ''Find the Special Relationship.''
After the personal warmth that developed between Mrs. Thatcher and President Reagan, the Bush-Thatcher relationship seems cool and British officials have become increasingly irked at the attention Mr. Bush is paying to Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany.
They were not amused when the West German Embassy held a special briefing for British reporters to talk about the cooperation and identity of interests between the United States and West Germany.
''It looks to us,'' a senior Foreign Office official said, ''as if the special relationship runs from Bonn to Washington these days.''
 
Brotherly Rivalry
It has become common in Washington to talk about the rivalry beneath the brotherly relationship between Mr. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.
This is partly because Mr. Baker has a taste for the dramatic and a flair for press relations that seem to elude Mr. Bush. Mr. Baker has occasionally upstaged the President on major announcements and today, apparently inadvertently, he took center stage again for a moment.
When the two left Winfield House, the American Ambassador's residence, for the drive to Lancaster House, Mr. Baker ended up in the limousine seat intended for Mr. Bush.
Thus, when the car pulled up and Mrs. Thatcher stepped forward, it was Mr. Baker who emerged to shake her hand.
The President of the United States had to scramble around the car to reach the red carpet. But Up in the Air . . . Mr. Baker may have been first out of the limo and the second most powerful man in Washington, but to British air traffic controllers, he was just another troublesome blip on the radar screen.
Mr. Baker took off for London from Brussels at about 7 P.M. on Wednesday after a meeting of 24 Western countries about aid for emerging democracies of Eastern Europe.
He had only a half tank of fuel for the quick hop. But Mr. Baker's Air Force plane arrived a half-hour ahead of schedule, or so he was told by London air traffic control, which ordered him to circle for an hour.
As Mr. Baker fumed, the American Embassy called 10 Downing Street, which in turn called the London tower and ordered them to get the Baker plane on the ground.
But Mr. Baker was short of fuel as well as patience and flew to Mildenhall Air Base 75 miles northeast of London near Cambridge, where American F-111's took off in 1986 to bomb Libya.
Ninety minutes later, cleared for London at last, Mr. Baker reboarded his plane, where a reporter observed wryly, ''Nice to travel with a guy who's got some clout.''
The Secretary of State, the President's best friend, smiled gamely.

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1520 words

HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
Jim Sasser, Reluctant Budget Chief Who Cornered President on Taxes

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
Senator Jim Sasser has detested math since grade school. He says he has no taste for intricate things, unless that means tinkering with the engine of a rust-coated 1967 Jaguar, now sidelined in the Senate garage, that he has been trying to fix up for years.
Yet there he sits, chairman by default of the Senate Budget Committee.
''For some people, the Federal budget is just a fascinating document, like the fellow who wants to sit around and work on a Rubik's Cube - it appeals to the same mentalities,'' the Tennessee Democrat said, hunching over a coffee table in his office, miming intense scrutiny of a budget. ''I didn't become a United States Senator to sit around and worry about the fine details of some kind of a dairy milk cow processing program or something like that.'' 
 
Putting Pressure on Bush
Whether by fortuitous timing or political acumen or both, Mr. Sasser has turned his disdain for decimal points into an asset. He has emerged as his party's point man - some less delicately say mouthpiece - in the war with the White House over the budget. He is also the one who stiffened Democrats' spines on the issue of making President Bush go first. As the keeper of the party line before the cameras, his partisan swipes helped build the pressure that led the Mr. Bush to renounce his ''no new taxes'' campaign pledge.
''You never know what's under a rock until you turn it over,'' said Senator Dale Bumpers, an Arkansas Democrat who is a close friend of Mr. Sasser's. ''When they turned that one over, and Jim Sasser emerged, they found a rare and unique guy who had been overlooked.''
Lost, not overlooked, is the word a number of Mr. Sasser's colleagues would have used. Since he came to Washington on the coattails of Jimmy Carter in 1976, Mr. Sasser has preferred the sidelines, rarely seeming comfortable attaching himself to great issues of the day. He stood by as younger, newer members - the junior Senator from Tennessee, Al Gore, for one - became better known inside and outside the Senate.
In an interview in his capital office during the Fourth of July recess, the 53-year-old Mr. Sasser relaxed in an armchair and spoke in a rambling Tennessee drawl, like a man in no hurry, and for all the world like a man unriled by a reputation that he has little patience for substance and that he has taken too long to make his mark.
''If I had come in here the first two or three years and tried to be a pretty flashy and superficial type of Senator,'' he said, ''I think it would have diminished my effectiveness in the long run.''
 
A Creature of Senate
''Perhaps I am more a creature of the Senate than Al,'' he said of Senator Gore, who was just 40 years old when he made a Presidential run in 1988. ''Let's face it, Al's seen a lot of it before. He grew up as the son of a Senator. That perhaps might make him more interested in moving to the big job. I tried to help him all I could. I think people make a great mistake if they sit around and become consumed by envy.''
Mr. Sasser was reluctantly thrust into the budget panel's top job after the chairman, Senator Lawton Chiles of Florida, decided to retire in 1988 and the two most senior Democrats in line for the post were unwilling to give up other chairmanships.
''I didn't really want it,'' Mr. Sasser said, adding that he would much rather head the Foreign Relations or Armed Services committees. ''The budget is almost an insoluble dilemma. But I got the job and I can see myself now, in some ways, actually enjoying it.''
Party leaders have turned to Senator Wyche Fowler Jr., a freshman from Georgia, to be the inside tactician at the budget negotiations. Mr. Sasser has become the outside man emerging from the closed sessions, tossing out red meat to reporters, often in colorful, though sometimes mangled, metaphors.
''Simply putting a new suit on that old corpse isn't going to revive it,'' he recently said after the Bush Administration presented a budget plan.
The White House is eager for budget talks because ''they saw that this horse was about to get out of the barn before they got it bridled,'' he said after winning $118 at the Kentucky Derby on a colt named Unbridled. Another time, he characterized the Administration's offer as warmed over, saying, ''The odor hasn't improved overnight.''
 
Challenging the White House
Suddenly, the man who says he is not a showboat, who says his biggest failing in politics is that he does not have an oversize ego, is challenging the White House on the evening news.
Mr. Sasser's style served the Democrats so well in the early days of the budget talks that often at the chairman's impromptu briefings outside the negotiating room, the panel's ranking Republican, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, would show up to keep tabs on what Mr. Sasser was saying and then turn to the microphones to dish out his version.
Richard G. Darman, the head of the Office of Management and Budget, a numbers-cruncher extraordinaire, is Mr. Sasser's antithesis, and there is no love lost between the two.
After describing the White House budget plan at a private session, Mr. Darman is said to have mounted a not-so-subtle attack on Mr. Sasser, declaring, ''I know there's one person who thinks it stinks.''
Mr. Darman declines to discuss his relations with Mr. Sasser. Mr. Sasser insists that there is nothing personal in their differences. ''I don't know what I've done that offended him particularly,'' he said.
''We may represent two different segments of American society,'' he said. ''He's highly educated, wealthy. My grandfather was a dirt farmer and my father was a civil servant. Maybe I look at the budget and Federal priorities more from the point of view of how they impact people.''
 
Lessons From Kefauver
Mr. Sasser, who has a moderate-to-liberal voting record, encourages the comparison to a former Democratic Senator from Tennessee, Estes Kefauver, a crusading populist who died in 1963. While he was attending law school at Vanderbilt University, Mr. Sasser would carry the Senator's bags and drive him around the state when he returned to Tennessee.
''From Kefauver, I learned the importance of retail, personal campaign politicking,'' he said. ''He was a great big bumbling sort of fellow and everybody instantly took a liking to him and wanted to help him. I'm not any more polished that Estes was. He was a graduate of Yale Law School and many people accused him of being an intellectual, masquerading as a bumpkin. People perceive me as mild mannered, accommodating, nonthreatening.''
Mr. Sasser knows how to spin a good tale, and he still manages to portray himself back home more as the Southern gentleman and less as the Washington insider. He takes great pride in the fact that Bill Monroe, often called the father of bluegrass, turned to him in a moment of need.
It was 1983, and President Ronald Reagan had invited several country music stars to the White House. ''Old Bill was wearing his big 10-gallon hat and all the trappings,'' Mr. Sasser says. ''Bill had forgotten that he had this big horse pistol in his briefcase.''
Luckily, Mr. Monroe did not bring his briefcase into the White House. But Mr. Sasser says that on his way home, the metal detector picked it up at National Airport here, and that Mr. Monroe was immediately grabbed by the police and hauled off to a nearby jail and booked.
 
Only One Phone Call
But he knew he could get his Senator on the phone. ''He had one telephone call,'' Mr. Sasser says, shaking his head, ''so he called over here. We got a lawyer and went over there and got old Bill out.''
So convincing is Mr. Sasser in his efforts to play down his own importance, that he even seems to question his place in the Senate, conceding something that few of his colleagues would dare whisper: ''It's not that I am so unique that others couldn't do as good a job as I would do.''
Mr. Sasser readily admits that there are many who know more about fiscal matters. Lance Simmens, the Senator's former economic counsel, remembers gently prodding his boss to attend committee meetings.
''He'd just kind of roll his eyes and say, 'Oh, do we have to listen to more of this?' Mr. Simmens recalls. ''Sometimes I had to pull him over there. But he always came.''
For all the professionally disarming style, Mr. Sasser is a former trial lawyer with pure partisan instincts. He used his three-year chairmanship of the Tennessee Democratic Party to establish a base of political support for his first campaign for political office in 1976, when he shocked the political establishment by running a successful campaign against the well-to-do incumbent, Senator William E. Brock 3d, by portraying himself as a man of the people.
Some would say it is only by happenstance that now, nearly 15 years later, the political instincts of the reluctant chairman of the Senate Budget Committee are re-emerging.
''With experience and seniority, he has gained courage and self-confidence,'' said Albert Gore Sr., the former Senator, who was something of a mentor to Mr. Sasser. ''He's coming along in a regular way.''

HEADLINE: Paul Wynne, Who Aired Diary on AIDS, Dies at 47

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 5

 BODY:
Paul Wynne, a broadcast journalist whose on-the-air diary about AIDS made television history, died of AIDS today at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center here. He was 47 years old.
Mr. Wynne, an entertainment reporter for three San Francisco television stations from 1972 to 1984, returned to the air in January 1990 with ''Paul Wynne's Journal,'' a firsthand account of his fears and triumphs as he moved toward death. 
Even in San Francisco, a city probably more sophisticated about AIDS than any other in the nation, the segment was stunning television, shocking for some viewers, inspiring for others and a ''reason to get up in the morning'' for its dying star.
The diary won rave reviews from television critics in the area. And KGO-TV, the local ABC affiliate that broadcast the journal, received scores of telephone calls and letters, a vast majority praising the station for its courage and Mr. Wynne for putting a face on the dread disease.
 
Taped From Hospital Bed
While the diary was available to other stations across the country, only one other broadcast it: KCET-TV in Los Angeles, which showed 18 installments of the diary on a weekend in June when the Sixth International AIDS Conference was being held in San Francisco and gay men and women in the United States were celebrating Gay Pride Week.
The series was taped from Mr. Wynne's hospital bed in recent weeks as his health deteriorated. The segments were often witty, but their subject matter changed as he became weaker.
Early in the series Mr. Wynne said he would not surrender to the paraphernalia of advanced AIDS, including the cane or the walker, but in a later segment he acknowledged that he had moved ''into the wheelchair phase.''
In another late segment, his face gaunt and his eyes hollow, Mr. Wynne told viewers, ''I'm very sick and I'm very weak; my life is very joyless and I'm very afraid.''
 
Commentary on Entertainment
Mr. Wynne was born in Shenandoah, Iowa, and grew up in Hillsboro, Ore. He received a bachelor's degree in theater from Willamette University in Salem, Ore., then served in the Army, where he began his journalism career at the armed forces television station in Fort Gordon, Ga.
In 1979, after leaving the military, he moved to San Francisco, where he held a series of jobs at local television stations, most of them doing commentary about entertainment. In 1984, while working at KGO-TV, the station decided not to renew his contract. After that he received no offers for on-the-air work and was unemployed.
In January, a former colleague at KGO carried Mr. Wynne's idea for an on-the-air diary to the station managers, who leaped at the chance to break new ground. The show was an immediate hit.
Mr. Wynne is survived by his father, Harold Wynne of Lincoln City, Ore., and by two stepbrothers, Brad Wynne of Centreville, Va., and Greg Wynne of Westchester, Calif.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul Wynne (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: What's a Doctor of Law but Hyperbole Anyway?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The French academic credentials of Pierre A. Rinfret, Republican nominee for governor of New York, are clearly not fungible with an American Ph.D. (front page, June 19), but before he is cast into outer darkness, a word might be said about ''degree inflation.'' The most egregious instance was the instant transformation of the old law degree, L.L.B., or Bachelor of Laws, into the chic J.D., or Doctor of Law. The actual equivalent of the Ph.D. in law is the S.J.D., Doctor of Jurisprudential Science, a degree awarded on completion of a substantial dissertation. The L.L.B. (alias J.D.) only proves that its recipient has emerged successfully from three years of processing in a sausage factory.
How this alchemist's dream was accomplished remains shrouded in mystery. The simple hypothesis is that law school deans, in possible violation of antitrust laws, engaged in a brilliant conspiracy some 25 years ago to up-scale the style of their products. However, this cannot be proven, or even brought to the threshold of litigation, as all lawyers are ''partis pris,'' all judges would have to recuse themselves, and the Fifth Amendment guarantee against self-incrimination would provide blanket protection.
This is not written with animosity, but with great respect for the elegance with which this coup was executed. In this world, to paraphrase St. Augustine, you take your breaks where you find them; poor Pierre Rinfret had not yet attained the market smarts to make him ''Dr.'' on the cheap.
 
JOHN P. ROCHE
 Medford, Mass., June 21, 1990
 
The writer is the John M. Olin Distinguished Professor of American Civilization and Foreign Affairs at Tufts University.

HEADLINE: Raising Taxes Will Strengthen Bush

BYLINE: By C. Fred Bergsten; C. Fred Bergsten is director of the Institute for International Economics, a policy research organization.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Democrats and many Republicans believe that President Bush's endorsement of higher taxes will hurt him politically. But they ignore the four major benefits that a successful resolution of the U.S. budget problem would provide.
First, interest rates would fall. The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, predicts that long-term rates, which drive investment and thus growth, could decline by two full percentage points. Key areas of the economy, such as housing, auto purchases and corporate spending on new equipment, should pick up quickly. The Fed must of course assure the needed monetary easing as soon as the budget package is sealed and delivered. 
Second, the trade balance would improve. The dollar would weaken with lower interest rates and, along with the lower cost of capital itself, boost American competitiveness. This, in turn, would help American companies to capitalize on the continuing economic booms in Europe and Asia. Lower dollar interest rates would also ease the debt burden in Latin America and expand the region's capacity to buy abroad.
Lower interest rates and stronger trade should offset, or more than offset, the adverse effects of a tighter budget on the economy. The U.S. can enjoy export-led growth for the next several years, benefiting from strong foreign markets in the 1990's just as we benefited from heavy infusions of foreign capital in the 1980's.
To be sure, correcting the budget imbalance would have been safer several years ago, when the economy was stronger. But the risks will almost certainly grow if action is delayed further. Moreover, any recession now would probably be quite mild and short-lived, with growth resuming by 1992. For the longer run, strong private investment and trade improvement provide a much sounder basis for sustained growth than the consumption-led, Government-financed expansion of the 1980's.
Third, fiscal policy can again become an active tool of economic policy. Today, with the deficit at current and prospective levels, the Government has virtually no way to respond if the economy falls into recession. Nor can we count on the Fed for monetary stimulation; not with a fiscal imbalance that would rise sharply in a recession and remain an inflationary threat. Budget action now would promote growth later as well as sooner.
Fourth, American foreign policy would strengthen substantially. Our credibility has been damaged by our unwillingness to provide even modest resources to support democratization in Eastern Europe and Latin America, international attacks on environmental degradation and initiatives in other areas. Budget correction would enable the U.S. to become a serious global player and leader again.
Notice that Japan responded immediately to the President's shift on taxes with new concessions last week, permitting a successful conclusion of the Structural Impediments Initiative. Mr. Bush's hand will be far stronger at the Houston summit meeting next week.
The magnitude of all these benefits will depend on the degree to which the President's willingness to raise taxes catalyzes both real spending cuts and a definitive resolution of the budget problem. The wisest course, economically and politically, is to agree promptly on specific measures to eliminate the deficit fully over the next four or five years.
The world of the 1990's and beyond will turn heavily on economic developments. The U.S. faces extremely tough competition from a uniting Europe, from Japan and from emerging powers in East Asia and elsewhere. Both our domestic prosperity and our global position depend on meeting that competition successfully. Budget correction is a central element in doing so.
Thus, President Bush's new stance on taxes marks his greatest contribution to the national interest to date. It may turn out to be his best political step as well.

HEADLINE: Who Pays for the Clean Air Act?

BYLINE: By Susan Lee; Susan Lee is writing a book on the origins of economic crises.

 BODY:
This time around, Washington couldn't be prouder. Twenty years ago, when the major provisions of the Clean Air Act were passed, the word ''cost'' was hardly mentioned. Now, with the bill in a House-Senate conference, the debate over amendments to the act is filled with figures purporting to capture the cost of the tiniest provision.
The trouble is, it's all hot air. Nobody has any idea what it will cost -worse, there has been a conspiracy of silence on who will pay the bill. 
There are plenty of estimates of the total cost. Unfortunately, the range is large; respectable guesses run from $22 billion to more than $100 billion a year, and almost nobody is willing to declare any number definitive.
As laughably flabby as the cost estimates are, at least they define the territory. Getting a grasp on the dollar number for the benefits is like charting Planet Debbie - virtually impossible. The problem is that the benefits from cleaner air are broad. They include everything from fewer deaths from lung cancer to more relief from sinus headaches.
Thus, estimating the money saved has to take into account profound speculation - like the value of a life (perhaps $2 million to $5 million), savings in medical costs and days lost due to respiratory diseases. It should include, too, less profound categories such as less frequent house painting and reduced damage to national monuments. Toting this up is a mug's game; unsurprisingly, there are no reliable estimates of the benefits.
Why, then, do we seem so eager to pass legislation that could be as expensive as $100 billion a year without knowing whether the benefits will justify the cost? Simply put, the discussion has not focused on who, ultimately, will pay; instead, there is an implicit promise that the Clean Air Act will be a free lunch.
Ask who will pay the bill, and the answer is that business will have to ante up. Granted, the added cost will be felt first by the tens of thousands of businesses that must comply with new regulations on acid rain, toxic emissions and urban smog.
Utilities will have to cut back on cheaper high-sulfur coal and use more expensive low-sulfur coal or install scrubbers to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions. Auto companies will have to limit tailpipe emissions of hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxide, and small businesses like bakeries, gas stations and restaurants will have to control their use of alcohol- and petroleum-based products that contribute to smog. Chemical and steel companies - and dry cleaners, auto body shops and pest control companies -will have to buy new equipment to control airborne toxic substances. But in the final analysis, business doesn't pay. We pay. Business will pass the increased cost along. Either consumers will pay in the form of higher prices for products or services, or workers will pay in the form of lower wages, or shareholders will pay in the form of lower dividends or stock prices.
That means we all will pay more for electricity, gasoline, cars, bread and paint. Workers in affected industries, like steel and mining, will absorb the cost by receiving lower pay hikes or benefits. People who own stock in utility or oil companies will find their dividends are lower or their stocks are worth less. And owners of mom-and-pop dry cleaners will take out less profit.
There is an indirect cost to all of us, too, because the economy won't grow as fast as it could otherwise. After all, money spent for pollution control cannot be spent to make widgets. Likewise, it cannot be spent for new equipment to produce widgets more efficiently.
Finally, the added cost to business will diminish the attractiveness of doing business here, and companies will relocate to other countries, taking production and jobs with them.
Perhaps the blank-check aspect of the Clean Air Act cannot be avoided. The law will mandate what experts agree are sensible goals, and incorporate efficient ways of achieving those goals; the cost will follow. But Congress, the Administration and environmentalists should come clean and point out who will ultimately cough up the money. Twenty-two billion dollars to $100 billion would buy a lot of research on breast cancer, Alzheimer's and heart disease. That's a significant trade-off - one that ought to be considered since the direct cost could be $90 to $450 a person a year.

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
America's Future

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: ASPEN, Colo.

 BODY:
Children were the theme of the International Design Conference in Aspen this year. For a week the participants heard architects, designers, teachers, psychologists and others talk about the needs of children. And all about, their own children played on giant balls, painted, built constructions and generally demonstrated the wonders of youthful imagination.
But in addition to those happy scenes there were reminders of a different and somber reality. Children are poor in extraordinarily large numbers. They are less healthy than their parents. The community gives them less care than any other of the rich industrialized societies gives its children. 
More than 20 percent of American children live below the official poverty line. In cities, the figure is 30 percent. Minority children are far more likely to be poor: 45 percent of black and 39 percent of Hispanic children. In this rich country 100,000 children are homeless.
A commission established by the American Medical Association and the National Association of State Boards of Education reported last month that American teen-agers have profound problems of physical and emotional health. The commission was made up of medical, education and business leaders, including former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop.
On an average day, the commission said, 135,000 students bring guns to school. Every year 1 million teen-age girls, almost a tenth of the age group, become pregnant; 2.5 million adolescents contract a sexually transmitted disease. More than 1 million are regular users of drugs. Alcohol-related accidents are the leading cause of death among teen-agers.
''Never before,'' the commission said, ''has one generation of American teen-agers been less healthy, less cared-for or less prepared for life than their parents were at the same age.'' The report said, as its figures indicated, that the problems are largely behavioral: excessive drinking, drug use, sex and violence.
Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, told the Aspen conference that in today's younger generation the rich are afflicted as are the poor. They, too, abuse drugs, alcohol and sex. They, too, seek instant gratification - and attention.
Distorted values in the young must reflect the social climate, Ms. Edelman said. We, the grown-ups, set the standards of ''personal greed rather than the common good.'' Our political system allowed two million children to fall into poverty in the 1980's while the number of billionaires quintupled. We talk about ''family values'' but don't practice them.
Changing the social climate is a long-run business. But there are immediate steps that can be taken to improve the condition of underprivileged children - and end what really is a national scandal.
Health is one area of clear need. All the advanced countries of the world except the United States have national systems of health insurance that give everyone access to medical care. But even failing that kind of universal system, this country could assure that the young get health care.
The A.M.A.-Boards of Education commission urged that teen-agers be guaranteed access to health services, including counseling, regardless of their ability to pay. The country's interest in the health of younger children is just as great. The problem is especially acute because working poor families often have jobs with no medical insurance.
Another area where progress can be made is child care. Both houses of Congress passed a comprehensive bill last year to help provide care for needy children of working mothers, but a final bill was never agreed. Surely the obstacles should be cleared away now.
President Bush has a particular opportunity for leadership. The country's responsibility to its children is a natural subject for him, involving as it does family values and the need for a stronger, better educated society in America's future.
One important symbolic step for the President is to join the World Summit for Children, which will take place at the United Nations Sept. 29 and 30. The idea comes from Unicef, the U.N. Children's Fund. Many heads of state and government are going to attend, and President Bush will surely want to take advantage of the opportunity.
There are so many things to be done for children. The co-chairman of the Aspen conference, Jane Clark Chermayeff, said: ''It's not that we don't know what to do. It's that we're not doing it.''

LENGTH: 1164 words

HEADLINE: Dinkins and Holtzman Contributors Handling City Bonds

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
Five investment concerns were recently selected to be underwriters for $6 billion in New York City bonds, and it now turns out, to no one's great surprise, that all five were major contributors to the campaigns last year of Mayor David N. Dinkins and City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman.
But so were companies that were not selected. And there lies an adage widely accepted by those doing business with the city: political contributions may not decide the race, but they help you to reach the starting gate.
The five contributed a total of $233,000 to the city's two top officeholders. They did so largely by packaging individual contributions from their employees - a process known as bundling that circumvents the spirit of the city's new campaign finance law, which was intended to keep big money out of municipal campaigns. 
The companies, picked last month by representatives of the Mayor and the Comptroller from a field of 53 companies, stand to make millions of dollars in fees for underwriting the bonds over the next two years. They are Bear Stearns & Company, First Boston Corporation, Goldman Sachs & Company, Merrill Lynch Capital Markets and Shearson Lehman Hutton. Officials of the companies said their donations were motivated only by good citizenship, but one official, who asked not to be identified, said, ''It's fair to say that the perception exists in the industry that since my competitors are making large contributions, I better make them too.''
The State Commission on Government Integrity, in its studies of campaign contributions to state and city officials, had reported that major shares of the campaign donations to State Comptroller Edward V. Regan and Ms. Holtzman's predecessor as City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin, had come from the investment banking community, which seeks bond underwriting contracts from both officials.
Spokesmen for the Mayor and the Comptroller, like the investment bankers, denied that the contributions were a factor in the underwriter selection process, but other City Hall aides familiar with the selection process, who asked not be identified, said that while the size of campaign contributions might not be the determining factor in selecting an underwriter, it was a consideration, particularly as many of the competitors are equally qualified.
''There was absolutely no consideration whatsoever given to the level of contributions, if any,'' said Albert Scardino, the Mayor's press secretary. ''They were evaluated on the basis of which could deliver the best services to the city and give the best interest rate.''
Glenn Goldberg, Ms. Holtzman's press aide, said the underwriter selection process was ''competitive and merit-based.'' He said the underwriters represented ''a balance of institutional and retail'' firms.
 
'Extension of Our Philanthropy'
Alan Greenberg, chief executive officer of Bear Stearns, echoed his investment banking colleagues when he said that the company contributed to politicians because ''you can't have a country without people running for office.'' He said the donations were ''an extension of our philanthropy.''
All five concerns contributed to both candidates directly and through employees.
Among the contributors were 28 employees of the First Boston Corporation, who gave $32,205 to Mr. Dinkins in donations ranging from $10 to $3,000. Fifty-eight employees of Goldman Sachs contributed $41,545 to Mr. Dinkins, while the concern's political action committee gave $6,000 to the Mayor.
Bear Stearns donated at least $3,100 to Ms. Holtzman as a corporation, and 103 of its employees gave an additional $34,550. Thirty-four Shearson Lehman employes donated at least $21,075 to the Holtzman campaign.
The contributions were backed up by politically influential officials of the companies. Robert Steingut, son of the late Stanely Steingut, the former Assembly Speaker, was a negotiator for Bear Stearns, while Ronald T. Gault, the negotiator for First Boston, was a Koch administration official and is a longtime friend of Mr. Dinkins. He contributed at least $2,500 to the Dinkins campaign.
 
Particularly Disappointed
Two concerns that were reported by City Hall aides to be particularly disappointed by their failure to win the underwriting contract had also been big contributors through their employees.
One, Prudential Bache Securities, and its employees had donated $24,730 to the Dinkins campaign, and Morgan Stanley & Company and its workers, $24,540. In contrast, employees of another losing bidder, Dillon Read & Company donated a relatively modest $4,545.
The employee contributions would normally be hard to track under the state election law, which does not require contributors to identify their employers. But the city law requires contributors to list their employers, and ''bundling'' can be tracked in the computerized records of the new City Campaign Finance Board.
The five underwriters represent an expansion of the city's underwriting group. In 1988, Goldman Sachs and Merrill Lynch were selected, but Merrill Lynch was dropped last summer on orders of Mayor Edward I. Koch because the concern was transferring some of its operations to New Jersey. It is now back on the list.
Two other politically influential concerns were selected for the first time as senior managers for a newly created equipment-financing program. Grigsby, Branford & Powell, which was described as a minority-owned firm by the Mayor's office, donated a total of $9,760 to the Dinkins campaign. The other concern, the Artemis Capital Group, which is owned by women, according to the Mayor's office, was not listed as a contributor.
 
Recommended by Committee
The five underwriting concerns were recommended by a committee of representatives of the Dinkins administration and the Comptroller's office, with the advice of two companies serving as the city's new financial advisers, the Public Resources Advisory Group and P. G. Corbin, a minority-owned concern. Each company gave at least $2,000 to the Dinkins campaign.
The underwriters were chosen through negotiations rather than competitive bidding, and the committee considered such factors as bond-marketing ability, outlets, other services and fees.
Carol Bellamy, the former City Council President and a partner in Morgan Stanley before she announced her candidacy for state comptroller in May, said she was involved in Morgan Stanley's losing bid to be a financial adviser to the city but was not part of the concern's futile effort to share in the underwriting.
She said that she was not familiar with the current underwriter selection process but that ''in the Koch-Goldin years, I happen to think they were more above board and less political than in many other cities and states.''
But a person familiar with the city selection process said the joint Mayor-Comptroller committee is generally ''instructed'' by the Mayor and the Comptroller. ''They are not agents on a frolic,'' he added.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
The Group Show as Crystal Ball

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH

 BODY:
THE group exhibition, that end-of-season ritual, is upon us, and with it comes the opportunity to take the art world's pulse. This year, these shows seem to be everywhere, uptown and down, with something to offer nearly every esthetic palate. Many of them are simply reprises of each gallery's stable of artists, but several exhibitions in SoHo, of which six are reviewed here, concentrate on emerging or little-known artists and offer some signs of things to come.
These shows mix styles and media, high points and low points, and several artists appear in more than one of them. They may lack in overall esthetic impressiveness, not to mention cohesiveness. But they say a lot about a younger generation of artists that has been waiting, somewhat restively, in the wings over the past season.
Fit into a nutshell, the signals they send might sound like this: Ostentation is out. The turn away from drop-dead, picture-perfect objects that reek of costly fabrication processes a la Jeff Koons and Ashley Bickerton continues. On the rise is the emphasis on simple techniques, hand-making, modest scale and inexpensive (preferably recycled, possibly organic) materials. Social concern in one form or another is in, and so is the kind of self-expression that delves unblinkingly into sexual or racial identity or oppression, or into class structure. 
The Conceptual impulse in object-making is as strong as ever, evident most directly in drawings and sculptures that incorporate language. Not surprisingly in these post-Mapplethorpe times, some of the words are the three-, four- and five-letter kind. There's also a frequent disregard for the art object that makes the early 90's sometimes feel a bit like the early 70's, and a concomitant rise not only in installation art, but also in performance work among the younger set. Finally, painting and abstract art in general are in such short supply -at least in these shows - that they seem more and more like a daring thing to do.
Above all: The pressure to make art about politics, especially sexual politics, is very real, what with the multi-headed Gorgon of AIDS, the abortion battle, the environment, American involvement in Central America and the debates on obscenity and freedom of speech. But in typical art-world fashion, this pressure is also coalescing into a fad, a bandwagon with many passengers of varying talent.
This weekend's exhibitions fall into two groups. The three most tightly focused ones attest to the emphasis on sexual and racial politics in art today, while three other shows offer broader views in hodgepodge surveys of 40 to 80 small works or drawings.
The relatively focused exhibitions are ''Eros/Thanatos; Death and Desire,'' at the Tom Cugliani Gallery (508 Greenwich Street, through July 17); ''Membership Has Its Privileges,'' at Lang & O'Hara (568 Broadway, at Prince Street, through July 27), and an exhibition at Wessel O'Connor (580 Broadway, near Prince Street, through July 14). This last show features the work of Ridgeway Bennett, a pair of young artists who hail originally from Zimbabwe and have worked together for nearly a decade, Marlene McCarty (who also appears in the other two shows) and Dread Scott (whose artwork using the American flag caused a furor at the Art Institute of Chicago last spring).
 Tom Cugliani Gallery
The work in these three shows runs from the personal to the documentary, from the subtle to the obvious. In the 11-artist exhibition at Cugliani, Jack Pierson has simply pinned dozens of snapshots of the same young man to the wall, an off-handed summary of sexual desire, while Hunter Reynolds's photographs trace his transformation from bearded man to heavily made-up Tootsie-like woman. Steven Evans and John Lindell deal, respectively, with male nudity and profanity, but in ways that are almost impossible to see. Deciphering their motifs relegates the viewer to the position of a squinting, narrow-minded voyeur.
Robin Kahn's paintinglike embroidery gives visual form to an obsession shared by both sexes, at least in America: it catalogues variations in the size and shape of women's breasts, while also acknowledging female nudity as one of painting's historical subjects. Ms. McCarty makes a similar acknowledgement; her small canvases reduce the female genitalia to four- and five-letter words, spelled out in blunt, computer-type graphics. At Lang & O'Hara, with a bit more economy and wit, Ms. McCarty exhibits a painting whose central vertical stripe, reminiscent of a Barnett Newman ''zip,'' spells out the word ''Testosterone.''
 
Wessel O'Connor
At Wessel O'Connor, in addition to Ms. McCarty's works, there are paintings by Ridgeway Bennett that merge sex and religion using a cross-like geometry, a three-letter word and a surface that includes a great deal of wax and, says the press release, some semen. Dread Scott attempts to mix the documentary with the spatially claustrophobic in an installation work titled ''Kinder and Gentler.'' The piece consists of four listening booths labeled, like restrooms, for whites, blacks, ladies and gentlemen only. Its main impact stems from two audio tapes the artist has spliced, one about violence against blacks, the other about violence against women, both of which begin with the urgent yet cadenced voice of Ntozake Shange performing her own work.
 
Lang & O'Hara
In ''Membership Has Its Privileges,'' the 10-artist exhibition at Lang & O'Hara, the scene shifts more to the country club set, to the presence rather than the absence of power and to the institutions that power generates. Sometimes this is quite literal: just inside the gallery door, Janet Bigg's grim little paintings invite us to consider the uninviting modern architecture of eight churches and libraries, each labeled with an imitation bronze plaque.
In a work titled ''Greek System,'' Kenneth Goldsmith, who is present in four of these shows, uses some old school fraternity paddles labeled with the Greek words for misogynist, egoist, conformist and so forth to imply a system of exclusion. And Dennis Farber hand-paints an innocent 1950's photograph of a child's birthday party, converting its participants into pre-school members of the Ku Klux Klan.
In the remaining group shows, the number of artists rises dramatically and, with it, the viewpoint broadens. Clearly not every emerging artist is making political art. In fact ''Meet,'' an exhibition at the Althea Viafora Gallery that weighs in with 42 artists, and ''Work on Paper'' at the Paula Allen Gallery, bear more than a passing resemblance to a survey of old-fashioned drawings. Like most, they show how artists continue to both accept and push against the definition of the medium.
 
Viafora Gallery
At Viafora (568 Broadway, at Prince Street, through July 21), Lily van der Stokker's ''Ja,'' a small, bright-colored marker drawing, condenses graffiti to a pleasing domestic scale. Matthew Barney's ''Drawing Restraint II (Documents)'' turns the act of drawing into a feat of engineering (and wall climbing). Also noteworthy are works by Kirsten Mosher, Christian Marclay, Tishan Hsu, Elliot Green and the ubiquitous Mr. Goldsmith (who, judging from these four ''at bats,'' may be at his best on paper).
 
Paula Allen Gallery
The Paula Allen show, with 81 artists, throws an even wider net, with a fair amount of humor in the catch. Fred Tomaselli turns out a beautiful rendition of famous constellations, naming each star for a different sleeping pill. With suave cartoonship, Kay Rosen's ''Classic Pair'' proposes that more than one King Xerxes be called Xeroxes. Kevin Carter smears the ink lines on a sheet of tablet paper to spell ''Drunk.'' And Howard Halle exhibits what may be the first Gorbachev-Bush shopping bag. Further interest - amusing or otherwise - is supplied by Dan Appel, David Hammons, Sean Landers, Kim Jones, Judy Ledgerwood, Zoe Leonard, Hunter Reynolds, Nicolas Rule, Ms. van der Stokker, Pamela Golden and B. Wurtz. The show remains on view at 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, through next Friday.
 
Andrea Rosen Gallery
The final mega-group show is ''Stendhal Syndrome: The Cure,'' a theme show with a gimmick at the Andrea Rosen Gallery (130 Prince Street, through Aug. 4). Working with Catherine Liu, a writer, and Curtiss Mitchell, one of the artists in the show, Ms. Rosen invited 48 artists to devise a cure for the so-called Stendhal syndrome, whose victims are usually travelers felled by the beauty of works of art. (Fittingly enough, the problem was isolated by a psychiatrist in Florence.) Each artist was given a white metal first-aid kit to work with, and many, although certainly not all, ended up using it. The power of music is several times proposed as an antidote to visual overload, but otherwise the cures offered are as various as the sensibilities of the artists involved. Joan Waltemath lined her kit with fur and play money and titled the result ''An Antidote Is Not a Cure,'' while Christian Marclay simply blew his up, exhibiting the charred remains as a piece of sculpture.
But the extremes of response are perhaps best summed up in those of Jessica Diamond and Felix Gonzalez-Torres. Ms. Diamond's wall drawing quotes a passage from Nabokov and then asks in effect, Who needs a cure?, while also directing those who ''can't take the heat'' to the nearest television set.
Mr. Gonzalez-Torres exhibits a box containing photographs, postcards, documents and newspaper clippings that center on the brutal murder, in Portland, Ore., in November 1988, of an Ethiopian immigrant by a gang of skinheads. Nothing cures esthetic overindulgence like a stiff dose of reality, the artist seems to say, a sentiment that, for better and for worse, many of his generation seem to share.

HEADLINE: Late-June Vehicle Sales Rose 12.5%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 5

 BODY:
Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks jumped 12.5 percent in late June, surprising analysts and raising hopes among auto executives that the industry had turned a corner after a nine-month slump.
The gains were shared by the General Motors Corporation, whose vehicle sales rose 17.8 percent, and by the Ford Motor Company, with a gain of 4.5 percent. The Chrysler Corporation's sales, however, fell despite an aggressive advertising campaign.
Many industry experts, at a loss to explain the late-June surge, said they expected auto sales to decline again in the next few months. Although auto sales in all of June were the best in five months, they still lagged June last year by 1.6 percent. 
 
Continued High Sales Doubted
''If sales continue at this level for the next few months, we may want to declare the auto recession over,'' said Scott Merlis, an automotive analyst at Morgan Stanley. But Mr. Merlis said he regarded June auto sales as a level that the industry will not be able to attain again until next year. ''Last month's sales were above the recent trend, and I would not be surprised to see them drop back down,'' he said.
''Weak underlying demand and a cautious consumer will hold further increases in check,'' said Tom Webb, chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Association, which represents 25,000 car dealerships.
In late June, cars sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 8 million, the highest rate since early January. The monthly sales rate of 7 million for all of June was also the highest since January, when buyers flocked to take advantage of hefty rebates and other financial incentives.
 
Incentives Dipped Industrywide
Incentives actually dipped industrywide by an average of about $200 a model in June. Economic indicators, such as income growth and interest rates, have not favored a spurt in car purchases, analysts said.
Similar late-month increases have been reported at other times this year, an anomaly some analysts attributed to the reporting systems of several of the Japanese auto makers that produce cars in the United States and tend to post the bulk of their sales at the end of each month.
For General Motors, the late-June gains came from the strong sales of a bevy of its compact and mid-sized models, particularly the Geo Metro and Storm, the Pontiac Sunbird and Grand Prix, and the recently introduced Chevrolet Lumina.
''For some time now, G.M. has outperformed its domestic rivals,'' said Jack V. Kirnan, an automotive analyst at Kidder, Peabody. ''G.M. has a lot of product momentum with its new vehicles so far this year.''
While General Motors and Ford both had gains, Chrysler's combined car and truck sales fell 11 percent in late June, and the performance of the nation's No. 3 auto maker was equaled for the second time this year by Honda, which reported it sold as many of its American-made cars as Chrysler.
 
Japanese Vehicle Sales Up
Indeed, the Japanese transplants increased vehicle sales 53.4 percent in late June, while the Big Three reported overall sales gains of only 7.7 percent.
For all of June, sales of cars imported from Japan fell 5.5 percent, and European imports declined even further. The Big Three also posted sales declines totaling 7.1 percent in cars, while their overall sales of light trucks rose 2 percent.
The largest sales gains for the full month were reported by the Japanese transplants, which increased car sales by 55 percent and won 4 points of market share over a year earlier.
Although analysts are generally skeptical that sales will continue to improve, the domestic auto makers are expecting a sales surge in the second half of the year, judging by their aggressive production plans.
At production meetings last week, the 11 domestic car producers added 62,000 cars and light trucks to their schedules for the third quarter, bringing the total planned output to 2.5 million for July through September, a 12 percent increase over last year's third-quarter production.
If the car companies hold to their preliminary production fourth-quarter schedules, the industry will wind up only about 5 percent below 1989's total output. Those plans could be upset, however, if the United Automobile Workers union, whose contract expires in mid-September, calls a strike.
 
Stocks of Unsold Cars Low
Dealer stocks of unsold cars are fairly low and are likely to remain below normal levels for the next few months, as many auto plants in the United States and Canada have begun extended shutdowns for vacations and new-model retooling. Mr. Webb, of the automobile dealers association, said the low inventories had halted the slide in dealership profits, at least for now.
Some analysts said strong auto sales in June may increase auto makers' profits for the second half of the year, because dealers will have to replenish their inventories.Car companies book revenues when they sell vehicles to dealers.
''This could be the first summer since 1984 when the domestic auto makers won't have to resort to big blowout incentives to get rid of their current models to make way for new ones,'' said Mr. Kirnan, at Kidder, Peabody.
J.B. Fitzpatrick, vice president of marketing and product planning at G.M., said that General Motors market share has improved steadily during the year, to 36.4 percent in June, an increase of four-tenths of a percent compared with a year ago.
By contrast, Ford's share of the domestic market fell to 23.8 percent in June, compared with 24.3 percent a year earlier. And Chrysler lost two full points of market share, falling to 12.1 percent, from 14.1 percent a year earlier.
The decline in sales and market share at Chrysler comes despite several months of aggressive advertising, including a recent campaign that compares Chrysler cars favorably to Honda automobiles.
''Chrysler's heavy advertising does not seem to be doing the company any good at all,'' Mr. Kirnan said.
Honda increased its share of the United States market to 6.8 percent in June, compared with 4.2 percent a year ago, as sales of its cars built in Marysville, Ohio, rose sharply.
The Toyota Motor Corporation also increased sales of its cars and trucks in June, assembled in Georgetown, Ky. But sales of imported Toyota vehicles fell in June, resulting in an overall United States sales decline of 5.6 percent for Japan's largest auto maker and a slight loss of market share, to 6.5 percent.
The Nissan Motor Company reported declines in sales of both imported and domestically produced vehicles, as overall sales fell 17.7 percent, and its market share dipped nearly a point, to 4.1 percent.

HEADLINE: No Change Seen at Fed On Rates

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Despite pressure from the White House and Congress to lower interest rates quickly to try to prevent a recession, the Federal Reserve apparently decided at a policy meeting this week to hold rates unchanged for the time being.
That was the assessment yesterday by some top Government officials outside the Fed and by Wall Street economists who monitor the central bank's activity. But the Fed's governing body did reportedly give some ground, the officials said, adopting a resolution that expressed a new willingness to lower rates. Such a resolution means that action could come this month if fresh data show that the economy is indeed sliding toward recession. 
The secretive Fed gave no hint of what its policy makers - its governors and the presidents of its regional banks - decided at the meeting on Monday and Tuesday in Washington. No sign of sympathy toward lower rates showed in the Fed's dealings in the Treasury securities markets yesterday. And Joseph Coyne, a Fed spokesman, declined to comment on reports that the policy makers had approved a new ''bias toward easing'' rates.
 
New Bias May Have No Effect
The new bias, in fact, may never be converted into lower rates. But in the arcane language of the Fed, the resolution expressed a greater willingness to lower rates than existed at the last policy meeting, in mid-May - if the mounting anecdotal evidence of a weakening economy also shows up in fresh statistical data. Since early this year the Fed has expressed no special inclination either to raise or lower rates.
''This is a very dicey time,'' said Robert Di Clemente, a Fed watcher at Salomon Brothers Inc. ''It could be we are on the verge of a recession, but the signals are mixed. It isn't as if the economy is going down in a straight decline.''
The first test of the central bank's intentions could come today, with the Labor Department's release of June employment numbers. Jobs have been growing much more slowly this year than last, and if the June figures show more weakness, the Fed might act.
 
What the Fed Could Do
If the Fed did act, it would do so by increasing bank reserves, thus setting off a chain of events that would lower interest rates. The chain of events set off by this action would lower interest rates on a variety of consumer and business loans. The lower rates usually encourage more borrowing to finance purchases and investment, thus stimulating the economy. Sometimes the rising activity pushes prices up, making the inflation rate rise.
But weak employment numbers might not be enough to make the Fed act, in the view of many experts. As recently as mid-June, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, said publicly that while the American economy was growing sluggishly, recession was a declining prospect, not a growing one.
Fear of a recession prompted the Fed to lower interest rates slightly in early November and again in late December. Shortly afterward, however, Government data showed strong activity in home construction and a sharply rising inflation rate, a surge in economic activity that lasted through the first quarter. But data released in May and June indicated that retail sales had deteriorated, along with consumer spending and construction activity. The only clearly strong sector was exports of manufactured goods.
 
'A Widespread Uneasiness'
''You don't find the confidence in the economy that you once did, at any level, in the small towns or the cities,'' said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana and chairman of Congress's Joint Economic Committee, who traveled in the Midwest this week. ''There is a widespread uneasiness; that's the best word to describe it.''
Apart from the state of the economy, the pressure on the Fed to lower rates stems from President Bush's new proposal to bleed roughly $50 billion from the budget deficit in a single year through a combination of increased tax revenues and reductions in Government spending. The twin actions would weaken the economy, by taking spending money from taxpayers' pockets and by reducing Government outlays for a wide range of activities.
The Bush proposal is now the key element in budget negotiations with Congress. But such a cutback in activity would set off a recession, many economists and politicians say, unless the Fed offset the cutback by lowering rates.
 
Traditional Focus on Inflation
The Fed traditionally concentrates on reducing inflation, which it tries to accomplish by manipulating bank reserves in such a way that rates rise for a variety of consumer and business loans. The high rates - home equity loans and long-term mortgage rates, for example, stand at 10 percent or more - are intended to discourage purchases and investments made on credit. Less of such activity, in turn, makes price increases less likely.
But when recession threatens, the central bank comes under pressure to reduce rates to encourage the borrowing that finances spending and investment, even at the risk of higher inflation. And right now Congress and the Bush Administration are campaigning vigorously for lower rates.
Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, for example, criticized the Fed yesterday for sticking stubbornly to inflation-fighting. ''In the United States it is not wise to emphasize an undying attack on inflation if it hampers economic growth,'' he said in a breakfast meeting yesterday with reporters.
 
Other Voices for Lower Rates
Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director, have also called on the central bank in recent days to lower rates to stimulate a sluggish economy in danger of recession. And in a rare attack on the Fed, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee, said in a Senate speech on June 18 that the Fed was fighting the wrong battle.
''What is the Federal Reserve trying to fix?'' he asked. ''If it is inflation, currently there is little evidence in the numbers that it needs fixing. Looking at the economic numbers, it is clear that adequate real growth, not inflation, should be our major concern.''
The inflation rate as measured by the Consumer Price Index has hovered around 4.5 percent a year for several years, although it jumped to an annual rate of more than 5 percent in the first quarter of this year.
 
Greenspan's Argument
Mr. Greenspan has argued that a plan to reduce the budget deficit significantly - a plan persuasive enough to make it credible to the the public and the financial markets -would result in lower interest rates without any Fed action. Among other things, chronic deficits raise expectations of inflation, and as these deficits subside, so do the interest rates that lenders charge to offset inflation, Mr. Greenspan and other economists argue.
But Mr. Brady said yesterday that Mr. Greenspan should help the deficit reduction negotiations along by taking the lead in lowering rates and not waiting for them to fall on their own. ''I've said to him that I don't think we should wait around,'' Mr. Brady said.

Sundstrand Sees Drop in Earnings

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: ROCKFORD, Ill., July 5

 BODY:
The Sundstrand Corporation said it expected second-quarter earnings to be down about $7 million because of losses from its Brazilian operation. In May, when business in Brazil almost came to a halt because of the Government's anti-inflation program, Sundstrand's Brazilian operation reduced its work force of 429 by 30 percent, to 318.
Sundstrand, which makes equipment for agriculture, construction and industry, said it had overcome most of the adverse results of its Brazilian operation and did not expect signficant additional losses from Brazil for the rest of 1990. In the the second quarter of 1989, Sundstrand earned $34.5 million.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Madison Ave. Turns an Ear To Rap Music

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
YO, Madison Avenue!
Rap music, the fastest-growing genre of popular music, is rapidly moving into the mainstream of American society. Now, not surprisingly, a growing number of advertisers are trying to cash in on rap's popularity.
British Knights, a New York athletic footwear company, recently said it would use the popular rap artist M. C. Hammer to give its commercials a hip-hop beat. Coca-Cola used a rap group in a new Sprite ad, and Pepsi has the Grammy Award-winner Young MC rapping the praises of ''Cool Cans,'' its big summer promotion. In addition, a number of agencies said they plan to use rap music in coming campaigns. 
Rap is characterized by rhythmic music and rhymed lyrics that are chanted to a driving beat. Although it originated in urban black communities in the 1970's, rap has broadened its appeal to include a diverse, but primarily young, audience that many advertisers are trying to reach.
This fall, for example, NBC plans to broadcast a new comedy, ''Fresh Prince of Bel Air,'' featuring the rap singer Wil Smith.
''Rap is the coming thing,'' said John Gross, a spokesman for J.S.M. Music, a New York-based music production company. ''We're working on a lot of demonstration tapes for advertisers that use rap.''
But some marketing experts warned that using rap in advertising could be risky because it could alienate many consumers.
''Advertisers that are using rap are gambling on the future,'' said Al Ries, the chairman of Trout & Ries, a strategic marketing consulting firm. ''Rap has had a lot of trouble cleaning itself up, and there's still no guarantee that it will totally move into the mainstream.''
Rap has been criticized for lyrics that are sometimes sexually explicit and for the violence that has accompanied some concerts. Although many rap music groups have toned down the anti-establishment messages in their songs and cleaned up their lyrics, the genre's bad-boy image lingers. Most recently, members of the rap group 2 Live Crew were arrested for performing a song that a Florida Federal court had ruled was obscene.
But some advertisers and their agencies are obviously willing to take the chance. One important reason is rap's ability to reach young consumers easily. ''Young people have always had their own language, and this is a way to get them to pay attention,'' said William Katz, a senior vice president at BBDO in New York, which created the Pepsi ''Cool Cans'' commercial. ''We have to be on the leading edge.''
But even so, Pepsi did not take any unnecessary risks. Young MC, who is featured in the ''Cool Cans'' spot, is upbeat and clean-cut, and he has a degree in economics from the University of Southern California. And, for the uninitiated, title cards translate the commercial's rap lyrics.
Aside from its appeal to the youth market, advertisers like rap because it is an effortless way to pack a lot of information into 30 seconds. ''Rap is perfectly tailored to the television commercial's short form,'' said Peter Foulds, the director of advertising at Pepsi. ''It's an easy way to tell a story.''
Some advertising executives also say rap music works better in commercials than some other kinds of popular music because the lyrics are spoken and are therefore more easily understood.
Rap performers have a cautionary note for advertisers. Already, imitations of rap music are cropping up in some commercials and authentic rappers say that is a mistake. ''It's offensive,'' said Marvin Young, who performs under the name Young MC.
''If the point is to reach young people, an imitation isn't going to have the right effect,'' he added. ''Rap fans will know right away when the music isn't the real thing, and the advertising is going to turn them off.''
