HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Fall in Light Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities dipped and interest rates rose slightly in fairly light trading yesterday, as dealers positioned themselves for the release this morning of June employment data.
The traders pushed prices lower early in the session in reaction to a report in The Wall Street Journal that the Bush Administration was considering whether to impose a sales tax on a wide range of securities, including stocks and bonds. Administration officials said yesterday that the odds were against such a tax.
Adding to the decline was news that automobile sales for the last 10 days of June were far stronger than expected. 
 
Eight Million Cars Sold
Automobile makers sold eight million cars at a seasonally adjusted annual rate during the period, the highest level since the middle of January.
''The numbers were much stronger than anticipated, and were the first sign of consumer strength in some time, but I would be cautious in assuming this means that consumer spending is about to rise,'' said Michael J. Moran, the chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc.
He noted that the domestic manufacturers, especially Honda of America Inc., which sold more cars than the Chrysler Corporation during the late-June sales period, often put on big incentives at the end of each month to spur sales.
''You would need to see additional healthy numbers before concluding that people are spending again,'' Mr. Moran said.
While talk of a securities tax and the auto sales numbers influenced trading to some degree, the dealers said the developments paled in significance next to the job data.
''Potentially, the employment figures are very important for all financial markets, '' a government bond trader said. ''If the bond market sees a good set of numbers, short rates are likely to fall even more, which in all likelihood will have an impact on the stock market and on the dollar.''
 
Predictions on Data
The traders and financial economists have said an increase in nonfarm payroll employment of less than 100,000 would have a salutary effect on interest rates. Conversely, if the employment number rises by 200,000 or more, market interest rates would almost certainly rise, they said.
Excluding census workers, many of whom were dismissed last month, most analysts estimate that non-farm payroll employment rose by about 160,000.
Some of the dealers said they sold securities yesterday to defend against the chance that the employment report might be stronger than anticipated.
By late yesterday, the Treasury's 8 3/4 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 103 26/32, down by 6/32, to yield 8.39 percent, up from 8.38 percent late on Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at 103 5/32, down by 3/32, to yield 8.39 percent. And the 8 3/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 9/ 32, down by 3/32, to yield 8.21 percent. 30-Year Bonds Down to 8.79% Before the coming auctions, the 30-year bonds to be sold on Tuesday for the Resolution Funding Corporation were offered on a when-issued basis late yesterday at a price to yield 8.79 percent, down slightly from 8.81 percent on Tuesday. The agency was created to finance the bailout of the savings and loan industry.
And the seven-year Treasury notes to be auctioned on Wednesday were offered in late when-issued trading at a price to yield 8.41 percent, up slightly from 8.39 percent.
While the yields on bonds and notes rose slightly, short-term rates on Treasury bills moved in the other direction. The traders said optimism that the job data might prompt the Federal Reserve to ease credit conditions, coupled with a drop in stock prices, generated demand for bills yesterday.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.65 percent, down by 3 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by a basis point, to a late offered rate of 7.56 percent. And one-year bill rates were unchanged, at an offered rate of 7.44 percent.
 
Moody's Upgrades County
In other developments, Moody's Investors Service Inc., which along with other primary ratings agencies has been busily downgrading the creditworthiness of various state and local governments this year, said yesterday that one of the country's critical problem areas in the 1980's had been returned to investment-grade status.
The agency said it had lifted its ratings on Wayne County, Mich., which includes Detroit.
Moody's lifted its ratings on more than $265.9 million worth of Wayne County's outstanding general obligation bonds to Baa, from Ba-1. The county had been rated at less than investment grade since October 1979.
The agency said in a news release that Wayne County was upgraded because it had carried out a state-authorized fiscal stabilization plan.
Activity in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds was light yesterday, the dealers said. The prices of most actively quoted issues were unchanged to up by an eighth of a point.
Meanwhile, the traders of investment-grade corporate bonds said the prices of most issues dipped by about an eighth of a point, largely in sympathy with the decline in Treasury prices.

HEADLINE: Japan Goals For 1990's

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 5

 BODY:
The Government ministry that helped engineer Japan's export-fueled economic boom says that in the 1990's Japan must turn inward and set its own house in order.
Financing priorities, once almost exclusively aimed at industrial growth, should shift to the nation's frayed infrastructure and frustrated consumers, says an advisory report approved today by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. 
While short on specifics, the ministry's vision for the 1990's addresses many of the demands for economic reform made by the United States in talks that led to last month's agreement on ways to tackle the United States trade deficit with Japan.
These include a push for more spending at home on public works like roads, sewers and parks -''areas in which Japan lags behind other major developed nations,'' a summary of the report said.
The report also repeatedly urges that Japan make life easier for its high-paying consumers, who should have ''the opportunity to choose what to purchase and the chance to decide what price to pay.''
The report also warns, however, that manufacturing is still vital to Japan's economy. It recommends that the Government nearly double financing of research and development to about 1 percent of the gross national product.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher In a Slow Trading Session

BYLINE: The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mostly higher on world currency markets yesterday in light and uneventful trading.
Traders in the United States and Europe attributed the rise to technical factors. Lou Calvello, a trader with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said several dealers were buying dollars to square up their positions ahead of today's release of unemployment data for June. 
The market has been anticipating the report for several days. ''Hopefully, it will spark some activity,'' said Jim Chorek, an analyst with MMS International in Chicago.
Trading was particularly thin, with many United States investors absent from the market as they extended their holiday, dealers said. United States financial markets were closed Wednesday for Independence Day.
Against the West German currency, the dollar settled in New York at 1.6517 marks, up from European trading and up from its Tuesday close in New York of 1.6505.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 151.00 yen from Wednesday's 150.30. In London, the dollar traded lower, at 150.50 yen. It closed higher in New York, at 150.57, against the European close, but lower than its Tuesday close of 151.00 yen.
In London, one British pound cost $1.7795, cheaper for buyers than Wednesday's $1.7845. In New York, it cost $1.7815 to buy one pound, compared with $1.7765 late Tuesday..
In New York, the dollar settled at 1.3998 Swiss francs, up from European trading and from the Tuesday New York close of 1.3930; 5.5430 French francs, up from Europe and from the Tuesday New York close of 5.5400, and 1.1640 Canadian dollars, up from Europe and from 1.1625 on Tuesday.
In the precious metals market, gold prices fell. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery traded at $361.40 an ounce, off 70 cents from late Tuesday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $360.50, off 50 cents.

PUB-DATE: July 7, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1, Column 7; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1715 words

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
NATO ALLIES, AFTER 40 YEARS, PROCLAIM END OF COLD WAR; INVITE GORBACHEV TO SPEAK

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 6

 BODY:
President Bush and the other leaders of NATO today issued a declaration to end four decades of cold war by proposing to act jointly with Moscow and other East Europeans in stating that ''we are no longer adversaries.''
Inviting President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to travel to Brussels to speak with them, the Western leaders promised a new defensive strategy that would make their nuclear forces ''truly weapons of last resort.'' They assured Moscow and the other Warsaw Pact nations that ''we will never in any circumstance be the first to use force'' and proposed that NATO, the Warsaw Pact and European states outside the two alliances join in a ''commitment to nonaggression.''
''Our alliance will do its share to overcome the legacy of decades of suspicion,'' they said. [Text, page 5.] 
 
Desire to Help Gorbachev
NATO's Secretary General will fly to Moscow to discuss the declaration with Mr. Gorbachev, whose own policies are under attack in the Soviet Union. Unspoken in the declaration is a desire by most NATO leaders to give Mr. Gorbachev striking evidence to demonstrate to his critics that his conciliatory policy toward the West is bringing results.
Mr. Bush said at a news conference that he thought the declaration would help Mr. Gorbachev deal with his ''hard-liners.'' But he continued to oppose direct American economic aid to the Soviet Union.
The steps taken today were also aimed at making it easier for Mr. Gorbachev to acquiesce to the unification of the Germanys, something specifically called for in the declaration.
In what was called the London Declaration, drafted over the last two days by their foreign ministers in the palace of Lancaster House, the NATO leaders were clearly trying to speak to history in the same ringing tones that the North Atlantic Treaty sent out from Washington at the height of the cold war when the alliance was formed.
 
'The Hand of Friendship'
''The Atlantic Community must reach out to the countries of the East which were our adversaries in the cold war, and extend to them the hand of friendship,'' they said, inviting the members of the crumbling Warsaw Pact to join in a declaration solemnly stating that the era of mutually hostile blocs was over. ''The walls that once confined people and ideas are collapsing,'' the allied heads of government said. ''As a consequence, this alliance must and will adapt.''
In a wide-ranging review of alliance strategy and force levels, the NATO leaders promised to prepare a new defensive approach, using small, multinational light forces stationed far from the former front lines instead of ''forward defense.'' They also pledged to reduce the reliance on nuclear weapons now enshrined in strategy of ''flexible response.''
They invited the Warsaw Pact coun-tries to establish a ''regular diplomatic liaison'' with NATO and agreed to strengthen the role of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe.
Significantly, they made a major concession to Soviet fears about a united Germany within NATO, and agreeding to set limits on German armed forces as soon as the United States and the Soviet Union signed a treaty reducing their forces stationed in Europe, later this year.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, who was effusive about the support he said he had received all along from Mr. Bush, said that German troop strength would be one of the topics he would discuss with Mr. Gorbachev when he flies to Moscow on July 15 to try to overcome Mr. Gorbachev's the Soviet leader's remaining objections to German unification.
The initial reaction from Moscow today was favorable. Mr. Gorbachev told ABC News that he saw ''very constructive signs coming out of this summit'' and that he was ''always ready to go'' to Brussels to meet with the Western allies.
 
Bonn Considers Aid to Soviets
Mr. Kohl said today that he would also discuss economic aid to the Soviet Union with Mr. Gorbachev, who sent a letter to Mr. Bush today formally requesting consideration of economic and financial aid for his attempt to transform the Soviet economy, according to American officials said. At a news conference, the President said, ''I have some big problems with that one'' as long as the Soviet Union spent so much on its military establishment and on subsidies for Cuba. But he said he had no objection to a West German decision to provide economic aid.
''As our alliance enters its fifth decade,'' the Western leaders said in their declaration, ''it must continue to provide for the common defense.''
''Yet our alliance must be even more an agent of change,'' they said. ''It can help build the structures of a more united continent.''
Reaffirming that ''security and stability do not lie solely in the military dimension,'' the allies declared:
First Use of Force Disavowed ''We will remain a defensive alliance and will continue to defend all the territory of all of our members. We have no aggressive intentions and we commit ourselves to the peaceful resolution of all disputes. We will never in any circumstance be the first to use force.''
Mr. Kohl and Mr. Bush insisted today that the agreement to give a commitment on manpower levels of a unified German military did not constitute the singling out of German forces. The United States and West Germany have been resisting any repetition of the harsh approach taken by the victorious Allies after World War I, when limits were imposed on German strength and sovereignty. They said the German levels would be set in the context of negotiations involving all the NATO and Warsaw Pact European forces.
It was Mr. Bush's proposal to declare nuclear arms to be weapons of ''last resort'' that prompted the most intensive discussions, with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and President Francois Mitterrand of France both insisting on a fuller explanation of why, even if the alliance reduced its reliance on nuclear weapons, it needed to make any potential aggressor worry that it might use them in self-defense.
 
Nuclear 'Last Resort'
''These will continue to fulfill an essential role in the overall strategy of the alliance to prevent war by insuring that there are no circumstances in which nuclear retaliation in response to military action might be discounted,'' the statement said, in words Mrs. Thatcher said she had ''spent a long time on.''
''However, in the transformed Europe, they will be able to adopt a new NATO strategy making nuclear forces truly weapons of last resort,'' the document said, referring to the United States, Britain and France. It promised a new NATO military strategy ''moving away from 'forward defense,' where appropriate, towards a reduced forward presence and modifying 'flexible response' to reflect a reduced reliance on nuclear weapons.''
Forward defense is the old alliance strategy of basing combat-ready American and German forces close to the East German border, ready to repel a conventional attack as soon as it starts. Flexible response is the NATO deterrence doctrine of keeping an attacker guessing about when and whether the response might be nuclear retaliation.
 
New Role for 35-Nation Forum
Finally, the NATO declaration proposed that the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a 35-nation forum that includes neutral nations as well as members of the Eastern and Western alliances, ''should become more prominent in Europe's future .''
This has been a longstanding demand of Mr. Gorbachev's., and The NATO document listed a series of steps to bring together all of the national leaders at least once a year, establish a center for the prevention of conflict and create an Assembly of Europe that would include parliamentary representatives of all participating countries.
Manfred Mr. Worner, NATO's Secretary General, will fly to Moscow on July 14 to explain the new NATO stance to Mr. Gorbachev and other Soviet leaders. Before departing for the United States this afternoon, President Mr. Bush said he expected to talk discuss the new position over with Mr. Gorbachev by telephone, ''perhaps within the next couple of weeks.''
''I think they have to sort it out now,'' the President Mr. Bush said. ''They have to decide what they want - how much of their gross national product ought to go into arms, whether the threat is much less than they have historically perceived. And once they take that decision, then we in the West will stand ready to work very cooperatively with them.''
 
Bush Balks at Economic Aid
But, he said, the alliance has made no decision to send money to the Soviet Union, and the United States does not want to. ''One problem is that a great percentage of their gross national product is going into the military,'' he said; another was ''spending $5 billion a year on Cuba, for example, to sustain a totaliatarian regime that is highly critical of the Soviet Union from time to time.''
''If the Germans decide they're going to do that, that's their business,'' Mr. Bush said. Asked what message he thought the alliance was sending to the Soviet leader, the President replied, ''I think it should be clear to Mr. Gorbachev, to his adversaries and to his friends inside the Soviet Union, that NATO is changing, and to the degree that they had seen it as a threat to their borders, they should look at it not as a threat to their people.''
After the President, Mr. Bush, the leader who seemed most pleased by what had been achieved here was clearly Mr. Kohl, who over for the last two days has held his own background briefings, in his own hotel, in his own language, while the other leaders were content with common facilities provided by their British hosts.
He was frank in acknowledging that the agreement on a new approach would not have been achieved without the American President. ''As far as I'm concerned, the chemistry is right with George Bush,'' he said. ''The present American administration has a very clear view of things.''
He Mr. Kohl was also clearly encouraged by the alliance's pledge to withdraw all American nuclear artillery shells from Europe if the Soviets made corresponding reductions. His Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, seemed persuaded that eventually all other short-range American and Soviet nuclear systems would follow.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
NATO ALLIES, AFTER 40 YEARS, PROCLAIM END OF COLD WAR; INVITE GORBACHEV TO SPEAK
Shevardnadze Says the Measures Herald 'a Safe Future' for Europe

BYLINE: By BILL KELLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 6

 BODY:
The Soviet Government reacted with enthusiasm today to Western proposals for a new order in Europe, and said the moves would strengthen President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at a time when he is under increasing attack from hard-liners.
Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said the measures approved by the London meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization ''pave the way to a safe future for the entire European continent.''
''In London it was declared that the West extends its hand to the East,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said, in a five-page official statement that treated the NATO meeting as a landmark. ''For our part, we are ready to extend our hand toward them.'' [Excerpts from the statement are on page 5.] 
 
Response to the Hard-Liners
The NATO proposals, which include a joint nonaggression declaration, new restrictions on the deployment and use of nuclear weapons, and a meeting of Mr. Gorbachev with NATO leaders, came as Soviet military officers and civilian hard-liners have tried to make the loss of Eastern Europe an angry theme at the Communist Party's nationwide congress.
''Now we can tell them they are wrong,'' Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, said today, adding, ''This has come at a good time, because he is being criticized.''
Never before has a Soviet leader's foreign policy been the object of such controversy at a congress of his party.
Since the party congress opened on Monday, the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Eastern Europe, unconditional arms cuts and acquiescence in the unification of Germany have been attacked from the podium and in corridor interviews as part of a humiliating retreat.
The criticism has alarmed party liberals, some of whom have responded to the oratory of the generals by raising the specter of a military coup.
There is little evidence that the public is upset about the tumbling of Communist Governments in Eastern Europe by democratic movements. But among the generation that remembers World War II, the loss of Soviet influence and the resurgence of Germany have stirred old fears.
Mr. Shevardnadze has likened the attacks on Mr. Gorbachev's Eastern Europe policy to the period of McCarthyism in the United States in the decade after World War II, when accusations were raised that the Truman Administration had ''lost China'' by allowing the Communists to win the civil war against Chiang Kai-shek.
''Strange as it may seem, we hear similar accusations in this country,'' he said, in a response last week to letters from readers of the Communist Party daily Pravda. ''It seems as if some people here would like to ferret out those who 'lost Eastern Europe.' ''
The latest blast from the military came on Thursday, when Maj. Gen. Ivan Mikulin, a party delegate, accused Soviet diplomats of ''seeing the world through rose-colored glasses'' and of rushing recklessly to withdraw troops from Eastern Europe.
''What can I say to those who ask why we allowed changes in Eastern Europe and agreed to withdraw our troops?'' Mr. Shevardnadze said of such critics. ''They mean to ask why we did not use tanks to 'restore order.' ''
Valentin M. Falin, chief of the international affairs department of the Communist Party Central Committee, tonight dismissed the speeches of the military delegates in a news conference, saying, ''These people have no power.''
But it is striking that top military officials have not taken the podium to defend Mr. Gorbachev and his policies.
Mr. Falin, who tends to strike cautious notes, struck one tonight in talking about the NATO proposals, saying, ''I believe we are speaking about promises by politicians for the future, with no dates attached.''
Mr. Gorbachev, in off-the-cuff comments at the party congress today, said he had not yet received a formal invitation to meet with NATO leaders, ''but I am always ready to go.''
The Foreign Ministry statement praised each of the Western initiatives, and pointed out that many of them had originated as Soviet proposals.
 
Dissolving Western Threat
Mr. Shevardnadze's statement was clearly intended to trumpet the NATO meeting as a triumph for the diplomacy Mr. Gorbachev calls ''new political thinking,'' and to assure the Soviet public that the Western threat is continuing to dissolve.
The Foreign Minister said the Soviets ''attach extremely great importance'' to the NATO statement disavowing aggressive intentions and forswearing the first use of force, and approved of the proposal that NATO and the Warsaw Pact sign a joint declaration on that principle.
''This creates a fundamentally different political climate in Europe and, given its consistent implementation in life, may form a conceptual foundation for a new security system in the continent,'' he said.
Mr. Shevardnadze praised as ''potentially important'' NATO's offer to revise key aspects of the West's military defense, including the doctrine of ''flexible response,'' which reserves the right to make first use of nuclear weapons in some circumstances. The new policy would describe nuclear arms as weapons of last resort.
''The invitation to speak in Brussels at a session of the North Atlantic Council, the proposal to establish diplomatic liaison with NATO and develop contacts in the military field are, in our view, important changes in NATO's stance,'' Mr. Shevardnadze said.
On one issue that has divided the Western alliance, financial aid to repair the Soviet economy, Mr. Falin said that it would be in the interest of the West to integrate the Soviet Union into the Western economy.
''If we want to avoid a split, you need to include the Soviets in the world system,'' he said.

PUB-DATE: July 7, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 4, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1116 words

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
An Alliance for a New Age: Has NATO Donned a Velvet Glove?

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 6

 BODY:
''Spectacular!'' said one of President Bush's aides today as the NATO summit conference ended. ''Got everything we wanted!'' said a second senior adviser.
''Leadership,'' Mr. Bush said jovially to an acquaintance as he left the hall. ''Maybe even vision.''
The American delegation left London tonight delighted that with only modest changes the 15 other members of the Western alliance had followed the script for the transformation of NATO that the President and his aides wrote last month. 
They were convinced that working especially closely with the West Germans, they had sent President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union the right kind of reassuring signals - the kind he had sought in a letter to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain.
But only the Soviet leader can make this meeting the sort of success that all participants proclaimed it to be, because only he can decide whether the package of initiatives approved by the NATO leaders is sufficient to ease the sense of insecurity long felt by the Soviet Union. And only if his answer is ''yes'' is he likely to move soon to eliminate the principal obstacle to the building of the new Europe, his opposition to membership in NATO for a reunified Germany.
 
Good Sounds From Moscow
Moscow's reaction was encouraging, particularly the comment of Gennadi I. Gerasimov, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, who said that the decisions here would make it possible for Mr. Gorbachev to rebut the hard-liners, both military and civilian, who oppose concessions to the West. ''Now we can show them they are wrong,'' Mr. Gerasimov said.
The allies tried hard. They gave Mr. Gorbachev assurances that limits on German troop strength would come sooner rather than later in the conventional arms negotiations in Vienna, a gesture by the Germans meant to allay a major Soviet concern, underlined by the promise of Chancellor Helmut Kohl to discuss the matter with Mr. Gorbachev in Moscow later this month.
They moved toward removal of nuclear artillery shells from Europe, a further step in a process that may lead to the realization of another Gorbachev objective - the denuclearization of Germany - although Mrs. Thatcher strongly opposed that this morning.
And they adopted Mr. Bush's vital bit of diplomatic phraseology, decsribing nuclear weapons ''in the transformed Europe'' as ''truly weapons of the last resort.'' To get that past President Francois Mitterrand and especially Mrs. Thatcher, the United States had to agree to embed the new language in the old context, so Article 18 of the communique says ''there are no circumstances in which nuclear retaliation in response to military action might be discounted.''
 
Other Inducements
There were other sweeteners in the 22-point document, including the expected invitation to the Soviet leader to address NATO, but what was most striking was the tone, which marked a radical change from that of past NATO communiques.
If some of the bureaucratic fudging and straddling of old were still there, the truculence of spirit was gone. In its place there was talk of nonaggression pacts, of overcoming ''the legacy of decades of suspicion,'' of fewer weapons and smaller armies. As intended, it all made NATO sound like a very different animal from the war machine the Soviets have taken it for.
What Moscow may find somewhat less comforting is the lack of detail on a number of matters, such as the future political roles of NATO and the 35-member Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, and the retention in Europe of ''an appropriate mix of conventional and nuclear weapons'' whose only conceivable target for the foreseaable future is the Soviet Union.
Having lost an enemy, NATO is seeking a new role, and it has not yet found it. The search is complicated by the wish to do three things at once: reassure the Russians, avoid sounding so friendly that calls for slashes in military budgets become irresistable, and find a rational underpinning for continued American involvement, both political and military, in Europe.
Even the vocabulary of the alliance needs updating, as leading European commentators have been noting recently. Peter Jenkins of The Independent in London wrote the other day, for example, that what was needed now was not so much ''deterrence'' of a Soviet attack, which is highly improbable, but ''insurance'' against some unforeseeable act of madness. So, Whither NATO? Obviously only a beginning could be made on such things in a bare three sessions at Lancaster House over the last day and a half.
Left all but untouched here was the very basic question of whether NATO is to be a transitional organization, ultimately to be supplanted by a pan-European security organization based on security conference, or whether it will survive, either alongside the security conference or as a unit within it. A corollary question, also pushed aside here, is how the Soviet Union will eventually be tied into whatever structure emerges, so it will be no more of a loose cannon on the deck of Europe than Germany.
''What we must aim for,'' a senior German official said in London this week, ''is a cooperative security structure for western Europe that includes the Soviet Union. We don't want in any way to push them out of things.''
Left for another NATO conference, months or years in the future, was the question of a new generation of tactical air-to-surface missiles, favored by Mrs. Thatcher and by some American planners as a means of carrying nuclear warheads from Western Europe across the newly democratizing countries of central Europe to the Soviet Union. For the moment, talk of ''modernizing'' the nuclear arsenal is badly out of tune with the message of non-aggression.
 
History in the Air
Left to be decided, in part at the summit meeting of the seven most industrialized nations in Houston next week, is the exact shape of a large program of economic support for Mr. Gorbachev, to be provided mainly by West Germany. It seems an inevitable part of the confidence-building program.
Yet history was in the air here, a sense of a new Europe, a place whose ''future belongs to freedom, partnership and openness,'' in the hopeful words of Manfred Worner, the NATO Secretary General.
A little more than 75 years ago in this old capital on the Thames, on Aug. 3, 1914, Sir Edward Grey, the British Foreign Secretary, surveyed the wreckage of his attempts to head off war and said, ''The lamps are going out all over Europe; we shall not see them lit again in our lifetime.''
This week in London, his heirs from the chanceries of the Continent assembled to try to make sure the lights are coming back on for good.

PUB-DATE: July 7, 1990

SECTION: Section 1; Page 5, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 2127 words

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Text of the Declaration After the NATO Talks

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, July 6

 BODY:
Following is the text of the final declaration issued by the NATO summit conference here today:
[1] Europe has entered a new, promising era. Central and Eastern Europe is liberating itself. The Soviet Union has embarked on the long journey toward a free society. The walls that once confined people and ideas are collapsing. Europeans are determining their own destiny. They are choosing freedom. They are choosing economic liberty. They are choosing peace. They are choosing a Europe whole and free. As a consequence, this Alliance must and will adapt.
[2] The North Atlantic Alliance has been the most successful defensive alliance in history. As our Alliance enters its fifth decade and looks ahead to a new century, it must continue to provide for the common defense. This Alliance has done much to bring about the new Europe. No one, however, can be certain of the future. We need to keep standing together, to extend the long peace we have enjoyed these past four decades. 
Yet our Alliance must be even more an agent of change. It can help build the structures of a more united continent, supporting security and stability with the strength of our shared faith in democracy, the rights of the individual, and the peaceful resolution of disputes. We reaffirm that security and stability do not lie solely in the military dimension, and we intend to enhance the political component of our Alliance as provided for by Article 2 of our Treaty.
[3] The unification of Germany means that the division of Europe is also being overcome. A united Germany in the Atlantic Alliance of free democracies and part of the growing political and economic integration of the European Community will be an indispensable factor of stability, which is needed in the heart of Europe. The move within the European Community toward political union, including the development of a European identity in the domain of security, will also contribute to Atlantic solidarity and to the establishment of a just and lasting order of peace throughout the whole of Europe.
[4] We recognize that, in the new Europe, the security of every state is inseparably linked to the security of its neighbors. NATO must become an institution where Europeans, Canadians and Americans work together not only for the common defense, but to build new partnerships with all the nations of Europe. The Atlantic Community must reach out to the countries of the East which were our adversaries in the cold war, and extend to them the hand of friendship.
[5] We will remain a defensive alliance and will continue to defend all the territory of all of our members. We have no aggressive intentions and we commit ourselves to the peaceful resolution of all disputes. We will never in any circumstance be the first to use force.
[6] The member states of the North Atlantic Alliance propose to the member states of the Warsaw Treaty Organization a joint declaration in which we solemnly state that we are no longer adversaries and reaffirm our intention to refrain from the threat or use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any state, or from acting in any other manner inconsistent with the purposes and principles of the United Nations Charter and with the C.S.C.E. Final Act. We invite all other C.S.C.E. member states to join us in this commitment to non-aggression.
[7] In that spirit, and to reflect the changing political role of the Alliance, we today invite President Gorbachev on behalf of the Soviet Union, and representatives of the other Central and Eastern European countries, to come to Brussels and address the North Atlantic Council.
We today also invite the Governments of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the Czech and Slovak Federal Republic, the Hungarian Republic, the Republic of Poland, the People's Republic of Bulgaria and Romania to come to NATO, not just to visit, but to establish regular diplomatic liaison with NATO. This will make it possible for us to share with them our thinking and deliberations in this historic period of change.
[8] Our alliance will do its share to overcome the legacy of decades of suspicion. We are ready to intensify military contacts, including those of NATO Military Commanders, with Moscow and other Central and Eastern European capitals.
[9] We welcome the invitation to NATO Secretary General Manfred Worner to visit Moscow and meet with Soviet leaders.
[10] Military leaders from throughout Europe gathered earlier this year in Vienna to talk about their forces and doctrine. NATO proposes another such meeting this autumn to promote common understanding. Wrole of the intend to establish an entirely different quality of openness in Europe, including an agreement on ''open skies.''
[11] The significant presence of North American conventional and U.S. nuclear forces in Europe demonstrates the underlying political compact that binds North America's fate to Europe's democracies. But, as Europe changes, we must profoundly alter the way we think about defense.
[12] To reduce our military requirements, sound arms control agreements are essential. That is why we put the highest priority on completing this year the first treaty to reduce and limit conventional armed forces in Europe along with the completion of a meaningful C.S.B.M. [confidence and security building measures] package. These talks should remain in continuous session until the work is done. Yet we hope to go further. We propose that, once a C.F.E. Treaty is signed, follow-on talks should begin with the same membership and mandate, with the goal of building on the current agreement with additional measures, including measures to limit manpower in Europe. With this goal in mind, a commitment will be given at the time of signature of the C.F.E. Treaty concerning the manpower levels of a unified Germany.
[13] Our objective will be to conclude the negotiations on the follow-on to C.F.E. and C.S.B.M.'s as soon as possible and looking to the follow-up meeting of the C.S.C.E. to be held in Helsinki in 1992. We will seek through new conventional arms control negotiations, within the C.S.C.E. framework, further far-reaching measures in the 1990's to limit the offensive capability of conventional armed forces in Europe, so as to prevent any nation from maintaining disproportionate military power on the continent. NATO's High Level Task Force will formulate a detailed position for these follow-on conventional arms control talks. We will make provisions as needed for different regions to redress disparities and to ensure that no one's security is harmed at any stage. Furthermore, we will explore broader arms control and confidence-building opportunities. This is an ambitious agenda, but it matches our goal: enduring peace in Europe.
[14] As Soviet troops leave Eastern Europe and a treaty limiting conventional armed forces is implemented, the Alliance's integrated force structure and its strategy will change fundamentally to include the following elements:
* NATO will field smaller and restructured active forces. These forces will be highly mobile and versatile so that Allied leaders will have maximum flexibility in deciding how to respond to a crisis. It will rely increasingly on multinational corps made up of national units.
* NATO will scale back the readiness of its active unitsreducing training requirements and the number of exercises.
* NATO will rely more heavily on the ability to build up larger forces if and when they might be needed.
[15] To keep the peace, the Alliance must maintain for the foreseeable future an appropriate mix of nuclear and conventional forces, based in Europe, and kept up to date where necessary. But, as a defensive Alliance, NATO has always stressed that none of its weapons will ever be used except in self-defense and that we seek the lowest and most stable level of nuclear forces needed to secure the prevention of war.
[16] The political and military changes in Europe, and the prospects of further changes, now allow the Allies concerned to go further. They will thus modify the size and adapt the tasks of their nuclear deterrent forces. They have concluded that, as a result of the new political and military conditions in Europe, there will be a significantly reduced role for sub-strategic nuclear systems of the shortest range. They have decided specifically that, once negotiations begin on short-range nuclear forces, the Alliance will propose, in return for reciprocal action by the Soviet Union, the elimination of all its nuclear artillery shells from Europe.
[17] New negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union on the reduction of short-range nuclear forces should begin shortly after a C.F.E. agreement is signed. The Allies concerned will develop an arms control framework for these negotiations which takes into account our requirements for far fewer nuclear weapons, and the diminished need for sub-strategic nuclear systems of the shortest range.
[18] Finally, with the total withdrawal of Soviet stationed forces and the implementation of a C.F.E. agreement, the Allies concerned can reduce their reliance on nuclear weapons. These will continue to fulfill an essential role in the overall strategy of the Alliance to prevent war by ensuring that there are no circumstances in which nuclear retaliation in response to military action might be discounted. However, in the transformed Europe, they will be able to adopt a new NATO strategy making nuclear forces truly weapons of last resort.
[19] We approve the mandate given in Turnberry to the North Atlantic Council in Permanent Session to oversee the ongoing work on the adaptation of the Alliance to the new circumstances. It should report its conclusions as soon as possible.
[20] In the context of these revised plans for defense and arms control, and with the advice of NATO Military Authorities and all member states concerned, NATO will prepare a new Allied military strategy moving way from ''forward defense,'' where appropriate, towards a reduced forward presence and modifying ''flexible response'' to reflect a reduced reliance on nuclear weapons. In that connection, NATO will elaborate new force plans consistent with the revolutionary changes in Europe. NATO will also provide a forum for Allied consultation on the upcoming negotiations on short-range nuclear forces.
[21] The Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe should become more prominent in Europe's future, bringing together the countries of Europe and North America. We support a C.S.C.E. Summit later this year in Paris which would include the signature of a C.F.E. agreement and would set new standards for the establishment, and preservation, of free societies. It should endorse, inter alia:
* C.S.C.E. principles on the right to free and fair elections;
* C.S.C.E. commitments to respect and uphold the rule of law;
* C.S.C.E. guidelines for enhancing economic cooperation, based on the development of free and competitive market economies; and
* C.S.C.E. cooperation on environmental protection.
[22] We further propose that the C.S.C.E. Summit in Paris decide how the C.S.C.E. can be institutionalized to provide a forum for wider political dialogue in a more united Europe. We recommend that C.S.C.E. governments establish:
* A program for regular consultations among member governments at the Heads of State and Government or Ministerial level, at least once each year, with other periodic meetings of officials to prepare for and follow up on these consultations;
* A schedule of C.S.C.E. review conferences once every two years to assess progress toward a Europe whole and free;
* A small C.S.C.E. secretariat to coordinate these meetings and conferences;
* A C.S.C.E. mechanism to monitor elections in all the C.S.C.E. countries, on the basis of the Copenhagen Document;
* A C.S.C.E. Center for the Prevention of Conflict that might serve as a forum for exchanges of military information, discussion of unusual military activities, and the conciliation of disputes involving C.S.C.E. member states; and
* A C.S.C.E. parliamentary body, the Assembly of Europe, to be based on the existing parliamentary assembly of the Council of Europe, in Strasbourg, and include representatives of all C.S.C.E. member states.
The sites of these new institutions should reflect the fact that the newly democratic countries of Central and Eastern Europe form part of the political structures of the new Europe.
[23] Today, our Alliance begins a major transformation. Working with all the countries of Europe, we are determined to create enduring peace on this continent.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher taking questions at the session in London yesterday; Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany making a point at the NATO meeting's final news conference. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Slides Again; Hope for Easier Credit Dims

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
In a report that further reduced hope for early Government action to lower interest rates, the Labor Department said today that the unemployment rate edged down another notch in June, to 5.2 percent, and that the number of new jobs rose to a higher level than most analysts expected.
Both figures showed growth to remain well short of robust. But when combined with the most striking element of the report, a very large upward revision in jobs for May as determined by the department's survey of business payrolls, the general reaction was that the Federal Reserve Board would find nothing to compel a prompt cut in interest rates to spur economic growth, as the Bush Administration has increasingly been urging.
For May, the increase in jobs, which includes temporary census workers, is now put at 356,000 instead of the 164,000 reported five weeks ago. Combined with an additional job increase in June and the second straight monthly decline of one-tenth of a point in the civilian employment rate, as measured by a separate survey of households, the data suggested an economy that is in no imminent danger of sliding into recession. 
Most analysts predict that the gross national product will rise by less than 2 percent in the second half of the year.
The number of people employed is growing very slowly not only because the economy is sluggish, but also for demographic reasons. This tight labor market makes it relatively easy to keep the jobless rate from rising, but is an obstacle to an easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
''It's pretty tough to ease into a 5.2 percent unemployment rate,'' said Alan C. Lerner, an economist for the Bankers Trust Company.
Another factor is a new-found steadiness in the industrial sector, where output continues to advance despite a continued loss of factory jobs.
Economists also noted that the number of hours worked rose in June for the second straight month. That was partly the result of a longer factory work week, an increase largely sustained in June after a jump in May.
Mindful of the sharp increase in fringe-benefit costs and upcoming labor negotiations in the auto industry and possibly concerned that military and other orders may be withdrawn, many employers are inclined to work existing employees overtime rather than hire new ones.
 
Signs of Weakness
But today's report also had evidence of weakness in the economy. The quarterly tabulation of unemployed workers who have given up looking for a job because they think they will not find one jumped nearly 20 percent in the April-June period, to 893,000, the highest level since the end of 1988.
''Certainly, this number bears watching,'' said the Commission of Labor Statistics, Dr. Janet L. Norwood.
There was also a sharp decline in the index that shows the percentage of industries adding workers as against shedding them. At 46.8 percent, down from 54.3 percent in May, the figure for industries adding workers was the lowest since late 1982.
''It's a very mixed bag of numbers'' said Joseph A. Wahed, chief economist for the Wells Fargo Bank. ''The economy's pockmarked and moving in fits and starts.''
But what was very clear was that growth in employment has slowed dramatically in the past 18 months. In the first half of this year, jobs in the private sector expanded by an average of only 110,000 a month, down from 135,000 a month in the second half of last year and from 220,000 a month in the first half.
The levels of new jobs in May and June were in line with the 1990 trend, but it was obscured by the hiring and laying off of temporary census workers. The increase in jobs last month was 40,000 after the subtraction of 57,000 census takers. In May, 200,000 census workers were hired, the department reported today, up from the initial estimate of 145,000.
Dr. Norwood said she was ''very unhappy'' that the May revision was so large but that it did not fundamentally alter the view that economic growth, though a bit stronger than had been thought, is ''still very slow.''
Manufacturing lost another 31,000 jobs last month, with small declines spread among several durable-goods industries and in food-processing and apparel. Some 335,000 factory jobs have been lost since March 1989. Jobs in construction fell for in June for the fourth straight month, to the same level as a year ago. In services, the health industry was the only big gainer, adding 40,000 workers.
There was no significant change in unemployment among major population groups. The rate for teen-agers eased to 14.1 percent from 15.5, as their entry into the summer work force was less than in the recent past.
The jobless rates for New York and New Jersey were unchanged at 5.1 percent and 4.8 percent, respectively.
As measured by the survey of households, 118,389,000 Americans had jobs last month out of a total labor force of 124,836,000. It was an increase of 39,000 from May. Combined with a decline of 168,000 in the labor force, that meant the number of unemployed Americans fell to 6,447,000.
The overall unemployment rate, which includes 1,630,000 military personnel stationed in the United States, declined two-tenths of 1 percent in June to 5.1 percent.

HEADLINE: In Texas City, Newcomer Brings Abortion Turmoil

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., July 3

 BODY:
Until recently, Corpus Christi was like most other cities when it came to the subject of abortion. There were strong feelings on both sides, but other questions, like whether to increase property taxes, seemed more urgent.
Then an anti-abortion crusader named Rex Moses came to town, saying he was called here by God because Corpus Christi means ''the Body of Christ'' in Latin.
It has been nine months since Mr. Moses arrived. The Roman Catholic Bishop has excommunicated at least two employees of local abortion clinics. The sheriff has hung posters of aborted fetuses in county offices. The City Council has been forced by petition to consider an amendment to the city charter saying that life begins at conception. A local doctor testified in court that his children fear protesters will burn their house down because their father performs abortions. And the local newspaper's opinion pages have been filled with heated reaction. 
 
'A Surfer on a Surfboard'
Groups on both sides say the catalyst for all this was the magnetic and intense Mr. Moses, although he says it is not so. ''It was going to happen anyway,'' he said. ''I'm like a surfer on a surfboard. I watched the wave as it was about to break and paddled fast enough to get on top of it.''
But the speed with which this issue exploded in Corpus Christi shows how close to the surface emotions run on the abortion issue and how little it takes to ignite them. ''This could happen in any city starting tomorrow,'' Mr. Moses said. ''Today it's happening here.''
Corpus Christi is a city of 275,000 people on the Gulf coast with an economy that revolves around the oil industry, shrimping, agriculture and ranching. It has nearly a dozen long-established anti-abortion groups, about as many groups that advocate abortion rights, and two clinics that perform the procedure.
The directors of the clinics have always been open about their jobs. Rachel Vargas, one of those excommunicated by the Bishop, has been the director of the Reproductive Services Inc. for eight years. Elva Bustamante, who has received two warning letters from the Bishop about possible excommunication, has been the director of the New Woman's Clinic for 12 years.
 
Moses Changed the Protests
The two women said in recent interviews that there had been protests at the clinics throughout their tenures, but the protesters kept away from the front door and did not approach anyone entering the building.
All that, they said, changed last fall, when Mr. Moses moved to Corpus Christi from Austin, where he had been organizing what he called ''rescues'' at abortion clinics for more than a year.
Mr. Moses, who is 35 years old, had become well known in Austin. Until 1988, he ran a consulting company there, specializing in managing retirement plans, and his income for that year was $218,932, The Austin American-Statesman newspaper said was shown by his tax returns, which Mr. Moses confirmed. He said he had always opposed abortion, and then he read about Operation Rescue in Atlanta, where protesters lay in front of abortion clinics to keep women from entering.
''I decided I couldn't live with the legacy I was leaving,'' he said of his four children. ''I couldn't keep living the most convenient life you can imagine, going to work and knowing that babies were being killed two miles away.''
Late that year, Mr. Moses said, he sold most of his interest in his company to his partner for $1. He gave away everything he owned, ''except for my house, a three-year-old truck and an eight-year-old car,'' then used his savings to charter several buses to drive Austin residents to Atlanta to participate in the protests.
Soon Mr. Moses was coordinating similar protests in Austin. At first, he said, he had the full support of local church leaders, but he said they backed away from him when the arrests began. From October 1988 to November 1989, 600 criminal trespass complaints were lodged against abortion protesters in Austin.
 
He Served Two Jail Terms
Mr. Moses has served two 30-day sentences on a contempt charge and is appealing an 18-month sentence for criminal trespass. He has also lost two civil lawsuits. The first, filed by the Ladies Center, an Austin clinic, resulted in a $587,000 jury award. The second, filed by a police officer who was injured while trying to lift a 300-pound protester into a police wagon, resulted in a $750,000 verdict from a judge. Neither fine has been paid. ''I would die before I would pay them a cent,'' he said.
Mr. Moses's tactics in some ways echo those of Randall Terry, the founder of Operation Rescue, whom Mr. Moses met with extensively in Atlanta two years ago and later in Texas. Mr. Terry said in a telephone interview that there might be more than 100 Americans who have given up their jobs and most of their possessions to fight abortion.
Mr. Moses said he no longer had any assets to seize, except his unoccupied Austin house, which is protected from creditors by Texas law. He said he had no income and was living off the donations that supporters make to his cause. He said he has not paid rent on the duplex he rents in Corpus Christi since February, explaining that the owner of the house was ''very sympathetic and patient.'' His family often eats food dropped off by strangers, he said.
He said he considered the lawsuits and jail time a necessary sacrifice, but was not willing to stay in Austin without the full support of the local churches. He began looking for a new city where he could lead his protests. From Corpus Christi originally, he said he came here for a visit last fall and was introduced briefly to Bishop Rene H. Gracida.
The Bishop has a reputation for outspokenness, and in a city where 55 percent of the residents are Catholic, his views are heard widely. In January 1989, he was among the first of many religious leaders in the country to call for a boycott of all products of the Pepsi-Cola Company because the company's advertising used a video by Madonna that the Bishop considered sacrilegious. Pepsi eventually withdrew the ads and canceled its contract with the singer.
 
'Where God Wanted Me'
Mr. Moses said his first meeting with Bishop Gracida was short but warm. That reception, among other things, including the city's very name, he said, convinced him that Corpus Christi ''is where God wanted me to be.'' He named his group the Body of Christ Rescue.
From the first protest coordinated by that group, it was obvious that Mr. Moses would face fewer impediments in Corpus Christi than he had in Austin. More than 250 people protested. There were 12 arrests but no one was charged with a crime. In the nine anti-abortion protests held over the last nine months, there have been a total of 16 arrests and one jail sentence of 30 days.
Shortly after the first protest, Mr. Moses met James T. Hickey, the sheriff of Nueces County, which includes Corpus Christi. An avuncular man, Sheriff Hickey says he has always been against abortion, but had not acted publicly on his beliefs.
The two men became friends, and in January Mr. Moses showed Sheriff Hickey a photograph of a 6-month-old fetus that had been aborted.
In an interview in his office, Sheriff Hickey recalled: ''He said, 'Sheriff, what are we going to do with this?' I said I would like to make it into a poster and hang it around the department so people can see what abortion really is.''
He did, bringing immediate questions from local news organizations.
In an interview with The Corpus Christi Caller-Times about whether displaying such posters were appropriate for an elected law-enforcement official, the sheriff was asked what he would do if called on to arrest abortion protesters who trespassed.
''I would feel like I was a party to the killing of babies,'' he said. ''I would be aiding and abetting murder. That is something I would not do. And nobody in my departnment is going to take any action without my order.''
The question is moot, since the city police, and not the county sheriff, have primary jurisdiction over the areas where the abortion clinics are situated. But the sheriff's answer brought strong reaction from the community. A Caller-Times poll found that although opinion was evenly divided on whether abortion should be legal, a majority disapproved of Sheriff Hickey's actions and statements. Nearly half opposed his position that he would refuse to arrest protesters and 66 percent said they do not believe a public official's personal beliefs should affect his public duty.
 
Sheriff Is Now Spokesman
The controversy made Sheriff Hickey an instant spokesman for the anti-abortion movement here. He is regularly seen, out of uniform, praying at anti-abortion rallies. Members of one anti-abortion group purchased space on 10 billboards around the city that quote the sheriff's statement, ''My first duty is to God.''
Bishop Gracida praised the sheriff publicly for his ''courageous and unequivocal statements regarding the nature of abortion.''
The Bishop is currently on his yearly vacation; no one reached at the diocese would speak for him.
While the personal pain of Sheriff Hickey and Mr. Moses were creating public controversy, that controversy was in turn causing personal pain for others. From January to June, the Bishop sent a series of letters to Mrs. Bustamante, Ms. Vargas and Dr. Eduardo Aquino, who performs abortions two days a week at the clinic where Mrs. Bustamante works.
The first letters explained that by working in an abortion clinic, the recipients were excommunicating themselves. The Bishop urged them to stop and gave them 30 days to reply. A second letter, received about three months after the first, was shorter and more forceful. Ms. Vargas and Dr. Aquino have since received letters of formal excommunication.
Dr. Aquino kept the letters to himself for a long time. He was battling Mr. Moses in court, trying to end the daily picketing that Mr. Moses was leading in front of the Aquino home. Dr. Aquino , is on vacation in Argentina, his native land, and could not be reached, his office said.
 
Doctor Wins a Settlement
In April Dr. Aquino was granted a temporary restraining order against the picketers after testifying that his children could not sleep for fear that the protesters would burn down the house. Later, Dr. Aquino won an $800,000 settlment for harassment against the anti-abortion group South Texas for Life. That award has been appealed but the pickets are no longer at Dr. Aquino's house.
Late last month, Ms. Vargas made her letters public, and Dr. Aquino and Mrs. Bustamante soon followed. The two women say they did not come easily to their views in support of abortion rights, but believe that they are not inconsistent with being Catholic.
''I know that if these abortions were not performed that eventually there would be a child,'' said Mrs. Bustamante, who has three children, one grandchild and five foster children. ''I wish with all my heart that every child that was conceived was a wanted child and wouldn't become battered or abused or ignored. But I don't think I have the right to tell anyone they have to become a parent.''
The three recipients of the letters say the Bishop's actions are political and point to the petition drive asking the Corpus Christi City Council to vote on a ''human life amendment'' that says life begins at conception. Twice the needed number of signatures have been gathered.
''The timing isn't coincidental,'' Ms. Vargas said.
Mr. Moses disagrees. ''This isn't politics,'' he said. ''This is divine intervention.''

HEADLINE: Louisiana Bill Would Require Warnings on Recordings

BYLINE: By JON PARELES

 BODY:
The first bill in the United States requiring warning labels on record albums with potentially offensive lyrics was passed last night by the Louisiana State Senate by a vote of 29 to 9. The bill, an amended version of legislation approved by the state's House of Representatives on May 10, requires warning labels on recordings with themes of rape, murder, suicide, illegal drug use, child abuse or satanic worship.
 
Another Look by House
To become law, the bill must be signed by Louisiana's Governor, Buddy Roemer, who has said he needs to examine it more closely and consider its financial impact on the state. It must first be sent back to the House for approval of Senate amendments. 
The bill originally made retailers responsible for labeling records, tapes and compact disks, and subjected them to felony charges for selling such recordings to minors. It was amended to make the recording industry responsible for labeling; selling such recordings to minors was reduced to the status of a misdemeanor.
The bill was passed despite warnings of legal problems and potential economic losses for the state.
''We pass bills all the time to have clean air, clean water,'' said State Senator Oswald Decuir, who presented the bill to the Senate. ''Why can't we do something to clean up the environment for children?''
Similar bills had been proposed in a dozen other states, but most that had not been defeated were withdrawn when the member companies of the Recording Industry Association of America, the trade group that includes the major companies, agreed to voluntarily place a warning sticker reading ''Parental Advisory - Explicit Lyrics'' on certain albums.
Record-labeling bills are pending in New York and New Jersey and in the Pennsylvania Senate, where the House of Representatives passed a labeling bill in December 1989.
The Louisiana bill has provoked strong concern inside and outside the recording business. A Louisiana state attorney, Charles T. Yeager, submitted a memorandum to a state representative advising that the bill was an unconstitutional attempt to regulate protected speech. Morality in Media, an anti-pornography group, has also worked against the bill, saying that it is overly broad. The Parents' Music Resource Center, which raised the outcry over controversial messages in pop lyrics, said it has never supported such legislation.
The merchandisers' association and the National Association of Independent Recording Distributors and Manufacturers had each planned to hold conventions in New Orleans, but said they would meet elsewhere if the bill becomes law.
The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, which presents the Grammy Awards each year, said it would eliminate New Orleans as the possible site of a Grammy museum if the bill becomes law.
Louisiana's recording industry, which had been growing slowly during the 1980's, is likely to be hurt by the legislation. ''The music business had really started to gain momentum, with all kinds of little private ventures going on,'' said Jan Ramsey, publisher of the Louisiana music magazine Offbeat. ''Then we have this stupidity, which is going to throw cold water on the whole business.''
Several organizations said they planned court challenges on First Amendment grounds if the bill is passed; they include People for the American Way, the liberal lobbying group; the Recording Industry Association of America, and the Pittsburgh-based National Association of Recordings Merchandisers, the record retailers' group.
 
'A Chilling Effect'
''The Supreme Court has clearly said you don't have to prohibit sales to be in violation of the First Amendment,'' said Deanna Duby, senior attorney for People for the American Way. ''Record dealers, rather than risk being in violation of the law, will refuse to carry certain records, certain types of music and certain artists. That would be a chilling effect.''
Last month, two members of the Miami-based rap group 2 Live Crew were arrested in Florida after they played songs from their sexually explicit album ''As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' at an all-adult show. A Florida record-store owner who sold the album was also arrested.
The arrests followed a Federal judge's ruling that the album violates Florida's obscenity law. The ruling is being appealed.

HEADLINE: Victory With Vision in Europe

 BODY:
After World War I, the victors carved Europe into unstable pieces and imposed a peace that scarred winners and losers alike. Germany was truncated geographically, and doomed to poverty by reparations.
After World War II the victorious allies divided Germany, the Continent and their minds, triggering 45 years of cold war. The Soviet Union grabbed the eastern half of Europe; Britain, France and the United States created the NATO military alliance and a framework of economic cooperation. 
Yesterday in London the heads of NATO, led by President Bush, began bringing the curtain down on the cold war. They fashioned a peace with vision, one that will open the door to a democratic and reunited Germany, one that reaches out to a dangerously wobbling Soviet Union, one that promises a whole Europe from the Atlantic to the Urals and the Baltic to the Adriatic.
The key to this vision is not to make the loser of the cold war, the Soviet Union, into a sore loser. The idea is to reassure Moscow, and thereby create a partner that can complete arms reduction treaties, agree to making Germany whole and participate in a more secure Europe.
Moscow's military leaders are plainly unhappy about the collapse of their position in Eastern and Central Europe. And there's evidence that they've caused Mikhail Gorbachev to drag his feet in arms talks. The London communique might help break deadlocks on negotiations to reduce forces in Europe and cut strategic arms. NATO's decision to adopt Mr. Bush's call to use nuclear weapons only as ''a last resort'' is likely to speed this process. To be sure, NATO will keep the option of employing these devices first and early. But the ''last resort'' proposal signals a declining reliance on nuclear threats, and sends a reassuring message to Europe as well as to the Soviet Union.
Moscow has moved ever closer to accepting the idea of a united Germany in NATO. Yet it's understandably concerned that the West, with its newfound strength, will isolate it.
The communique does much to alleviate that concern. NATO leaders invite Mr. Gorbachev to address the alliance, and Warsaw Pact countries to apply for observer status. Soviet leaders responded to the offers enthusiastically. These moves underline NATO's resolve to transform itself from a military into a political alliance that will not ignite historical Russian paranoia.
NATO also has sensibly taken care to keep itself intact. Changes in the Soviet Union look irreversible, but hard-liners could make a comeback. Moscow pledges to reduce forces, but that process is only beginning.
Above all, alliance leaders proved in London that they are prepared to go beyond NATO. Their proposals to expand the purview of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe point toward a Europe-wide security system. This larger vision inspires the realistic hope that this time, Europe could become whole and at peace.

HEADLINE: Peru: No Vietnam in the Andes

 BODY:
President Bush's offer of military aid for Peru's antidrug campaign raises fears that he'll involve the U.S. in another Vietnam. Those fears are unwarranted. A tough military strategy in the Andes, coupled with substantial development aid, is essential to antidrug policy. 
The Administration sent increased aid to Colombia last summer, after the Colombians began an aggressive campaign against drug traffickers. In January Mr. Bush met with the Presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia to discuss a wider program. Funds are flowing to Colombia and Bolivia, but Peru remains on hold as its President-elect, Alberto Fujimori, ponders the issue.
Framing U.S. policy is especially difficult in Peru because of a vicious guerrilla group, Sendero Luminoso, or Shining Path. It has flourished inland, gaining ground while the national Government is beset by severe economic problems.
These guerrillas are violent terrorists. But that by itself does not justify sending U.S. military advisers into the middle of an apparent civil war. What justifies the military aid is the Shining Path's heavy involvement in sustaining coca production. It thereby presents a clear threat to the United States.
So why the anxiety about fighting these guerrillas - especially since the aid would consist only of equipment and training? No one proposes to involve U.S. troops in combat. Some worry that if U.S. advisers are wounded or killed, the Administration would face irresistible pressures to escalate. Others fear the aid would give too much political power to the Peruvian military. Mr. Fujimori's effectiveness remains unknown. Why take even a small chance?
Because common sense suggests it's a reasonable risk. Drug enforcement agents have already suffered casualties in the Andes and elsewhere without provoking military intervention. And the $35 million President Bush wants this year would finance neither a dramatic U.S. escalation nor a major expansion of the Peruvian Army.
Mr. Bush's plan is also challenged by drug policy experts who argue that it's hopeless to attack a single country or regional source of supply, since other suppliers soon might enter the picture. The experience of recent months suggests otherwise. The Colombian campaign apparently disrupted trafficking enough to puncture the market for raw coca leaves in Bolivia. Thousands of growers began seeking help to plant other crops.
And drug enforcement officials now begin to detect the effects of reduced supply on the U.S. market. Prices of cocaine products are rising and purity is falling. Apparently it is not so easy for traffickers to adjust.
The progress in Colombia and Bolivia exceeds anything even the most hawkish drug warriors might have predicted only months ago. It vindicates the limited help Mr. Bush offers Peru, and the limited risk.

HEADLINE: Sharper Data for Rent Guidelines

 BODY:
New York City's rent control laws force landlords, tenants and bureaucrats into periodic confrontations: how much rent is fair for what kind of housing? A recent tax law creates a new, solid basis for such discussions - one that turns out to support the landlords' position.
Apartment house owners believe that operating costs ought to consume no more than 50 percent of the rent dollar, leaving the balance to cover the costs of mortgage debt and a return on the owner's equity investment.
In setting fair rent levels, city officials have in the past relied on theoretical ''baskets'' and other models prepared by economists. Thus in May, the city Rent Guidelines Board referred to an estimate of the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal that placed operating and maintenance costs of stabilized apartments between 52 and 56 percent of legal maximum rent. On that basis, the board proposed an increase of 3 percent in rents on one-year leases. 
But now, with the board preparing to make a final ruling on next year's rents, there is a better data base. A new law requires owners of income-producing properties to submit statements of revenues and operating costs to tax officials who are preparing new assessed valuations.
These tax returns, which only recently became available, show that operations and maintenance expenditures - including real property taxes, fuel, electricity, labor and repairs - consume an average of 65 cents of every rent dollar actually collected in stabilized buildings.
To be sure, landlords seeking to minimize tax liability have an incentive to maximize costs on tax returns. But the law requires accuracy, and city officials accept the returns as consistent with reasonable estimates of operating costs.
Does the tax-return figure of 65 percent justify a rent increase of more than 3 percent? That is up to the Guidelines Board to decide. But better information can't hurt. It will help the board reach a fair conclusion, and help the public understand how fair the board has tried to be.

HEADLINE: Behind Japan's Birth-Rate Furor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It was most unfortunate that ''Tokyo Official Ties Birth Decline to Education'' (news article, June 14) conveyed a misinterpretation of my statements on the effect of higher education in Japan on the labor market. The article was based on a Japanese newspaper report that misinterpreted a statement I made at a ministerial meeting June 12 on the effect of the aging of Japanese society.
Reportedly, my statement at the meeting was that ''The reason for an alarming decline in Japan's birth rate is the Government's policy of encouraging women to obtain higher education.'' 
What I did say was that the ministries of education and labor should initiate a comprehensive study on the relationship between higher education and its impact on employment.
Naturally, the report stirred fury among Japanese women. Even before I read the newspaper, I received phone calls of protest at home early in the morning. I am deeply concerned that inaccurate reporting in the foreign press could not only hurt me and the Japanese people, but mislead foreign readers as well.
To explain: The Japanese birth rate, that is, the average number of children a woman is expected to have in her life, dropped from 2.14 in 1965 to 1.81 in 1984 and to 1.57 in 1989. The comparable figure in the United States has not shown significant movement and was 1.87 in 1987. The Japanese decline is usually explained by a change in attitude to marriage; the physical, psychological and economic cost of raising children, and the housing problem.
The decline in the birth rate, together with the lengthening of life expectancy, has brought about a rapid aging of Japanese society, creating major challenges for our social security system as well as for the future course of our Government's fiscal position, with which I am deeply involved.
In view of the decline in the birth rate and the acute labor shortage in Japan - as well as the increase in the ratio of people seeking higher education regardless of their sex - I stated my belief that it was time for the Government, especially the ministries of education and labor, to review higher education policies.
I would add that my wife, Kumiko, is a college graduate and that we are happy with our five children, two boys and three girls, from a daughter who just graduated from college to the youngest, who is in the second grade.
 
RYUTARO HASHIMOTO
Minister of Finance of Japan
 Tokyo, June 16, 1990
