HEADLINE: Parents Are Suing Parents In Long Island Murder Case

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MINEOLA, L.I., July 6

 BODY:
Three months after Robert Golub was convicted of the murder of Kelly Ann Tinyes in Valley Stream, her parents have sued his parents, contending that Mr. and Mrs. Golub bear partial responsibility for the girl's death because they had failed to supervise their son properly.
The suit also contends that Robert's younger brother, John, 14 years old, was involved in the murder, even though he was not charged.
The lawyer representing the Tinyes family, James T. Gucciardo, said of the Golub parents, ''They knew about Robert's psychiatric problems and they knew about his drug use, and they have a responsibility for the conditions in that house.''
In March 1989, Kelly's naked body, beaten and strangled, was found in a closet in the Golubs' basement. Weeks later, Robert Golub, then 21, was arrested and charged in her death. Robert, who told investigators that he had used steroids and other drugs but never discussed his psychiatric history, was convicted of second-degree murder in April. He has appealed the conviction and is serving a 25-year-to-life sentence in the Fishkill state prison. 
The father, John A. Golub, told Newsday on Thursday that the allegations were ridiculous. Robert Golub's lawyer, Salvatore Marinello, did not return calls.
 
Difficulties in Proof
Legal scholars said the contention that parents were liable for their children's criminal behavior was not new. In the case of Laurie W. Dann, 30, who shot six second graders in 1988 in Winnetka, Ill., killing one, the parents of the slain child have sued Miss Dann's parents. The victim's parents contend that the parents of Miss Dann, who killed herself after the attack, should have known that their daughter had severe mental problems.
Victor E. Schwartz, a partner in the law firm of Crowell & Moring of Washington and a co-author of a widely used casebook on tort law, said that in most similar cases the criminal children were younger and their crimes less serious than murder. Mr. Schwartz said such cases were difficult to win because it was difficult to prove what the parents could have done to prevent their child's behavior.
''It's hard for the plaintiff to establish a viable theory under which the jury is convinced that the parents could have done something to stop the child,'' he said.
Mr. Golub's age makes the case more difficult, he said, adding, ''It's going to be difficult to get a jury to accept the idea that a parent of a 20- or 21-year-old could in fact stop their child from using steroids or using drugs, because of the compulsive nature of the behavior.''
 
Instances of Discipline
Mr. Golub was living at home. A loner whose hobby was bodybuilding, he had worked at odd jobs over the years, but was unemployed and dependent on his parents at the time of the murder. At the trial, the prosecution used photographs and descriptions of the rubble-filled basement and unkempt house to show that the parents were poor housekeepers and inattentive.
The father testified that Robert had sometimes misbehaved and been disciplined. Once, the father removed the door from Robert's room, so Robert could have no privacy.
In a telephone interview today Mr. Tinyes said that he hoped that the suit would provide answers to questions still surrounding the murder. Since Robert's arrest, the Tinyeses say, they have suspected that the brother, John, an acquaintance of Kelly, 13, from school and the neighborhood, had something to do with the murder. John was not called to the stand.
He will have to answer questions in the civil case, Mr. Gucciardo said.
 
'The Evidence Was Destroyed'
''John J. didn't murder Kelly, but everyone feels that there was some role John J. played,'' said Mr. Tinyes, who owns an automobile-collision shop. ''But there was a massive cleanup in the basement, and the evidence was destroyed.''
In their suit, the Tinyeses say they are seeking $100 million in damages for the death, $100 million because Mr. and Mrs. Golub ''failed to supervise the activities at the residence,'' $200 million on the ground that his parents knew or should have known that Robert was vicious and mentally incompetent, $100 million on the ground that the younger brother aided in the murder, $100 million on the ground that the parents knew or should have known that their sons were using drugs and alcohol at home and $2 million because the Golub family ''concealed, hindered and/or obstructed the discovery'' of the body.
Such suits are important to victims' families, because they help them control a situation, unlike in a criminal trial, said Dennis Holland, co-chairman of Justice for All, a victims' rights group. This year Jack Henry Abbott, convicted of killing an aspiring actor in 1981, was ordered to pay $7.57 million in damages to the victim's family.
''In a criminal proceeding the victim's family has no say,'' Mr. Holland said. ''In this situation the family has the right to obtain their own attorney, and they can call the shots.''
Mr. Tinyes said his family was still bitter and angry at the Golubs, who still live down the street. ''But,'' he added, ''we can't put a price on what we've lost and we can't get our daughter back.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JULY 7, 1990

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
 One hundred savings institutions have been chosen for top priority investigation by the Bush Administration, which has been stung by Congressional criticism that it has moved tentatively and ineffectively to prosecute savings and loan fraud. Each of the 100 units will be subject to stepped-up enforcement action. [Page 1.] The unemployment rate edged down another notch in June, to 5.2 percent, the Labor Department reported, and the number of new jobs rose to a higher level than most analysts expected - 356,000 instead of the 164,000 initially reported five weeks ago. Although the data showed growth to have remained well short of robust, the general reaction was that the Federal Reserve would not ease monetary policy, as the Bush Administration has been urging. [10.] Inflation posed too great a danger to allow interest rates to decline, Federal Reserve policy makers concluded at their May meeting, newly released minutes of the meeting show. [32.] The ''paperless office,'' trumpeted by computer companies a decade ago, is still an elusive goal, 55 million printers and billions of reams of paper later. [1.] 
 
 
 
Markets
 Interest rates soared as prices of Treasury securities plunged. Traders cited the Government's employment report. The Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in 2020, were offered at 102 21/32, down 1 5/32, while the yield climbed to 8.50 percent from 8.39 percent on Thursday. [29.] Stocks surged 25.74 points, to 2,904.95, as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average, as the market shrugged off the Government's employment report. The rise overcame much of Thursday's 32.42-point slide, but volume dropped to the year's lowest level. [29.] The dollar was up against the yen and pound but down against the Deutsche mark and Swiss franc in domestic currency trading. Gold prices also ended mixed. [38.] Prices of grain and soybean futures plunged for the second day as more weather forecasters predicted ideal weather next week in the Midwest. [38.]
 
 
 
Companies
 British Airways has ordered Boeing 747-400 jumbo jets, Rolls-Royce engines and components that could ultimately be worth more than $8 billion. The deal involves firm orders for 21 of the long-range planes, worth $4.15 billion, and options for 12 more. The airline said it also planned to spend $1.07 billion for about 160 Rolls-Royce RB-211-524G engines and spare parts. [29.] Mack Trucks announced a $100 million takeover bid from Renault Vehicules Industriels, France's state-owned truck maker, which already owns a controlling interest. Mack, which bears the most famous name in American truck-making, said that it expected to report a $90 million loss for the first six months. [29.] The New York Stock Exchange censured Shearson Lehman Hutton, and fined the brokerage house $500,000 for improper actions during its 1986 merger discussions with the E. F. Hutton Group, Wall Street executives said. The firm settled the charges without admitting or denying guilt. [29.] Digital Equipment will open its annual DEC World computer trade show Monday in Boston with a range of computer hardware and network announcements. Its VAX computer line has been under pressure in recent years from systems that run Unix. [31.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
 Investors should add to municipal bond positions, in light of expected tax increases, tax and investment professionals say. Cuts are likely in capital gains taxes, the experts add. Your Money. [30.] Two medical researchers in Madison, Wis., patented a cream they said embodies a natural process for reclaiming skin damaged by sun and aging. Patents. [30.]

HEADLINE: British Air Purchasing Boeing 747's

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, July 6

 BODY:
British Airways P.L.C. placed an order today for Boeing 747-400 jumbo jets, Rolls-Royce engines and components that could ultimately be worth more than $8 billion.
The deal involves firm orders for 21 of the long-range planes, worth $4.15 billion, and options for 12 more, worth $2.76 billion. The airline said it also planned to spend $1.07 billion for about 160 Rolls-Royce RB-211-524G engines and spare parts and $133.7 million for components from other British manufacturers.
Although the airline said the order was its single biggest investment in new aircraft, there was no competition for it. The battle for the business occurred in the mid-1980's and was decided in 1986, when British Airways ordered 19 747-400's and bought options for 12 more. Indeed, seven of the firm orders placed today involve exercising the 1986 options. Two other options were previously exercised. The first plane from the 1986 order went into service a year ago. 
 
Another Order Planned
But a battle is under way for another British Airways order. The airline plans to place an order later this year for planes that will replace its fleet of 25 Lockheed Tristars and McDonnell Douglas DC-10's.
The Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation of the United States and Airbus Industrie, the four-nation European aircraft-manufacturing consortium, are fighting for that order of medium- and long-range planes, which is expected to be worth $3.56 billion. The competing aircraft are the Boeing 767X, McDonnell Douglas's MD-11 and Airbus's A330 and A340.
 
Delivery to Begin in 1992
British Airways currently has 13 747-400's in its fleet. The number would rise to 42 based on the firm orders and 64 if all options are exercised. Delivery will begin in 1992 and will be completed in 1999, British Airways said.
The airline currently operates the 747-400's on routes to Australia, Southeast Asia, Japan, North America and South America. They will soon be introduced on its service to South Africa. British Airways also has 23 Boeing 747-200's.
Lord King, chairman of British Airways, said the deal signed today gave his company the right to convert the orders for any new variants of the 747 Boeing might produce. ''It is possible that during the delivery period Boeing will produce a larger version of the 747,'' he added. ''Although no details have been confirmed, we envis-age that new 747 variants could provide passenger capacities between 450 and 600 seats.''
The 747-400's that British Airways has in service have a range of 8,000 miles and have 386 seats, including 18 first class, 74 club world or business class, and 294 economy.
Lord King said today's order ''will insure that we have a sufficient flow of 747-400's to meet the growth in our intercontinental network forecast for the 1990's and beyond. The aircraft will provide extra capacity as well as allowing us to replace older Boeing 747 equipment.''
James C. Halstead, an analyst at Salomon Brothers in London, said the planes that British Airways needed to replace the most were 16 747-100's that have been in service since the early 1970's, and four 747-200's that have been used since the early to mid-1970's.
Noting that the manufacturers of commercial jetliners were sitting on huge order backlogs, he said that British Airways was probably also playing it safe with its latest purchasing deal. ''They've got the equipment other people may not be able to get,'' he added.
When formerly state-owned British Airways began its life as a public company in February 1987, it was saddled with a relatively old fleet. Since then it has been aggressively modernizing it.
In its fiscal year that ended March 31, the company took delivery of 21 new planes worth 800 million ($1.32 billion). It currently has a fleet of 230 planes.
As of March 31, the company had 58 aircraft - including the 747's ordered in 1986 - on firm order. The value of those planes was worth more than $3.56 billion. It is also awaiting delivery of 13 767-300's and 27 737's, and has options on 19 767-300's, 16 737's and 8 of British Aerospace's short-range ATP turboprop airliners.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The assembly line at Boeing's Everett, Wash., 747 plant. British Airways has ordered 21 Boeing 747-400's as part of an $8 billion order. (Associated Press) (pg. 31)

HEADLINE: JOB FIGURES DEPRESS BOND PRICES

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Interest rates soared yesterday as prices of Treasury securities plunged. The sharp price declines were fed by conflicting employment data released by the Government before trading began in New York and the losses became even more pronounced during the session.
On one hand, the Government reported that non-farm jobs rose by only 40,000 in June, less than half the number that was expected. But this did not cheer the bond market because the Government also revised its May employment data to show a gain of 356,000 jobs, more than double the number previously reported for the month. 
''Because the employment numbers released this morning were rather strange, the Street immediately labeled them as suspect and quickly focused its thinking on the unprecedented volume of Treasury paper to be auctioned next week,'' said Mark A. McCluskey, chief money market trader at the New York branch of Bank Julius Baer of Zurich. Equally disconcerting, Mr. McCluskey added, was the widespread belief in the fixed-income market that the Federal Reserve could not lower interest rates because the Treasury needed to attract ever-increasing numbers of buyers for the record volumes of debt it was issuing. Needed for Savings Bailout Much of the increase in Treasury debt offerings reflects the need to raise funds for the bailout of the savings and loan industry. On Tuesday, a record $5 billion of 30-year bonds are scheduled for sale to help the Government's bailout effort. The bonds traded yesterday on a when-issued basis to yield 8.88 percent, up from 8.79 percent the day before.
Mr. McCluskey said that ''there is also concern among dealers that the Street will have to develop a much larger short position before the Treasury's quarterly refundings in early August.''
''Otherwise, no one will stick his neck out at the refunding,'' he added. ''Despite today's selloff, there are still relatively few shorts in the Treasury market.''
One reason for the absence of short-sellers is that many market participants were expecting prices of fixed-income securities to rise and interest rates to decline now that the Administration and Congress appeared to be moving to reduce the budget deficit.
Dealers and other professionals normally sell Treasury paper short as a hedge against a price decline. Often, a large volume of short-selling will exert temporary upward pressure on interest rates.
As it was, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 8.75 percent issue maturing in 2020, were offered late in the session at 102 21/32, down by 15/32, while the yield climbed to 8.50 percent from 8.39 percent, both the day before and a week ago. The long notes, the 8 7/8's of 2000, dropped 24/32, to 102 14/32, for a yield of 8.50 percent.
Among the shorter notes, the 8 3/8's of 1992 lost 7/32, at 100 3/32, and now yield 8.32 percent; the 8 1/2's of 1994 dropped 10/32, to 100 7/32, for a yield of 8.43 percent. While interest rates rose on the Treasury's 10-year notes, to 8.50 percent from 8.40 percent during the holiday-shortened week, they were declining on comparable West German and Japanese maturities.
 
German and Japanese Declines
The rate on West Germany's 10-year Government long bonds slipped to 8.67 percent, from 8.70 percent a week ago. The rate on Japan's 10-year bonds, the longest maturity in Tokyo, fell to 7.18 percent from 7.35 percent during the week.
On Wednesday, the Treasury will auction a record $8 billion of new seven-year notes, which traded yesterday on a when-issued basis to yield 8.52 percent, up from 8.41 percent the day before. The sale would raise $3.25 billion of new cash, some of which would undoubtedly be employed in the savings bailout.
At the short end of the Treasury market, the discount rate of the 90-day bills jumped 9 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 7.76 percent; the six-month bills climbed 10 basis points, to 7.58 percent.
Dealers said part of the rise in bill rates could be attributed to the record $18 billion of three- and six-month bills that the Treasury will offer at its weekly auction on Monday.
The bill auctions are expected to raise $1.9 billion of new cash, some of which would also go toward the savings rescue effort, dealers said.
The Federal Reserve once again intervened to add reserves to the banking system by effecting $2 billion of repurchase agreements on behalf of customers. Federal funds, the key rate that banks charge each other for temporary funds, were being traded at 8 5/16 percent at the time and continued at that level throughout the session.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
A Few Deductions About New Taxes

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
No sooner had the words ''tax revenue increases'' formed on Presidential lips than citizens began asking what to expect and how to protect themselves. Four tax and investment professionals, despite some wisps of clouds in their crystal balls, ventured to respond to those questions.
''We will probably get a capital-gains reduction, because everyone agrees it generates revenue in the first couple of years'' by inducing people who have assets that have appreciated to sell them, said Thomas P. Ochsenschlager, head of the office of Federal tax services in Washington for the Grant Thornton accounting firm. Also, it is a cause to which President Bush has long been committed. 
''The only disadvantage is that it is perceived to be a benefit to the wealthy, so the Democrats will want a trade-off,'' Mr. Ochsenschlager added, possibly elimination of the ''33 percent bubble.'' He also cited as possibilities tax increases on tobacco, beer and wine and gasoline and environmental hazards, which he called ''the better mousetrap of the moment.''
The 33 percent bubble refers to the 5 percent surcharge levied on certain upper-income taxpayers to eliminate the benefit of the 15 percent rate on the first part of their income. Once that benefit is gone, they are taxed at a flat 28 percent. For married taxpayers filing jointly, for example, that happened in 1989 when taxable income exceeded $155,320. If they were taxed at 33 percent instead, the Government projects, an additional $45 billion would be collected over the next five years - a rather small amount given a budget deficit projected at $160 billion for 1991. Capital gains are taxed as ordinary income.
Mr. Ochsenschlager put the odds of a capital-gains reduction - perhaps a maximum rate of 20 percent - at 70 to 75 percent, but he saw only a 50-50 chance of a 33 percent top rate, given the pressure for more palatable ways to raise revenues. Asked what investors should do to prepare for tax changes, Stephen P. Rappaport, author of ''The Affluent Investor: Investment Strategies for All Markets'' (New York Institute of Finance, Simon & Schuster, 198 pages), said, ''It might be a good time to increase holdings of municipal bonds, in light of the tax exemption afforded.''
Mr. Rappaport, who is also first vice president and manager of municipal research for Prudential-Bache Capital Funding, said that for many dual-income couples in the 33 percent bracket, a buy-and-hold strategy for a portfolio of municipal bonds could be attractive, with maturities staggered from 5 to 10 years.
Because the Tax Reform Act of 1986 made real estate investments relatively unattractive, ''we're really looking at financial portfolios,'' he said.
Martin Jaffe, senior vice president and chief operating officer of Wood, Struthers & Winthrop, the investment-management subsidiary of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said that for people taxed at 28 percent, the after-tax yield on Treasury bonds is close to that of municipals, and they ''are more liquid and you sleep better.'' But for those in the 33 percent bracket, he said, municipals have a yield advantage, and any general rise in tax rates could cause them to trade at a premium.
Mr. Jaffe also considers it likely that the capital-gains rate will be cut, possibly to between 15 and 19 percent, but he cautioned against waiting for a cut before selling shares.
''If we really believe a stock is overvalued and has vulnerability, we'd sell regardless of the capital gain,'' he said. ''If we felt a stock was going to move with the market and didn't have a lot of downside, we wouldn't be in a rush to sell,'' because frequent taxable trades limit portfolio growth.
For shareholders who have very large gains, often ''we'll use that stock for charitable gifts,'' Mr. Jaffe said, because the full appreciated value is deductible for those who are not subject to the alternative minimum tax. If rates rise, the deduction would be worth more.
Like Mr. Ochsenschlager, David A. Berenson, national director of taxes for Ernst & Young in Washington, advised people who have the choice to recognize income this year rather than defer it to future years.
Although he foresees ''a good probability that Bush can avoid'' a top rate of 33 percent, Mr. Berenson said, ''Don't think you are ever going to see taxes lower than they are this year.''
With the mandate to cut the deficit, he said, Congress will move to raise revenue. Likely possibilities in today's political environment, he said, include taxes on securities sales to offset a capital-gains cut, environmental and excise taxes, lower caps on deductions for home-mortgage interest, the end of deductions for second homes, and additional estate taxes.
Far too little attention is being given to what effect these taxes would have on the economy, Mr. Berenson said. With the home-building industry already sluggish, taxes that make home ownership less attractive may tip the industry into recession, he added, costing American jobs.
He advocates instead a tax policy that encourages savings and investment - restoring the deductibility of individual retirement accounts for everyone, for instance - and one that discourages excess consumption by taxing luxury goods, domestic products and imports alike. That would raise revenue and lower the trade deficit, Mr. Berenson contends, but because it seems politically unlikely, he advises people to prepare for the possibility of a recession.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Control Data Acts To Sell VTC Unit

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 6

 BODY:
The Control Data Corporation is again seeking buyers for VTC Inc., its 400-employee semiconductor maker in Bloomington. Contol Data reached an agreement in the spring to sell the unit to Seattle Silicon of Bellevue, Wash., for an undisclosed amount, but delays in arranging financing have cost Seattle Silicon its exclusive purchase rights. VTC is Control Data's last big money-losing operation. Control Data, also based in Bloomington, created $100 million in reserves last year to compensate for the losses it expects to incur on the sale.
In a separate matter, Control Data this week sold Doane Information Services, a publisher of agricultural newsletters and software. Doane, which has 50 employees, will become a division of Doane Agricultural Services of Cherry Valley, Ill. No terms were disclosed.

HEADLINE: Fed Voted in May Against Lower Rates

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers concluded at their May meeting that inflation posed too great a danger to allow interest rates to decline, minutes of the meeting released today show.
The eight-week-old records were made available amid signs that the policy makers had decided at their most recent gathering on Monday and Tuesday to stand ready to shift their policy and nudge interest rates lower if the economy weakened further.
Unidentified Government officials outside the Fed were quoted in published reports today as saying they believed the directive adopted earlier this week allowed a relaxation of the tight credit policy if additional signs of economic sluggishness emerged. 
Analysts were split over whether the June employment report released today by the Labor Department provided such evidence. The unemployment rate slipped to 5.2 percent, from 5.3 percent, but non-farm job growth was a weaker-than-expected 40,000.
In May, members of the Federal Open Market Committee voted by 10 to 1 to maintain the existing credit policy and directed central bank officials to be equally ready to raise or lower rates, depending on developments on inflation and economic growth.
Members agreed that ''current information on business conditions pointed on balance to relatively moderate but sustained economic expansion.'' At the same time, the members ''generally agreed that the prospects for significant reductions in inflation pressures during the quarters immediately ahead were not promising.''
W. Lee Hoskins, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland and a prominent advocate of a tough anti-inflation policy, voted against the directive. He argued for a tighter credit policy ''to help assure that progress would be made toward a reduced rate of inflation.''
Mr. Hoskins said tighter credit would ''enhance the credibility and effectiveness of monetary policy in countering the persisting strength of inflationary pressures,'' according to the minutes.
Other members, who were not identified, went along with the directive but said that ''the need to contain and ultimately to reduce inflation might well require a firming of policy at some point.''
The Federal Reserve has been fighting inflation with higher interest rates since early 1988. In mid-1989 it began nudging rates down amid concern that the economy might topple into a recession. However, since late December, the Fed has held steady. The Federal funds rate, the interest charged among banks for overnight loans, has hovered around 8.25 percent since then.
The open market committee, which is made up of the seven Fed governors and five of the system's 12 regional bank presidents, meets in secret eight times a year to formulate monetary policy. Minutes are released about six to eight weeks later, a few days after the next meeting. There was one vacancy among the governors at the time of the May meeting.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar and Gold Are Mixed On News of Unemployment

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar ended up mixed in domestic currency trading yesterday. It had closed higher overseas after the release of a better-than-expected unemployment report in the United States.
Gold prices also ended mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery slipped 30 cents from late Thursday to settle at $361.10 an ounce. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $360.20, down 30 cents. 
Despite a continuing slump in the nation's manufacturing and construction sectors, the unemployment rate fell to 5.2 percent in June from 5.3 percent in May, the Labor Department reported.
 
Jump in Jobless Was Expected
Many traders had expected unemployment to jump to as much as 5.5 percent, a rise that could have encouraged the Federal Reserve to ease interest rates to stimulate the economy.
But the report ''dispelled some anticipation that the Fed might ease,'' said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. Higher interest rates make dollar-denominated securities more attractive, and thereby enhance foreign investors' needs for dollars to buy debt instruments.
The dollar rose overseas, but turned mixed when trading shifted to the United States. Dealers said the much-anticipated employment report failed to move the market significantly, and activity was relatively thin.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 150.95 yen, down 0.05 yen from the Thursday close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted higher at 151.00 yen. In New York, the dollar rose more than 1 yen, to 151.70, up from 150.57 yen on Thursday.
The British pound rose in London to $1.7865, from $1.7795 late Thursday. In New York, a pound cost $1.7865, more expensive than the $1.7815 of Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's late rates, included: 1.6515 West German marks, down from 1.6517; 1.3983 Swiss francs, down from 1.3998; 5.5435 French francs, up from 5.5430; 1,211.50 Italian lire, unchanged, and 1.1619 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1640.
In London, gold was quoted at a late price of $361.25 an ounce, up from $359.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold was quoted at $361.25, up from $359.50. In Hong Kong, it dropped 21 cents an ounce yesterday, to $361.26.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;
Shopping for CD's

 BODY:
Yields on bank certificates of deposit rose briefly in May but have slipped gradually since, and rate analysts expect them to move lower through most of 1990. Investors may want to lock in current interest rates. Certificates of deposit are as safe as Treasury securities, while requiring far smaller minimum investments. Rate changes run in cycles as long as two and a half years; the present down cycle is in its 14th month, making short-term certificates the best buys. HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Travels in the U.S.: Savings Via Coupon Or Club

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
More and more vacationers are seeking significant discounts on hotel rooms in the United States through special clubs or coupon books. Those savings can extend, too, to some rental cars and short-term condominium rentals.
This relatively new opportunity to save money is provided by companies that offer discounts of up to 50 percent that become available when there are unsold rooms at participating hotels and motels and unrented cars or condominiums.
Membership in travel clubs costs $40 to $100 a year. Only one coupon book is available now, for $29.95. 
''Hotels participate in discount programs like this because getting half-price is better than an empty room,'' said Jerry H. King, president of Momentum International, a travel club based in Carrollton, Tex.
''The hotels are betting on you using their amenities, like restaurants and bars, when filling a room,'' added Arthur Salus, president of the Privilege Card, another travel club with headquarters in Duluth, Ga.
Here is how the clubs work: members typically receive an identification card and a directory of hotels and vacation condominium units. When they want to make a reservation, they select the area and a hotel from the directory and identify themselves as a member of the particular club.
Generally, reservations cannot be made more than 30 days in advance, and space must be available for the requested dates. The identification card must be shown at the time a vacationer checks in, and the prearranged discount from the standard rate is automatically applied.
 
Planning Ahead
 The hotel coupon book, ''Travel America at Half Price,'' is published by the Entertainment Publishing Corporation of Troy, Mich., which also publishes discount books for restaurants, theaters and sports events in many areas of the country.
When using the coupon book, reservations must be made in advance and members must identify themselves as participants in the program to be confirmed at the discount rate. Upon arrival, the coupon is presented and the discount granted.
One drawback of the vacation clubs is that you may not know the quality or location of the room until arrival. On the other hand, if deluxe accommodations are available, you can get them at the discounted price.
For travelers who prefer to shop for their own bargains on the phone, hotels and rent-a-car companies have a wide range of promotional packages. Employees of companies big and small can usually take advantage of the corporate discounts negotiated by their employer even when they travel on vacation.
''It's a jungle,'' said Bonnie Kogos of Zenith Travel, a New York travel agency. ''There is no one lowest rate anymore. You really have to keep scouting and getting leads.''
''It's like any other scenario as far as shopping is concerned,'' said Roxana Lewis of Chartwell Travel, a travel agency in Inglewood, Calif. ''You've got to know your territory.''
The current pricing pattern in travel stems from what economists call elasticity of demand - the responsiveness of buyers to changes in price.
When businesses in the hospitality industry think that a large group of consumers will not reserve a room or car at a higher price, at least some prices may be lowered in hopes of attracting more customers.
''The ability to find unusually good buys is a very recent phenomenon,'' said Bjorn Hanson, a senior principal of Laventhol & Horwath, a certified public accounting firm that serves many travel-related companies. ''There is some kind of embarrassment factor in not wanting to sound cheap. But the person at the reservation desk couldn't care what your income is.''
 
Questions to Ask
Mr. Hanson and other experts advise consumers to ask these questions when making reservations:
* What's the basic rate for the room or car?
* Are there any weekend or off-season packages, when a $100-a-night room may be on sale for, say, $65?
* Are there any lower rates available?
* Are there any restrictions when booking one of these special rates?
 ''A lot of cities have summer slumps,'' said Ed Perkins, editor of the newsletter Consumer Reports Travel Letter.
 ''Chicago and Phoenix are both having major summer promotions. The best way to get this kind of information is to call the convention and visitors' bureau of the city.''
 
Top and Corporate Rates
 The corporate rate is the price established by companies with a hotel chain and rental car concern for their employees' business travel. It is typically 10 to 30 percent less than the top rate for that room or car.
And frequently the corporate rate will be given to workers of those companies, if rooms or cars are available, just for the asking.
''In most major companies, they would be able to do that,'' said Dolly Bees, travel planning manager of the USF&G Corporation of Baltimore.
Ms. Bees, who is also an official of the National Business Travel Association, added, ''You can put in the contract that the hotel and car rental company will acccept leisure travelers at the corporate rate.''
 
HOTEL PLANS WITH DISCOUNTS
Here is a list of hotel plans that offer discounts up to 50 percent when space is available to members who pay an annual fee.
Concierge - 1050 Yuma Street, Suite 310, Denver, Colo. 80204. Telephone: 800-346-1022. $69.95 a year.
Entry Unlimited - 6404 Nancy Ridge Drive, San Diego 92121. Telephone: 800-843-0265. $39.95 a year.
Momentum International - 2201 Midway Road, Suite 100K, Carrollton, Tex. 75106. Telephone: 800-822-5449. $50 a year.
Privilege Card - 3473 Satellite Boulevard, Suite 200, Duluth, Ga. 30136. Telephone: 800-359-0066. $49.95 a year.
Quest International - Chinook Tower, Box 4041, Yakima, Wash. 98901. Telephone: 800-325-2400. $99 a year.
Travel America at Half Price - 2125 Butterfield Road, Troy, Mich. 48084. Telephone: 800-521-9640. $29.95 for half-price coupon book.

HEADLINE: How Stanford, Wealthy and Wise, Is Cutting Costs to Stay That Way

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif.

 BODY:
On paper, Stanford University looks flush. As it turns 100 in the fall, this college of lush greenery and rust-tiled roofs is blessed with prestige, a $2 billion endowment and generous alumni who have raised nearly $1.1 billion in a fund drive.
But because its leaders expect fewer Government research grants and stiffer resistance to tuition increases, Stanford sees lean years ahead.
So the school is slashing its budget 13 percent, laying off nonteaching employees and tearing up organizational charts - all the while pledging not to raise tuition by more than 1 percentage point above the inflation rate.
 
Stanford Is First to Act
All the nation's richest and top-ranked universities face the same pressures, but Stanford is the first such school to take drastic action. 
''These concerns are quite common,'' said Henry Rosovsky, acting dean of Harvard University's faculty of arts and sciences. ''I admire Stanford for the fact they've started to tackle this, and I'm quite sure the rest of us will follow fairly soon - not necessarily in terms of major cuts, but in terms of attempting to deal with these financial questions.''
Stanford, about 35 miles southeast of San Francisco, is acting now because short-term expenses like covering a sizable budget deficit and paying out $124 million to repair damage from last fall's earthquake are converging with several long-term problems.
University officials believe the easing of East-West tensions will curb the flow of Government-sponsored military and scientific research. At the same time, faculty members conducting Government research say the steep rates Stanford charges for expenses like staff and utilities could jeopardize their ability to win such grants.
Meanwhile, parents and students have been angered by soaring tuition in the last decade, including several increases of more than five percentage points above the inflation rate. That anger persuaded Stanford officials that they could not continue to meet expenses with large tuition increases.
 
'We Can't Do That Anymore'
James N. Rosse, Stanford's provost, said that in the past many top colleges insisted that such increases were needed to attract the best professors or buy expensive equipment like atom-smashers that would give students opportunities they could not find elsewhere.
''Can I really afford to raise tuition above inflation?'' Mr. Rosse said, tracing the decision-making process. ''If so, I can afford this program. You quickly persuade yourself you ought to have the program. We prospered as an institution by following that strategy, but the world has changed and we can't do that any more.''
One result has been months of budget-cutting and streamlining. This has brought satisfaction in reducing a bloated bureaucracy along with widespread anxiety and plummeting morale among employees.
Mr. Rosse announced the austerity plan in February, set preliminary cuts for each department, reviewed department proposals and announced cuts and layoffs last month. So far, 131 of Stanford's 6,415 non-teaching employees are scheduled to lose their jobs this fall. More layoffs could come by September 1991, though all teaching positions are exempt.
Departments have devised hundreds of ideas to save money, including closing the student infirmary and referring students to nearby Stanford Hospital at an annual saving of $130,000; charging graduate students $8 an academic quarter for aerobics classes, which they now attend at no cost, and consolidating orientation mailings to new students at an annual saving of $4,000.
 
Cutting the Bureaucracy
Not only does Stanford have to decide which services are essential and which are frills, officials say, but also how to speed decision-making and rethink cumbersome management procedures.
''The administrative side of this university could be more businesslike,'' said Susan M. Schaffer, vice president for administrative resources, who came to Stanford last year after serving as a vice president at United Airlines. ''They have adopted academic decision-making processes that, frankly, are not particularly useful. There are processes here that require seven signatures. This consensus environment leads to very few people really having to stick their necks out, because no one person has the power to say, 'This is the hill we're going to take.' ''
To end some duplication of services, for instance, Stanford has created a vice president for student resources, eliminating two senior positions and consolidating services that were scattered over several departments.
Mr. Rosse estimates that the changes so far should save freshmen entering this fall $1,000 in their senior year alone. Fees will rise only 5.5 percent, to $20,210 next year, the smallest increase among leading research universities, according to a survey by College Bound, a newsletter for college admissions officers. Yale's tuition, room and board will rise 7.8 percent, to $20,820, and Harvard's will go up 6.5 percent, to $20,655.
But these cutbacks have not come without a cost.
 
'I Don't Understand Really'
''It's hard for people to understand, and I don't understand really, why this cut is necessary in a year where we're raising $1.1 billion,'' said Carolyn Lougee, associate dean of humanities and sciences, who serves on the steering committee overseeing the cuts. ''We're being forced to do things like lay off people that we never do.''
Most of the money raised in the fund drive is earmarked for specific programs, Mr. Rosse said. The cuts were necessary, he went on, because expenditures like medical insurance and library acquisitions were skyrocketing while income from research grants was dropping. Stanford faced an immediate budget deficit this coming academic year of $7 million, worsened by the bill for earthquake repairs.
Tuition and payments for room and board account for 43 percent of income in Stanford's 1990-91 operating budget. The fee charged to faculty members with Government grants for their use of Stanford buildings and equipment accounts for 30 percent more. Seventy-eight percent of each grant goes to Stanford; the rate is one of the highest among major universities.
But parents' anger over tuition increases and faculty anger over the research fees persuaded Stanford officials that they could no longer rely on yearly increases from these two chief sources of income.
The provost's office calculated that holding down these increases would cost Stanford at least $18 million over the next three years. Because such estimates have proved low in the past, Mr. Rosse said, he added $4 million to arrive at a total cut of $22 million.
Because most of the budget goes toward salaries and benefits, and because the university will not cut student financial aid, faculty positions or debt payments, Mr. Rosse said, layoffs in nonteaching jobs were inevitable. Rumors about who would lose their jobs have been circulating since February, when Mr. Rosse announced the cost-cutting drive. Most employees will find out in the next two months.
 
Bitterness on Campus
Various employee unions have staged protests, and union employees who will be replaced by nonunion contract workers staged a job action at a student center, but so far there have been no major strikes. Still, there is some bitterness.
''I think the good will and morale have really been squandered,'' said Daniel Ramirez, an administrative assistant in the residential education department,which pays for advisers, seminars and guest speakers in every Stanford dormitory. Although he expects to keep his job in the department, which faces a 20 percent budget cut, Mr. Ramirez said it would be so differently defined that he would be spending more time on menial work and would have to consider working elsewhere.
Proposals to cut the libraries' budgets 20 percent provoked concern among professors and librarians. But Mr. Rosse noted that Yale's library costs were $16,600 for each faculty member in 1987-88, as against $20,000 at Stanford.
While plans to cut the human resources office budget 30 percent drew little protest, proposals to eliminate residential computer clusters or to charge graduate students for aerobics classes brought howls.
In the end, the steering committee reduced the cuts for residential education from 20 percent to 15 percent, and library cuts from 20 percent to 16 percent. The computers will stay, but to save $105,000, the university is reducing maintenance; and students will have to wait longer to get computers repaired. But graduate students will have to pay $8 an academic quarter for aerobics classes.
No one is sure what effect the cuts will have on life at Stanford. But Joan K. Krasner, chief of access services for university libraries, said she felt certain that faculty members and students would feel the difference.
''There will be a slowdown in delivering documents, there will be a slowdown in book inventory, getting books on the shelves,'' said Ms. Krasner. ''While I think any organization can do some belt-tightening, I think once you get beyond that, you start to lose some services.''
Students will be most immediately affected by cuts in the number of graduate student advisers living in dormitories, a reduction in career counseling services and in dormitory-based programs. But over all, said Norman Robinson, acting dean of student affairs, ''I think the impact is really going to be almost imperceptible.''
Brad Hayward, a sophomore who is managing editor of the student-run newspaper, The Stanford Daily, said many students were concerned that the school could lose some of the intimacy that residential education programs brought to undergraduate life. But, he added, ''a lot of students understand what's at stake here.''
The stakes, Ms. Schaffer said, are as high as those faced by American corporations in the 1980's, when international competition forced thorough streamlining. ''The university is just entering the 1980's,'' she said. ''Just as corporate America in the 60's and 70's could keep on spending, keep on pushing costs through, all of a sudden it came to a crashing end. They have to have their ideals confront the changing realities of the economic situation.''

HEADLINE: U.S. READY TO LET SATELLITES GO UP ON SOVIET ROCKETS

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has decided to allow American commercial satellites to be launched on Soviet rockets for the first time, Government and industry officials say.
As a result of decisions made at the White House this week, an Australian commercial venture, the Cape York Space Agency, will be permitted to hire an American company to run a base in northern Australia from which Soviet rockets will carry satellites into orbit for customers from around the world, perhaps as early as 1995, the officials said.
The project provides a major opportunity for the Soviet Union to expand its international space business and is expected to increase foreign competitive pressures on the American rocket industry.
 
Industry Is Divided
Domestic rocket companies had opposed letting the Soviet Union provide launching services for American customers, but the satellite makers had favored opening up the market. Representatives for both groups said the Administration's decision seemed evenhanded, since it includes provisions intended to insure that the Soviet Union prices its rockets fairly. 
In recent years, the United States has shifted the job of launching privately owned satellites from the Government's space agency to aerospace companies. In August the McDonnell Douglas Corporation became the first company to conduct a commercial launching in the United States, and nearly a dozen launchings by several companies are expected this year.
 
Among Thorniest of Issues
But the domestic industry faces intense competition from the European consortium Arianespace, and the availability of inexpensive rockets from China and the Soviet Union is also a worry. The domestic industry has invested hundreds of millions of dollars in a business fraught with technical risks.
This week the National Space Council, an interagency committee headed by Vice President Dan Quayle, completed a broad set of recommendations on the international launching business. The decision to approve the Cape York project was among the thorniest issues in the council's policy review.
Last year China won limited approval from the United States Government to launch a few American satellites from Chinese territory. But despite the warming in Soviet-American relations, and considerable interest from American satellite companies in using Soviet launching services, there has never been any sign that the United States was ready to abandon its opposition to a cooperative arrangement, especially if it meant launching American satellites from Soviet soil. Rocket and satellite technologies are strictly controlled because of their military applications.
 
The Australian Arrangement
Now the State Department, with the approval of the White House, intends to grant an initial export license to the USBI division of the United Technologies Corporation to operate the Cape York station, where Soviet Zenit rockets could be launched beginning in 1995. The project, estimated to cost nearly $500 million, is backed by an Australian real estate development company and would not receive any Australian Government money. The Soviet space agency, Glavkosmos, would supply rockets and engineers, but would not own a share in the venture.
Despite strong opposition from American rocket manufacturers and some skepticism by other Federal agencies, the State Department is expected to issue the Cape York license once President Bush approves the new policy governing the international trade in rocket-launching services, several officials said.
The proposal for the Australian launchings of Soviet rockets first surfaced last year, but the Bush Administration decided not to make a decision on it without conducting a broad review of its policies for promoting the domestic commercial space industry. The Reagan Administration had never considered letting the Soviet Union launch American satellites, but improving relations between the two countries made the Australian proposal palatable to the Bush Administration.
Although the National Space Council's recommendations will not become final until formally approved by President Bush, the new policy has already been explained by White House officials to a few Congressional aides, and after several weeks of intense review virtually all the details have been agreed to by senior officials on the space council.
 
'A Middle Approach'
Dawn Gifford, a Washington lawyer who is director of the Competitive Alliance for Space Enterprise, an industry group that represents rocket makers and satellite makers, said the Administration had taken ''a reasonable approach'' in its policy review. ''My impression is that they have taken a middle approach that will wash well with both sides,'' Ms. Gifford said of the industry's reaction.
One rocket industry official said the new policy appeared to include safeguards against unfair competition from the Soviet Union, but this executive cautioned that enforcing those provisions might be difficult.
Satellite manufacturers tend to favor letting the Soviet Union supply launching services.
Although more licenses would be needed later for American-made satellites to be launched from Cape York, the decision to allow an American company to manage the operation in effect insures the approval of subsequent licenses as long as Australia and the Soviet Union adhere to conditions laid down by the United States.
Those conditions, as outlined in the space council's recommendations, include a Soviet promise to limit its overseas launching to a single site and to abide by an international agreement controlling the export of ballistic missile technologies, which have commercial and military uses.
Domestic rocket manufacturers, supported by officials from agencies as diverse as the Defense Department and the Transportation Department, have argued that the domestic rocket industry would suffer unfairly in a head-to-head competition with Soviet suppliers.
But the State Department viewed the Soviet-Australian proposal favorably, and American satellite companies warned that if they were prevented from putting their payloads on the cheapest available rockets they would eventually lose business to emerging foreign satellite makers who faced no such restrictions.
 
Australians Eager for Business
The Australians had pressed the proposal vigorously because they are eager to play a bigger role in the potentially lucrative aerospace business.
The Administration's policy statement declares it is in the economic and national security interests of the United States to maintain a healthy commercial industry for launching satellites. But it seeks to foster that industry by promoting further research into advanced rockets that would cost less and be more reliable, rather than by using trade barriers.
An official said the policy called for negotiating new ''rules of the road'' with the European Space Agency, which controls Arianespace. The official said such rules might include limiting subsidies and defining fair pricing for launching satellites.
The Soviet Union and China would be expected to adhere to the same fair-trade policies in pricing their rockets on the world markets, even though it is very difficult to estimate fair prices for rockets designed and built in controlled economies. How to Enforce Fair Pricing? One major point that remains to be resolved is how the United States and other Western nations would enforce the fair-pricing rules.
Some Administration officials favor using export licenses as the enforcement mechanism. For example, if the United States determines that the Soviet Union is pricing its rockets too low, licenses would be refused for future American launchings from Cape York, shutting the Australian base off from its biggest source of customers.
But the State Department is arguing that the export control laws, which it administers, are meant only to prevent the sale of militarily useful technologies to potential adversaries, and not to enforce fair-trade rules.
The domestic rocket manufacturers are already complaining that China has violated the agreement it signed last year, when the United States first allowed that country to launch a few American satellites on Chinese rockets. The American companies say China submitted an unreasonably low bid when it recently won a contract to launch a communications satellite for an Arab consortium.
The American companies, supported by their European competitors, are urging the State Department to revoke licenses for the Chinese to launch more American satellites if the United States determines that the Chinese bids have been unfairly priced.

HEADLINE: EVOLUTION IN EUROPE;
Bush Accepts Japanese Aid to China, With Limits

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOUSTON, July 7

 BODY:
President Bush told Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan today that the Administration would not oppose Japanese plans to resume its multibillion-dollar program of aid to China. But he urged Mr. Kaifu to slow down the aid plan and limit its scope.
Mr. Bush's meeting with Mr. Kaifu, coming a day after the NATO summit meeting at which the alliance declared that it no longer viewed Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union as adversaries, reflected the approach that the United States intends to adopt at the meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations that begins here on Monday.
Administration officials said that while the United States would encourage its industrial partners to seek reform in China and the Soviet Union, it accepted that each country must pursue its own foreign-policy objectives without interference from Washington. 
Mr. Bush has come under attack for not taking a more punitive stand toward China after the massacre at Tiananmen Square, and his acquiescence on the Japan loan issue may well revive criticism that his policy toward China is too accommodating.
Administration officials said that Mr. Bush would also be acquiescent about German aid to the Soviet Union because ''the Germans are hoping no one here will put a fly in the ointment as they try to buy Soviet acquiescence on German unity,'' and the President would go along with that.
 
A Cable to Gorbachev
Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said today that Mr. Bush had sent a cable to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday afternoon as he returned on Air Force One from the NATO summit meeting.
''This was a rather lengthy cable, which gave the President's personal reflections on the summit, expressed his support for the reforms that President Gorbachev is undertaking and just gave a little personal emphasis to the conclusions of the NATO summit in terms of the changing nature of the alliance and their reaching out to the Soviet Union.''
The President confirmed to reporters on the flight from London to Houston on Friday that he had received a letter from Mr. Gorbachev, but would not disclose the contents. Administration officials said today that the letter was a plea from Mr. Gorbachev for the United States to help him with his faltering economy, similar to a request that the Soviet leader recently sent to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain.
Japanese officials said they were hoping that at the summit meeting here this week they would persuade the six other industrial nations - the United States, West Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada - that continuing sanctions against Beijing would only isolate the Chinese leadership, reducing the likelihood of reform. The sanctions, including a ban on high-level contacts with Chinese officials and a freeze on development loans, were imposed at last year's economic summit meeting in Paris, after hundreds of students and other protesters were killed in the Tiananmen Square uprising in June.
''We can understand the Japanese wanting to proceed, because of their unique relationship with China,'' a top Administration official said. ''But we wish they would proceed in a more restricted form than they now envision.''
 
The Japanese Position
Regardless of the position of its industrial partners, Japan is inclined to resume credit and aid to China independently.
''We're seeking a full understanding of the legitimacy of our argument at the summit,'' Taizo Watanabe, the chief spokesman for the Japanese Government, said. ''But there does not have to be any written statement on the China issue this time.''
''Our position is that no one has forgotten Tiananmen Square, but there is more to be gained in terms of reform from an open-door policy toward China,'' Mr. Watanabe said.
Japan has been China's main source of aid and credit, and it planned a $5.2 billion, five-year program of loans. Starting last fall, Tokyo began resuming some disbursements under an existing aid program, but the freed money was earmarked mainly for the likes of food and drugs.
 
Pressure on Kaifu From Business
The Kaifu Government is coming under mounting pressure from the Japanese business community to restart normal lending to Beijing. And Japanese officials have signaled that Tokyo, with its strong links to its big Asian neighbor, is preparing to act independently of its Western industrial partners, if necessary.
''The Japanese want to change world policy on China, but they seem increasingly willing to go it alone on this,'' said Edward J. Lincoln, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution. ''What the Japanese want from this summit is some sign from the Bush Administration that they won't take too much heat from the United States if they do resume aid to China.''
As for direct aid to the Soviet Union, Prime Minister Kaifu reiterated his stance that Japan will not participate in assistance until Moscow has settled a 45-year-old territorial dispute over four islands at the end of the Kurile chain that the Soviet Union seized at the end of World War II.
 
U.S. Stand on Aid to Soviets
In an interview here on Cable News Network, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d reiterated that even though Germany and other countries meeting here plan to send money to the Soviet Union, the United States will not provide credits or direct economic assistance.
''Before we spend taxpayer dollars on direct economic assistance to the Soviet Union, we ought to have some reasonable idea or some reasonable faith that the money is going to be well spent,'' he said.
''Some countries here will want to go with direct economic assistance,'' he said. ''Other countries, the United States included, will say we really ought to see some progress toward economic reform before we make the same mistake we made with respect to Poland in the 1970's and advance financial or economic assistance before appropriate reform.''
He added, ''We can be helpful on the economic side with technical economic assistance - help show them the way to get to a truly free-market economy.''
President Bush plans more meetings with allies for Sunday. He is scheduled to go to church in the morning with Mrs. Thatcher and to meet afterward with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada about the environment and the future of Quebec in light of the constitutional crisis there.
Mr. Bush also planned a meeting with Jacques Delors, the president of the commission of the European Community.

COUNTRY: CHINA (96%); UNITED STATES (95%); EUROPE (94%); GERMANY (94%); JAPAN (94%); FRANCE (92%); UNITED KINGDOM (79%); EASTERN EUROPE (72%); 

STATE: NORTH CENTRAL CHINA (90%);

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Lawmakers Pass Bill to Raise Income and Gas Taxes

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 7

 BODY:
After three weeks of bitter negotiations that often lasted late into the night, the Massachusetts Legislature today sent a $1.6 billion tax package to the desk of Governor Michael S. Dukakis. The Governor's press secretary said Mr. Dukakis would sign the bill early next week.
The bill includes the first permanent income tax increase in the state since 1975, and is a concrete signal that Massachusetts' political leaders are coming to terms with the fact that the state's economic boom of the 1980s has ended.
The bill will raise the gasoline tax from 11 cents to 21 cents a gallon and broaden the sales tax to cover certain professional services for the first time. 
Like other states in New England and the Northeast, the state has been trying to deal with an economic downturn that has caused persistent budget problems.
The Massachusetts Legislature debated the bill late Friday night and this morning in an atmosphere of crisis. The government has not yet passed a budget for the fiscal year 1991, which began on July 1. The 1990 fiscal year ended with the state borrowing to meet a deficit estimated at $1.1 billion. Based on current proposals for the 1991 budget, the gap between spending and revenues could be just as large.
 
Opponents Gather Support
Opponents of higher taxes are gathering support for a November referendum that would reduce tax and fee revenues by at least $1.6 billion in the next three years. Jim Braude, director of Tax Equity Alliance of Massachusetts, an independent lobbying group that supports a tax increase, argues that the number would be closer to $3 billion in the next 18 months.
Citizens for Limited Taxation, the independent organization that initiated the petition, uses the slogan, ''The only alternative to tax limitation is unlimited taxation.'' In 1980, the group successfully organized voters to pass the statewide proposition that capped local property tax increases at two and a half percent a year.
In June, Standard & Poor's, the Wall Street credit-rating agency, cited the November referendum when it put Massachusetts' bond rating on credit watch, which means that if the state does not get its fiscal house in order, its credit rating could decline. Massachusetts's rating is already the lowest among the states.
The new tax bill will expand the sales tax, which is 5 percent in Massachusetts, to cover business services such as legal, engineering, accounting and architectural transactions. The tax will also cover a variety of general services, such as some long-distance telephone calls, photographic services, credit reporting and computer repairs.
 
State's Authority Challenged
Critics in the Legislature have charged that the state lacks the legal authority to tax services, while revenue officials have expressed concern about their ability to enforce the levy. After a flurry of criticism, Florida repealed a similar sales tax on business services in 1987.
Critics have also said the tax will send the wrong message to businesses that are trying to manage in a slowly growing economy. In June, the state's unemployment rate rose from 5.5 percent to 5.8 percent. The Revenue Department announced on Friday that state tax collections during the last fiscal year dropped 3.3 percent, the first time revenues have dropped since 1975. Corporate taxes skidded 19.3 percent. Legislators predict the bill will raise $1.1 billion in new tax revenues this fiscal year, and $1.6 billion next year. The bill will raise the income tax rate to 5.95 percent this year from 5.75 percent. The rate had previously been slated to drop to 5 percent on Jan. 1, 1991. The after-tax capital gains tax rate will rise from 5 percent to 6 percent. Under the proposed legislation, the income tax will again go up in 1991 to 6.25 percent, and then back to 5.95 percent in 1992.
Since 1988, when state tax revenue increased only 2.1 percent, uncontrolled spending and disappointing tax collections have virtually paralyzed a state government that had grown accustomed to double-digit revenue growth for much of the decade.
Joseph Slavet, a senior associate at the John W. McCormack Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Massachusettsin Boston, said: ''The official behavior was to consider'' disappointing revenues ''as a short-term situation that would turn itself around. From thereon in, it has been downhill.''

HEADLINE: Homeless Advocates Debate How to Advance the Battle

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
This week's suicide of Mitch Snyder, the nation's best-known advocate for the homeless, came at a time when their movement was already hurt by internal strife and an apparent decline in public support.
Recent months have brought signs of what advocacy groups have begun to call a backlash against the homeless, including cuts in municipal aid to them around the country, evictions from public places and increasing public anger at begging and street encampments.
The 46-year-old Mr. Snyder, who was found hanged on Thursday at the large shelter for the homeless that he ran here, agreed in an interview last month that the movement had lost its momentum. ''We're at the point now that we were at 10 years ago,'' he said. ''We're stagnating. The issue is in recession.'' 
 
Creating Compassion
Mr. Snyder and Robert Hayes, founder of the National Coalition for the Homeless, were the two most prominent leaders of the homeless advocacy movement in the 1980's.
But in the last year, both encountered criticism within their own organizations, largely a result of personality conflicts and their reluctance to delegate authority. Last October, Mr. Hayes left his full-time job with the National Coalition to resume a law practice, infuriating Mr. Snyder, who argued that Mr. Hayes had an obligation to continue working full time for the homeless.
In a sense, the movement for the homeless is now marked by paradox.
On the one hand, more than a decade's work by advocates like Mr. Snyder and Mr. Hayes has attracted enormous attention to the problems of the displaced, whose numbers have been estimated at anywhere from 600,000 to three million. The advocates' work has established a vast network of shelters and enlisted the help of an army of student, professional and religious volunteers.
On the other hand, that showing of public support appears contradicted by the signs of a backlash among a larger public.
 
Less Money and Less Sympathy
Among these signs was a battle that Mr. Snyder lost last month in Washington, where the City Council voted to set limits on the right to shelter that it established in 1984. In May, Philadelphia cut $2 million from a program for the homeless, a reduction that officials said would mean the loss of 500 beds. And the day after Mr. Snyder was found hanged, the police in San Francisco began enforcing a ban on sleeping in public places, emptying out a plaza outside City Hall where up to 350 people had been living.
Even in Santa Monica, Calif., which has earned a reputation for generosity toward the homeless by feeding 300 people a day on the lawn outside City Hall, there is evidence of declining public support: After a homeless man stabbed an elderly woman there in March, a debate ensued over whether the city had been too generous.
Mr. Hayes said Friday that the movement had been at ''a pivotal moment'' even before Mr. Snyder's suicide, which he characterized as not only tragic but also ''lousy timing.''
Mr. Hayes, like other homeless advocates, described Mr. Snyder's death as an irreplaceable loss. ''It's going to hurt tremendously,'' Mr. Hayes said. ''Mitch was the dynamo.'' Need for New Tactics?
But others expressed confidence that the homeless movement was broad enough to be effective without him. And his detractors, including Stuart Butler of the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research center based in Washington, suggested that it might even benefit from an absence of his often confrontational tactics, which included prolonged public fasts, the setting up of ''Reagansville'' shacks in the public park across from the White House early in the Reagan Administration and the dousing of Government offices with blood.
In last month's interview, Mr. Snyder defended those tactics: ''You have to make people angry to make them think.''
He also agreed that the record of his movement had become one of success and setback, citing the one major piece of Federal legislation that the movement won in the 1980's. That law, the Stewart B. McKinney Homeless Assistance Act of 1987, named for the late Republican Congressman from Connecticut, was largely a result of Mr. Snyder's lobbying Jim Wright, then the Speaker of the House. But it provides only modest amounts of money and dedicates it primarily toward emergency relief rather than measures that would prevent homelessness.
 
The Importance of Housing
Among the issues that sometimes divide the movement's advocates is a debate over the causes of homelessness, in particular the impact of a loss of low-income housing in the last decade. Mr. Snyder often argued that the homeless were little different from other people, just poorer and less lucky, and that the main solution to their problems was to build more housing.
But other advocates, often with little publicity, have expressed frustration with that view. In an interview before Mr. Snyder's death, Sister Connie Driscoll, a nun who heads the Mayor's Task Force on Homelessness in Chicago, criticized Mr. Snyder and others for not emphasizing mental illness, drug abuse and a lack of personal responsiblity as causes of homelessness.
''That's all they do is keep screaming, 'Housing! Housing! Housing!' '' she said. ''Housing is only part of the problem.'' She added that Mr. Snyder ''has done more to damage the cause of homelessness than anyone I know.'' She declined to comment on Friday.
 
'Seriously Ill People'
Mr. Butler, director of domestic policy studies at the Heritage Foundation, argues that the apparent public backlash amounts to a rejection of the view of homelessness put forth by advocates like Mr. Snyder.
''I think it was a fundamentally flawed strategy to argue that the homeless are 'just like me and you,' '' he said. ''I think they should have argued from the start that these are seriously ill people.''
But Mr. Hayes said this debate was simply one of semantics. ''I'm the first to say that many people need more than housing,'' he said. ''But none of those other things - from substance-abuse treatment, to psychiatric care, to remedial education for kids - will work in the absence of housing.''
In addition to disagreements about the causes and solutions of homelessness, advocates have also fought over institutional authority. Earlier this year, members of Mr. Snyder's organization, the Community for Creative Non-Violence, complained to him that he had become too dominant in an organization intended to function by consensus. He pledged to step back and allow others more latitude.
 
Strife Among the Advocates
Several members of the organization also complained that its 1,400-bed shelter, to which Mr. Snyder had pointed as a nationwide model, had become plagued by widespread drug use. They won the expulsion of several resident employees who organization members said were promoting a drug trade there.
Mr. Hayes's organization has also been troubled by internal fights. A year ago, the director of the Washington office, Maria Foscarinis, split from the National Coalition to form her own organization, the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty. She has described the split as an unfriendly one resulting from quarrels with Mr. Hayes.
Since then, the National Coalition has had three different directors and is now searching for a fourth.
While infighting and setbacks are typically part of any movement, several experts cautioned that they tell only part of the story of the state of homeless advocacy. Stephen Burger, executive director of the International Union of Gospel Missions, said he had often disagreed with Mr. Snyder's tactics. But he credited him and other national advocates with placing the problem on the political map.
''I think he brought a great deal of attention to the problem,'' Mr. Burger said. ''The question is whether other people will pick it up.''
