HEADLINE: Summary of Action in New York Legislature's 213th Session

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 7

 BODY:
In a flurry of last-minute activity during the final days of its 213th Session, the New York State Legislature approved measures to create a children's health insurance program, to cap the fees that doctors may charge the elderly and to pump $420 million into New York's hospital system.
The Legislature also acted to raise workers compensation rates for the first time in five years and to allow private betting parlors to compete with the publicly controlled Off Track Betting network.
The state's 211 lawmakers, all of whom face re-election in November, recessed at 11:38 A.M. on July 2 and are expected to spend the rest of the summer campaigning.
Before leaving Albany, the Democratic-led Assembly approved 1,677 bills, the Republican-controlled Senate 1,758. Of those, 958 bills passed both houses. 
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has already signed 370 of these bills into law; over the next few weeks hundreds more will cross his desk.
The Legislature is unlikely to return to Albany before the Nov. 6 elections. But a post-election session to deal with transportation issues appears inevitable. A corporate surcharge that generates $300 million a year for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is to lapse on Dec. 31. If it is not renewed by the Legislature, transit fares will rise steeply.
These are the major actions of the session:
 
The Budget
The state's fiscal problems absorbed most of this year's legislative session. Attempting to close a budget gap that seemed to grow wider with each passing week, the Governor and the Legislature imposed the largest tax increase in state history, totaling $1.4 billion.
The Legislature did not approve a new budget until seven weeks after the legal deadline, a record-breaking delay. The $49.8 billion budget held increases in spending for many programs to a rate lower than that of inflation. Spending from the state's general fund, made up of most state tax revenues, increased by 1.5 percent, one of the lowest rises ever. Total state spending, including Federal grants, increased by 6 percent.
Although the budget provides funds for few new programs, it supplies money to construct 4,300 new prison beds and to create several new drug treatment centers, including eight centers designated for addicted mothers and their children.
In a historic move, the Governor and the Legislature also agreed to a plan to phase out the state's annual spring borrowing. The borrowing allowed the state to roll forward an accumulated deficit of almost $5 billion. Under the plan to phase it out, long-term bonds will be issued to pay off the deficit over the next 30 years.
 
Taxes and Fees
The largest tax and fee increase ever enacted by the State Legislature included these elements:
A delay in the income-tax reduction scheduled for the fall. The cut, which is intended to bring the state's top tax rate down to 7 percent from 7.875 percent, is now scheduled to begin next year and to be phased in slowly over the following three years.
A 15 percent surcharge on corporate tax payments.
An increase in the gross receipts tax on refiners and producers of petroleum products.
A two-cent-per container tax on nonrefillable soda bottles and cans.
A doubling of the excise tax on beer, to 12 cents a six pack.
An increase in the excise tax on hard liquor: for liquor over 48 proof to $1.70 a liter from $1.40, for liquor 48 proof or less to 67 cents a liter from 55 cents.
A five percent surtax on automobile rentals.
A five percent surtax on hotel rooms costing more than $100 a night.
An expansion of the state's sales tax to cover such services as parking, interior decorating and private detectives.
An increase in professional license fees, for doctors to $105 from $40 a year, for lawyers, to $150 from $50 a year.
The Legislature also approved, and the Governor signed, measures authorizing New York City to increase its income-tax rates, its mortgage recording tax and its hotel tax.
 
Health
LEGISLATION PASSED Would revise the state's health care reimbursement formula to pump $420 million into hospitals, create incentives for hospitals to expand outpatient care and establish a state-subsidized health insurance plan for poor children.
Would allow individuals to sign proxy statements appointing surrogates to make health care decisions on their behalf if they become incompetent to do so themselves.
Would cap the amount above federally approved Medicare reimbursement rates that doctors may charge the elderly.
Would reduce the cost, expand the eligiblity limits and simplify registration procedures for the state's prescription drug subsidy program for the elderly.
Would insure that donated organs are distributed fairly to transplant patients and would provide for the licensing of tissue banks.
Would expand insurance reimbursement for cancer drugs when prescribed for conditions other than those for which the drugs have been federally approved.
Would create a new licensing and certification board for acupuncturists.
LEGISLATION KILLED Would have banned the free distribution of cigarettes and banned cigarette vending machines except in bars and tobacco-related businesses.
Would have streamlined the physician discipline process by eliminating both the Board of Regents and the health commissioner from the decision-making chain.
Would have allowed dying patients to draw benefits from their life insurance policies while they are still alive.
Would have enabled the state to pay premiums for private medical insurance for poor AIDS patients who no longer work rather than paying for their Medicaid benefits.
Would have assisted the establishment of more communal housing for AIDS patients by increasing state payments to those who operate the homes.
 
Welfare and The Family
LEGISLATION SIGNED Requires government agencies to inform community officials about children's boarding homes proposed for their neighborhoods.
LEGISLATION PASSED Would establish guidelines bringing New York into conformity with the Federal welfare reform law passed in 1988, which provides for increased educational and training opportunities for young mothers.
Would allow parents to surrender their children for adoption without appearing in court, thus speeding the adoption process for children in foster care.
Would require that court-ordered child support payments for welfare recipients be automatically deducted from paychecks.
Would expand the state's Medicaid coverage to children under 6 years old to comply with a Federal mandate.
Would establish a registration system for day-care centers.
LEGISLATION KILLED Would have instituted a ''no-fault'' divorce law, allowing couples to divorce after an 18-month separation even if one spouse did not want the divorce.
Would have stopped the state from collecting the names and Social Security numbers of women who have had abortions or miscarriages.
Would have required parental notification when a minor seeks an abortion.
 
Energy and the Environment
LEGISLATION SIGNED Provides for a $1.9 billion environmental bond act to be placed on the ballot in November.
Restricts development on most of Manhattan's West Side waterfront from Battery Park City to 35th Street.
Requires an assessment of solid waste impact as part of an environmental impact statement.
Renews the tax exemption for residential solar and wind energy systems.
Increases the fuel efficiency requirements for state-owned automobiles to 29.5 miles per gallon from 27.5.
LEGISLATION PASSED Prohibits the use of packaging materials that contain levels of lead, cadmium, mercury or chromium that exceed specified limits.
Requires hazardous waste producers to put into effect plans to reduce the amount of waste they generate.
Requires the recycling of chlorofluorcarbons from automobile air-conditioners.
LEGISLATION KILLED Would have required companies that store, process or handle extremely hazardous substances to draw up ''risk management programs'' assessing the possibilities of chemical releases.
 
Criminal Justice
LEGISLATION SIGNED Makes it a criminal offense to possess an electronic stun gun.
LEGISLATION VETOED Would have reinstated the death penalty.
LEGISLATION PASSED Would allow houses and apartment buildings that are the site of drug dealing to be seized.
Reduces the burden of proof in cases of abuse against children younger than under 11.
Makes it a crime for a juror to enter into negotiations for a post-trial story.
Establishes regulations for labs that analyze genetic material for forensic purposes.
Requires a defense attorney to prove to a judge that information about a victim's sexual history is relevant before it may be introduced as evidence.
Makes it a class E felony to engage in the business of transmitting money without a license.
LEGISLATION KILLED Would have created a new crime of ''bias-related violence.''
Would have banned the sale of assault rifles.
Would have created a sentence of life without parole for certain murders.
 
Government
LEGISLATION SIGNED Gives the Legislature the final say in whether Staten Island could secede from New York City.
Gives journalists absolute protection from contempt, in both civil and criminal cases, for failing to disclose confidential information obtained and sources used in the course of news gathering.
Exempts native Americans who consider themselves citizens of a sovereign nation from taking an oath of loyalty to the United States Constitution when starting a government job.
LEGISLATION PASSED Would establish a series of measures to improve the financial and programmatic accountability of state-financed drug treatment programs to the Department of Substance Abuse Services.
LEGISLATION KILLED Would have given New Yorkers the right to force the Legislature to vote on issues of concern by collecting 250,000 signatures on petitions.
Would have prevented candidates from being thrown off ballots for trivial errors on their qualifying petitions.
Would have forced a number of elected officials, including the governor and legislators, to forfeit their salaries and per diem payments for each day that the state budget is not passed after April 1, when the fiscal year begins.
 
Education
LEGISLATION SIGNED Authorizes the New York City schools chancellor to transfer principals among schools.
Makes it illegal to pass a school bus on any school property when its red lights are flashing LEGISLATION PASSED Would create stricter state oversight of for-profit trade schools and give students at such schools expanded rights to tuition refunds.
Would abolish the Board of Examiners, which licenses teachers in New York City, and replace it with a new licensing division under the control of the city's schools chancellor.
Would extend a requirement that local school districts transport certain handicapped children to and from the nonpublic schools that they attend.
Would expand the allowable uses of absentee ballots in school board elections.
Would require colleges to provide information to students on sexual assault prevention.
Would increase financial aid and support services from the State Department of Education to local libraries.
LEGISLATION KILLED Would have altered the state education-aid formula to direct more money to New York City.
Would have eased the requirements for part-time college students to receive tuition assistance.
Would have authorized school districts to conduct fingerprinting and other background criminal checks on any employee.
 
Housing
LEGISLATION PASSED Would reduce the costs to tenants of certain capital improvements on their rent-controlled and rent-stabilized apartments by requiring landlords to extend the amortization period from five years to seven years.
LEGISLATION KILLED Would have reorganized the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, consolidating several finance agencies and creating a new position of state housing director.
Would have imposed a 15-year moratorium on the conversion to market-rate apartments of low- and moderate-rent units built under the state's Mitchell-Lama program.
Would have prohibited credit agencies or other organizations from sharing information about tenants who had lodged complaints against their landlords.
Would have required that aged and disabled tenants receive notification of eviction proceedings at least 90 days prior to the proposed termination date of the tenancy.
Would have required that residential leases be written in ''a clear and coherent manner using words with common and everyday meanings.''
 
Consumer Affairs
LEGISLATION SIGNED Expands the automobile ''lemon law'' to include any new car either purchased or registered in New York State.
Allows consumers to return a car deemed defective under the ''lemon law'' to a local dealer rather than having to transport it to the manufacturer's regional office.
Requires manufacturers to give a full refund or replacement of a motor home deemed defective under the state's ''lemon law.''
Prevents insurance companies from raising insurance rates in New York to recoup their losses in other states caused by across-the-board reductions mandated by referendum or other regulations.
Requires cable television companies to provide 30-day notification of any significant changes in programming.
Enacts a ''pet lemon law,'' allowing consumers to return a pet later found to be ill or malformed.
LEGISLATION PASSED Would prohibit retail merchants from writing down the credit card number of a customer on a personal check.
Would prohibit video rental outlets from disclosing video rental tape or sales records without a customer's approval.
Would expand the time warranty provisions for cars purchased under the used car ''lemon law'' to 90 days from 60 days for a car with less than 36,000 miles and to 60 days from 30 days for a car with more than 36,000 miles but less than 80,000.
Would increase amounts of automobile liability insurance drivers must carry on their policies to $25,000 from $10,000 for injury of one person and $50,000 from $20,000 to for injury of more than one person.
Would require expanded warranties on auto parts.
Would raise the cap on what health clubs may charge for annual memberships from $1,200 to $3,600.
Would require more frequent state inspection of indoor tanning salons and higher penalties for defective equipment.
Would require more frequent state testing and inspection of all bottled water products sold in New York State.
Would require manufacturers to offer verification for any advertising claims made about water-treatment devices for home faucets.
Would require travel promoters to provide prospective customers with a full disclosure of the prices and terms of travel arrangements.
LEGISLATION KILLED Would have given the consumer the right to cancel within three days any sales order placed over the telephone.
Would have transferred responsibility for auto insurance on rental cars from the rental company's policy to that of the person renting the car.
 
Labor And Business
LEGISLATION SIGNED Raises New York State's minimum wage for all workers to $3.80 an hour and to $4.25 an hour in April 1991 and forbids use of the federally approved sub-minimum, or ''training,'' wage.
LEGISLATION PASSED Would raise workers compensation benefits for the first time in five years, to a maximum of $350 a week in July 1991 and $400 a week in July 1992, and gradually eliminate the distinction that required lower rates for partially disabled workers.
Would provide expanded state grants and other assistance for New York companies seeking to export their products.
LEGISLATION KILLED Would have required the use of American-made steel in major construction projects unless the cost was unreasonable or the steel was not available in adequate quantity.
 
Transportation
LEGISLATION SIGNED Requires motorists to turn on their headlights whenever it rains or snows.
As part of an omnibus trucking bill, allows some wider trucks on New York State roads but also imposes new safety measures on trucks, including stiffer penalties for drunken-driving or safety-inspection violations and a ban on the use of radar detectors by truckers.
Gives the public a minimum of 30 minutes to speak on a topic on the agenda of a meeting of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
Increases fines for people who illegally park in handicapped parking spots.
LEGISLATION PASSED Would authorize New Yorkers to vote on a constitutional amendment repealing a prohibition against charging tolls along the Erie Canal although a similar vote is required in next year's legislative session before the measure may be put before the voters.
Would authorize the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to proceed with plans to install an automated fare-collecting system on New York City's subways and buses.
Allows design and engineering work for the fourth lane of a 12-mile section of the Long Island Expressway between Huntington and Hauppauge to proceed before an environmental impact statement has been completed.
Would create a Nassau County-wide parking violations bureau.
LEGISLATION KILLED Would have established a dedicated trust fund for highway and bridge repairs from existing highway, gasoline and other taxes.
Would have reduced the blood alcohol level for a driving-while-intoxicated conviction to .08 from .10 for all motorists and to .04 for those under 21 and would have allowed immediate on-site license suspension upon arrest on such a charge.
Would have raised the penalties for operation of a boat while drunk and would have required boat operators to submit to breath tests.
Would have permitted automobile registrants and holders of driver's licenses to request the Department of Motor Vehicles to keep their names and home addresses confidential.
Would have removed the New York State Thruway Authority's jurisdiction over the control of billboards within two miles of any exit on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway.
 
Agriculture
LEGISLATION PASSED Would prohibit the use of eminent domain for converting farmland into solid-waste sites.
Would authorize the commissioner of agriculture and markets to indemnify farmers whose poultry are ordered slaughtered because of exposure to salmonella poisoning.
Allows proceeds from the sales of beeswax and honey to be counted toward the $10,000 gross sales requirement for land classified as agricultural property.
LEGISLATION KILLED Would have established a ''dairy farmer's bill of rights,'' intended to provide protections against coercion by milk dealers.
Would have reduced the tax assessment on many farmlands to discourage sales of such property.
Would have created a special agricultural studies scholarship program for children of farm families, intended to encourage them to stay in agriculture.
 
Miscellaneous
LEGISLATION SIGNED Expands simulcasting of horse races, allows race tracks to operate their own teletheaters and telephone-betting lines and reopens Tioga Park Raceway near Binghamton.
LEGISLATION PASSED Would outlaw dwarf tossing and dwarf bowling in places where alcohol is served.
Would outlaw the use of vertebrate animals in school science experiments that cause pain, suffering or death to the animal.
Would outlaw the playing of ''boom'' radios in cars at high volumes.
Would designate the emerald green Empire spring mineral bottle of Saratoga as the official state bottle.
LEGISLATION KILLED Would have allowed alcohol to be sold in pool halls.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 15, 1990, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about bills adopted in the New York State Legislature misstated the status of one.
The bill, which would have made it illegal to use vertebrate animals in school science experiments that cause pain, was passed by the Assembly but killed in the Senate.

HEADLINE: Jill Dara Suttenberg to Wed in August

 BODY:
Mr. and Mrs. Stewart Suttenberg of Syosset, N.Y., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Jill Dara Suttenberg and David Matthew Altshuler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan A. Altshuler of Belmont, Mass. Miss Suttenberg, 24 years old, graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University. An associate at Corporate Decisions, a Boston management consulting firm, she is also a saxophonist and the director of the Sunday Jazz Band at Harvard. Her father is an engineering department manager at the Unisys Corporation in Lake Success, L.I. Her mother, Judye Suttenberg, is a division sales manager in the Plainview, L.I., office of World Book Childcraft International, an educational publishing company in Chicago.
Mr. Altshuler, 25, graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and is a candidate for a Ph.D. in genetics and an M.D. at the Harvard Medical School. His mother is an academic program officer for the Massachusetts Board of Regents of Higher Education in Boston. His father is the Ruth and Frank Stanton Professor of urban policy and planning at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government and Graduate School of Design.

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Bennington College;
Trying to Shake Off 'Anything Goes' Image

DATELINE: BENNINGTON, Vt.

 BODY:
Long known for its free-spirited environment, Bennington College is trying to shake off the image that, in the words of one administrator, ''anything goes here.''
Recent disruptive events at this more liberal of liberal arts colleges have prompted students, faculty members and administrators to think seriously again about codes of conduct and to enforce them.
Last fall, students in one dormitory were redistributed to other dorms after the students held an ''immorality party'' during a parents' weekend. The party included the crucifixion of a dead oppossum. Last month, a tenured drama professor was discharged after a board of students and faculty and staff members found that he had violated sexual-harassment guidelines. 
The teacher, Leroy Logan, has denied the allegations, and has filed an appeal of the decision with the college president.
 
'Tolerance Is Not a License'
This was the second time in 20 years that a faculty member had been dismissed for sexual harassment at Bennington, where roughly 600 students come each year to study in an environment free of grades and other traditional measures of performance.
Many in this close-knit community see a need to set explicit codes of behavior. But some worry that the college's valued tradition of tolerance may be endangered.
The college's president, Elizabeth Coleman, insists that while the community will continue to strive to break academic conventions, it should also acknowledge the responsibilities that come with freedom.
''Tolerance is not license,'' Dr. Coleman said. ''The challenge is how to make that clear without compromising spontaneity.''
Dr. Coleman and the community have several other challenges ahead. Administrators, faculty members and students are reviewing the school's curriculum, while admissions guidelines have been reorganized to include a second high school teacher recommendation. In addition, the college is about to embark on a $30 million capital campaign drive to expand the library and to start the first substantial endowment at the college since it was founded in 1932.
Dr. Coleman and other college officials declined to comment on the details of last month's sexual-harassment case.
 
Money Problems Fade
People from all sectors of the college say the dismissal and other events of the last year are signs of a renewed emphasis on defining and enforcing codes of conduct at the school, as well as of a sharper focus on educational priorities.
Dr. Coleman said the initiatives have become possible only since the college emerged from a financial crisis in the early 1980's.
''For years, all Bennington talked about was money,'' Dr. Coleman said. ''Despite its brilliant history and its brilliant pedagogy, the college has been strangely inarticulate about the educational experience it offers.''
Joan Goodrich, the director of student affairs, said the perception that ''anything goes'' at Bennington is no longer accurate. Until about three years ago - shortly before Dr. Coleman became president - Ms. Goodrich said, the school's disciplinary guidelines for both students and faculty members were ill-defined and inefficient.
''We were unable to function internally because our procedures were faulty,'' Ms. Goodrich said. ''Rules and Bennington didn't seem to go together.''
Now, she said, the school is evolving. ''We're readdressing the values that Bennington was about to begin with.''
 
Sex-Harassment Complaint
The interim sexual-harassment policy was put in place in September 1989. Work on the policy began a year earlier, but the process was speeded up after a female student, who said she was frustrated with existing procedures, took a complaint of sexual harassment to the Vermont Human Rights Commission.
That matter was settled with no finding of liability, though the woman received $4,000 from the college as part of the settlement and the college agreed to adopt comprehensive sexual-harassment guidelines.
''They told us we had to get our act together,'' Dr. Coleman said. A final version of the sexual-harassment policy was adopted last month.
The policy sets forth a three-tier system of response to harassment allegations. Possible responses include informal counseling and mediation by a senior college official. Both of those actions may be bypassed in favor of a formal complaint and inquiry. Any action may be appealed to the president, whose decision is final.
Not everyone at the college is happy with the new guidelines. Some students and faculty members are concerned that the rules have altered what they describe as a special student-mentor relationship at the college.
''The students are almost apprentices to you,'' said William Dixon, who has taught in Bennington's music department for 22 years. ''We know them both as students and as people, but now I think the tendency would be to back off from being that kind of teacher for fear of repercussions.''
Others, however, applaud the effort to define norms of behavior. ''A student has to be able to say, 'Whether you mean it or not, you're making me uncomfortable,' '' said Lillia Mead, a junior from New York City who studies dance and psychology.
 
'Immorality Party'
The movement toward disciplinary enforcement is not confined to sexual relations. Ms. Goodrich said that in recent years the college has tried to combat the perception on and off campus that destructive behavior is acceptable here.
To accomplish that goal, the judicial committee was revamped in 1987 to include faculty and staff members as well as students. Before then the committee comprised only students.
''If I had a complaint, the students took the whole system completely as a joke because the committee was made up of their friends,'' Ms. Goodrich said.
The newly constituted committee went through a baptism by fire last fall after the administration began a series of discussions on student behavior.
A group of students took exception to the tenor of the discussions, and in protest threw an ''immorality party'' during parents' weekend. The students who were involved vandalized their dormitories and scrawled antiadministration graffiti on the walls.
When dormitory members refused to single out particular students for blame, the committee recommended disbanding the entire dormitory. The administration agreed.
''The entire school spent too much time talking about students who had sabotaged their own rights,'' said Michelle Bogin, a senior literature major from New York City. ''We have to remember that we're really here for the education.''

HEADLINE: FILM;
Etienne Chatiliez Fishes His 'River' For Clues to Life

BYLINE: By DONALD CHASE; Donald Chase is the author of ''Filmmaking: The Collaborative Art'' (Little, Brown).

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Etienne Chatiliez is the big noise these days in popular French cinema. In 1988, after directing some 70 television commercials notable both for their humor and their against-the-techno-glitz-grain narrative qualities, he made a resounding leap into feature film with ''Life Is a Long Quiet River,'' which opens in New York on Friday at the Paris Theater.
A mordant social comedy about the collision of two families of vastly different classes and values, the ironically titled ''River'' became the most-seen and most-discussed French film of its year. It even gave such an American blockbuster as ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit'' a run for its francs. Then, earlier this year, the 38-year-old Mr. Chatiliez adroitly sidestepped a sophomore slump with ''Tatie Danielle,'' a ''Driving Miss Daisy'' antidote whose seniorcitoyenne heroine copes with old age through a calculated, often hilarious misanthropy. (Miramax will release the film in the United States early next year.) So, why, over late-morning toast and tea in the sunny kitchen of his sprawling Right Bank apartment, is the lanky, dark-blond director a tad grumpy? 
It turns out that one mark of his success is membership on the board of the French governmental organization that supplied about 15 percent of the production budget of ''River.'' This requires Mr. Chatiliez to read screenplays submitted for subsidies by other writer-directors. And because he wants to give as well as he got, he says he goes each afternoon ''to the park with two scenarios, resolving not to leave until I've read them carefully. And then, suddenly, it's 5 o'clock - the day's gone.''
Mr. Chatiliez's penchant for dispensing equal justice comes as no surprise to anyone who has seen his (and co-screenwriter Florence Quentin's) satirical skewering of both the families on which ''Life Is a Long Quiet River'' centers.
One, the Le Quesnoys, leads an almost insanely regulated haut-bourgeois existence centered around work (the executive-type father); home (the maid-assisted, charity-minded mother); school and church (the five robotlike children, each undergoing a traditional Roman Catholic education) and healthy family outings (canoeing is the sport of the moment).
In contrast, the Groseilles live on the margins of society, in a chaos compounded of unemployment (the father); fads and fancies (astrology and hair coloring on the mother's part); and truancy and petty theft (the six unruly children).
The two families are brought together by a plot device: the put-upon mistress-nurse of an obstetrician reveals that 12 years earlier she switched the nametags on the Le Quesnoy and Groseille babies born within minutes of each other. The right-thinking Le Quesnoys pay to ''adopt'' their Groseille-reared son (who has most of the bad habits of his environment). At the same time, they try to keep from the Groseille girl they've raised (and to whom they've passed on most of their prejudices) the secret of her lowly birth.
''The idea with the Groseilles was to have people acting more like animals than human beings,'' Mr. Chatiliez says. ''They're not showing that they love each other. They don't have to show that they love each other - it doesn't matter.
''And the other family is totally the contrary. They had to be so careful with each other: 'You're so cute; you're so nice' - all day long. But it doesn't prove anything. And that was the idea. Between the people who don't show and people who show affection - where is the truth?''
Not, on the evidence of the film, in any meaningful exchange of values or life styles between the two families. ''I don't think that the Le Quesnoys learned one thing, except maybe that life isn't as pretty as they thought it was,'' Mr. Chatiliez remarks. ''And the Groseilles only found'' - through their exploitation of the Le Quesnoys - ''another way to make money without working for it.'' But the director says that it was not his and Miss Quentin's intention to judge or propose solutions.
''We only wanted to show what we had seen around us,'' he elaborates, ''and to laugh because we don't like to cry at something when you can laugh. But I don't think that a movie can change things.'' This apparent pessimism could stem from the fact that in all the considerable public and private discussion that ''River'' inspired in France, Mr. Chatiliez says, ''Everybody was talking about people like the Groseilles and the Le Quesnoys, but it was always the guys next door. It was like talking about people who drink and drive - you're never the one.''
If the film also prompted debate on the general question of nature vs. nurture, this was in line with the most serious intention the director will admit to. ''It was a way to say: Maybe you're blood, but maybe you're education, too. If you were to be separated from your natural family and brought up by another one, you wouldn't be the same person.''
As for Mr. Chatiliez's own education, it ended with the completion of his studies at a public high school, rather early for someone who was ''part of a bourgeois family from the north of France.'' In fact, ''River'' was shot in the Lille area, about 130 miles north-northeast of Paris, not far from the director's birthplace. ''But,'' he says, ''we were not at all like the Le Quesnoys, not at all. My parents had education and culture, but they were not rigid; they let me do whatever I wanted.'' What he wanted was to go, at age 18, to Paris, where he worked in advertising for 10 years, mostly as a copywriter, before beginning to direct commercials. ''No, the Le Quesnoys come from other people I met when I was young, from details that stay in your mind as if it were a bank.''
The Groseilles, in turn, were inspired by ''someone vaguely an actress'' whom Mr. Chatiliez had directed in a commercial. ''She would come to the set with two or three of her children, who would steal everything in sight.'' She also had a husband just released from prison - exactly the situation of the oldest Groseille son.
For Mr. Chatiliez, one pleasure of movie making is working with actors, and he considers himself fortunate to have begun his feature career working with a large number of debutant juvenile actors. ''They are who they are,'' he says. ''They're not 'acting'; they're just playing. It was a relief to me, because doing your first film with Catherine Deneuve and Gerard Depardieu, you're not on the same level; you're scared. With kids nobody knew anything.''
Feeling ready now for Miss Deneuve and Mr. Depardieu after directing the venerable stage actress Tsilla Chelton in the title role of ''Tatie Danielle,'' Mr. Chatiliez also mentions some Americans he particularly admires: Robert De Niro, Richard Dreyfuss, Meryl Streep, Laura Dern and Sally Kellerman. But having had daunting experiences directing American commercials, on which he was asked to be ''just a technician,'' he has little desire to work for a Hollywood studio. (Walt Disney Studios is, in fact, planning an Americanized remake of ''River,'' in which Mr. Chatiliez is not participating.) ''I'm talking in my films about myself,'' he says, ''about what I see and know. I'm talking about society, about what's happening today in France. So I think I'd like to stay here.''

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Presenting the Bolshoi: It's a Long Way From Sol Hurok

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
When it opens on Tuesday at the New York State Theater, the Bolshoi Ballet will not look too different from the way it did on recent visits. During the two-week engagement, the company will present a familiar quota of full-evening classics and spectacles - from ''Swan Lake'' and ''Romeo and Juliet'' to ''Ivan the Terrible,'' a modern-day signature work by Yuri Grigorovich, director and chief choreographer of the Moscow troupe for the last 26 years.
In addition, there will be a program of short works and excerpts drawn from a repertory that includes ''Petrushka,'' ''La Sylphide,'' ''Le Corsaire,'' ''Don Quixote'' and ''Paquita,'' as well as Mr. Grigorovich's ''Spartacus'' and ''Golden Age.'' Although Irek Mukhamedov, the Bolshoi star who recently left Moscow to join England's Royal Ballet, will not be performing with the company here, Americans will have their first look at three new Russian male stars - Gedeminas Taranda, Yuri Kletsov and Mark Peretokin. Leading the company of 120 dancers will be Lyudmila Semenyaka, Aleksei Fadeyechev, Nina Semizorova and Nina Ananiashvili.
But there are significant - and controversial - differences, which are in large measure the product of perestroika, the restructuring of Soviet society and its economy. This year, the Bolshoi is being presented by a new team: the Entertainment Corporation USA and James M. Nederlander, the Broadway producer. 
Founded in 1982 by Peter Brightman and Victoria Charlton, the London-based Entertainment Corporation Group has moved in on the Soviet performing arts. The English husband-and-wife producing team quickly began to bring Russian attractions to Britain, and in 1988 started negotiations with Soviet authorities to bring the Bolshoi Ballet to the United States.
The Metropolitan Opera, which last presented the Bolshoi in New York, lost out to the Entertainment Corporation primarily because it could not offer as extensive a tour as the British firm, according to Charles Dillingham, former executive director of American Ballet Theater and president of Entertainment Corporation USA, the British organization's New York arm. After the New York engagement, the seven-city tour will continue with performances at the Filene Center/Wolftrap Farm Park in Vienna, Va. (July 24-29), the Arie Crown Theater in Chicago (Aug. 1-5), the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles (Aug. 7-9), the Civic Theater in San Diego (Aug. 21-24), Blaisdell Arena in Honolulu (Aug. 29-Sept. 2) and the Wang Center in Boston (Sept. 6-9).
But the Entertainment Corporation also offered something extra: a business partnership with the Bolshoi, as well as the Kirov Ballet of Leningrad, that has raised cries of commercialism here and in the Soviet Union. Under the terms of exclusive six-year agreements with the Bolshoi and the Kirov, and Gosconcert, the Soviet State Artists Agency, the Entertainment Corporation will copyright the Bolshoi and Kirov names, develop international corporate sponsorships and license and market products bearing the dance companies' names. The troupes also plan to endorse products.
Gosconcert and the two ballet companies will receive 60 percent of all profits, with the rest going to the Entertainment Corporation.
''We have now spent well over a half million on development capital to register and protect the names,'' Mr. Dillingham said in a recent interview in his office near Lincoln Center. The Entertainment Corporation and the Nederlander Organization will split profits from the tour, the cost of which Mr. Dillingham describes as ''in excess of $10 million,'' with a fee that Mr. Dillingham would only term ''substantial'' going to the Bolshoi Ballet.
Not everyone is happy with this new step into the future. The agreements helped to stir a recent one-day hunger strike in Moscow by six Bolshoi artists, led by Yuri Grigoryev, a singer with the Bolshoi Opera, in response to what Mr. Grigoryev labeled ''an atmosphere of money making'' at the Bolshoi.
Mr. Dillingham said: ''Grigoryev is a singer in the opera, a tenor in the chorus, but what he really is is the head of the Communist Party at the Bolshoi Theater. It's very hard for Americans to understand how the party had this apparatus in every institution in the country. Under perestroika, this man is losing his power. They don't listen to him anymore. So, he is seizing every opportunity he can to attack management, because the ground is shifting under his feet.
''One example of that is that his contract has not been renewed. Under the old, pre-perestroika conditions, this would have been unheard of. He could have sung until he was 90. And, of course, he's got people in his group, party members, who are clinging to the old levers of power.''
Mr. Dillingham described the strike as a protest not only against Mr. Grigorovich, but against Vladimir Kokonin, the administrative head of the entire Bolshoi theater, and Aleksandr Lazarev, the artistic director and chief conductor of the Bolshoi Opera.
But New Yorkers have also been complaining about commercialization of the company. Ticket prices, which range from $25 to $105, are the highest that have ever been charged for a ballet presentation in New York City. Comparably, the New York City Ballet charges from $6 to $46. Ticket prices for the Australian Ballet, which opens at the Metropolitan on July 23 for a week, range from $11 to $85. ''Ticket prices will not be as high on the rest of the tour,'' Mr. Dillingham said. ''The State Theater is a thousand seats less than the smallest theater elsewhere on the tour. Even at these prices we will just break even. I know it's a high prices, though translated into pounds it is about the same as charged in London. It is a higher price than people are used to paying here. We agonized over it and finally decided we had to at least break even.''
Mr. Dillingham pointed out that the tour expenses entail hotel accommodations and travel that must be arranged for 165 people. ''There is an orchestra of 80 in each city,'' he said. ''The Bolshoi doesn't travel with an orchestra, so we have to re-rehearse in each city. The company has a big repertory, lots of scenery and huge backstage costs.'' Neither Mr. Dillingham nor Mr. Nederlander would discuss their projected profits from the tour.
Yet, according to Mr. Dillingham, it has become less cumbersome to present Soviet performing arts companies today. The 1959 engagement of the Bolshoi Ballet in New York, its first in America, was the result of 30 years of negotiating between the impresario Sol Hurok and the Soviet authorities.
''It would be very easy to say that it was easier in the old days, when you just went to Gosconcert and made a deal and came away,'' Mr. Dillingham said. ''But no one really wants to go back to that. Under perestroika, the companies and artists are much freer. There is much more of a Western atmosphere, more competition. That's what we have been trying to teach the Russians about, and they're learning very quickly. It is a vast change, and for the better.''
Dealing with Soviet authorities has, in most instances, also become more efficient. ''An example,'' Mr. Dillingham said, ''is that once the contract was signed with Gosconcert in 1988, we were basically free to arrange everything with the company, such as repertory and theaters. Instead of having to go through a bureaucrat and Gosconcert for answers, we can go to the company director through Telex. As the Russians are now dealing with management all over the world, they're learning much more about how the West does business, organizes, communicates in general.''
Ballet, Mr. Dillingham continues, has had to become a business in the United States to survive. ''You see that with the troubles that some of the companies, like Dance Theater of Harlem, are having. And I don't think they're the fault of the company. Business, the corporations, are bailing them out.''
''But a similar situation confronts the Bolshoi and the Kirov. Under perestroika, the essence of the economic restructuring is to reduce Government subsidy of enterprises. The two companies must earn more of their income from tours abroad.'' Mr. Dillingham said that every major performing company in the world, including the Royal Ballet and the Royal Danish Ballet, has told him that their governments are trying to reduce subsidies and encouraging them to tour. ''Not that there will be no subsidy, but less,'' he said. ''So, companies are touring more and raising their fees, all over the world. Hard currency is hard currency.''

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
An Architecture That Set Out to Shake the World

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger

 BODY:
It is convenient to forget that for a brief moment in the 20th century, the Soviet Union was a throbbing center of modern art and architecture, perhaps even the most advanced country of all in terms of its official level of taste. Modernism was not born there, but it could well be said to have reached its fastest, and in some ways its most promising, flowering in the Soviet Union. Where else, after all, could modernism's utopian, socialist leanings be in such perfect sync with everything going on in the realm of politics? Art as revolution, revolution as art: in the late teens and through the 1920's, art and revolution were as one, the new art the perfect embodiment of the new world the Leninists were making. 
It did not happen that way, of course, and therein lies a tale that tells us far more about the nature of politics than about the nature of art. Ultimately, as the Soviet Union grew less radical and more repressive, as its utopian dreams turned into dictatorship, so, too, did its willingness to let modern art be its symbol. In the 1930's the country went from celebrating modern art to condemning it - abstraction was purged as surely as a Stalinist enemy, and a clunky, heavy-handed historicism, euphemistically named social realism, took over as the official style. The purge, at least in architecture, was so complete that most standard histories, even in the West, dismiss Russian modernism with a couple of lines: it is as if all of this had hardly happened at all.
''Architectural Drawings of the Russian Avant-Garde,'' which opened late last month at the Museum of Modern Art, where it will remain through Sept. 4, tries to right the balance. This handsome exhibition of roughly 150 drawings comes from the A. V. Shchusev State Research Museum of Architecture in Moscow, the major archive of Russian avant-garde architectural material, and it marks the first time that any of these pieces have been shown in the United States.
That alone justifies a trip to the Modern: No one can walk through the first-floor galleries and ever again think that Russian architecture went from onion domes to Stalinist towers in a single leap. Here before us are three roomfuls of stunning evidence that a rich and fertile period lay in between - a period whose legacy is admittedly more a matter of drawings than of actual buildings, given that Russia in the 1920's was longer on imagination than on economic strength or technical expertise. (Stuart Wrede, the Modern's director of architecture and design, makes the telling observation in the exhibition catalogue that ''perhaps, as in the case of the Futurists in Italy, the country's technological backwardness was liberating.'') But if ''Architectural Drawings of the Russian Avant-Garde'' is laden with impressive drawings, this is hardly the exhibition on the architecture itself that we have been waiting for, or on Russian modernism in a broader way, or on the complex and intriguing relationship of this whole tradition to the architecture of today.
For by limiting the exhibition to the drawings borrowed from the Shchusev Museum, the Modern and Mr. Wrede have chosen to cast their net narrowly - so narrowly that they have not even included several closely related objects from the museum's own collections. Thus the museum's works by Kasimir Malevich, the artist who was a major influence on Russian avant-garde architecture, as well as the museum's exquisite model for Le Corbusier's proposed Palace of the Soviets, are conspicuously absent from this exhibition, even though they would have broadened its scope and deepened its meaning considerably. (In a kind of grudging acknowledgment of their importance, however, these objects have been set apart in the museum's architecture and design galleries on the fourth floor, three floors away from the main exhibition.) So we are left with a main event that, if visually potent, is strangely narrow in scope. I don't mean to make so much of this, but it was an odd curatorial decision to show the drawings from the Shchusev collection in a kind of vacuum, given how much there is to say about the connections between Russian avant-garde art and architecture. And it becomes even stranger still when you consider the close ties between all of this architecture and the Deconstructivist style that the Museum of Modern Art itself proclaimed to be the mode of the hour just two years ago. For Russian avant-garde architecture is what primarily inspired Deconstructivism; the name of this trendy style of our day is even a play on Constructivism, the school within the Russian avant-garde that emphasized clarity of structure. Is it that the Modern, having made such a fetish of the child two years ago, now wants to disown the connection between Deconstructivism and its much more interesting parent?
Only Mr. Wrede knows, and he does not say. If his intent was to let these drawings from Russia speak for themselves, however, this exhibition does that well. Even without the broader context that would enrich them, the drawings tell a story, and it is a remarkable one, a tale of the gradual eclipse of architectural vision by bureaucratic philistinism.
How passionately the Russian avant-garde architects believed in the ability of architecture to remake the world! And how decisively was their quest destroyed by a government that, the more repressive it became, the more determined it was to stifle modernism. Never has there been a clearer demonstration of the extent to which modernism represented a kind of intellectual freedom, a freedom intolerable to a dictatorial regime - except, of course, in Nazi Germany, where the same tragic drama was playing itself out, with the same poignancy.
It is easy, but facile, to conclude from all of this that the connection between modernism and an open society is a complete and natural one, and that wherever freedom flourishes, modernism does as well. It's not nearly so simple, of course, as the recent architectural history of this country makes clear. Modernism did flourish in the United States after World War II, but less as a symbol of revolution than as its very opposite, as a symbol of the corporate state.
Indeed, the irony of American architectural history is that modernism here came to represent not utopian, socialist yearnings but corporate power in the form of the glass skyscraper. In the last decade American architecture has returned to classicism, but this only compounds the irony. For in this country, the move back toward classicism represents not a movement toward repression, as it did in the Soviet Union, but a search for greater breadth of expression than the corporate modernist style permitted.
It would have been gratifying to see some of these issues addressed in the Modern show. But let me conclude with the drawings themselves, and a few of the most compelling images. There are several extraordinary drawings here: the rendering of Griguri and Mikhail Barkhin's crisp, lithe building of 1927 for Izvestia, one of the few works of Russian avant-garde architecture that was actually built; the projects by Alexander and Viktor Vesnin and by Konstantin Melnikov for Pravda (why is it that newspapers were such eager clients of these architects?); Alexander Gegello's office for the Anglo-Russia Trading Company, which suggests the projects of Ricardo Bofill; and Vladimir Fidman, Danill Fridman and Dmitri Markov's Lenin State Public Library, a huge and spectacular ink rendering for a sleek modernist composition of floating planes and masses that, had it been built, would have been one of the major modern civic buildings of the world.
The exhibition shows us the gradual decline from ambitious works like these, most of which were done in the 1920's, to the heavier, overbearing designs of the 1930's. Classicism - called, in one wonderful phrase of officialspeak, ''critical assimilation'' - crept in, killing this architecture bit by bit, like a virus. There are a few exceptions, such as the remarkable proposal of 1934 for the Commissariat of Heavy Industry by Ivan Leonidov, a multi-towered Constructivist extravaganza that seems to foreshadow every architect from Cesar Pelli and Helmut Jahn to Kenzo Tange and Norman Foster. But in general the pieces get more and more heavy-handed, culminating in Vladimir Gelfreikh, Boris Iofan and Vladimir Shchuko's Palace of Soviets scheme of 1934, a bloated skyscraper-temple topped by a grotesque 25-story statue of Lenin, the whole thing a deadening classical pile worthy of Albert Speer.

HEADLINE: ANTIQUES;
A Collector Of the Unusual: Korean Ceramics

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Many art and antiques dealers began as collectors, exploring the offbeat areas that others overlook. This was the case of Keum Ja Kang, a Korean newspaper photographer who came to the United States in 1963 on an assignment and decided to stay. After she completed graduate studies in Far Eastern art at Columbia University in 1975, Mrs. Kang started collecting in a field then considered rarefied but which is now gaining an enthusiastic following among museum curators and collectors: Korean art and antiques.
A dealer since 1981, Mrs. Kang stocks Korean artifacts dating from the third century B.C. to the 20th century at the Kang Collection gallery, open by appointment, in Mrs. Kang's home at 250 West 90th Street in Manhattan. The gallery's selection is predominately ancient ceramic vessels, though it includes stone sculpture, painted screens and century-old chests. What is particularly appealing to today's collectors, especially of ceramics, are the prices, which are far lower than those for Chinese and Japanese objects of the same periods. 
''Right after my graduation from Columbia I began collecting like mad,'' Mrs. Kang said. ''To me the strong forms of ancient Korean earthenware pots are fascinating. There is endless variety and many animal-shaped containers. I have not seen any other pottery in the world that has so many forms. The plainness of the surfaces also attracts me. Except for some scratches and stamped designs, they are virtually undecorated.''
Mrs. Kang was initially frustrated in her search for Korean antiquities and art because neither was handled in the 1970's by most of New York's Oriental art dealers. Books on the subject were also scarce, as she discovered while doing research for her master's thesis, which focused on Korea's Three Kingdoms period, from A.D. 313 to 668, a high point in the development of the country's ceramics. Many of the robust vessels filling the shelves and table tops in Mrs. Kang's gallery were produced in this period.
Most of these were made as ceremonial works for tombs - jars the size of basketballs, bowls on pedestals with triangular cutouts in the bases. One 26-inch-tall gray stoneware piece from the Kaya Kingdom glows with red and orange patches of color and is exuberantly shaped with a narrow neck, flared mouth and pointed base. ''This would have been set in the earth to stand upright,'' Mrs. Kang explained. The price: $11,000.
The form most identified with ancient Korean ceramics - the pedestal-based bowl fired as one piece - is represented by a handsomely proportioned example from the fifth century, painted on the outside with rows of crosshatching, calligraphic loops and triangles. It sells for $2,500.
Another Kaya vessel, a 13-inch-tall gray stoneware jar, is a triumph of understated decoration, incised from its gently flared mouth to its rounded base with finely drawn horizontal and vertical lines. The surface appears to be decorated with wide bands of an apricot glaze. But, Mrs. Kang explained, ''the apricot color is mud from centuries of being buried in the earth. If you would really wash it, the color would disappear.'' Its price is $6,500.
One the earliest objects on display is an oval-shaped sand-colored clay jar, with two sturdy handles and a flared mouth. The 16-inch-tall roughly textured vessel is a relic of the early Iron Age from the third century B.C. The price is $4,500. A group of smaller pots, four to six inches tall - from the third to fifth centuries of the Kaya Kingdom and fifth and sixth centuries of the Silla Kingdom - are priced from $250 to $950.
Ceramics of this quality were hard to find when Mrs. Kang began collecting in the 1970's. The challenge spurred her to return home. ''In 1978 I said every day to my husband, 'Let's go back and live for a while in Korea,' '' she recalled. Mrs. Kang and husband, Byung Kang, an engineer, gave up their work - Mrs. Kang was then a freelance photographic retoucher - and moved with their two young sons to Seoul.
On their return to New York in 1981, Mrs. Kang was laden with the fruits of her collecting in Korea. She opened her gallery on Fifth Avenue across from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, certain that Korean art would be in demand because of the exhibition ''5,000 Years of Korean Art Treasures,'' which traveled to the Met in 1981.
Despite public interest in the exhibition, Mrs. Kang said, strong demand never materialized, although museum curators began to stop by and several bought a piece or two. (Mrs. Kang has sold ceramics to the Metropolitan Museum, the Cleveland Museum of Art, the Brooklyn Museum, the Seattle Museum, the Worcester, Mass., Art Museum and the Freer Gallery of Art in Washington.) Mrs. Kang moved to her present gallery in 1987, convinced that another exhibition, ''From the Land of Morning Calm: Korean Art at the Brooklyn Museum,'' which ran from October 1987 to January 1988, would spur collecting.
''My gallery opening was in October after the stock market collapsed,'' she said. ''For six months nobody came. But with the 1988 Olympics and Korea's economic boom, American museums began to feel they needed some pieces of Korean art.''
Mrs. Kang still buys most of her pieces in Korea, where ceramic antiquities are increasingly difficult to find. The earthenware tomb vessels she favors were discovered in the 1960's when major highways were under construction. ''Very little is left from the tombs uncovered then,'' she said.
But she is not discouraged by the dwindling supply. What does come to the market is now sought by Korean, Japanese and American collectors and museums, and prices are escalating. ''If the prices continue to go up, more pieces will come into the market,'' she said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
One Germany, United by Dreams of Cars and Color TV's
 
The last time anyone decided to rejoin a unified German government peacefully and voluntarily was in 1935, when the Saar region held a plebiscite. Ever since, Germany's neighbors have viewed its consolidation, or expansion, with alarm. But two German economies became one last Sunday with scarcely a protest from the surrounding nations. Instead of exhibiting nationalistic pomp, East Germans flashed their West German marks. In Berlin's Alexanderplatz, fireworks, not firepower, were on display.The major parade was straight to the shops. Until a year ago, many East and West Germans were reluctant to so much as talk about unity for fear of upsetting their respective allies. True, other West Europeans are worried about a united Germany's economic might. And some East Europeans say they can't stand the sight of haughty German investors, no matter how much aid they bring. But a nation forged by Bismarck with blood and iron has been restored with the prospect of cars and color televisions for all. 
 
Lambada: Royalties at Stake
 
French and American pop-culture merchants have discovered that the Lambada is even trickier than it looks. The French society of composers decided last week that the Lambada, supposedly Brazilian, had its roots in Bolivia. The society confirmed that the brothers Gonzalo and Ulises Hermosa of Bolivia had written the original melody, ''Llorando Se Fue,'' or ''He Left Crying.'' With the addition of a new title, a groin-grinding dance and high-volume hype, it re-emerged as the song ''Lambada.'' The French bought Lambada records by the millions, and the Bolivians sued for their share of the royalties; the French press reports an out-of-court settlement. In the United States, movie makers who tried following the steps immediately tripped and dropped their audiences. ''Lambada,'' released by Warner Brothers, and ''The Forbidden Dance,'' released by Columbia Pictures, played to savage reviews and nearly empty theaters.
 
Eastern Europe, Soviet Trade
 
Eastern Europe might need every mark, dollar and pound it can get to offset the possible loss of favorable Soviet trade deals. The Group of 24 industrial nations, formed to coordinate aid to Eastern Europe, decided last week to extend help to Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, East Germany and Yugoslavia. It has already pledged $14 billion for Hungary and Poland.. But the Soviet Union plans to require payment in hard currency next year for the its energy exports to Eastern Europe. Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, estimates the cost to Eastern Europe at $10 billion to $12 billion. ''These countries are still in a very precarious position,'' he said.
 
Brazil Lowers the Barriers
 
Brazil came out last week as an unlikely friend of free trade. Zelia Cardoso de Mello, Minister of the Economy, said that computers, cars and raw materials will soon be able to enter tariff-free. Brazil has long regarded boatloads of foreign goods with the enmity most countries reserve for ships carrying hostile troops. Now, with anti-inflation plans faltering, the Government is counting on imports to keep prices down. ''It's obviously a desperation move,'' said Lance Taylor, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
 
COMPANIES
A Drug to Restore Youth?
 
A drug that can bring youthful vigor to the elderly, and to some pharmaceutical stocks as well? Researchers reported last week that a genetically engineered form of human growth hormone can reverse many of the effects of aging. After six months of hormone injections, 21 men lost fat, gained muscle, augmented their kidney and heart functions and regained thicker, younger-looking skin. The hormone, naturally available only in minute quantities, is produced genetically by Eli Lilly & Company and Genentech Inc. Researchers warned that the long-term effects of the growth hormone are unknown. As for the short-term effect on investors, on Thursday they made Lilly and Genentech the only two of the 15 most active Big Board stocks to gain. Both added fractions on Friday.
 
Fidelity Takes On More
 
Fidelity Investments has reached out to grab more business from the brokerage houses. Fidelity agreed last week to sell the popular John Nuveen & Company unit investment trusts, or fixed portfolios of municipal bonds. The trusts, with sales charges averaging 4.9 percent, have usually been sold through banks and retail brokers. Fidelity is best-known as the nation's largest manager of mutual funds, most with low sales charges or none, and most sold directly to investors. But Fidelity already has its own discount brokerage and a line of mutual funds with higher sales charges that are marketed through retail brokers. For Fidelity, a competitor can also be an ally.
 
British Order for Boeing
 
British Airways P.L.C. placed an order on Friday for as many as 33 Boeing 747-400 jumbo jets, worth as much as $6.9 billion. Lord King, the British Airways chairman, said his company has the option to convert its order to even larger 747's, should Boeing build them, carrying as many as 600 passengers. Boeing says no decision has been made to introduce larger planes.
 
Forstmann's Buyouts
 
Talks like Trump, buys like Scrooge: Last week, Theodore J. Forstmann announced another buyout with no ''junk bonds.'' His firm, Forstmann, Little & Company, agreed to purchase the General Instrument Corporation, a maker of cable television equipment, for $1.6 billion. About $800 million will come from the Forstmann buyout fund, the rest from banks. In February, Forstmann bought Gulfstream Aerospace for $825 million. After nearly two years with no deals, Mr. Forstmann is apt to boast. ''We're getting back to the real money people and we're in an extremely strong position,'' he said. ''We've done the two largest deals this year.'' Not quite; the Norton Company went for $1.9 billion earlier this year. Some analysts say that Forstmann might have to make a more generous offer for General Instrument to fend off rival bids.
 
Getting the Bond Business
 
Spokesmen for New York Mayor David N. Dinkins and City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said last week that campaign contributions have nothing to do with becoming one of the city's bond underwriters. Of the 53 who applied, the five chosen underwriters - Bear Stearns, First Boston, Goldman Sachs, Merrill Lynch and Shearson Lehman - and their employees contributed a total of $233,000 to the campaigns of the city's top two officials. Some heavy contributors got none of the city's business, but the firms that won were among the largest givers. They will split millions in fees from underwriting $6 billion in bonds over the next two years.
 
In Brief
 
Mack Trucks Inc., an ailing company with a famous name, received a $100 million takeover bid from Renault of France on Friday.
 
*
 
Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. agreed on Friday to pay the New York Stock Exchange a record $500,000 fine in connection with its purchase of E. F. Hutton shares in 1986. Shearson admitted to no wrongdoing.
 
THE ECONOMY
 
The Fed Holds Firm
 
Just when the Federal Reserve Board seemed in a summery, rate-cutting mood, out came a moderately strong employment report. An increase of 39,000 jobs in June lowered civilian unemployment one-tenth of 1 percent to 5.2 percent. And a revised figure for May raised that month's employment gains to 234,000. Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman Sachs, said that the economy is not as weak as many analysts had thought. With productivity rebounding from a first-quarter slump, he said, ''You could get a fairly healthy rise'' in gross national product for the second quarter. The Fed's governing body apparently decided last week to hold rates steady for the time being, but expressed more willingness to lower them in the future. Congress and the White House have been calling for looser credit to head off a possible recession. But the employment report, said Mr. Giordano, ''all but closes the door on an easing of Fed policy this month.''
 
In Brief
 
The Bush Administration has targeted 100 savings and loans for top-priority investigations. Some are still in business.
 
*
 
The Office of Thrift Supervision wants Thomas Spiegel, the former head of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, to repay $19 million that he is accused of turning to his personal use. Among the expenses in question: airplanes, resort condominiums, a French wine-tasting course and 55 guns.
 
*
 
The Government has decided to open to the public its enforcement proceedings against failed savings and loans, including the one involving Neil M. Bush, the President's son.
 
*
 
The White House and Congress are considering a tax on the sale of securities to help close the budget deficit and balance lower taxes on capital gains. Political opposition to the plan appears to be strong.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 8, 1990

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7, Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1841 words

HEADLINE: Turning Rah! - the Fourth R - Into Summertime Profits

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

DATELINE: GREELEY, Pa.

 BODY:
There was trouble with the Low T-Straddle. Christal Kelly had gotten up there - eight feet above the ground, propped up by two fellow junior high students - but her eyes were squeezed shut.
''Open your eyes, Chris,'' another squad member, from Plains, Pa., beseeched her. ''C'mon, open them!''
''She's either going to close her eyes or hold her breath,'' another colleague sniffed. The ribbing worked. Her lashes lifted. Then she spoiled it all. She screamed. ''Now that was not necessary,'' someone sighed. In the leafy tranquillity of the Pine Forest Camp, tucked in the heart of the Poconos, 400 teen-agers (398 females, two males) from junior and senior high schools had come to be told how to do Side Hurdler jumps and Double Hooks and Hanging Stag pyramids and all those other refinements obligatory to true success as a cheerleader. 
Shaping young women (and occasionally young men) into cheerleaders, the everlasting dream of millions of teen-agers, is the business of the National Spirit Group. Headquartered in Dallas, the company runs 430 cheerleader camps a year, mostly in the summer, in every state but Rhode Island. They normally last four days, and cost $99 to $140, including room and board, which sounds tempting enough to 150,000 teen-agers a year to badger their parents until they pay.
Parents, of course, get bombarded by entreaties from a perplexing array of camps and clinics eager to teach their children something they don't already know. Instructors will patiently show them how to play golf, lose weight, ride horses, act, dance, do embroidery, sail, paint, improve their reading, play football, churn butter, work a computer or feel like an astronaut - as long as you pay the price. Thousands of instructional camps exist in the country, according to the American Camping Association, and their number and diversity is steadily expanding.
Getting into cheerleading instruction is not something you plan on. The origins of the National Spirit Group go back to 1948 and Lawrence Herkimer, a former Southern Methodist University cheerleader with a round, expressive face. Maybe the name means nothing to members of the physics club, but Mr. Herkimer did some stupendous things for cheerleading. He invented the pompon. And he devised one of cheerleading's most popular maneuvers - the inimitable Herkie Jump. The jump was conceived while Mr. Herkimer was a crack cheerleader in college during the mid-1940's, when cheerleaders were predominantly men. To execute it, you swing the right arm upward to begin your leap, and as you depart the ground, your left hand clutches your hip while the left leg is propelled out parallel to the ground and the right leg is drawn back.
When he was in college, Mr. Herkimer organized a national cheerleaders' club and published a magazine called Megaphone. After he graduated, he began teaching gymnastics and staging cheerleader clinics.
His popularity spread to such an extent that he was showing up at a school a week, doing backflips all over the place.
The development of color television got him headed toward pompon thoughts. ''I figured there had to be something more colorful on the field than a chrome stick that the cheerleaders twirled,'' he recalled one morning in his Dallas office, ''so I got the idea to put some colored paper on a stick.''
After Mr. Herkimer had been teaching cheerleaders for several years, his wife wisely reminded him that it was unlikely he would be able to do the Herkie Jump forever. He set up a company in his Dallas garage that sold kits explaining how to cut the paper to put together a pompon. Then he developed a pompon-making machine and began selling finished pompons. He had a pompon patent and a corner on the market for a long time. To this day, he sells millions of pompons a year.
Eventually, he expanded into a supply company, selling pompons, cheerleading uniforms and megaphone earrings. Demand to learn cheerleading persisted, and so he hired instructors to teach his methods at cheerleading camps. Now he also teaches drill teams and dance squads.
His company, he said, should attract $50 million in business this year. To staff the camps, he hires 500 part-time instructors a year, mainly teachers or college cheerleaders, many of them schooled at a Herkimer camp. ''We've never had a down year,'' he said. ''I feel we have a recession-proof business. If times get bad, a father would sell the boat before he would tell his daughter she can't have pompons and her cheerleader sweater.''
In 1986, Mr. Herkimer sold his company to the BSN Corporation, a sporting goods concern, which in turn sold it in June 1988 to the New York-based Prospect Group, an astonishingly diversified enterprise that owns a railroad, grows mushrooms, hunts for gold and sells Swiss Army knives. Mr. Herkimer, though, continues to run things. His operation is the largest in the business, though you can't do anything without competition today, and so there are others like the United States Cheerleader Association and the Dynamic Cheerleaders Association that compete for teen-age lungs.
Mr. Herkimer has had curious things happen to him. He once did 38 backflips to complete a commercial for Cheer detergent, sweating through five shirts before it was a wrap. He had a candy bar - the Herkie Bar - named after him that did O.K. for a few years before being dropped. He appeared on the television show, ''What's My Line,'' and he fooled everyone but Tom Poston.
Now that he's 64 years old, he mostly supervises the business. ''The backflips aren't any good anymore,'' he said, ''and the Herkie Jump, I'm sad to say, just isn't as high as it used to be.''
Jane Hodge killed a mosquito. Then she pushed the squads to swing their arms more vigorously. Ms. Hodge was the chief instructor for the Pine Forest class. She was demonstrating the ''whip'' approach to initiating a cheerleader jump, during which one swung one's arm briskly down and through. If the whip baffles you, there are other approaches like the ''punch'' and the ''dip.'' The ''dip'' requires strong abdominal muscles and could quickly convince you to perfect the whip.
Her face pale and piquant, a lanky high school freshman went up into the air in an attempted toe touch. The toes, alas, remained untouched. ''Get the feet higher,'' she was told. ''Kick them up.'' Jump class wound down in a mass of sore muscles. Without pause, partner stunt class commenced. Teen-agers in prodigious numbers practiced the Double Thigh Stand and the Low T-Straddle and the Hanging Stag out on the grass, riotous with weeds. Some squad members became ''climbers'' who had to go up in the air; others were ''bases'' who stayed on the ground and supported weight. Most preferred life as a base. ''Get up there?'' one mentioned. ''I would just die. I was born to be a base.''
Bernadette Kosek, an instructor fresh out of Penn State, sized up her squads, assembled on the tennis courts. ''Now don't let her get too far forward, or she'll eat the cement,'' she said. The exhortation was directed at a squad doing a Hanging Stag.
''Some take right to this,'' she said. ''Others have never taken a step on somebody in their lives.''
After a half-hour of lurching bodies, cheer class began. ''Hey fans. Hey fans. Yell blue.'' ''Red. White. Bears win tonight.'' ''Sink it. Sink it. Slam it through for two.'' Much sound was being created. Wherever you were, within miles of the camp, even with ears stuffed with pillows, you heard them. They were told to have pliant wrists, to have loud, clear speech, unhesitating.
Roaming about the perimeter of the squads, fighting deafness, was Jerry Preschutti, the assistant principal at Mid Valley High School in Troop, Pa., and the camp director. The vast majority of National Spirit's camps are operated by the company, which typically rents idle college campuses and ships a part-time manager to the site to direct things. Mr. Preschutti, though, operates the Pine Forest camp himself, leasing the site from the owners. He runs six courses a year, charging $99 per cheerleader, $24 of which goes to National Spirit. Mr. Preschutti is responsible for the housing and food, while National Spirit supplies the instructors and curriculum.
''This is my 21st year,'' Mr. Preschutti said. ''Some of the girls come with a lot of instruction. Some come with nothing. But, believe me, they all leave with something.''
It was lecture time. Everyone squatted down on the tennis courts and listened raptly as the instructors counseled the attendees on appropriate sideline strategy. It was hard to fault the advice:
* ''Don't chew gum. No one wants to see the gum get stuck in your hair so you go all game trying to pick it out.''
* ''No winking at your boyfriend during the game, or yelling, 'Hey, mom, when are you picking me up after the game?' ''
* ''When an opposing player is hurt on the field, don't say, 'O.K., we got him good.' When he gets up, you clap even if he's the star quarterback of your archrival.''
Evenings were reserved for evaluations. Squads chose a cheer and a sideline chant and performed before an instructor. Devoid of coaching, the squads grew calm and possessed of powers. They cheered. They chanted.
No evaluations were too harsh, for the instructors did not wish to spread penitential gloom. As Mr. Preschutti summed it up: ''You can't be too negative with cheerleading. It's not right.''
What was this bug about cheerleading that attracted the lust of young women?
Amy Shappell, 17, from Kennett High School in Kennett Square, Pa., could say. ''When I was in third grade, all the older and prettier and more popular girls were cheerleaders,'' she said dreamily. ''So I wanted to be like them.''
Distilled to its essence, cheerleading was attestable power. Or could be. It was also ridicule from female classmates. After all, the stereotype of the cheerleader has long been uncheering. As Louise Milewski, the adviser from West Chester (Pa.) East High School put it: ''They have been thought of as flakes. Empty-headed. Rah-rahs.'' Or as Deb Hirsch, the coach from Upper Dauphin (Pa.) High School, added: ''Airheads who can't do anything but giggle.''
A lot of squads try to do extra nice things to win respect. The Kennett students go around and paint houses for those who can't afford real house painters. The Upper Dauphin squad challenged the football team to do aerobics with the cheerleaders to demonstrate their prowess. ''You know what?'' Ms. Hirsch said. ''The players dropped.'' Under evil skies on the fourth day, the cheering was over, and the instructors doled out a string of awards to the bedraggled cheerleaders. School buses pulled up to return the squads to a quieter world. Some of the teen-agers would still require divine intervention to become stellar cheerleaders, but all of them gave off a vibration of utter merriment. Bad jumps had receded into the mists. Gilded memories remained.
Karen Lee from Cherry Hill (N.J.) High School West gave a big wave and said, ''Like, too much!''
