HEADLINE: Technology;
Rehabilitating the Image of the Two-Stroke Engine

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
When the Berlin wall opened last fall, one recurring image of a society where technology had stood still for 40 years was the little East German Trabant automobile, with its noisy two-stroke engine spewing pollutants and fumes. Westerners are more accustomed to two-strokes in lawnmowers than in cars.
But if two-stroke engines seem like yesterday's technology, they may also be tomorrow's. Limited in appeal for decades because of high emissions, poor gas mileage and a rough idle that prompted the nickname ''corn popper,'' two-strokes also have inherent advantages of light weight, small size and simplicity. This has prompted nearly every major automobile manufacturer to look at them anew. 
At recent car shows, the General Motors Corporation displayed a sleek sports car and Toyota a luxury coupe equipped with prototype two-stroke engines.
Both manufacturers say cars with such motors could be in production by 1995. Automobile engineers say advances in electronics and fuel-injection systems have made possible smooth-running, powerful two-stroke engines that meet current and anticipated emission-control requirements.
''We're interested because the fundamentals are just so good,'' said Donald Runkle, General Motors' vice president of advanced engineering. Two-stroke ''engines are lightweight and they're small so the horsepower per pound and the horsepower per size are excellent,'' he said.
Two-stroke engines differ fundamentally from the four-strokes in most cars in that they develop power once for every two strokes of the piston - up and down. That equals once for every complete revolution of the engine crankshaft.
Four-stroke engines require two complete turns of the crankshaft - two up and two down strokes of the piston - to develop power from each cylinder. A three-cylinder two-stroke has the same firing frequency as a six-cylinder four-stroke.
Typical two-strokes also have far fewer moving parts. Four-stroke engines have one or two intake valves to let gas and air into the cylinder, plus one or two exhaust valves to let exhaust out, which must be carefully timed, requiring a complex system of camshafts driven by chains or belts. In a two-stroke, the motion of the piston itself uncovers an intake port and an exhaust port, simultaneously letting air and fuel in and the exhaust out.
The problem with this arrangement is that a lot of unburned and partially burned fuel is left in the exhaust, giving two-strokes a level of hydrocarbon emissions about 100 times that of a comparably sized four-stroke engine. That statistic alone spelled the death of two-stroke automobiles, at least in the United States, over 20 years ago. Sweden's Saab sold a small two-stroke engine car here until 1968, the same year emissions control laws went into effect.
To overcome emissions problems, General Motors' new engine uses fuel-injection technology developed by Ralph Sarich, an Australian inventor and founder of the Orbital Engine Company of Perth. Mr. Sarich's design, also licensed by Ford, improves on typical fuel injection, which squirts liquid fuel into the intake manifold by blasting the fuel directly into the cylinder with compressed air.
The air helps vaporize the fuel quickly, prompting more complete burning, while electronic control of the injection and spark allowsvery precise timing of fuel delivery and firing of the piston. By injecting the fuel after the exhaust ports have closed, the General Motors engine avoids passing unburned gasoline out with the exhaust.
Many modern two-stroke engines use some kind of blower, like a turbocharger, to force out exhaust gases, but the General Motors' design relies on pressures created in the engine's crankcase, a simpler approach.
''We're looking for the elegant solution - no valves, no turbocharger,'' said Mr. Runkle. The three-cylinder engine has a displacement of 1.5 liters, weighs just 165 pounds and develops 110 horsepower.
General Motors' engine needs further development to establish its reliability, but already, automotive engineers are enthusiastic about the design's potential. Because the engine is so much smaller than a four-stroke of comparable power, a car's engine compartment could be smaller too, reducing aerodynamic drag. With reduced weight, power steering would be unnecessary, providing further gains in efficiency.
''If you could propagate the size and weight savings throughout the vehicle, there might be in excess of a 20 percent fuel economy gain,'' said David E. Cole, director of the Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation at the University of Michigan. ''It's a carrot of considerable magnitude.'' he said.
Where General Motors has opted for the ultimate in simplicity, Toyota has taken a far different approach. Toyota's six-cylinder two-stroke engine also uses direct fuel injection, but it uses double overhead camshafts and four valves per cylinder, as in the four-stroke Supra or Cressida engines, which it closely resembles. A supercharger forces pressurized air through the intake valves to blow spent exhaust gases out of the cylinder.
While this engine is no lighter or less complex than its four-stroke brethren, it does offer the advantage of smoother running - a two-stroke six-cylinder engine is as smooth as a four-stroke 12-cylinder engine - as well as greater power and torque at lower engine speeds. Toyota also claims conventional valves - called poppet valves - and supercharging allow a cleaner running engine.
''The use of poppet valves gives us unusually precise control over the combustion sequence; it keeps the mixture in the combustion chamber longer and allows us to burn it more completely,'' said Michael Michels, product news manager for Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Toyota believes the engine's low-r.p.m. power and inherent smoothness lend themselves to luxury car applications, and is currently testing it in a Soarer, a large two-door coupe not sold in the United States. Automotive journalists have been impressed. ''It was everything they claimed,'' said Dennis Simanaitis, engineering editor of Road & Track, after driving the two-stroke equipped Soarer in Japan. ''The engine has a lot of bottom-end torque, a lot of power,'' he said. ''It was quite smooth; it did not have the popcorn sound of the old Saab,'' he said.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Our Disastrously Archaic Farm Policy

BYLINE: By JAMES BOVARD; James Bovard, associate policy analyst at the Cato Institute in Washington, is author of ''The Farm Fiasco.''

 BODY:
Our 60-year farm-policy civil war is increasingly devastating to American competitiveness. The Department of Agriculture will reward farmers for keeping idle almost 60 million acres this year - equivalent to shutting down all the crop land in California, Colorado, Kentucky, Louisiana, Montana and Wisconsin. Paying farmers not to work has become the foundation of American farm policy. 
In 1933, President Franklin D. Roosevelt sought to solve the farm emergency by paying farmers to slaughter their pigs, plow their cotton under and reduce their plantings. Paying farmers to reduce their plantings was a temporary, ''emergency'' measure that became institutionalized because politicans and bureaucrats could not think of any better way to control farmers. In 30 of the last 34 years, the Department of Agriculture has tried to balance supply and demand by rewarding farmers not to grow on their land - through set-asides or acreage reduction programs.
Set-asides are a political response to what Washington perceives as ''excess capacity'' - too many acres producing a given crop. Yet, a 1988 Department of Agriculture study by Dan Dvoskin concluded that excess capacity exists for commodities which have traditionally been given the most subsidies. Subsidized crops have four times as much excess capacity as unsubsidized crops.
Set-asides have become a drag on farmers. The Agricultural Policy Working Group, a private research institute in Washington, estimates that set-asides, by forcing farmers to leave good land unplanted, increase the average cost of production for a bushel of corn by 33 cents. Since the variable cost of production in the most efficient corn-growing areas is only $1.25, this has a big impact on American competitiveness. A recent Department of Agriculture study concluded that acreage reduction programs alone have added about 7 percent to farm land values. But Government cannot drive up land values without increasing farmers' costs, and thus decreasing competitiveness.
Set-asides presume that the United States is the Saudi Arabia of wheat and feed grains - and that we can cut back our production, drive up prices and increase our profits. If nobody else in the world had any farm land, this policy might make sense. But, in recent years, while Uncle Sam has bled taxpayers to bribe farmers not to work, foreigners have planted fence row-to-fence row and are taking over world markets. The European Community has boosted its wheat exports by 40 percent since 1985, while the United States has had almost no gain.
Set-asides are intended to drive crop prices higher than they would be otherwise. Yet, at the same time, farms have been shut down to drive up crop prices, the United States has also spent billions of dollars since 1985 on export subsidies to make American crops cheaper overseas. Export subsidies are the antidote to set-asides and other Federal programs making American crops uncompetitive on world markets.
Every acre of Government set-aside land is an indictment of the failure of Federal planning. It means that Government attracted too much capital to agriculture. Permanent set-asides mean Government perpetually attracts too much capital to agriculture, and then, instead of allowing a natural adjustment and the capital to flow out, perpetually intervenes to keep some of that capital idle.
Paying farmers not to work is economic insanity. It is easier for politicans to shut down American agriculture than to straighten out the tangle of self-defeating Federal farm policies. The sooner we abolish our tangled farm programs, the more competitive American agriculture will be.

HEADLINE: Currency;
The Dollar's Down Again

 BODY:
For those planning a trip to England this summer, the news in recent weeks has not been so good. Since the beginning of June, the pound has risen by 10.5 cents, to $1.7865, from $1.6810. This is a 6 percent increase - or, put another way, a 6 percent cut in the budget for American travelers. And four cents of the pound's rise came in the last week. John Major, Chancellor of the Exchequer, aided the rally with a speech in the House of Commons. The Chancellor said interest rates in Britain would have to remain high because of the continued rapid growth in loans, which spur spending and aggravate inflation. Meanwhile, for those Americans who are going to Germany, the news has been only half as bad, with the dollar falling 2.8 percent since June 1.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
A Sin Tax On the Sale Of Stocks?

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Are stockbrokers to be treated like liquor store owners, with the Government making more money than the businessman every time a sale is made?
That, to many frightened Wall Street executives, is the scariest part of the rumored transfer tax on the sale of securities, which would be set at five-tenths of 1 percent of the value of the stock or other security.
On a $50 share of stock, the tax would be 25 cents each time it was sold. That may not sound like much, but the broker's commission on an institutional trade is likely to be in the range of 5 cents a share. So the tax would give the Government five times as much money as the broker. 
That is the kind of treatment the Government normally reserves for transactions of which it strongly disapproves, but has despaired of stopping. Liquor and cigarettes are high on the list of such commodities, but brokers would like to think their functions - raising capital for enterprises and keeping New York a leading financial center - are thought better of in Washington.
Such a tax would change the way Wall Street operates. There would likely be less liquidity in the market, as fewer investors would be willing to make quick trades. Many complicated investment strategies, which rely on quick trades in several related markets, might become prohibitively expensive. For that reason, advocates may promote the tax as a way to return to the good old days, before futures and options and program trading.
No doubt some trades would move offshore. Others would simply not be done, and the brokerage industry, already choking with excess capacity, would be likely to see more layoffs, consolidations and bankruptcies. With fewer people willing to trade, volatility could increase, and it is possible that money would be siphoned into other investments, such as bank deposits, instead of stocks and bonds.
Whether the threat of the tax is real or not is an open question. But the securities industry is taking it very seriously. Thursday's Wall Street Journal report that the tax was a live possibility stalled a stock market rally, although for the week the Dow Jones industrial average still rose 24.26 points, to 2,904.95. The Dow was aided by a Friday rebound that sent blue-chip stocks up on the slowest trading day of the year, despite a rise in interest rates that helped drive the Dow utilities average to its lowest level in two months.
In opposing the tax, some on Wall Street are warning that Thursday's 32.42-point Dow drop was just the start, unless the idea is quickly dropped. ''I can't believe that Congress would do that and take the very high risk of a new break in the stock market,'' said James Jones, the chairman of the American Stock Exchange.
Many countries have similar taxes, although the trend has been to eliminate or reduce them. Those taxes have often driven business to other countries, but it is less clear that they have depressed prices. But Mr. Jones, a former House Budget Committee chairman, understands what plays in Washington, and his comment may have set the tone for a bitter fight.

HEADLINE: Birth Pains;
Now Playing on the World Stage: The Taming of the New

BYLINE: By R.W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
THIS is an extraordinary summer in international affairs, a summer when the leaders of the West are trying to keep the mighty steed of change from galloping away from them, trying to tame it and guide it.
Almost every week, some group of senior statesmen meets somewhere to grapple with the opportunities, the complexities and the dangers - for all three have arisen at once - created by the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe, the turbulence in the Soviet Union and the reunification of Germany.
This weekend a traveling phalanx of politicians and experts and journalists is making its way from London to Houston, from a summit meeting of the 16-nation North Atlantic Treaty Organization to a summit meeting of the seven most powerful industrial nations, known as the G-7, from discussions of how to assure the Soviet Union of the alliance's peaceful intentions to discussions of how to shore up the rapidly disintegrating Soviet economy.
To a surprising degree, the conference in Europe that ended on Friday and the one in Texas that starts tomorrow have come to focus on the same short-term and long-term goals. 
Short: How to persuade President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union to drop his opposition to membership in NATO for a reunited Germany, thus removing the last significant roadblock to the creation of a new state at the heart of Europe through the anticipated holding of all-German elections on Dec. 2? That would constitute by far the most signifcant step yet taken in building the new architecture of Europe.
Long: How to adapt the network of systems and institutions built up since the war, in the military and political and economic fields, to the brave new world represented by a much more integrated Europe, stretching well beyond the Vistula if not yet to the Urals, where the threat of nuclear holocaust has receded if not yet disappeared?
President Bush, whose blueprint the NATO meeting followed closely, was delighted with the results here; indeed, he told two of his close aides afterward that he was optimistic that President Gorbachev would see the actions taken by the alliance as a guarantee that, in the words if the communique, ''the alliance will do its share to overcome the legacy of decades of suspicion'' between East and West. In Moscow, the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, was enthusiastic, saying the NATO actions ''pave the way to a safe future'' for Europe.
The blueprint had been cleared in advance with West Germany, still another sign of the fact that the true trans-Atlantic ''special relationship'' these days links Washington and Bonn, not Washington and London, as before, and the stolid Chancellor Kohl praised Mr. Bush in terms bordering on exuberance.
By the conclusion of the talks, there was a sackful of symbols, each designed to make it that little bit easier for Mr. Gorbachev to say ''yes'' to Germany on NATO: an invitation to speak to an alliance meeting, a commitment to speed the removal of nuclear artillery shells, a promise of non-aggression pacts, a subtle shift in the wording of NATO nuclear strategy - this last important enough for President Francois Mitterrand of France and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Great Britain to resist it - and a commitment to thin out the ''forward defense'' maintained for decades by the allies.
Perhaps most important was yet another gesture by Chancellor Kohl, who has driven the process forward for months and did not slow down in London. He agreed to come to grips almost at once with one of the questions that worries Moscow most, for obvious historical and geopolitical reasons: a limit on the size of the new German armed forces. ''Such a declaration is an indispensable signpost on the road to German unity,'' Mr. Kohl said, and those traveling with him said the agreed cap might be as low as 300,000 troops, which would represent a large cut from the current West German level of more than 400,000.
Mr. Gorbachev had appealed, in a letter to Mrs. Thatcher delivered on the eve of the conference, for just that kind of reassurance on security questions, and he appealed, in a letter to Mr. Bush delivered as the President prepared to leave for Houston, for similar gestures on the economy.
Those will prove harder for the West to deliver, as Mr. Kohl acknowledged in a background talk with German journalists. He has proposed an aid program for Mr. Gorbachev that could amount to as much as $50 billion, but he said he knew it wouldn't emerge from Houston as an agreed-upon plan because of American, British, Canadian and Japanese opposition.
Mr. Bush made a big thing at his news conference about opposing direct aid now, arguing that too much of Soviet spending still goes to the military, insisting that broad economic reforms are needed and suggesting that Soviet aid for Cuba made it hard for him to send help without arousing the ire of the right wing of his own party.
 
'Their Money, Not Ours'
But the President also said that what Germany did was its business and commented that a breach in the alliance on this issue ''doesn't concern me one little bit.''
Indeed, as one of Mr. Bush's closest aides readily conceded, it is very much in the interest of the United States, as well as in the interest of Germany, if Mr. Kohl is able to ''buy'' Soviet approval for unification, ''as long as it's their idea, not ours, and it's their money, not ours.''
''Could be the biggest leveraged buyout ever,'' the aide said.
For its part, the United States may agree this week to send more technical assistance and other aid to the Soviet Union. So may Britain and others. But in the long run, diplomats said, it will be Germany, possibly with the help of France, that will make the outright grants.
So the implicit ''deal'' on Germany may be emerging from this month's deliberations, much as everyone shies away from that word: a security package that Mr. Gorbachev can sell as a demonstration that his retreat from eastern Europe has enhanced rather than dimished Soviet interests, and an economic package that enables him to temporarily relieve the domestic political pressure - all in exchange for Moscow's approval of German reunification once the party congress ends.
Even if that comes to pass - and it is still a hope or at best a calculation, not a fact - the larger institutional questions will remain.
Such as: If NATO, of which the Soviet Union is not and will not become a member, is to be the main security organization in post-post-war Europe, won't the Soviets feel isolated, as the Germans did after World War II? If, on the other hand, that role passes eventually to the 35-member Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, will the conference not become a mere talking shop, as powerless and unfocused as the League of Nations?
Such as: How long will the Germans tolerate nuclear weapons of any kind on their soil, let alone the new generation of which Mrs. Thatcher speaks so constantly? For that matter, how long will they want large numbers of foreign troops in their nation?
For all the NATO allies, the broad tasks ahead include fostering democracy in the former satellite countries of eastern Europe, keeping the United States engaged in Europe, building new bridges to the Soviet Union, trying to avert a descent into chaos there, continuing to promote western European unity, all at once, with few precedents to fall back on. Not the work of two summit conferences or a single summer or a year.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1115 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Beyond Plain Vanilla: Immigration Has Accentuated Canada's Diversity

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

 BODY:
As the historical story goes, when Jacques Cartier, the French explorer, stepped ashore in 1535 at the rapids near what was to become Quebec City, he confronted a band of curious natives. Looking around at the pristine countryside, he asked them in French and sign language what they called that place. The Indians, looking about their humble village, replied ''kanata.'' It is the Huron-Iroquois word for ''settlement.''
Thus conceived in bilingual misunderstanding did the world's second-largest country get its name, Canada. There have been many such ''kanatas'' in Canada's history. The French-English split, highlighted by the failure last month of the Meech Lake accord, an attempt to draw Quebec into accepting the country's eight-year-old constitution by acknowledging the French province as a ''distinct society,'' is but the most dramatic. 
Although from the outside its image is that of a vat of vanilla yogurt, Canada in fact has always consisted of many disparate pieces sprawling over a country so immense that its southernmost tip in Ontario is actually closer to the Equator than to the top of Canada.
This geography, harsh climate, different languages and divergent cultures often make that land seem less like a single nation and more like a conservative collection of feuding fiefdoms. Quebec has its own vibrant culture and celebrities who are virtually unknown next door in Ontario and vice versa. Canada's politically under-represented West resents the economic dominance of central Canada, which is jealous of the West's oil and gas. Every region tells ethnic jokes about the residents of Newfoundland, Canada's newest province, where they refer to people from other provinces disparagingly as C.F.A.'s (Come From Aways).
 
Recruited Immigrants
Centrifugal forces are always at work in Canada, which was settled not by waves of immigrants moving inexorably from sea to sea, but by many ethnic groups recruited overseas to settle in particular places where the young country needed more people. Though efficient, this method did not create a population with a broad sense of the land. Canada's immigration laws help perpetuate these ethnic population pockets and identities by creating a special status called Landed Immigrant, which allows newcomers to become Canadian while keeping their old nationality.
Even native Canadians work to isolate themselves; the Indians and Inuit of the vast Northwest Territories plan to divide that 40 percent of Canada's geographic mass along racial lines into two pieces.
From the beginning, each segment looked out for its own. In 1867, under the threat of expansion by the United States, Britain finally persuaded Canada's disparate regions to become a single country. As the price of its assent, British Columbia insisted on a rail line to connect it with the rest of the vast new nation.
Even now, each group is striving to be heard. The required ratification of the Meech Lake accord by the 10 provincial legislatures was blocked not by an English- or French-speaker but by the filibuster of Elijah Harper, a Cree Indian in the Manitoba Legislative Assembly who wanted distinct recognition for native peoples.
 
Recognizing Everyone
Also awaiting special recognition were Canada's feminists, not to mention groups representing the mushrooming ranks of Canada's newer immigrants from Commonwealth lands in Africa, the Caribbean, Hong Kong and East Asia. Today, nearly half the children in Vancouver's school system have English as a second language. The city of Toronto, Canada's largest, routinely sends out property tax notices in six languages - English, French, Chinese, Italian, Greek and Portuguese.
But many Canadians now see a fraying of traditional civility into the kind of outspoken divisiveness that has characterized the mixed records of other bilingual countries. There has been vocal resentment in some areas over the impact of rich Chinese fleeing Hong Kong, bidding up Canadian real estate prices, replacing traditional bungalows with mansions seen as ostentatious by neighbors. Shouting matches and racial slurs erupted in Calgary recently over a school board decision to allow teen-age Sikh boys to wear their ceremonial daggers in school when other youths were not allowed even pocket knives. Earlier, the Federal Government decided that Sikhs who become Mounties can wear their turbans instead of the traditional trooper hat. Even though the number of such Sikhs may one day be counted on one hand, it was the kind of ''foreign'' symbol that now arouses some Canadians to raise their voice.
Quebec has always taken the lead in separatist actions. The province's move in late 1988, in open defiance of a Supreme Court decision, to outlaw any outdoor English signs while continuing to demand special protections for French-speakers offended even many liberal Canadians elsewhere. It seemed to violate the unwritten agreement that Quebec's minority English community would be protected. As one result, nearly 100 communities outside the province passed resolutions declaring themselves English only, a meaningless move since few had many French residents anyway.
Then there are the political divisions. Newfoundland, the other stumbling block to Meech Lake's ratification, is governed by Premier Clyde Wells, a close confidante of Pierre Elliott Trudeau, the former Liberal prime minister who has long opposed the accord.
Jean Chretien, the newly elected leader of the opposition Liberals, calls Canada's current mood ''a growing distemper.''
''The world,'' he warns, ''has known other serene communities that have come apart from internal tensions.''
There is evidence, too, that while the specter of Quebec's separation struck terror into the hearts of most Canadians before the defeat of a provincial referendum on the issue 10 years ago, the prospect of Canada and Quebec falling out of love now draws fatalistic shrugs.
''It is,'' Peter C. Newman, an author and nationalist, said sadly, ''as if Quebec is growing out of Canada and the rest of the country says, 'Enough already with your constant demands for special this and special that.' ''
The political price of all this unrest is likely to be steep for Prime Minister Brian Mulroney. He treated the high-pressure, high-stakes Meech Lake talks like the former labor negotiator he is, relying on last-minute concessions that did not come. And the three-year Meech Lake process allowed too much time for an initial consensus to erode. Mr. Newman likened it to 10 co-workers who agree to lunch together and then schedule an hour's debate on where to go.
''Nothing in life is unanimous,'' he said, ''especially in Canada.''

LENGTH: 860 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Even an Earthquake May Not Be Enough to Pry Open Iran

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
WHEN the earth trembled in late June and swallowed part of northwestern Iran, the world responded quickly.
Iran may have isolated itself diplomatically for the last decade, but here were hundreds of thousands of souls in need of doctors, food, housing, solace and, all too often, burial. The world wasted little time offering a helping hand.
But it did not take long before raw political considerations took over: Who should get the assistance? Who should be allowed to provide it? How much aid would be accepted, and what kind? Even as Iranian officials recorded earthquake tolls of epic dimensions - 40,000 dead, 60,000 injured, 500,000 homeless - it was clear that the disaster had become one of the more important diplomatic events in the Persian Gulf since the 1988 cease-fire in the Iran-Iraq war. 
For Iran's president, Hashemi Rafsanjani, the earthquake was an opportunity to extend his policy of opening doors to the West. Demonstrating his political primacy, he prevailed over hard-line Islamic radicals who had inveighed against accepting so much as a bandage from foreigners, especially the Great Satan itself, the United States.
By the same token, overseas aid donors were well aware that they had a rare chance to peel away a diplomatic veil from Iran. As one European diplomat in Teheran put it, ''we would all be foolish not to act on this.''
It was an interesting display of political theater. Here was Iran, already struggling economically after the war with Iraq, looking for foreign investors, requiring outside help to rebuild battered cities and towns, and now knocked for a loop by nature. Yet Mr. Rafsanjani, while needy, was not about to go forth as a supplicant. Instead, he presented himself as magnanimous in his willingness to accept foreign assistance - a leader so reasonable that he would deal with any country except Israel and South Africa.
Whether Iran's foreign relations genuinely change remains to be seen. Officials in Teheran acted quickly to dampen speculation that dealings with the United States were about to improve dramatically or that Iran would intervene to win freedom for remaining American hostages in Lebanon. In fact, one Iranian official seized upon the United States Government's slender contribution to the earthquake relief effort -$295,000 - as proof of Washington's insincerity.
Still, the Iranian situation was benign compared with other times relief has been used as a political tool. The famine in Ethiopia is an example of a much more vicious pattern. Many of the emergency food supplies have been blocked because of Government bombings of Massawa, a key port that had fallen to Eritrean insurgents. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front offered to withdraw its forces from Massawa and allow relief workers to move about freely if the Government promised not to attack any more. But until he yielded recently to United States and Soviet diplomatic pressure by promising to stop the bombing, President Mengistu Haile Mariam took the position that help for his starving people counted less than the battle against his enemies. Now that he has relented, it is the insurgents' turn to play politics with aid. There are reports that they prefer that no food comes into the country because relief supplies could benefit the Government.
Developed countries, too, are hardly immune from charges of favoritism and corruption in distributing disaster assistance. In Italy, investigations continue into the distribution of an estimated $50 billion in reconstruction money that poured into Irpinia, a region southeast of Naples, where a 1980 earthquake killed more than 2,700 people and devastated dozens of villages. If even a fraction of the allegations are accurate, billions of dollars fell off the truck as the money came in from Rome, and earthquake victims ended up as minor shareholders in the public largesse.
Corruption also played a role after a 1972 earthquake killed 10,000 people in Nicaragua. Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle declared himself in charge of the emergency committee distributing the millions in humanitarian aid that poured in. The outrage in the middle class and private sector over the diversion of much of the aid helped fuel the revolt that ended in the rise of the Sandinistas and the overthrow of General Somoza.
But Iran has solid experience with disaster relief after nearly a decade of war and centuries of enduring in one of the world's most violent seismic zones. Foreign crews, saying that the medical emergency was limited and that aid distribution seemed orderly, folded their tents early and went home.
That suited Iranian leaders just fine. All along, they made it clear that they wanted only material from overseas, not people who might start poking around into sensitive areas.
In the end, political considerations touched almost every detail of the relief operation, down to expressions of thanks. Last week, Mr. Rafsanjani sent messages to 98 governments and agencies that had provided help. Conspicuously missing were three countries at the top of any Iranian fundamentalist's hate list - Iraq, Saudi Arabia and, of course, the United States.

PUB-DATE: July 8, 1990

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1050 words

HEADLINE: The World;
On Tokyo's International Shopping List: More Clout

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
ONLY a year ago the 1990's seemed bound to be the age of Japanese influence, as the biggest Pacific power approached the Pacific Century.
Japan's coffers were overflowing and its leaders were beginning to focus on how to turn economic power into international clout.
In Asia that age is already arriving, as Japanese industry and the policies that support it in Tokyo emerge as the single most important factor in the growth of countries like Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia. But the reverse alchemy that was expected to turn gold into political glitter elsewhere around the globe has yet to work. 
In fact, as Japan joins its Western allies in an economic summit meeting in Houston that is to be devoted largely to changes in Europe and the Soviet Union, it is discovering that differences in its agenda and the West's are becoming more difficult to paper over. In recent weeks, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and other political leaders have hinted that Japan may edge out on its own in dealings with China and the Soviet Union. But, as always, the Japanese are reluctant to openly split with the United States, which may no longer dominate the world of cars and ships but remains Tokyo's political mentor.
This hesitation by Japan is rooted in a growing awareness that its economic strength masks some critical political weaknesses that still cripple its ability to develop a foreign policy that can venture beyond Asia.
The problem is hardly a shortage of money or willingness to commit large sums to foreign aid; rather, it is a question of direction and vision. In Eastern Europe the Japanese admit they have remained largely on the sidelines, as lost as an American business executive arriving connection-less in Tokyo. And though Japan wants a larger regional role in Asian politics - and started by playing host to talks over Cambodia a month ago -memories of the Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere rarely fail to come up in conversation.
Complicating the matter is a sudden and somewhat sharp difference of opinion with some Western allies on how to handle the Soviet Union and China. As West Germany advocates economic aid to prop up the Soviet economy, Japan is making it clear that Gorby-mania will have to be financed from elsewhere until Moscow moves to resolve a 45-year-old argument over who owns four Northern Islands between Hokkaido and Sakhalin that Japan claims were illegally wrested from it in the closing days of World War II. ''We have to make it abundantly clear that for Japan it will not be possible'' to provide economic aid to help perestroika, Mr. Kaifu said in an interview here on Friday as he prepared for the meeting of the seven major industrialized nations in Houston that begins tomorrow.
In China, Japan has the reverse problem. Sanctions imposed at last year's Group of Seven meeting remain against Beijing, freezing a $5 billion aid package promised by Japan two years ago. Japan went along with the post-Tiananmen Square sanctions when it seemed that they would last only a few months; now its leadership is growing increasingly worried that relations are stagnating and that continuing policies that isolate China invite economic disaster and perhaps an explosive political result. With China pressing Tokyo for a quick resumption of aid, something that Japanese businesses with interests there strongly support, Mr. Kaifu's Government is building a case for becoming the first to reopen the spigot. It will be the first test of whether Japan feels as confident moving on its own in Asian diplomacy as it does in Asian business, where executives revel in the fact that American and European competitors are so preoccupied with Europe that they have left some of the world's most booming markets in Japanese hands.
But Japan is still loath to set off on its own, at least openly. And therein lies the Japanese difficulty: a desire to be something more than the world's piggy bank, but a deep confusion about how to chart its own course.
''There is this perception gap,'' a senior official in Japan's foreign ministry said a few days ago, talking about the widespread assumption that Japan's ability to send both foreign aid and its industrial hordes translates into immediate influence. ''In the long term, we are very aware of our financial power, and what that will bring us. But in the short term, it does not work to our advantage.'' The reasons are several, a mix of political confusion at home and a fear of provoking resentments abroad. The most important is that Japan's foreign policy goals are almost never a matter of broad political debate. Japan remains so preoccupied with domestic issues, the economist Naoki Tanaka complained in a recent article in the magazine Gekkan Asahi, that ''there has been little discussion of how the world's biggest creditor should behave.''
Others say Japan is not uninterested, merely confused. Seen from Asia, the world looks very different than it does from the European border. Japanese military experts never miss a chance to point out that disarmament has yet to begin in the Pacific. The result is a paralyzed Japanese defense policy. As the argument rages over whether the Soviet Union remains the main threat to Japanese security, the country has virtually suspended consideration of its five-year defense plan, unable to decide how to justify the rapid, American-inspired growth of its military budgets.
The issue will become more acute as the Pentagon begins to cut troop levels in Japan and Korea, and faces the prospect that it may be forced to abandon its bases in the Philippines. Japan has made it clear that it has no intention of lifting the 1,000-mile limit that keeps its forces close to Japanese shores - and out of regional conflicts.
The new stress on economic rather than military security, however, may ultimately prove Japan's solution. Professor Nishihara and a group of high-ranking foreign ministry officials recently became the first Japanese to participate in a NATO seminar - a session on NATO's efforts to find new roles for itself. ''Because economic dimensions are coming in,'' Professor Nishihara said, ''we have to be involved.'' Over time such considerations could still usher in an age in which Japan can press its own agenda, if only it can first set one.
